Title: Sandalwood celebs moot low key celebrations for Ugadi this time
Content: Ugadi, which marks the new year in Kannadiga households, is about embracing it with all the sweetness and a pinch of salt. This is done, quite literally, with households having a mix of bevu and bella (neem leaves and jaggery). This year, with the COVID-19 pandemic causing a dent in the celebrations, Sandalwood’s leading ladies say that the scale of their celebration might be much lesser, but their spirits remain the same, as they look forward to a happier, healthier year.Since the shutdown, I have been at home with my family. We keep switching between watching movies, playing games and chatting. Everyday feels like an extended weekend, and I think we’ll be doing the same on Ugadi too. It is going to be yet another day spent with my family and loved ones during this quarantine.A simple puja with family this year. I was supposed to be travelling, but the lockdown has come as a blessing in disguise, as I am able to stay at home and spend time with my family, especially my grandmother, who is also here with us. While the norm is to visit a temple and do a puja, considering the current situation, we are going to keep it low key and have a simple puja at home with the traditional bevu-bella.I will donate the money I normally splurge on myself. This time of the year is doubly special for me as it has both Navratri and Ugadi. I wanted to fast for eight days and have a big ceremony on the ninth day, but that won’t happen. Instead, this year, I plan on using the time to reach out to those in need. I have already begun by donating masks and gloves.I want to make the most of the time with family. Ugadi is a time to meet everyone in the family and other loved ones. This year, though, since we are social distancing, we will not have family over at our place. We plan on making the most of our time together at home. We will have a small puja, of course, followed by a simple,traditional meal.I’ll enjoy mom’s home-cooked delicacies and relax. I’m spending Ugadi at home with my parents. My mother might cook some delicacies, which will be the extent of the festivities for us. I’ll help my mother in the kitchen, and around the house. I have also been utilising the time I’ve had at home to just relax, watch movies, read books, and pursue hobbies that have been on my to-do list for a long while. During the lock down period, my mother has been trying her hand at photography, so, I might assist her with that over Ugadi.I wish to begin the new year on a positive note I am looking at beginning the new year with a lot of positivity, as that is the need of the hour. My mother and I will have simple celebrations of the festival at home, with a traditional home-cooked meal. We realise that this year is taxing for many households, so I pray for them and hope to help them in whatever way I can.

Title: #CoronaConcern: K’wood celebs provide relief for beleaguered industry workers
Content: With Kollywood shutting down operations and suspending all film shoots from March 19 following the Coronavirus situation, the most affected have been workers in the industry, who have been struggling to make ends meet. On Monday, RK Selvamani, the president of the Federation of Film Employees of South India ( FEFSI ), had appealed to the film fraternity to extend financial help for the over 26,000 members of the body, who depend on daily wages.Angamuthu, secretary, FEFSI, says that the body needs at least `5 crores to ensure the welfare of its members. “This is in addition to the other 10,000 people who are related to cinema,” he says, adding, “Actors like Rajini, Sivakumar family, Sivakarthikeyan, Vijay Sethupathi Parthiban , Narain, Roshan, Sachu, and others like filmmaker Vetri Maaran, producer Thanu have contributed to FEFSI. We are expecting other leading stars like Kamal Haasan, Ajith and Vijay also to do their bit. FEFSI has also requested the CMO to donate. We are awaiting a favourable reply and contribution from the government’s side, too.”Following his appeal, a stream of film personalities have now contributed to the relief fund for workers, either by donating cash or rice bags. While Sivakumar, Suriya and Karthi jointly donated `10 lakh, just a few hours after RK Selvamani's request, Sivakarthikeyan also donated `10 lakh for the FEFSI members. Parthiban, Prakash Raj and Mano Bala provided rice bags weighing 25kg each respectively. On Tuesday, Rajinikanth donated `50 lakh, about 25 per cent of the money requested by Selvamani, while Vijay Sethupathi chipped in with `10 lakh.Rajinikanth `50 lakhSivakarthikeyan `10 lakhVijay Sethupathi `10 lakhSivakumar,Suriya and Karthi `10 lakhVetri Maaran `2 lakhHarish Kalyan 1 lakhNarain `25,000Roshan `17,000Sachu `10,000Parthiban 250 rice bagsKalaipuli S Thanu 250 rice bagsPrakash Raj 150 rice bags

Title: Bengaluru gets a whiff of fresh air, but will it last?
Content: In the days since the COVID-19 pandemic scare took grip of the city, life has been far from normal for most people, what with many choosing to work from home, resulting in a sharp drop in traffic. Then, when the government affected a partial shutdown, factories and other establishments that were hitherto contributing to the poor air quality of the city, scaled down operations or shut them altogether. The result — readings on the Air Quality Index (AQI) across the city, right from Hebbal to Silk Board, have been phenomenal.“The pollution load has most certainly come down over the past 10-12 days because of COVID-19 and most of the stations have recorded moderate to satisfactory air quality levels,” says Karnataka State Pollution Control Board (KSPCB) Member Secretary Basavaraj V Patil. Even the Krantiveera Sangolli Rayanna Railway Station, which is a problem point for the pollution control board, has shown a marked decrease in the AQI level. “From March 9 to 19, the city railway station has recorded a reduction in pollution levels, but it continues to be above 100,” he adds.According to the Karnataka State Pollution Control Board (KSPCB), the city’s pollution levels dropped by 40-50% on Sunday's Janta Curfew. Basavaraj, though, is not thrilled that the city’s better air quality is a result of a forced shutdown. “We need to understand that the reason behind this improvement in air quality is not good. In the interest of current and future generations, we need to look at ways to reduce the pollution load even on normal days, and not just because of a pandemic," he adds.Seema Mundoli, faculty at Azim Premji University for urban sustainability, agrees and adds, “It would be foolish for us to celebrate a reduction in pollution levels because of the shutdown. One would not want to pay such a huge price for reduced pollution levels. To contain the city’s increasing pollution level, we need political will and resolve, which is, unfortunately, lacking. Air pollution is a national health crisis and will require a much better thought-out strategy to combat it.”

Title: Peepal Tree’s new album is a tribute to good old Bengaluru
Content: City band Peepal Tree is all set to take you on a nostalgia trip with their latest album, for which they have collaborated with music composer Sandeep Chowta . The four-song album, titled 560001, is all about Bengaluru, focusing mainly on the positive aspects of namma ooru.Speaking about the new album, Sujay Harthi, vocalist of the band, says, “Bengaluru gets a lot of flak because of its bad traffic and poor infrastructure and. So, with this new album, we want to shed light on the positives that the city offers. There are two songs about Bengaluru in the album. The first track has a folk tune, Cheluvayya Cheluvo, which a lot of people will be able to relate to immediately, while the second number is about friendship. These songs, we feel, will immediately take Bengalureans back in time.”The album, which will be released online on March 30, also features Kannada rap artist Gubbi. Sandeep, who has composed and produced the album, says, “Since the album is about good things about the city, the timing of the launch is kind of perfect, given the lockdown and situation we are currently in. The music and lyrics are essentially about the memories we share in the city.”Why the title 560001? “It’s a Kannada album and Sandeep wanted it to be a tribute to the city, where all of us have grown up here. We thought of many names. But 560001 stuck with us, because it’s the pin code of MG Road, and this neighbourhood has been a hub of culture activities for the past few decades. Be it performance arenas or popular hangouts, MG Road has been the place to be. All of us have fond memories of this area, which is why we agreed on this title,” says Sujay. Giving a little insight into the genre of the album, Sujay says, “It’s a complete deviation from the our band’s sound, which is Rock Funk. But this was not a deliberate attempt. We, too, were surprised with the outcome. Hope the audience will enjoy it.”

Title: #CoronaImpact: A summer sans camps in Chennai
Content:
In this testing time of the Coronavirus and social distancing, however, the summertime phenomenon has become y... Read More

With schools shut due to #CoronaScare, summer vacation is fast approaching, and with it come warm memories of vacation, scoops of ice cream and time in the sun. But for children , it also means summer camps . In this testing time of the Coronavirus and social distancing, however, the summertime phenomenon has become yet another casualty.

With Section 144 being imposed in Chennai, for the time being, summer courses and sports camps, too, have been cancelled. M Raghu Raman, founder of UV Global pre-school, says that the current slot of summer camps offered by his school stand cancelled. “Given the current scenario, we have cancelled the first batch which was supposed to go on till April 8. We maybe cancelling future programmes based on the circumstances. It is dampening spirits, but social distancing is something that we all need to collectively follow,” he says, adding that the children’s safety will always remain top priority.

Zinnera, from Hello Kids Butterflies, adds that the inquiries for classes have dialed down. “We had scheduled two sets of camps in April and May each. We might have to push the camp dates to some time after April 15, now, if normalcy returns. There were a few enquirers in the beginning, but now it has been completely silent,” she notes.

This camp was supposed to be her first time organising such an event. “Our lineup included arts and crafts, self-defence, storytelling and toiletry training. We are hoping for the best as that is all we can do right now,” she adds.

While business has been hit hard, it is imperative to forgo whatever the situation demands, says Gayathri, founder of city-based organisation Little Walks, who has called off a five-batched set that was to begin from April 5. “We know that it will be hard on the parents as well who would have to pay attention to every action of their children while keeping them indoors. Hence, our team recently started sending tips, single-player board game ideas, and worksheets to our parents circle via WhatsApp,” Gayathri explains.

Going digital could just be yet another solution, Raghu chimes in. “We are trying to rope in some partners to get online material like programmes on storytelling and DIY hacks, etc. We are also connecting with parents to welcome ideas from their side. Given social distancing, we should see technology as an enabler,” he adds.

Personal attention and hand-holding, however, are unique to physical summer camps, adds Saritha, from The Brainbay Edu-Spark in the city. “We engage seven students with one teacher at our camp. But online, we can spend time with less students. Personal attention will be less and time management will be difficult,” she says.

Can children, however, make do without such collectives? Camps like these are essential in the development of motor and sensory skills, says Nandini, a young mother of three-year-old Sudhiksha. “Kids today are nothing like us, 90s kids. The world is getting competitive and every child is expected to be extremely talented, which is quite challenging. Summer camps like these help in the development of basic skills,” she says.

The closure of camps also poses a challenge to working mothers like her. “It is quite difficult to keep the kids occupied. Online programmes might work for kids above five years of age. But younger children need assistance to handle devices. For now, the kids are keeping their grandparents busy,” she says with a smile.

Title: Sathyam Shivam Sundaram completes 800 episodes
Content: Kannada soap opera Sathyam Shivam Sundaram has reached a milestone of 800 episodes. The serial which has Chethan Chandra in the lead role went on air on August 2017. Chethan Chandra is playing the role of Shiva in the serial.The serial which is the remake of the Hindi serial Ishqbazz marked the debut of Chethan Chandra in small screen. The story is about three love stories of siblings who all hail from of a rich family. The soap opera has continued to impress it’s viewers.

Title: Rakshit Shetty’s busy with the script of his next during shutdown
Content: Before the COVID-19 pandemic intensified in India, actor-filmmaker Rakshit Shetty was on a long shooting schedule for 777 Charlie in Rajasthan and Punjab. He returned to Bengaluru on March 14, and has been self-quarantined ever since. “Since we had been travelling so much for the film, it was our social responsibility to isolate ourselves and not meet anyone in person during this time,” says Rakshit, adding, “I am using this time to finish the script of Punyakoti . I’ve found a new favourite spot in my balcony, where I’ve been writing for a while now, and I’m hoping to get most of my work ready soon.” The actor adds that while work has been keeping him busy, his wish is to be with his family in Udupi at this time.As for his other projects, he says that the film Richie, which is an extension of his character from Ulidavaru Kandante, is on track. “I will first start Sapta Sagaradaache Yello, once the current situation gets a little better, following which I’ll concentrate on Richie, Punyakoti and Tenali respectively.” In the meantime, the actor has also championed the cause of social-distancing by urging his followers on social media to stay home.

Title: Sandalwood celebs ask citizens to be responsible during the 21-day lockdown
Content: Prime Minister Narendra Modi announced that the country will be going into lockdown for 21 days to ensure that the coronavirus outbreak can be contained. Sandalwood celebs took to social media to spread the word about the same and asked people to stay at home. Actor Ganesh wrote, "India lockdown for three weeks. Please stay at home." Actress Samyukta Hornad wrote, "Take this seriously for the benefit of our families and our nation. Please don't panic. The supply of essential items will continue." Actress Nishvika posted, "What I want to say: I don't understand why people have to ask and plead us to stay home. Just follow the fudging rule. Don't be an idiot and die or kill others. What I say: stay health, (spread) love not corona." Actor Pannagabharana compared the lockdown to a stay in the Bigg Boss house and asked people to stay motivated. However, actor Ashita Chandrappa shared that the Bigg Boss house did not have the advantages that the cozy atmosphere of a home had. She added that while she knew that Pannagabharana was joking, there were many others making the comparison, hence she clarified. "This (life outside Bigg Boss) is better," she wrote, adding, "That's a game, this is life."

Title: Interesting food facts you didn't know about Ugadi and Gudi Padwa
Content: This is the first day of the Chaitra month in the Hindu Lunisolar Calendar (the first month of the year). For people in Northern India, this day marks as the beginning of Navratri. But, do you know what it is called in South? Across Maharashtra, the day is known as Gudi Padwa and the Telugu people celebrate the New Year with Ugadi. The most beautiful and interesting thing about all the regions is, they celebrate the day with traditional foods and rituals. Here are some interesting food facts associated with Ugadi and Gudi Padwa that you probably did not know:1. They both are harvest festivals of their respective regions. The day signifies the end of one season and the beginning of another. During this period rabi crop is just harvested and the market prepares itself for mangoes.2. The day is celebrated as Navreh by Kashmiri Pandits, Cheti Chand by Sindhis and Sajibu Nongma Panba Cheiraoba in Manipur.3. In many Maharashtrian families, the day begins with the preparation of traditional dishes like Shrikhand and Puran Poli.4. On the auspicious occasion of Ugadi, an interesting and healthy concoction of six ingredients is made. If experts are to be believed, each ingredient symbolizes an emotion and is to be consumed by the family members. These ingredients and emotions are neem buds/flowers (sadness), jaggery (happiness), green chilli (anger), salt (fear), tamarind (disgust) and unripened mango (surprise).5. In Andhra Pradesh, the day is celebrated with a stuffed paratha-type dish that is called Bobbattu. It’s a traditional flatbread recipe made with refined flour, chana dal, sugar, sooji, cardamom, salt, turmeric and oil. It is called Obbattu or Holigein Karnataka. It is eaten topped with ghee or milk or even coconut milk.6. On this auspicious day, people in the Konkani region of the country prepare Kanangachi Kheer. Apet from this, they also consume boiled sweet potato, coconut milk, rice flour and jaggery in varied forms.7. In rural parts of Maharashtra, there is a ritual of making a gudi (doll) om this day. The doll is made with a bamboo stick, neem and mango leaves, red garland, with an inverted copper or silver pot for a face. After the rituals are done, the doll is placed outside the main door, for others to see.

Title: Alia Bhatt urges people not to abandon pets out of coronavirus scare
Content: As misinformation surface online that animals spread coronavirus is causing many pet owners to abandon their pets, actor Alia Bhatt on Tuesday took to social media to clear the misconception around the issue.The 27-year-old actor posted a statement on Instagram in which she emphasised that "there is currently NO EVIDENCE" to suggest that pet animals can be a source of infection to humans."The 'Highway' actor also quoted the statement of Maharashtra's Health Minister Rajesh Tope 's saying, "there is no case in the world of domesticated animals spreading coronavirus and people should not abandon their pets for fear of infection."She further urged the pet owners to maintain good hygiene including washing one's hands before and after handling animals as well as their food.The star also pointed out that if one is not in a good health condition should avoid direct contact with your pets.Many other Bollywood celebrities like director Rohit Shetty , actor Anushka Sharma , and Preity Zinta have urged the people to stop abandoning their pets in the light of coronavirus.Growing misinformation is causing a lot of people to abandon their animal friends with many of them being deserted on the roads.

Content:

Film director Ram Gopal Varma on Tuesday paid his regards to the doctors, who are working tirelessly for treating patients suffering from COVID-19.Varma tweeted pictures of medical practitioners, who developed rashes and marks on their faces due to wearing surgical masks for a very long time. Title: 'I was looking forward to climbing Mt. Everest, I will not give up on my dream'
Content:
‘It has been a dream since 2016’

Going sustainable with solar energy

Harshvardhan Joshi with solar panels at Mt. Himlung Himal in Nepal

The outbreak of coronavirus Covid-19 has thrown life off kilter in more ways than you can count. The world’s major events — political , social, sports, fashion and more — have been cancelled and postponed indefinitely, in addition to schools and colleges and places of work being shut. And recently, all expeditions to Mount Everest were cancelled, just ahead of the climbing season. Harshvardhan Joshi from Mumbai, an avid climber who was to make his first attempt at scaling the mountain, chats with BT about how his big dream to scale Mount Everest will have to wait. “I have mixed feelings. I was really looking forward to climbing Mt. Everest, and at first, I was very disappointed. People around me — my parents and friends — know how much it mattered. But of course, at this point, things are not in our control. My Everest dream awaits. I will not give up on it and I hope to climb there next April,” he says.This 24-year-old IT engineer has been nurturing his dream since the last four years. He says, “In 2106, I decided that I would attempt Everest. It’s something I have been cherishing.” From the word go, it involved a plot of planning, prep and effort. He affirms, “Every summer, in these last few years, I stay in the Himalayas for six to seven months. I was born and brought up in Vasai, but now I spend most of my time in Ladakh , climbing and training hard. I have been a mountain guide for many westerners. That is out of passion, but it’s also to train for Everest. In winter, I also go to Kashmir for skiing, for a month.” He’s definitely got the call from the mountains, then! “Definitely! I’m a Ladakhi by heart. I was trying to settle there, too, in 2018, but I couldn’t, so I thought let’s focus on Everest first.Harsh also planned to make it a completely solar-fuelled ascent, in keeping with the trend of sustainable travel. He says, “My aim was also to create awareness about solar energy. I believe in impact tourism, which is about going to a place and developing it sustainably. I thought I would carry solar panels to remote villages in the Everest region. I calculated the carbon offset — by understanding how much my sherpa and I would reduce carbon emissions by switching to solar energy.If we can be completely solar dependent in such fragile environs, then we can do so in the city, too. That said, the bottomline is, we all need to consume less, no matter where we are.”

Title: 14 fresh cases in kerala as many violate lockdown guidelines
Content: KOCHI: Kerala reported 14 coronavirus (Covid-19) cases on Tuesday, taking the total number of positive cases in the state to 105. A health worker is among those infected, chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan told reporters after a review meeting.A nurse who was working in Kottayam district is the first coronavirus case among health workers in the state. Of the 14 cases reported, eight people have come from Dubai while three persons had come in direct contact with Dubai returnees. One person had come from Qatar and another from the UK.Six of these cases were reported in Kasaragod, two in Kozhikode and one each in Thiruvananthapuram, Alappuzha, Kottayam, Palakkad, Ernakulam and Malappuram. As many as 72,460 people are under observation in the state, of whom 467 are admitted in designated isolation wards. Four persons were treated and discharged earlier.The chief minister warned of strict action against those violating the lockdown restrictions. He said no private vehicles will be allowed on roads unless there is an emergency. It has been made mandatory to provide details of those venturing out during the lockdown and any violation will be dealt with seriously, he said.Vijayan said shops supplying essential commodities can remain open from 7am to 5pm but there will be restrictions on people assembling there. He said the government would hold discussions with other states to bring back students from there.Meanwhile, confusion prevailed on the first day of the state-wide lockdown on Tuesday, with people trying to find loopholes and police trying to enforce the lockdown order. Police registered 402 cases across the state for lockdown violations, with Thiruvananthapuram city leading the chart with 121 cases. As many as 47 cases were registered in Ernakulam city.

Title: #CoronaShutdown: Travel plans cancelled, but celebs agree that health & duty towards society come first
Content: I was supposed to come to Jaipur to attend a friend’s wedding. I was also planning to spend some quality time with my parents. We generally don’t get long breaks to travel because of our professional commitments.After the corona outbreak and lockdown, I cancelled the plan and will spend some time at home in Mumbai instead with my wife.Sanjay with fiancee PoonamI had booked tickets to go to Bhopal for a very close friend’s wedding, who happens to be actor Zaan Khan’s brother. But as the coronavirus situation developed, my parents made me cancel the tickets. Now, I am staying at home and spending time with my fiancee Poonam and my dog Flirty.I was to attend a wedding with my family in Punjab. We had booked tickets for this trip for almost three months ago. We all were quite excited about it but we have called off the plan now. I think it was the best decision, given the scenario. In fact, after this, I have been proactively advising people to stay home and socially distance themselves to curb the coronavirus pandemic.I was supposed to come to Jaipur for an appearance at an NGO’s event. Dausa is also my hometown and I was looking forward to meeting my parents. But in these tough times, we should collectively stand strong as a nation and follow the precautionary measures. My show Lukka Chuppi’s shoot is stalled, like other shows, and I am spending quality time with myself.I was supposed to travel to Jaipur in April to meet my family after four months. But it was only a sensible and rational decision to cancel the plan and stay home. My parents offered to visit me in Mumbai, but I requested them to stay put at home. It is my humble request to everyone to refrain from stepping out of their homes. Hum ghar ke andar toh corona bahar. As citizens of this country, we must follow these protocols to curb the spread of the virus.On my birthday, I had planned a simple celebration with my family and sister-in-law, whom I was going to meet after three years. My wife and daughters were equally excited. We had planned a fun road trip to M’how in Indore. However, we will now celebrate my birthday at home. Self-isolation is the best way to tackle the spread of this contagious pandemic.My wife and kids were to go to Goa before me and I was to join them for three days a week later. We had planned our stay at a villa in south Goa. But in light of the coronavirus outbreak, we decided to cancel our trip. We must understand the severity of this situation and take all necessary steps to safeguard ourselves and our loved ones. No travel plan or work is as important as one’s health. Maintaining social distance is crucially important to protect yourself.

Title: #CoronaConcerns: Fitness enthusiasts turn to virtual workout sessions and fitness apps
Content: With gyms and fitness chains across NCR temporarily shut down because of the coronavirus outbreak, fitness enthusiasts are turning to online workout videos and fitness apps to stay in shape. Following the trend are common man and celebs alike, including Deepika Padukone, Shilpa Shetty and Sara Ali Khan, who are regularly posting their 'workout at home' videos online and sharing tips on how one can replace their gym workout routine with exercises at home. The transition from the gym to their living rooms isn't easy, but a few fitness enthusiasts tell us how to focus on fitness while staying indoors.In the last 10 days, Gurgaon-based runner Tanya Agarwal has trained herself to do a combination of yoga and other exercises that can be easily done even in a small space at home. She had to give up her running routine and outdoor workout after she decided to observe social distancing. "I use a chair to do dips, skipping rope and squats. I exercise for around 45 minutes each day at home. When I started working out at home, I realised that there are so many things that we can do even without any gym equipment. For instance, one can climb up and down the stairs for leg exercises and if one is trying to lose weight, then full-body exercises can be done, too, without any equipment. While I am working from home, if I feel like taking a break, I do skipping for five to 10 minutes."Another runner (marathoner) and designer, Namrata Joshipura, has not gone to the gym for the last 15 days. She says, "I used to go to the gym for strength training, which can be easily done at home with a little improvisation. To all runners, I suggest go for solo runs early morning."While walking around home might not qualify as an exercise for many, but Viren Barman, a fitness trainer and Mr India 2016 first runner-up, says that it can add up to your exercises without exhausting you. "If working at home doesn’t come easy for you, then begin with 15-10 minutes of exercises that you already know. Plus, include a walk around the house every few minutes. After three-four days, try increasing the duration. There are so many exercises that one can do with resistance bands. One must also divide exercise routines into strength training and weight training," says Viren.Online workout videos are turning out to be a big help for those who find it difficult to work out at home. Several gym chains and instructors have been posting workout videos regularly ever since gyms have been shut. "Honestly, I never thought I would be able to work out at home as I was quite used to working with equipment under the guidance of a trainer. I was worried that I might miss out on my workout for months if I do not work out at home. However, my gym has started online classes for members and they are very helpful. I also looked for online dance classes, so that I don’t get bored of doing similar workout at home each day," says entrepreneur Faizi Khan.Triathlete and triathlon coach Siddhant Singh Chauhan has switched to a cycling app through which one can train along with other cyclists across the globe. "It is an indoor training app wherein you can even customise your training plan. It is, thanks to these apps, that my workout has not been affected in terms of intensity and volume," says Siddhant, a corporate communication consultant from Gurgaon.The best part about workout at home is that you can divide your workout into two parts. One can even utilise the time that was earlier spent on commuting to the workplace. "I definitely have more time for workout now, as I used to spend four hours in a day commuting between Delhi and Gurgaon," says Siddhant. Several others feel that the time that one would spend for coffee breaks in the office can now be utilised for small walks, skipping or doing squats in between work. "If you tend to take a break after every hour or so while working from home, then have a list of your favourite exercises that you can do in five minutes after every hour. For example, if you like doing squats, try doing 10 squats in every break you take. You will end up doing 50 squats by the end of the day," says Tanya.

Title: Celebs go low-key with Gudi Padwa celebrations
Content: Usually, I begin the day by hoisting the gudi. It symbolises new beginnings, new hopes and aspirations. I have been celebrating it from my earlier days in Pune. Given the current situation, we need a lot of good vibes and positive energy. So, I’m going to celebrate it at home in a low-key manner, but the traditional way.We must respect the lockdown as it is the need of the hour. But at the same time, we should celebrate every occasion that brings us cheer. This year, we will celebrate Gudi Padwa in a small way.Gudi Padwa is believed to ward off evil, invite prosperity and good luck into our homes. So, this Padwa will be all about offering prayers for the entire country to ward off the evil of coronavirus. This year's celebration is certainly going to be different as it is all indoors and without any guests.Every year, my sisters, Tejaswini and Shivangi, would get together with me to celebrate. But this year, we will perform the pooja in our respective homes. Balcony pe gudi ubharenge and we’ll have puranpoli after offering it as naivedya. This year, we all have to ensure that we don’t organise family gatherings.I’m at home in Mumbai and will not be able to meet my family in Pune. So, I'll just make video calls to my parents. It is going to be a virtual Gudi Padwa for me. I'll hoist a Gudi on my balcony, perform a small pooja and make some special food. I’ll also pray for everyone’s well-being.It’s going to be a very private celebration this year. We are not stepping out and no guests can come over. I won’t be making any sweets either, as with the gyms closed, diet is a big concern. I won’t be able to step out to buy the kadu-nimb and toran, with which we decorate the gudi. However, I will draw a rangoli outside my door. I will hoist a gudi with a new cloth and wish everyone on the phone.On Gudi Padwa, we invite auspiciousness, positivity and well-being into our lives. My parent’ wedding anniversary falls on this day as per the Hindu calendar and generally, we celebrate it with a massive feast with all extended family members. However, this year, because of the quarantine, we will limit it to a video call with them. At my marital home, I will be making some puranpoli with my daughter Rianna, who loves cooking. We will also create some multi-hued rangolis in our home temple.Gudi Padwa is synonymous with immense joy and positivity. Since I am at home, I will help my mother make puranpoli and shrikhand. This year, it is going to be all about family time for me.We are all anxious, as these two weeks are critical for India. This year, too, we will hoist the gudi, but I will dress it up in a simple manner.All of us are practising social-distancing and self-isolation, so we will make our gudi with whatever is available at home. We plan to make garlands from newspapers and paint them. During these tough times, celebrations and auspicious occasions lend a feeling of togetherness and the hope that we’ll win over all hurdles. The biggest change this year is that while earlier, I would pray for the well-being of my family, now, I am praying for the whole world.We’re celebrating the festival indoors. We may not get the flowers, but we’ll follow the other rituals. The celebrations will be intimate. Didi Maushi (Lata Mangeshkar) is at Peddar Road, Aai (Asha Bhosle) is at her residence in Lower Parel and I am at mine and yet, we feel so connected and together. My cousins and younger kids in the family, who were studying abroad, have returned home in time, so we’re all in this together. This pandemic has forced us to think about our priorities and just how important family time is. On this festive day, I hope that we become more responsible individuals.I hope that this Gudi Padwa puts an end to the spread of the coronavirus. I wish and pray for a year of positivity and peace of mind. May this new year bring a lot of good health and hopefully, everyone can make some money as people have incurred a lot of losses, too.

Title: COVID-19: Robert De Niro urges people to stay at home
Content:
Robert De Niro is watching you. Stay home. Save lives. #NewYorkStateStrongerTogether https://t.co/WgAsBuIrKk — Andrew Cuomo (@NYGovCuomo) 1584924906000

In a bid to combat the spread of the coronavirus , actor Robert De Niro shared a video message for his followers urging them to stay indoors during this trying time.The 76-year-old star was recently seen recording a public statement encouraging everybody to practice self-isolation amid the coronavirus outbreak The video was part of a series released by New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo 's office in its ongoing effort to stop the rapidly spreading virus from doing more damage.In the shared 24-second long video, the actor who is seen at the comfort of his house begins the video by saying "Hello, this is Robert De Niro. We all need to stay home.""We need to stop the spread of this virus and we can only do it together. Not just to protect ourselves but to protect others and all the older people you love. Please...I'm watching you," he added.Many actors from the industry are putting their best foot forward to raise awareness of the importance of self-isolation during the outbreak of coronavirus.

Title: Singer-songwriter Lady Gaga postpones release of 'Chromatica' due to coronavirus outbreak
Content: Posting a long letter on Instagram on Tuesday, singer Lady Gaga has announced that she is postponing the release of her new album 'Chromatica' due to the outbreak of coronavirus The 33-year-old singer started the letter by asking people if they are safe and social distancing by staying at home."First of all, I wont to make sure everyone is staying safe and practicing social distancing. Please know that I'm thinking of you all," the musician's letter read. "I wanted to tell you that after a lot of deliberation, I've made the incredibly tough decision to postpone the release of Chromatic. I will announce a new 2020 releasedate soon," she said.After announcing a push-back of her much-awaited album the singer then threw light on the tough times that the world is currently battling."This is such a hectic and scary time for all of us, and while I believe art is one of the strongest things we have to provide joy and healing to each other during times like this it just doesn't feel right to me to release this album with all that is going on during this global pandemic," said Lady Gaga."I had so many fun things planned for us to celebrate together... I had a secret Coachella set lined up, and a lot of other fun surprises some of which I'm still planning to share with all of you very soon! Chromatics is still very much on the way and I can't wait," she added.She ended the note by asking people to stay home and stay kind with each other in the testing times. "I ask you to practice that kindness in these trying times. I hope you can see that when the album does come out, I want us to be able to dance together, sweat together, hug and kiss each other, and make it the most bombastic celebration ofall time," said the 'Shallow' singer."And until that time comes, LET'S ALL STAY HOME! But I promise you that when we can go out again, I'm going to make it SO MUCH FUN. I can't wait to be dancing with you all!" she added.Check out her post here:

Title: India Coronavirus: People scramble for essentials after speech, PM says don’t panic
Content:
More on Covid-19

NEW DELHI: As the 21-day lockdown sent people rushing late Tuesday to groceries and convenience stories and triggered panic buying, the PM tweeted, “My fellow citizens, THERE IS ABSOLUTELY NO NEED TO PANIC.” In another tweet, he said, “By converging around shops, you are risking the spread of Covid-19 . No panic buying please. Please stay indoors. Centre and state governments will ensure all essentials are available.”Raju Chhetri, a resident of Patparganj, was among those who had made a dash for the nerabymarket after hearing about the lockdown. He returned home empty-handed. “I visited five shops to buy a packet of atta. I was ready to settle for any brand but they didn't have a single packet left. The only option was to buy loose stuff of inferior quality,” he said.The story was the same everywhere — the fear of one’s larder going empty before the lockdown ends.H ow will a family survive without going out for 21 days? There is hardly anything in most stores. They should have given us some breathing time before announcing such a long lockdown, said Revathy S, a customer at a supermarket in Bengaluru’s Richmond Town.At 9.25pm, a crowd of shoppers arrived outside a closed DMart outlet at Powai in Mumbai and began arguing with the security guards. They demanded to know why the shutters had been rolled down “so soon”. By 9.30pm, Powai police arrived and placated the residents, saying that DMart would reopen on Wednesday. In several other Mumbai localities, the police made announcements asking people not to panic and assuring them that shops would reopen the next day. CM Thackeray and tourism minister Aaditya Thackeray, too, issued similar appeals. Dadar resident Sushma More said, “I have bought lots of sprouts as it is the best food to stock safely for a month or so.”The crowd in Bandra’s Pali Market had begun to shrink around 7.30pm, only to swell again at 8.30pm, following the PM’s address. The market was teeming with shoppers till 10pm. In Kolkata, long queues outside shops prompted Bengal CM Banerjee to make a fervent appeal to citizens not to step out and go on a panic buying spree.

Title: ‘Parents should limit talks about Covid-19’
Content: PATNA: Parents are exploring different ways to keep their wards busy as children and teenagers are having a tough time in comprehending the monotonous environment during the lockdown. Be it lifestyle, social or environmental changes, the Covid-19 pandemic is impacting the children in many ways.The UNICEF has talked about six strategies that can be used to cope up with the growing anxiety in teenagers and children during lockdown. It has also put forth a list of educational platforms and resources in order to help parents, teachers and school administrators to provide an educational set up for children and interact with them during the long periods of school closure.Psychiatrists in the city said it is important for parents to stay informed about the current situation and to look after their children’s mental well-being. “In situations like these, children tend to get irritated and frustrated, which further leads to anxiety disorders and depression. Since, the usual lifestyle has completely changed in the lockdown scenario, the urge of going out is even more,” said Binda Singh, a clinical psychiatrist.She added: “Parents and adults in the family should limit their talks about Covid-19. Besides, they should be careful about what they say in front of their kids.”Some of the parents have been spotting behavioural changes in their kids. “My 11-year-old daughter suddenly started screaming about getting infected with coronavirus . She also said she had a sore throat. It took us several hours to calm her down. We then decided to limit her exposure to television and mobile phone,” said Arpita of Jagdeo Path.Several parents said they are using various ways to divert their kids’ minds. “Recently we found a website which has made a number of children’s books free to listen to. It is better than watching online videos. Besides, it keeps my children distracted from what’s happening outside,” said Neetu Rakesh Singh of Kankarbagh.“I have got my son enrolled in an online class as the pressure will quadruple once the schools get reopened,” said Rashmi Sinha of PC Colony

Title: PMC intensifies disinfection drive
Content: PATNA: Patna Municipal Corporation (PMC) has intensified spraying of disinfectants in various localities of the town in order to prevent the spread of Covid-19 virus.The drive was carried out in Tuesday under the supervision of Mayor Sita Sahu, PMC commissioner Himanshu Sharma , additional municipal commissioner (enforcement and sanitation) Sheela Irani and executive officers of all circles.PMC officials said that 19 jetting machines were pressed into service to spray calcium hypochlorite, a disinfectant used for bleaching and purification, on the roads for several hours in all six circles— Azimabad, Bankipore, Kankerbagh, New Capital, Patliputra and Patna City. Besides, the anti-mosquito fumigation chemicals were also sprayed in several localities.Mayor Sahu also instructed the sanitation workers to disinfect public places, roads, streets and even some offices on alternate days. “We are not carrying out the drive regularly because of the fear of getting infected. We also expect to get more disinfectant solutions in few days. Sanitization workers were also asked to wear masks and hand gloves for their protection. Public places are being sanitised several rounds, but this is the first round of sanitization drive of city roads, streets and localities,” Sahu added.In Kankerbagh circle, the disinfection drive was carried out from Malahi Pakri to 90 feet road, Rajendra Nagar roundabout, Sabzi Mandi, Kanti Factory road and old bypass among others. The drive also took place at PMCH, NIT- Patna, Arya Kumar road and Bikhna Pahari to Musallahpur Hat under the Bankipore circle.Areas like Badi Pahadi, Jakariya Pul, Panchvati Colony, Adarsh Colony, Patan Devi , Ramna Vidyalaya and Bhadra Ghat were sanitised in Patna City circle, whereas in Azimabad circle, the drive was conducted from Ashok Rajpath to Malsalami police station, Takht Shri Harmandir Sahebji, Kangan Ghat and Qila Ghat.The workers in Patliputra circle sanitised officer’s flat, Patel Nagar, Christian Colony, Cheena Koti, Lodipur and Patiputra Colony. In the New Capital circle, the workers busy sanitising areas like SK Puri, Boring road, Boring Canal road, Gandhi Maidan, Police Colony, Raj Bhavan, Kaushal Nagar and Desh Ratan Marg.

Title: Over 120 who returned from corona-hit countries ‘missing’
Content: PATNA: State health department officials are in a tizzy following an order to re-examine the health of those people, who had returned to their villages from coronavirus-affected countries recently. Reason— scores of them have gone missing.More than 120 people from three districts in north Bihar — Muzaffarpur, Gopalganj and Saran are reportedly missing as the addresses and mobile phone numbers mentioned in their passports were found to be non-existent. Majority of them have either shifted to other places or changed their mobile numbers mentioned in their passports.“Among 150 returnees in Muzaffarpur, 68 are traceless. Similarly, 24 out of the 657 people are missing in Gopalganj followed by 30 out of 118 passengers in Saran district. Similar reports are pouring in from other districts as well,” Muzaffarpur civil surgeon-cum-chief medical officer (CMO) Dr Shailesh Prasad Singh said.The state surveillance unit (SSU), sources said, has handed a list of altogether 16,447 passengers with their names, addresses and cell phone numbers to the districts asking them to carry out a screening again in view of the coronavirus infection.Altogether 909 passengers, who have returned from coronavirus-affected countries after January 15, 2020 have been identified by the SSU and kept under home quarantine , according to a report issued by the health department on Tuesday.Patna topped the list where 100 passengers are under home quarantine followed by 74 in West Champaran, 72 in Gopalganj, 63 in Madhubani , 57 in Saharsa, 55 in Saran respectively.“It is possible that several of them skipped the screening at airports or later came in contact with people infected with coronavirus. So they need to be checked again,” says an SSU official.Saran, Siwan, Gopalganj, Muzaffarpur, Sitamarhi, East Champaran, West Champaran, Darbhanga, Madhubani, Madhepura, Saharsa, Supaul, Samastipur and Vaishali are among the districts, which are facing problems in tracing people.“We are caught in a dilemma. We have sought more details from the ministry of home affairs, which sends the list of passengers coming to India from corona-affected countries to the state. In fact, it’s an arduous task to comply with the order in the absence of relevant information,” said Gopalganj civil surgeon-cum-CMO Dr Nand Kishore Prasad Singh.Saran civil surgeon-cum-CMO Dr Madhveshwar Jha said, “As per the SSU’s latest order, we have to quarantine all those passengers at temporary quarantine centres set up in panchayat buildings or government schools in respective areas of the district. To date, they were quarantined at their respective homes.”Earlier, Gopalganj DM Arshad Aziz said government schools in panchayats have been turned into temporary quarantine centres to provide shelter to people who returned from abroad. He, however, claimed that all precautionary measures have been taken to contain the spread of coronavirus in the district, which shares its border with Uttar Pradesh.A senior IAS officer posted at the headquarters in Patna said a piquant situation was witnessed last week when residents of a village in Muzaffarpur district didn’t allow people to go to their homes without medical check after their return from abroad. As a result, they got their health examined at the SKMCH in Muzaffarpur.

Title: Sensex up 693 pts on global eco boosters
Content: Mumbai: Boosted by the surge in economic stimulus packages from around the world and expectations of one by the Indian government, the sensex surged about 1,800 points in mid-session on Tuesday. However, it gave up a large part of the gains as a similar package was not announced here during the day. The sensex closed 693 points up at 26,674. The Nifty closed 191 points higher at 7,801.The gains came despite a Rs 2,153-crore net selling by foreign funds, while domestic institutions were net buyers at Rs 1,554 crore, BSE data showed. Of the 30 sensex constituents, 19 closed higher, while 11 ended in the red. Among the gainers, Infosys, RIL and HUL contributed the most, while selling in HDFC, ITC and M&M limited the index’s rise.But market players fear that the day’s gains could be short-lived. Kotak Securities executive VP (equity technical research) Shrikant Chouhan said, although India and other countries had relief measures to stabilise the falling stock markets, the fear of coronavirus is increasing day by day and will do so till a solution is found for it. Technically, Nifty has good support at the 7,500 level, while on the upside 8,170-8,200 would be a major hurdle.After the Prime Minister announced a 21-day nationwide lockdown, market players are not sure if this will include the stock market and banking services. They feel if the markets are open, two things will decide direction for Wednesday’s trade — the impact of the lockdown on the economy, and how the Wall Street closes on Tuesday night. In early trades, the Dow Jones and the S&P500 indices were up 8.4% and 7.3% respectively as of 9.15pm IST, which points to some relief rally on Dalal Street on Wednesday, they said.

Title: No person test positve for Covid-19 on Tuesday, says govt
Content: Jaipur: Health authorities heaved a sigh of relief on Tuesday as no person tested positive for Covid-19 in the state.A 17-year-old person, resident of Jagatpura, was admitted to the SMS Hospital on Tuesday, his report is, however, awaited. He has been shifted to Charak Bhawan, which has been developed as corona hospital. He was suffering from cough.So far, in the state, 32 people have tested positive for the disease till Tuesday. “No person tests positive for Covid-19 on Tuesday. However, the result of five samples taken from suspected patients - two from Bhilwara, one each from Dausa, Tonk and Kota, are inconclusive. Hence, these samples are sent for re-test. One sample from a suspected Covid-19 patient has tested negative for the disease,” said Rohit Kumar Singh, additional chief secretary (health).According to the health department report, so far, till date from January, they have tested 1,464 samples and out of those 1,417 have tested negative. The report said that the result of six samples is awaited.In Jaipur, 488 people with influenza-like illness were tested for Covid-19, out of those, six have tested positive. Till date, 13 people have already been diagnosed with Covid-19 in Bhilwara, three in Jodhpur, four in Jhunjhunu, two in Pratapgarh, one each in Sikar, Pali and two Italian tourists were tested positive for the disease.However, the high court observed, “We are satisfied that all appropriate measures are being taken by the Centre and the state government to control and combat the menace of coronavirus and therefore, we are not inclined to pass any interim direction at this stage.”

Title: Bigbasket buys milk delivery co DailyNinja
Content:
Bengaluru: Online grocery major Bigbasket said it has acquired subscription-based milk delivery platform DailyNinja, backed by investors like Sequoia Capital and Matrix Partners, in an all-stock deal. The deal will help the Alibaba-backed company consolidate its leadership position in the segment as it will bring over 1 lakh customers being served by DailyNinja into the fold of its similar service, BBDaily .

Bigbasket said BBDaily currently makes around 1.6 lakh deliveries a day of items like fresh fruits, vegetables, bread, dairy, eggs and, personal and baby care products. The deal will help BBDaily expand its volumes by three times in the next 12 months. TOI had reported about Bigbasket’s plans of acquiring DailyNinja last week, and had added that it was in talks to buy Delhi-based Milkbasket too.

“DailyNinja currently has a large network of milkman partners, which will enable us to expand our offerings under BBDaily. Our relationship with the key national brands as well as the supply chain built over the years will help us deliver strong value proposition to them. We also aim to improve delivery productivity and achieve breakeven much sooner than planned,” said Bigbasket CEO Hari Menon.

Title: Travel cos, airlines to give only credit notes, no cash refunds
Content:
Chennai: Airline and travel planners are offering credit notes to customers whose travel plans have been cancelled due to corona virus pandemic, as full refund is becoming a stretch on their finances.

Upon directions from the aviation regulator, DGCA, flights from 00:00 hours on March 25, 2020 to 23:59 hours on March 31, 2020 have been suspended. Following the order, a few airlines offered passengers with credit account in the same PNR with the same ticket value for later date, while others offered free rescheduling. Travel planners on the other hand are willing to pass on credit notes against tour bookings to customers.

Indigo in a statement said, “Please be assured that your Booking Reference/PNR, will stay safe as a credit account in the same PNR with the same ticket value. The credit account can be used for travel before September 30, by the same passenger.”

AirAsia India offered flexibility credit options for its passengers, which included booking to a new date for free and Spicejet said it will give credit notes with a one year validity.

Travel companies are facing acute cash flow issues. “With 90% bookings cancelled over the last few days, we do not have the resources to provide refund, thus we are offering credit share with customers. There is no expiry date for this credit, so one can use it for their next travel with us. For people who fear travel for the long run may use our other services like visa and passport, rail passes, cruise,” said Seema Ahmed, general manager of Gainwell Travel.

“At present, we have about 2%-3% of credit notes passed on to our customers, and expect it to go up going forward,” said Hari Ganapathy, co-founder of Pickyourtrail, which offers personalised travel packages.

“As a traveller, one may not want to go to the same hotel, or destination once this chaos ends. Thus, we do not recommend or offer hotel credits since it will not work on customers,” he said. Pickyourtrail has formed a recovery team to explain customers on trip cancellation and rescheduling.

Some are pushing their vacation to September and beyond. “Some customers are willing to reschedule holiday trips post October for countries like New Zealand, Australia, Bali, Singapore. However, everyone wants to cancel trips to Europe,” Ganapathy added.

Title: Medicos rue shortage of protective kits
Content: PATNA: With suspected cases of Covid-19 rising across the state, doctors, nurses and paramedical staff are facing a dire shortage of Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) kits, which include masks, gloves surgical gowns and eye gear to protect them from the virus.The shortage of PPE kit has forced the doctors to opt for the normal mask and other medical supplies. Health workers rely on PPE to protect themselves and their patients from being infected and infecting others.Dr Ravi Ram, a junior doctor at NMCH, who is suffering from fever and cough, complained that there was no PPE kit for doctors, who are treating Covid-19 suspects and patients. “We have sent a letter to the principal secretary of health department on Wedneday urging him to provide ventilator, PPE kit, isolation ward, hand-sanitizers and N95 masks at NMCH. Otherwise all doctors would get infected,” Dr Ravi told this newspaper on Tuesday.He claimed that around 15 doctors and health staff at NMCH are on sick leave after they developed fever, cold and cough. They have quarantined themselves in their homes.Dr Raman, who is the president of Junior Doctors Association , NMCH, said the doctors don’t need extra pay announced by chief minister Nitish Kumar, instead they are demanding health equipment.The junior doctors at Patna Medical College and Hospital (PMCH) also complained of shortage of protective gears. One of the junior doctors said they were increasingly worried and doubtful that they could be expose not only themselves to the virus, but also their families and others.A resident doctor at AIIMS , Patna, claimed that there were enough PPE kits, but they are facing shortage of N95 mask. “We need N95 mask for doctors treating patients at emergency ward, because there are chances that the suspected cases may be carrying the Covid-19 virus. The surgical mask won’t be effective to protect doctors from the virus,” the doctor said.Sanjay Kumar, principal secretary of health department, told this newspaper that all necessary medical equipment are being made available to the hospitals. “It is an ongoing process and the medical equipment is consumable items. It cannot become a reason for evasion of duties,” he said, adding that doctors who are complaining of being sick, should give their samples for testing.

Title: Rush of flyers at Patna airport
Content:
Representative image

PATNA: Heavy rush of passengers was witnessed at Patna airport on Tuesday as it was the last day for domestic flight operations . People from across the country landed here to return to their homes.

Altogether 23 flights were cancelled on Tuesday due to operational reasons and airport lockdown in other states. IndiGo and GoAir cancelled seven flights each mostly on routes connecting Patna with Mumbai, Delhi and Hyderabad, while five flights of Air India and four of SpiceJet were suspended.

A special flight was operated by SpiceJet between Kolkata-Patna-Kolkata (SG-911) on Tuesday for students from Bihar , who were stuck in West Bengal . “The flight arrived at Patna airport at 7pm with 100 passengers,” an executive of the airline said.

Meanwhile, four airport express special buses operated from the city airport on Tuesday for the convenience of passengers. Transport secretary Sanjay Kumar Agarwal said arrangements were made to send those people home who reached the city from Kerala and other places on Tuesday.

“Since operation of domestic flights will stop from 11.59pm on Tuesday, we were expecting rush at the airport,” Agarwal said.

Title: Bihar govt extends OTS scheme for three months
Content:
Sushil Kumar Modi

PATNA: Deputy chief minister Sushil Kumar Modi said on Tuesday that the government has extended the period of the one-time settlement (OTS) scheme by three months for the resolution of the pre-GST (Goods and Services Tax) tax disputes worth Rs 604.84 crore. It has also reduced the settlement amount of Rs 155.06 crore under the OTS scheme.

Modi said that the last date for the filing of applications was March 25. In accordance with the government’s move on the OTS scheme, the remaining tax disputes would be cleared over the next three months.

While the GST regime came into force in the country on July 1, 2017 after the merger of existing taxes like value added tax (VAT), entry tax, luxury tax, entertainment tax, etc in it, the tax disputes in question are related to the pre-GST or to the VAT regime.

“As per the OTS scheme, the traders concerned will have to pay 35% of the disputed tax amount, along with 10% of the interest and penalty charged on the disputed tax amount,” the deputy CM added.

He said that as many as 23,695 applications have been received till date. Of them, 6,080 applications had been cleared and Rs 20 crore deposited into the state exchequer. Prior to that, Rs 59.66 crore had already been deposited by the parties concerned, and Rs 75 crore remains to be recovered.

Title: Hyderabad: Covid-19 helpline proves hard to reach
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: Though the state government claims to have made enough arrangements deal with Covid-19 cases, reality seems quite different. Despite a 24-hour helpline being set up for Covid-19-related concerns, few are able to get through to authorities, and even if they do, medical teams are not reaching their locality to conduct tests and take the infected to hospitals.

Syed Abdahu Kashaf, a resident of Malakpet, said, “I received a call from a lady who works in HiTec City. She had trouble breathing, high fever and throat pain which are symptoms of corona. I dialled helpline number 104 nearly 6 times, but there was no response.” He tagged minister KT Rama Rao on Twitter and said, “Sir @KTRTRS, we tried calling 104 for 6 times they failed to respond it’s positive case of #COVID-19 she came to Hyderabad on March 17 via flight from Jabalpur. She is ill from 5 days. She stays in a hostel and communicated with more than 50 other women. Please take necessary action.”

Similarly, P Suresh from Balanagar area said no action had been taken despite authorities being informed about a person who returned from Italy with symptoms of Covid-19.

GHMC deputy commissioner Prashanthi Vangeepuram and Cyberabad police responded after seeing the video on Twitter and collected details. Meanwhile, chief minister K Chandrashekar Rao, on Tuesday said, “ For any medical emergency, call 100. Police will take them to hospitals or make arrangements.“

Title: HUL replans operations to protect staff health, shield business
Content: MUMBAI: Office-based employees of Hindustan Unilever ( HUL ) went into a work-from-home (WFH) mode from March 17 itself, and the Rs 38,000-crore FMCG major has already framed a new set of protocols for employees, area sales managers (ASMs) and the field force.An incident management team (IMT) — a cross-functional steering committee — has been set up to lead multiple pillars for Covid-19 readiness, and over 1,000 circle meetings (virtual meetings each manager has had with his or her team) have taken place to cover the last blue-collared employee on the shop floor.The company has mapped 40-50 top mission-critical roles, with a plan of two levels down as substitutes to ensure business continues if any individual is unable to attend to a role.For its 140 ASMs, the directive is — in any given week — very few managers would travel in the market for business-critical work. Similarly, for office support, a small number of managers would come to office, while a higher number of remaining managers would work from home . Managers are rotated between these three work locations on a weekly basis to ensure social distancing, safety and business continuity. The standard operating procedures talk about what an ASM’s life would look like when he or she is in the market and what would it look like at home .“What’s happening today is unprecedented. The new set of protocols we have put in place will allow us to play a dual role of an employer as well as a provider of essential products like soaps and packaged foods to consumers,” said HUL executive director (HR) Anuradha Razdan.The company has plotted a large matrix classifying towns, areas and micro-areas that are operating in line with government advisories. “With this matrix, we ensure we continue to have contact with the trade and at the same time we minimise exposure and risk. For example, for our field force, there are clear guidelines and we make sure everyone has a shared understanding of this,” said Razdan.Considering that the situation is dynamic, leaders are required to demonstrate quick decision-making. The day starts with a virtual stand-up meeting and ‘check-ins’ to ensure all feedback goes upwards and then seeps down to the people. Leaders are told to listen in and share in. Every team has these meetings, preferably first thing in the day. “The objective is to create a virtual intimacy that will allow people to stay positive even through these very unprecedented times by keeping employees positive and bring transparency of communication,” said Razdan.At the top, the management committee of HUL meets CMD Sanjiv Mehta where the discussion is around the health & safety of people, business continuity, long-term strategy & opportunities, and how the company can keep the momentum going. Mehta is all set to hold his second virtual town hall, something that he would otherwise address once every quarter.“Communication is critical to reflect the new ways of working. So from the supply chain leadership team, it goes to the unit leadership team, or the factory heads and then to the factory leadership team, and then to the first level of manager who has a meeting on the shop floor with blue-collared employees,” Razdan said. In the next few days, the new protocols would reach over two lakh people in the extended ecosystem.The company is, however, not trying to centrally drive engagement, with team leaders developing their own personal style. “Teams are developing their own rituals and rhythm of work. For instance, we have a team that works in the big data. On the first day, they said they have set up a routine to have ‘coffee check-ins’. Another team celebrated a virtual birthday. Our R&D teams in Bengaluru decided to have a ‘Vitamin D stand-up meeting’ — sitting at home in a corner which gets sun, because otherwise in a WFH situation one wouldn’t get enough sun. We are channelling people’s ideas and learning from them,” said Razdan.Empathy is equally important. “When Sanjiv (Mehta) calls up, the first question is, ‘How are you feeling today?’ There’s also a plan to have a mindfulness session virtually to keep employees motivated.”Meanwhile, as the days progress and employees settle into their WFH routines, the tone of communication is expected to evolve to the next level. “This week was all about settling in. There’s a helpline especially created for the current stage, because they have a number of questions and they want to be heard. We want people to use this time to reflect and do things which one would not have been able to do earlier. In the coming week, once we’ve settle in this new normal, the entire focus should be back to business,” said Razdan.

Title: Home isolation must for those from big cities: Pune zilla Parishad
Content: PUNE: The zilla parishad (ZP) on Tuesday made home quarantine mandatory for those going back to their villages in the district from Mumbai, Pune and other cities.A sizeable rural population from Khed, Junnar, Ambegaon and other villages in the district work in big cities, which are among the most affected by the Covid-19 contagion. “Our medical teams, along with talathis, gramsevaks and other officials, will monitor the health status of villagers daily and if anybody is found suffering from cold, cough and fever, he/she will be immediately referred to the nearest quarantine facility. We have created isolation wards at different locations,” Pune ZP CEO Ayush Prasad told TOI.According to the district administration, about 50,000 people have returned to 1,000 villages in the district. “We have asked village-level revenue officials to ferret out details of these people and asked our health officials to check their health,” added Prasad.A section of revenue and health officials, however, conceded that carrying out such health checks would be a huge task for them since many people stay in far-flung hamlets. “Considering the skeletal manpower and inadequate healthcare facilities at the village level, it would be difficult to provide them timely and quality healthcare. We have asked village sarpanchs and police patils to provide details of these people,” said another ZP official.At many places, there is only one primary healthcare centre for 10 to 15 villages with very few beds. “The district administration has prepared quarantine facilities at tehsil and towns. Over 3,000 people are home quarantined and their health is being monitored daily,” the official added. The ZP administration swung into action after a 41-year-old anganwadi sevika from Velhe taluka tested positive for Covid-19. “The woman had gone to attend a wedding in Navi Mumbai and it is suspected that she contracted the disease from a virus-affected person there. The villagers are scared across Velhe as many people who were in Mumbai and Pune have returned to their native villages. Similarly, there are hundreds of people in other tehsils. How can we trace each of them in a very short time,” said another official.“Keeping people in home quarantine in a village is a tough task as most houses are small. Secondly, they use common toilets. Due to this reason there are high chances of villagers coming in contact with each other. Thus, creating adequate common quarantine facilities across the district is necessary,” a senior health official from the ZP told TOI.

Title: NGOs join battle to combat coronavirus in tigerlands
Content: Nagpur: Even as cities have geared up to tackle novel coronavirus (Covid-19) outbreak, NGOs working in the buffer zone of tiger reserves are also doing their lot to screen villagers for symptoms and to spread awareness about the dreaded infection.In a major awareness and health check-up camp for tribals, Satpuda Foundation , an NGO working for tiger conservation in Central India, screened 300 residents of six villages in the buffer zone of Pench Tiger Reserve (PTR), Maharashtra.A unique mobile health service (MHS) of Satpuda Foundation is helping tribal villagers of Pench by educating them about the dos and don’ts to save themselves from acquiring coronavirus infection. The MHS, which was launched to serve locals living around the reserve in January 2014, has come handy during the novel coronavirus outbreak.“Though Section 144 has been imposed in Nagpur and academic institutions have been closed down, health sector staffers are serving day and night in this critical situation,” said Kishor Rithe, president of Satpuda Foundation. Satpuda’s mobile health service has conducted health camps and offered medical assistance to 300 patients from six villages — Wagholi, Sillari, Khursapar, Sawara, Khapa and Ghoti.“Those suffering from fever and cough were particularly worried about the possibility of having coronavirus infection. However, it was found that people there suffered from routine fever and cough,” said Dr Manohar Khode , who is serving the tribals for more than 20 years in Melghat, after the health camps.“The MHS, which is also spreading awareness on dos and don’ts to prevent spread of coronavirus, has treated around 70,000 patients in the last six years and also offered further support for surgeries, eye operations and dental extractions. Medicine is also being distributed for free,” said Rithe.Satpuda’s conservation officer Mandar Pingle , Bandu Uike and Dilip Lanjewar informed that in the second phase similar screenings will be done from March 23 in six villages in the buffer zone of Pench on Madhya Pradesh side.Similarly, in the buffer zone of Melghat Tiger Reserve (MTR), Dr Ashish Satav’s MAHAN (Meditation, Addiction, Health, AIDS and Nutrition), an NGO providing preventive and curative medical facilities to tribals, also screened many villagers for coronavirus-like symptoms in the last 20 days.Dr Satav said, “Our team is spreading awareness among tribals from 35 villages in the tiger reserve buffer. Two villagers having corona-like symptoms were referred to Amravati, but these patients tested negative.”“We are creating massive awareness on precautions to be taken as many villagers are still unaware about the repercussions of the deadly virus. They have also been told not to leave their homes or go outstation,” said Dr Satav.

Title: Drunk man cuts neck fearing arrest
Content:
Nagpur: A drunk man cut his own neck with a small knife at his house after fearing police had come to arrest him on Monday at Sudama Nagar. The drunk man, Satish Channe, suspected that police had come to arrest him after his girlfriend went missing.

Cops said they went to the house of the accused following a control room call that a person was thrashing his family members. When cops reached the house, he started abusing them and also manhandled the cops. The cops snatched the knife from his hand before arresting him.

Ambazari police have registered a case of obstructing a government official from discharging his duty. Cops said Channe sustained minor cuts on his neck during the drama. Channe has several old offences against him and was also externed from city limits earlier.

Title: Facebook Jio Stake News: Facebook in talks for 10% in Jio: Report
Content: BENGALURU/MUMBAI: Social media giant Facebook is in talks to buy a 10% stake in Reliance Jio, billionaire Mukesh Ambani ’s telecom and internet services venture, the Financial Times reported on Tuesday citing two people with knowledge of the matter.The US-based technology giant, which also owns Instagram and WhatsApp, was close to signing a preliminary deal but the negotiations got delayed due global travel bans arising from the current coronavirus pandemic.The development comes as Reliance Industries ( RIL ), the parent company of Jio and which also has interests in petrochemicals and retail, has been looking to induct foreign partners in all businesses as it plans to deleverage itself. While a Facebook India spokesperson did not reply to TOI’s queries till the time of going to press, Reliance could not be reached for comment. The FT report added that Google had also engaged with Reliance Jio earlier.For Facebook, India is the largest market in terms of users with its products seeing rapid adoption on the back of the proliferation of cheap internet plans. But the Silicon Valley-based company has also faced issues in India — from fake news across its platform to delay of payments services under its messaging unit WhatsApp.Last year, reports had stated that Japan’s SoftBank may invest in Reliance Jio. A JP Morgan research report gave Jio a potential valuation of $50 billion, while Bernstein pegged it at $60 billion.At the RIL AGM in August last year, Ambani had said that the company will become a zero net debt company in 18 months. This is being done through a slew of equity partnerships in various businesses. RIL has been in talks to sell stake in its petrochemicals business to Saudi Arabia’s Aramco, but the deal has reportedly faced delays.It has already finalised deals for its retail petrol pump business with BP and for telecom tower assets with Canada’s Brookfield, which is scheduled to be closed by the end of the financial year ending March 31, 2020. RIL closed last financial year, which ended in March 2019, with a net debt of Rs 1,54,478 crore.Jio became India’s largest telco by subscribers, reaching 370 million connections, in January. It also has digital media apps like JioTV, JioSaavn, JioCinema and JioNews. Over the last three years, Jio has also been making acquisitions as it looks to get into new areas like online retail & commerce, education and healthcare along with plans to build a broader ecosystem of internet services and drive synergies with its retail business as well.

Title: Sena MP opposes rly line through Melghat
Content:
Nagpur: Known for his wildlife love, Shiv Sena MP from Buldhana Prataprao Jadhav has urged Union environment minister Prakash Javadekar not to sanction gauge conversion through Melghat Tiger Reserve (MTR). Instead, he wants the line to pass through his constituency in larger interests of both, people and wildlife.

In a letter written to Javadekar on March 17, Jadhav has pointed out that Melghat is among the first 9 tiger reserves of the country declared in 1973. The reserve has 50 tigers and upgradation of meter gauge line to broad gauge will cause disturbance to wildlife and also reverse benefits accrued from rehabilitation of 13 villages from core area of the reserve.

As per the uni-gauge policy of the Union government, all meter gauge lines are being converted into broad gauge. Accordingly, the 176km line between Akola-Khandwa passing through the tiger reserve is also being upgraded by the Indian Railways.

Of the 176km railway line — Akola-Akot (44km), Akot-Amlakhurd (78km) and Amlakhurd-Khandwa (54km) — 38km passes through the core buffer area of the tiger reserve and requires forest diversion of 161 hectare area. The railway ministry has sanctioned Rs 1,421.25 crore for the project.

Jadhav said the project needs clearance from the Supreme Court and also the environment ministry. The proposal contains dismantling and open cutting of Talai tunnel of 360 metres which will require major cutting and blasting of rocks using heavy machineries and explosives.

“The proposal also contains realignment away from the existing meter gauge track to ease sharp curves of 23.48km out of the 38km track length from the reserve. The proposal has been recommended by Akot deputy conservator of forest considering the dangers,” said Jadhav.

The Sena MP said the gauge conversion will in the long run increase train traffic which will result into huge disturbance to the presence of 8 tigers and other rich wildlife in the project area.

Jadhav said country’s premier Wildlife Institute of India (WII), Dehradun, in its recommendation on January 17, 2019, had recommended that best mitigation for the railway line through the tiger reserve is ‘avoidance’ and go for alternative alignment.

If the alternative alignment is taken, then the track passes through Jadhav’s constituency and he says it will not only benefit at least 2 lakh people but also bring about economic development of the backward region. “It will save precious forest and wildlife too,” said Jadhav.

Earlier, 30 NGOs, including Vidarbha Chamber of Commerce, Satpuda Foundation and political representatives of the region had voiced their concern against the project. Over 60,000 individuals from 68 countries have signed an online petition to save the tiger reserve.

Title: Cab drivers, delivery staff seek govt relief
Content:
Bengaluru: The Indian Federation of App-based Transport Workers (IFAT), which counts lakhs of gig economy workers like Uber and Ola drivers along with food delivery staff for platforms like Swiggy and Zomato , has urged the government to direct ride-hailing platforms to reduce their commission to 5% till the pandemic subsides in India.

Uber and Ola typically charge 25-30% as commission per ride from drivers, IFAT’s national general secretary Shaik Salauddin said. IFAT, in a letter dated March 22 to the PMO and the finance ministry also sought assistance for the delivery staff of Zomato and Swiggy with state-level minimum wages. Over the past week, earnings have taken a severe hit for app-based cab drivers, while online food delivery orders are declining as well, affecting the income of delivery partners.

“Even today, amid the coronavirus situation, cab platforms are sending reminders to our drivers to pay EMIs. Is this being helpful in a time like this when earnings are down drastically?” added Salauddin.

This comes at a time when Uber and Ola have temporarily shut operations in some cities in line with government orders from Monday.
