Ola said it is already waiving off lease payments for drivers operating vehicles owned by its subsidiary, Ola Fleet Technologies. “Driver-partners, who are currently in distress due to the temporary lockdown to arrest the contagion of COVID-19, will stand to benefit with the reduced economic burden during these times,” an Ola spokesperson said. Uber and Swiggy spokespersons declined to comment, while TOI could not elicit a response from Zomato.

Title: Hackathons look at out of the box solutions for Covid pandemic
Content:
Chennai: ‘One could 3D print a ventilator to deal with a shortage or build an app where medical professionals can train people to help patients who may be Covid positive.

With ideas and tech-based solutions brewing, virtual hackathons are being conducted by entrepreneurs and the developer community coming together and by companies such as Hacker Earth and Skillenza. At Coronathon, the dedicated hackathon conducted by developers coming together, close to 25 projects and about 1,500 people are involved. “In a span of 2 days since we went live, we have seen these people come on board. Not only will the ideas be brainstormed and developed, every Sunday, we will present these ideas – which are in the demo stages — to panellists who include industry players and officials from the government,” said Paras Chopra, one of the organisers and founder, Wingify.

The hackathons would have problem statements that include solutions for online learning to help the student community using AR/VR and AI-based contact tracking solutions for healthcare and designing community maps to track the spread of the virus.

Bengaluru-based Skillenza has a Rs 8 lakh prize money and sponsors from Microsoft, gaming company Unity and the government of Jharkand among others for winning ideas to solve Covid-related issues. “We have 5,000 entries so far. We are concentrating on bringing in a gaming-based approach to solve epidemic issues, tracking community cases and management of home-based quarantines, reinventing the live experience of a video class, learning apps for kids, training the trainers, or AI in education,” said Subhendu Panigrahi, founder, Skillenza.

Prime Ventures-backed Hacker Earth has its hackathon going live from March 24 and would end in May. The platform has called out for developers all over the globe to develop solutions for issues on the ground. Some of its problem statements read: Analyze the data around Covid-19 events and predict potential Covid-19 cases across the globe on a day-to-day basis and Build a travel dashboard aimed at helping people traveling in the critical situation, to give them ways to take the safest route, visit nearest clinics/hospitals facilitating check-ups, etc.

“Through this hackathon, we are looking to bring the global tech community together to identify solutions that can help mitigate the outbreak and its impact,” Sachin Gupta, CEO, Hacker Earth

Title: Smartphone shipments to India may dip for the 1st time
Content:
Chennai: India — the world’s second largest and the fastest growing smartphone market will witness a forgetful year with shipments into the country remaining flat or registering a fall over last year, as Covid-19 dents demand.

The Indian smartphone market surpassed the US for the first time in 2019 on an annual level, becoming the second-largest smartphone market globally, reaching 158 million shipments in 2019 with 7% YoY growth, due to the expansion of Chinese brands with their aggressive pricing and promotional strategy. It was expected to grow by up to 14% in 2020, according to analyst firm TechArc.

With the Coronavirus pandemic smashing the supply chain and bringing Chinese production to a screeching halt, the supplies to the global market are severely impacted. Just as the Chinese factories are getting ready to restart production, India has announced an unprecedented lockdown with factories remaining shut or working with truncated production schedules.

“The Indian smartphone market is expected to decline 4.2% for the full year 2020 in the worst case scenario, while the best case scenario a growth of 3.2% year-on-year. Sell out in offline channels will be impacted immediately, although ecommerce sites such as Amazon and Flipkart are still operational with work in progress deliveries,” analysts at research firm Canalys wrote in a note.

Earlier the slump was predicted based on supply side issues, but with the Indian government locking the country down, coupled with economic uncertainty, the issue has shifted from supply side to demand. “An optimistic view is growth returning sooner than later with China resuming production slowly, a pessimistic view would be a washout while a probabilistic view is a recovery in the last quarter (of calendar year),” said Navkendar Singh, research director – devices and ecosystem, India & South Asia, IDC. He said, in a post Corona situation, the buyer might look at smartphone replacement as a non essential and hence hold back fresh buys.

Demand drop will not be restricted to India. “The combination of a slower return to normal levels of demand in China (where we now expect a double-digit decline yoy), high-single digit decline in Europe, and low-single digit decline in North America is now leading us to forecast a (-) 3.1% decline in industry volumes – which in magnitude will eclipse the declines seen in recent years,” wrote analysts at JP Morgan in a research note.

Notwithstanding all the gloom, with the 5G roll out gaining shape, and pent up demand, could push purchase of 5G compatible handsets in China this year and other markets next year.

Title: We may become more productive working from home
Content: By Prabir Jha As the country and the world battles the threat and hysteria over the Covid-19 virus, organisations and governments have responded in varying degrees. Some have encouraged their teams to work from home , others have mandated a more severe shutdown. Curtailing of travel facilities and other support systems have also made a new acronym familiar to many — WFH (work from home).This round of WFH is more to push for limiting group contact and prevent the risk of the spread of coronavirus , and not as much for work-life balance or flexi-work. But my sense is that this will take us to another phase of influencing the future of work — a subject for another day. The big debate is: Will this WFH shift lead to reduced emotional connect at the workplace?While the ruling is not out yet, organisations and leaders can use this time to create a stronger emotional connect within their teams and with the firm:*Encourage sharing of WFH stories: Most organisations turn sterile and believe there must be some firewall between home and work. Managers hardly appreciate the domestic distractions, interests and predicaments of their teams. If only they knew, some could empathise and encourage better. Today, there is an opportunity to share a glimpse of the “person” behind the role. As people share, they will express another side of their persona. I am convinced that it will only help build greater empathy , respect and support for each other.*Change the nature of meetings: Office meetings are constrained by a physical environment. WFH meetings will be quicker and shorter. However, it could allow itself to more enquiries about each other, at the beginning or the end, given the health worries. Leaders could learn to lead meetings with empathy rather than just run directive meetings. To me, this is an opportunity for nuancing leadership development. And yes, if you want meetings to be an opportunity for high-potential people to sit and observe, you can more easily invite younger talent to “sit in” and observe. This could be a great way of becoming more egalitarian and yet develop your talent.*Smart home working may leave more time for emotional connect: A lot of time at work is sitting through hours of unproductive work and meetings. Possibly, we will get more efficient and productive at work, operating from home. Companies could share virtual tips and training inputs on these. These will be techniques that can help carry forward improved productivity at even a physical workplace. The time saved could be used to call another colleague or relative, text with those you have not for a long time, help with stuff at home without the stress of travel and just connect with family better to improve relationships at home. Companies could even explore some games and group exercises for families to try out at home, and even run a fun competition along those lines. As a CHRO, I always encouraged family days, as a better engaged family is a better engaged employee. Let families be grateful to the company for helping them get closer. And more grateful families will improve employee engagement. Most of all, the hysteria and tension will be somewhat dissipated too — an important societal contribution to be made.*Create more virtual clubs for interest groups: WFH could be a very good time for organisations to think of creating virtual interest groups, cutting across locations, functions and designations. Imagine creating a community of dog lovers or photo enthusiasts. Away from the classical barriers of a physical workplace, it could be such a silo-breaking opportunity. And common interests can even dissolve frosty work relationships as they discover some things that they never ever knew about one another. Positive emotions are incubated, never directed.*Use time away from home to pause and reflect: WFH also is a great time to take anger, angst and frustration away from the recall of an inimical workplace or work relationship. It helps put life and relationships in perspective. As one has more time to pause and reflect, it can help many to wonder if many of the disturbed relationships were worth it. And to resolve to repair and let go.To attempt new beginnings. And if companies could help with some virtual counselling support through their employee-assistance programmes, many could be encouraged to liberate themselves from dysfunctional relationships. A more self-aware mind surely will bring to work a more empathetic heart. And positive relationships indeed build better business results.Every crisis has its silver lining. Am sure the current health scare and a responsible WFH regimen will enable us to see a more emotionally sensitive future of work. Let’s not see these days as a break from work. Let’s make this count more. Let’s help build more emotionally stronger relationships and, in turn, enhance the ‘Optimism Quotient’ of our workplace to bounce back stronger.(The writer is the founder & CEO of Prabir Jha People Advisory

Title: Whisky, rum distilleries to make sanitisers now
Content:
Bengaluru/Mumbai: You know the drill: Clean your hands with an alcohol-based hand-rub or wash them with soap & water to control the transmission of the coronavirus. But, with an extraordinary demand for the hand sanitiser , it’s hard to find it on retail shelves or is out of stock on e-commerce platforms.

It’s here that the distilleries are stepping in. With alcohol being the star content of the sanitiser, the distillers want to make it in a bid to fill a national need during this time of crisis. They have approached the Centre with the proposal and are hoping for permissions from the states and Union territories as alcohol is regulated by them.

“It has been brought to our notice that distilleries can also produce sanitiser, for which necessary permissions may be accorded by the states and Union territories on a priority basis,” read the circular issued by the consumer affairs ministry.

Diageo is the first big player to have received permission to manufacture hand sanitisers from its 15 units across the country. The maker of Smirnoff vodka and Vat 69 whisky said its distilleries will be “repurposed” to produce around 3 lakh hand sanitisers.

Radico Khaitan, on the other hand, has geared up to make hand sanitiser from its Rampur distillery in Uttar Pradesh. “The drug officers will visit the distillery. Production should begin as soon as we get the licence,” said the company’s COO Amar Sinha .

The alcoholic beverage sector’s move comes when it has been losing sales because of the closure of bars, pubs and discotheques in several parts of the country.

With this, Indian spirit makers join their US and European counterparts, which have switched from distilling alcohol to producing hand sanitiser to help communities battle the Covid-19 crisis. The WHO has recommended that the hand-rub solution should contain at least 60% alcohol concentration to stem the spread of the virus. “The ministry has urged the chief secretaries of states to provide a waiver in excise duty for units distilling alcohol. Excise duty is prohibitive and, when included in the manufacturing cost of sanitisers, it doesn’t work out to be feasible,” said Indian Spirits & Wine Association chairman Amrit Kiran Singh. States earn 20-30% revenues from excise duty and value-added tax on alcoholic beverages. The other option, said Singh, is to allow distillers to “denature” alcohol for units that have GST registration. “Denatured alcohol, which is alcohol not meant for human consumption, is under GST and is lower than excise duty. This will make alcohol available in a cost-effective manner to the sanitiser industry,” added Singh.

A few days ago, craft beer maker Goa Brewing Company tweeted that it was making sanitisers available at a nominal cost to fight the shortage. “Our brewing team is making them using WHO guidelines for our tribe in Goa. If you carry your own bottle, you can take a free refill from our brewery.”

Reacting to the tweet, Albinder Dhindsa, CEO of online supermarket Grofers, said, “We would love to sell it on @Grofers if you can make enough.” Dhindsa had earlier said that his firm ran out of stock with its in-house sanitiser brand O’range after demand spiked for it this month.

Title: ‘RBI needs unconventional measures to boost liquidity’
Content:
Mayur Shetty | TNN

Mumbai: Bank chiefs have said that mutual funds, corporates and some private lenders are facing a liquidity crunch and the Reserve Bank of India ( RBI ) needs to take unconventional measures to unfreeze the markets in the coronavirus crisis. “All cash collections and consequently cash flows have gone into a freeze. Mutual funds are facing redemption pressure and unprecedented selling has hit bond markets,” said a bank chief.

Bankers said that most of RBI’s measures have been conventional — providing additional liquidity to banks through repos and open market operations. However, given the distressed situation of businesses, banks cannot provide loans. “The US Fed has taken some really exceptional measures to prevent a credit freeze. Other central banks are taking similar steps. Many were expecting the RBI to announce its package on Monday,” said the chief of a second public sector bank.

On Monday, HDFC Bank chief Aditya Puri said that there was no choice but to provide forbearance to borrowers. The Basel Committee on Banking Supervision — a global bank watchdog group — on Friday discussed easing rules to avoid banks facing huge provisions for supporting companies hit by the coronavirus crisis.

Puri said that his bank had over Rs 35,000-crore surplus funds but had a simple condition for lending — borrowers should demonstrate that there will be cash flows to be able to make the repayment. The government has nudged public sector banks to provide additional credit lines, but they say providing cash support without assurance is difficult.

In the US, the Federal Reserve has re-introduced a term asset-backed securities facility that was there during the global financial crisis. It has also enabled employers to claim funds through primary market corporate credit facility and secondary market corporate credit facility. Smaller lenders are seeing demand for funds from state governments where different departments are drawing the deposits. “Once the damage is done, it is difficult to come back. Companies are not able to keep up their commitments and are sitting on potential defaults. What is needed is a 15-day or a one-month window where everything is frozen,” said a banker.

Obligations include letters of credit that come up for payment, taxes, and salaries which the government has asked all employers not to hold back. Bankers said that while the economic package can take some time, liquidity is a problem for some players and the RBI needs to provide a window for mutual funds to raise funds.

Title: No screening of cane cutters at Beed border
Content:
Aurangabad: With a surge in the number of confirmed coronavirus cases in Western Maharashtra, with five fresh cases being reported from Sangli and Satara districts, many sugarcane harvesters are now leaving the region and making inroads into Marathwada.

A group of sugarcane harvesters from Satara district, which reported a confirmed coronavirus case on Monday, entered Beed district in a tractor trolley on Tuesday. TOI found them violating the lockdown at Shivaji Chowk in Beed city.

Around five men, five women and three children were travelling in a double trolley attached to a tractor. They were carrying utensils, bedding and clothes and were headed to Takalwadi village—around 10 to 12km from Beed. The group was traveling via Baramati route on Ahmednagar highway and entered Beed from Jamkhed.

Incidentally, the Beed administration has deployed teams at 14 of the district’s border check posts to screen new arrivals. However, the aforementioned group was not screened.

When asked about the cane cutters, district collector Rahul Rekhawar said that as thousands of people pass the check posts, it was not possible to screen all of them. “We are taking down details of all the new arrivals. Our teams will be reaching to their respective villages or residences in the city and screening them,” said Rekhawar.

Notably, a large number of people from the villages in Beed travel to western Maharashtra during the crushing season for harvesting sugarcane. Now that the crushing season has come to an end and many sugar factories have shut their operations following the outbreak of coronavirus in the state, many people are returning to their hometowns. Therefore, the district administration is required to take alert steps to ensure the workers are screened properly.

Meanwhile, Beed police found two men having the stamp of quarantine on their hands roaming outside in Bashirganj on Tuesday. According to sources, the duo were from Pune. The men have been sent to quarantine by the police.

Title: Patna University shut till March 31
Content: PATNA: Patna University (PU) on Tuesday announced closure of all its wings, including postgraduate departments, institutes and colleges, till March 31 in view of the coronavirus lockdown.PU has directed all its teachers and non-teaching staff to be available on their contact numbers given in the university’s telephone directory. Besides, the heads of departments and principals of colleges have been told to keep the phone numbers of all teachers and employees of their respective institutions so that they may be contacted if their services are needed. Faculty members, including guest teachers, have been asked to prepare academic notes, research projects and online content on different topics during the period of closure as notified by PU earlier. The duty of employees, who are engaged in essential services like health and cleanliness, will be decided by the registrar.All classes have already been suspended in PU since March 13.All varsities to remain closed: In a notification issued by additional chief secretary R K Mahajan on Tuesday, the education department announced closure of all universities and colleges in the lockdown areas of the state till March 31.

Title: Bihar govt plans to assess impact of lockdown on informal sector
Content:
PATNA: The industries department has planned to make an impact assessment of the lockdown on the informal sector of the economy as this sector is the major provider of job opportunities through self-employment in the state.

“The impact assessment will be a prelude to the most likely announcement of incentives for the people involved in the informal sector,” a highly placed source in the department said.

While CM Nitish Kumar on Monday announced incentives for the families of the poor and agricultural workers as well as pensioners, it was also felt that the impact of the lockdown on the informal sector should be assessed for the ameliorative measures to be taken in the future.

The impact assessment and announcement of ameliorative measures would also require holding discussions with the representatives of industry and trade bodies, like Bihar Chamber of Commerce and Industries and Bihar Industries Association .

While Bihar is basically a non-manufacturing state as the share of its manufacturing sector in the state’s GSDP was 8.2% in 2018-19, the volume of the informal economy is second biggest after the agriculture and allied activities (forestry and fishing) whose share in the state’s economy is 21.3%.

In tune with the same, the volume of the informal economy comprising employers as self-employed persons and workers involved is large. It includes small scale labour intensive work, like trade, repair, tailoring, food preparation, loading, shoe repairing, helper in household and roadside vendors (cheap clothes, fruits, vegetables and popular food items).

The impact of the lockdown due to coronavirus on these activities has been glaringly visible. The Maurya Lok shopping complex here wears a deserted look, and so are the sites in other localities and along all major and minor roads. The sellers of handloom clothes and tailors accompanying them have become jobless, as was visible on Beerchand Patel Marg, off the Income-Tax roundabout here.

Most of the handloom cloth dealers and tailors were from distant Darbhanga, Madhubani and Jehanabad districts. One of them, Khalid, said, “Yes, today we are jobless. Around 100 others were given licences by Patna Municipal Corporation last year, but their fate hangs in balance now.”

Shekhar, who is from Mohaddinagar in Samastipur district , had been selling fruits worth Rs 5,000 per day near the branch of State Bank of India (SBI) in Sri Krishnanagar locality, but has now been sitting idle. Tuntun Sah from Buddha Colony, who was selling fruit juice near the same bank branch, has also been left lamenting the big hit that his daily earning has suffered due to the pandemic coronavirus.

Title: Two killed in separate incidents in Sheikhpura
Content:
Representative image

BIHARSHARIF: Two persons were killed in separate incidents in Sheikhpura district on Tuesday.

In the first incident, a farmer Guntur Yadav was shot dead at Kabirpur village under Sheikhopursarai police station. Neeraj Yadav, son of the deceased, said his father had gone to his fields when miscreants shot him dead.

Sheikhpura SP Daya Shankar said prima facie old rivalry seemed to be the reason behind the crime. He said police investigation has been launched and criminals will be nabbed soon.

In another incident, a man stabbed to death his brother over some property dispute. A police officer said Jitendra Kumar was attacked with a knife by his brother at Chitaura village under Sheikhpura police station. He said the injured succumbed to his injuries on way to the hospital. He said raids were being conducted to arrest the accused.

Title: Islamic bodies ask people to offer ‘namaz’ at home
Content: PATNA: In view of the Covid-19 pandemic, several Islamic religious organizations on Tuesday urged the Muslim community not to gather at mosques for prayer services. They also advised people to offer ‘namaz’ at home.Only the ‘imam’ (one who leads the prayers), ‘muezzin’ (one who proclaims the call to prayer) and the mosque administrators will offer prayers at mosques five times a day.The Imarat-e-Shariah, a leading Islamic body which has jurisdiction over Bihar, Jharkhand and Odisha , stated that the ‘azan’ (prayer calls) would continue to be intoned from mosques and community prayer held five times a day.According to a statement signed by Imarat-e-Shariah head Maulana Wali Rahmani , arrangements should be made at mosques for enough space between two people and handshakes avoided.Meanwhile, the Bihar State Shia Waqf Board has ordered that ‘jummah’ (Friday prayers) in all Shia mosques across the state will remain suspended. Board chairman Irshad Ali Azad said all other congregations at mosques had also been banned with immediate effect. Jamaat-e-Islami Hind president Maulana Rizwan Ahmed Islahi told this newspaper that an advisory had been issued asking Muslims to offer prayers at home, instead of going to a nearby mosque.“We have asked people to follow the advisory of the health department to maintain hygiene. The Friday prayer have also been called off,” he said, adding, “Only the ‘imam’, ‘muezzin’ and administrations will offer prayers at mosques. Prayer calls will be made by the ‘imam’ five times a day.”The Islamic bodies have also instructed all ‘imams’ to ensure that the sanitization of mosques is carried out daily. In many areas of Patna, the ‘imams’ are using loudspeakers to ask people to offer prayer services in their houses.

Title: ‘Housing societies must watch people coming from abroad’
Content: PATNA: Housing societies should keep strict vigil on people coming from abroad, especially countries affected by Covid-19 , and ask them to confine themselves in their rooms for two weeks, RERA (Bihar) chairman Afzal Amanullah said.“Apartment owners association and security guards should be proactive to find out cases where people try to hide their recent travel history. Even family, friends and neighbours should come forth in identifying such people and report it to the authorities,” he said.Nodal officer for Covid-19 in Bihar, Dr Ragini Mishra, said people who have returned from other countries have already been asked to register for home isolation by calling on ‘104’. “All those returning from abroad have been told to stay in home isolation for 14-days and update us about their condition on a daily basis,” she said.Asked what to do if anyone violates the norms, Mishra said action can be taken against such people under the Bihar Epidemic Diseases, Covid-19 Regulation 2020. “Anybody who comes across people having arrived from abroad and roaming around before completing the 14-days quarantine period can file a complaint against them,” she said.Rakesh Shrivastava, secretary of a residential society on Digha-Danapur Canal Road, said a resident who returned from Saudi Arabia was spotted roaming around. “Even though he completed his 14-day quarantine in Delhi, we have asked him to stay indoors for another 14 days. Besides, proper sanitization of all the buildings in the society has been done. Elevators, stairs and corridors were also cleaned,” he said.Rajesh Mishra of Ramnagari Mor said no precautionary measure has been taken by his society’s committee members. “A student returned from China in February but no instructions were given to her by the society,” he said.Realtors, on the other hand, advised the management committees to keep a check on people coming back from abroad. Sachin Chandra , president of Bihar chapter of Builders’ Association of India (BAI), said the management committees need to be extra conscious in the wake of the global Covid-19 outbreak.Patna civil surgeon Raj Kishore Choudhary said thousands of people were reaching home. “It is not possible to keep a check on everybody. As a citizen, it is the duty of everyone to stay in isolation for 14 days and report us in case they get any symptoms,” he said.

Title: Empty roads, markets as people stay indoors
Content: PATNA: A day after people in Patna and elsewhere in the state rampantly flouted the lockdown announced by the state government to prevent spread of coronavirus , the situation improved on Tuesday with thin traffic on the roads.Very few vehicles engaged in transportation of essential commodities were seen on the streets, while the number of people in the markets in morning and evening hours also reduced significantly. Only medical shops, groceries and vegetable and fruit kiosks were allowed to remain open.Patna SSP Upendra Kumar Sharma said only a handful of people are trying to violate lockdown. Since Monday, police have collected Rs 10 lakh as fine under the amended MV Act from those people who were found hitting roads without a valid reason.Most of the major towns in the state too wore a deserted look on Tuesday following strict implementation of the lockdown.Following reports of largescale violation of lockdown orders in Gaya, the district administration issued an order banning all movement between 7pm and 6am except in case of medical emergency. Gaya DM Abhishek Singh also ordered closure of all grocery shops before 6.30pm.In Khagaria, residents thronged markets on the second consecutive day of lockdown to buy essential commodities. Khagaria DM Alok Ranjan Ghosh and SP Meenu Kumari held a meeting with foodgrain and vegetable dealers association on Monday and asked them not to hike prices of commodities.While people mostly remained indoors in Nalanda and Sheikhpura districts on Tuesday, the lockdown scene improved in Nawada too. The Nawada administration has set up five check-points in the town to scan people coming from places like Gaya, Koderma (Jharkhand), Patna, Biharsharif and Jamui. DM Yashpal Meena has opened a grievance cell and citizens have been asked to report cases of blackmarketing and over-pricing of products.In districts like Sitamarhai, Samastipur, Bhojpur and Madhepura, the lockdown was strictly enforced. People remained indoors and came out of their houses only to purchase essential commodities like groceries, vegetables or medicines. However, in Sitamarhi, police had to force some bikers to pay fines at several places. All entrance roads to Madhepura town were cordoned off by the district administration.West Champaran sealed its borders with neighbouring East Champaran, Gopalganj and Kusinagar (UP) districts. Magistrates deployed with police enforced the lockdown. In Bagaha and Ramnagar, three shopkeepers selling non-essential items like paint, battery and hardware were booked for opening their shops.(With inputs from Abdul Qadir in Gaya, N P Thakur in Khagaria, Farrukh Nadim in Biharsharif, Tirthraj Kushwaha in Bagaha, S B Sinha in Nawada, S K Singh in Sitamarhi, Praveen in Ara, D N Saha in Madhepura, Abhay Mohan Jha in Bettiah and S K Jain in Samastipur)

Title: All railway stations locked down
Content:
PATNA: The East Central Railway (ECR) on Tuesday locked down all railway stations under its jurisdiction following termination of trains which started journey before March 22.

A statement issued by ECR chief public relations officer Rajesh Kumar said no one is allowed to enter the station premises in all five divisions of the ECR – Danapur, Mughalsarai, Dhanabd, Sonepur and Samsstipur. Railway Protection Force (RPF) has been asked to apprehend the violators. Barricades have also been placed at the main entrance point of Patna Junction.

“The Ernakulam-Patna Junction Express (16359) was the last passenger train which terminated at Danapur at 9.35am on Tuesday. Altogether 3,500 passengers reached Danapur by this train, while 478 and 331 passengers got down at Buxar and Ara stations, respectively,” the CPRO said.

He added that all passengers underwent thermal screening conducted by a team of railway and state government doctors at Buxar, Ara and Danapur stations. “These passengers were later allowed to go home,” he said.

After the Railway Board announced suspension of train movement in the country on March 22, the ECR cancelled altogether 274 mail and express and 389 passenger trains running on various routes of its five divisions.

Asked about ticket refund process, the CPRO said, “Railways has simplified and made alternative arrangements for refund of tickets to passengers. Instead of visiting PRS counters at stations, people can get refunds online,” he said, adding railways has allowed passengers to take full refund of journey tickets booked till June 21.

According to the CPRO, 40,878 passengers have so far been screened at 175 different stations falling under ECR’s jurisdiction.

Title: Pune: PCMC sets up 275-bed facility in Bhosari
Content:
Residents rue rise in prices

PUNE: The civic body has set up a 275-bed facility in Bhosari to accommodate those advised home quarantine.“The facility has been set up at a welfare hostel in Bhosari. The unit would be used to accommodate those who have been advised home quarantine but cannot stay at their residence due to various reasons,” Namdev Dhake , the ruling party leader at Pimpri Chinchwad Municipal Corporation, said.“There could be some who may not have anyone to take care of them or they may not be having adequate space to practise self-isolation. The facility would cater to the needs of such people,” Dhake said.Dhake said that the new unit would be in addition to the existing facility at New Bhosari, YCM Hospital and the proposed 500-bed unit at Balewadi Sports Complex. The civic body has asked private hospitals in twin towns to set aside 50 beds for isolation at their facilities, Dhake said.“Besides, a 100-bed isolation facility would be set up at the Jijamata hospital in Pimpri,” Dhake said.The civic officials said as many as 1,160 people have been sent to mandatory 14-day home quarantine in Pimpri Chinchwad. The corporation is mulling extending the time period by an additional two weeks. The area did not record any new positive case for the fourth consecutive day.Residents across twin towns complained of an increase in vegetable prices at the local neighbourhood stores.“The shopowners tell us that inconsistent supply is responsible for increased prices. The vegetable prices have almost doubled over the past week. The government should advise people against panic buying, otherwise there would be utter chaos soon,” Prachi Surve, a resident of Pimple Saudagar , said.

Title: As Delhi retreats indoors to remain safe, helps face up to harsh reality
Content:
Those who stepped out were mostly on foot going to the nearest grocery store

NEW DELHI: Having realised that the janata curfew was just a trailer and the lockdown could now last for days, people on Tuesday seemed to be falling in line. Unlike Monday, few people ventured out on Tuesday. Even within gated colonies and housing societies, streets were rather empty. The morning walk at the neighbourhood park or taking the dog out for a walk were, however, activities that could not be postponed or sacrificed, it seemed.

Not everyone agrees with people’s reluctance to give up that walk for catching the early morning air. Bhavreen Kandhari, a resident of Defence Colony, expressed his concern. “We have a WhatsApp group for the colony and people had all sorts of excuses to go out to the park and exercise. When there is a pandemic raging, people need to stay indoors as much as possible and not go out for something that is not essential,” he said.

Many RWAs are themselves enforcing the curfew, keeping gates locked and asking people not to step out unless it’s urgent. In several parts of the city, RWAs have stopped the entry of outsiders, including domestic helps and car cleaners. Those who were stepping out said they were going only to the nearest grocery store. “My baby is just three months old and even though we have stocked up quite a few things, there are a few more that we need. We don’t know what the situation is going to be in the coming days and I cannot take a risk with my child,” said Sahil Malik, a resident of Hari Nagar.

At cooperative societies in Dwarka, RWAs said they had coordinated with the district magistrate to get passes issued for essential services workers like guards and plumbers for each society. “Some people with dogs did step out during the morning, but most people have complied. No maids are being allowed now and these passes once issued will make the entry of essential services workers much easier,” said Sudha Sinha, president, Federation of CGHS, Dwarka.

RWAs at Janakpuri have asked people to allow their domestic helps to stay at home. “They were all paid their salaries and told about the safety measures they should adopt at home. One of the residents in the colony has recently returned from Toronto and has been quarantined at his house along with his family. Even though he tested negative, we want to make sure that everyone here stays safe,” said Bhavneet, a member of the C Block RWA.

“My employer has declared work from home for all employees. It has now dawned on me that my maid too needs to be at her place just as we are at ours. We decided to pay her salary and asked her to stay at home,” said Vishal Banga, a resident of Janakpuri. An elderly resident of Rajouri Garden, Brijender, said they had advised all domestic helps to come at their own risk and asked their employers to pay their salaries and explain to them why social distancing was important.

While the domestic helps do appreciate the concern and gesture of their employers, they have other worries. “I have been working at a colony for the past 10 years and have been paid regularly too but we have to pay rent for the one-room house we live in and I am sure that our landlord will not let us stay if we don’t pay up. If I spend less on other necessities, I will be able to pay the rent this month, but I just hope that this problem does not last long because otherwise it will become a major crisis for people like me,” said Shakuntala. Another maid, Usha, said that she and her daughters have paid their dues but she fears that if the crisis gets prolonged, they will not be able to stay afloat.

Meanwhile, people are getting used to their new situation. For 28-year-old Romi Bhatia, this is the time for bonding with her husband as they are both working from home. “I have been working from home for the past three days and my husband for the past two days. We got married recently and couldn’t even go for our honeymoon since the situation started deteriorating suddenly. Even though this is a terrible reason for being confined to our homes, I’d like to look at this positively and take it as a chance to spend time together. Now that the maids have also been advised to not come to work, we will also be doing the cleaning together,” she said.

Title: Telangana: DSP, cook test positive for coronavirus
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: Bhadradri Kothagudem deputy superintendent of police (DSP), whose London-returned son tested positive for Covid-19 recently, has tested positive for the infection. The DSP’s cook also tested positive, while his wife and two Home Guards, who were in contact with the patient, have tested negative. The police officer have been quarantined.

On Monday, Kothagudem police registered a case against the DSP and his son, who returned from London via Dubai on March 18, for hiding his son’s travel histroy and violation of home quarantine rule, after the latter tested positive for coronavirus. After the DSP’s son tested positive, health officials carried out contact tracing and zeroed in on the people whom he came in contact and started the isolation process.

Earlier, Bhadradri Kothagudem superintendent of police Sunil Dutt had said that among those who have been isolated, the DSP’s wife and two home guards tested negative for the coronavirus. The SP had also said that four others, including his relatives and staff working for DSP, are still in isolation as their results are yet to come.

Meanwhile, Abbayya, inspector of Aswaraopet in Bhadradri Kothagudem district, was transferred on Monday and attached to the district police headquarters for hosting a dinner for several people in the town, violating the restrictions over mass gathering of people and social distancing.

Title: Health experts ask Patnaites to follow healthy lifestyle
Content: PATNA: As people continue to stay at home on Day 2 of the coronavirus lockdown in the state, health experts advise them to follow a healthy lifestyle and practise mental health exercises. They urge people with depression and anxiety to take extra care at a time when a lot of misinformation is being circulated on the social media.Associate professor and nodal officer of the de-addiction centre at the Nalanda Medical College and Hospital (NMCH), Santosh Kumar, told this newspaper that people should try maintaining a routine amid the lockdown.“Staying at home for a long time can get monotonous, but adopting unhealthy practices during this time can have a long-term impact. People, especially young adults, should ensure that they stay active, do exercises and do not disturb their sleep cycle in order to remain physically and mentally fit,” Kumar says.He adds, “Instead of using their cellphones and watching TV continuously, people should do something productive like reading their favourite books, cleaning their wardrobes, cooking or sketching. Those suffering from mental illnesses should stay in touch with their specialists.”City-based clinical psychologist Dr Binda Singh shuns those, who spread fake news on social media. She says, “A lot of people tend to believe everything that is shared online. That leads to anxiety among them.”She, therefore, asks everyone to use social media only to stay connected with their friends and relatives, “instead of sharing irrelevant and fake news about Covid-19”.Meanwhile, some Patnaites claim that they are going through a tough time these days. “I am in my house for more than five days now. I have severe headache every time I check my cellphone, which is loaded with unnecessary messages related to Covid-19,” says Radhika Sinha (35), a resident of Kadamkuan Jagdeo Path resident Sumit Singh (23) says the feeling of being isolated is enough to make him anxious. “My sleeping and eating habits have changed because of which I am not able to concentrate on anything. I feel constantly burdened,” he adds.

Title: Hospitals ‘deny’ treatment to Rohtas youth with Covid-19 symptoms
Content: PATNA: The family members of a 22-year-old youth, who returned from Pune on Monday, have alleged that their son has been refused treatment despite showing symptoms related to Covid-19 virus. Pune, where he works at a cement factory, was placed under lockdown by the Maharashtra government recently.The family from Darihat in Rohtas district is running from pillar-to-post for his treatment. The youth’s father, Awadhesh Singh, said his son, Sikandar, fell sick soon after he returned home from Pune on Monday. “We took him to a private hospital at Dehri-on-Sone from where he was referred to the government sub-divisional hospital after his condition deteriorated on Tuesday,” he added.The victim’s family had to persuade the staff at the sub-divisional hospital to get him admitted for treatment. “But as soon as the para-medical staff got to know about Sikandar having symptoms of coronavirus , they asked us to shift him to Narayan Medical College and Hospital at Jamuar near Sasaram in Rohtas district for better treatment,” he said.Shockingly, Sikandar was denied admission there and reportedly asked by the staff on duty to take him to home. “My repeated pleas to get him admitted fell on deaf ears at the Narayan Medical College and Hospital,” said his brother Shailendra, who had accompanied him.Seeing no hope, they brought him back home after taking advise from a local private medical practitioner.“I contacted government officials right from the sub-divisional level to the state headquarters but to no avail. Even the Rohtas district magistrate as well as the SDO of Dehri-on-Sone didn’t take notice of my repeated request,” said the hapless father.When contacted, Rohtas civil surgeon Dr Janardan Sharma said, “As soon as the matter came to my knowledge, I directed officials of Narayan Medical College and Hospital to get the patient admitted. I am not getting connected to the family to convey this message.”The PRO of Narayan Medical College and Hospital, Surendra Singh, however, denied the charge levelled by the victim’s relative. “We have created an isolation ward of 25 beds to provide treatment to patients with coronavirus symptoms,” he said, adding, six samples were sent to RMRI in Patna for test. Earlier, the test reports of two suspected patients were found to be negative.The ordeal of the family, however, didn’t end there. A police officer deputed at the Dehri town police station intercepted the vehicle carrying the patient for treatment. “He (cop) was asking for money to allow the vehicle to move on the road as there was lockdown in the entire state,” lamented Shailendra, who had returned from Pune with Sikandar on Monday.Both brothers left Pune for home on March 21 after senior officials of the factory in which they worked told them about the lockdown and closure of the factory for indefinite period. “We will contact you once the situation normalises,” Shailendra quoted the factory officials as saying.The journey from Pune to Dehri-on-Sone in Rohtas was not an easy task. “We alighted from the train at Mughalsarai (now Dindayal Upadhyay) railway station from where we caught another train to reach Dehri-on-Sone. As there was lockdown, we had to pay a hefty sum to the auto-rickshaw driver to reach home,” Shailendra added.

Title: 12 teams to keep check on hoarding by traders: Chief secretary
Content: PATNA: The state administration has devised a two-way policy to ensure supply of essential consumer goods to the people during lockdown Chief secretary Deepak Kumar said while 12 teams have been set up in Patna to keep a vigil on the people trying to hoard the food material, the officials of the department concerned will also be in touch with traders to ensure regular supply of the food stuff.Kumar, however, said there would be no shortage of food material anywhere in the state. Instructions have already been issued not to stop trucks carrying foodgrains and other eatables. Some relaxations have been made in the existing laws for the purpose, he told reporters after a review meeting.“All the food supply/distribution units will remain open. There will be no impact of lockdown on these units as they have been exempted from its preview,” the CS said, and warned the hoarders of stern action.The government would also initiate adequate measures to keep the prices of essential commodities under control. A senior officer posted with the state food and consumer protection department said an eight-page order with regard to supply of essential commodities has already been issued.The officer said though section 7 of the Essential Commodities Act 1955 dealt with action against hoarding of commodities, the approval of senior officials was required before taking any action against any trader. The copy of the order issued on March 21 was sent to all the divisional commissioners, district magistrates and the superintendents of police.Meanwhile, the Vaishali district administration has set up a special cell to deal with the coronavirus complaints in the district. Altogether six passengers, who reached from coronavirus-affected countries, were quarantined at their homes.20 held for violating lockdown: The police on Tuesday lodged 38 FIRs and arrested 20 persons for violating lockdown across the state on Tuesday, ADG (headquarters) Jitendra Kumar told TOI over phone. “Altogether 1046 vehicles were seized and Rs18.5 lakh was collected as fine from them for violation of MV Act in order to enforce lockdown sternly across all districts,” he said, adding that the lockdown was more effective on Tuesday.

Title: Here's what actor Chetan Kumar is doing in shut down
Content: Recently hitched, actor Chetan Kumar has been posting cute pictures of his married life. And, the actor did not shy away from sharing a rather cute video of him spending his time at home amidst lockdown. "Rocking the quarantine life... Courtesy: wifey #quarantinelife #corona #quarantineandchill #stayhome #staysafe" posted the actor with a video of him chopping vegetables. The cute video did bring a smile on everyone's face. How cute do you think it was?

Title: Delhi: Working tirelessly, just so that you can keep going
Content: NEW DELHI: Ever since the capital has been locked down to curb the spread of Covid-19, there are people who have been working tirelessly to keep the essential services operational. However, providing healthcare, food, transport and sanitation facilities in the time of corona has not been an easy task for these frontline heroes.“Most of us are doing our job without wearing masks and gloves. Officials may claim to have provided such equipment, but we are yet to get these facilities. There is so much pressure of sweeping roads and completing other sanitation work that we hardly have time to think about these things,” said Rajendra Mewati of United Front of Municipal Corporations of Delhi Employees.Chhoturam, a sanitation worker, travels almost 10km to work from his Trilokpuri residence. “I pick up garbage in the morning and then work in the sanitary department. Some residents refuse to even come downstairs to hand over their garbage bags,” he said.Saurabh Gupta, a ration dealer running a fair price shop in south Delhi, does not have the luxury of social distancing because he provides subsidised ration to poor. He has kept a sanitiser bottle outside his shop to ensure beneficiaries clean their hands before approaching the counter. “I try to maintain a distance of one meter, but when the illiterate beneficiaries require support in making a thumb impression, I have to get closer to them,” said Gupta.“I wear a mask and keep sanitiser at my shop. But getting vegetables from the nearby Okhla Mandi is a risky affair as a large number of vendors gather there,” said Arun Kumar, who runs a vegetable shop at C-Block Market, East of Kailash.Kumar’s daughter Ankita, 18, is a student of first year BA (Hons) Hindi. She said that even the customers have been advising them to use masks and sanitisers. “I had to submit assignments in April, but that got postponed owing to the situation. Now, I can’t even borrow books from the college library,” she added.Delhi Transport Corporation is providing much-needed transportation to those involved in essential services, but its own drivers, conductors and other staff are facing a problem in reaching the bus depots. “Most of us reach depots on personal vehicles and are stopped several times en route. Those coming from NCR face major problems,” a DTC employee said .“We’ve made contingency provisions of boarding and lodging for the field-level employees at our various sub-station buildings,” said a BSES official.Northern Railways said that their staff were being stopped at several locations owing to confusion over whether railway operations were still functional. “Police and administration officials may not be aware that while all passenger-carrying train services have been stopped, the railways continues to bring essential goods through freight trains,” said a senior northern railways official.

Title: Pune: Court to hear pre-arrest bail pleas of Girivan project directors on March 27
Content:
Representative image.

PUNE: A sessions court on Tuesday posted for March 27 the hearing of the pre-arrest bail pleas of Jayant Mhalgi (63) and his wife, Sujata (58), the two directors of Sujata Farms Private Limited, in the alleged Rs 96.99 lakh cheating case related to a plot scheme at Girivan hill station project in Mulshi taluka near the city.

Additional public prosecutor P S Agarwal told TOI, “The matter came up before additional sessions judge S N Sonawane, but the court had to put off the same for March 27 for want of the Paud police’s report on the pleas. Also, a written submission is expected from the lawyer of the original complainant who joined the matter today.”

Lawyer Suchit Mundada , representing the Mhalgis, told TOI, “We have made a request to the court to issue directions to the police against taking any coercive action against the applicants till the matter is heard.” However, prosecutor Agarwal said the court did not pass any directions on it.

The Paud police recently booked Mhalgi and his wife, Sujata, managing director and director of Sujata Farms Private Limited which floated the Girivan project at Dongargaon and Hotale villages 30 years ago, following an FIR by Kothrud resident Jayant Bahirat (57) alleging that they had cheated him and 14 other investors in the plot scheme.

Noted actor Vikram Gokhale, who has been named in the FIR as chairman of the company, has been granted interim bail by the court and his pre-arrest bail plea is scheduled for a hearing on March 31.

The complainant has alleged that the three company office-bearers misrepresented the scheme as “government recognised” and misused the goodwill as well as their relationship with late former MP Rambhau Mhalgi to lure investors. He further alleged that after collecting money, the firm failed to get the plots demarcated by the state land measurement officials.

In their plea, the Mhalgis have contended that they have not committed any crime as alleged and the company being a co-owner of the remaining plots in the scheme, had objected to land measurement. They stated that the firm never claimed the project as being `government recognised’ and the FIR itself describes the project as a private hill station. Moreover, sale deeds have been executed between the firm and the complainant and other investors, their names have been entered in the mutation entries and appear in the 7/12 extracts as owners.

They stated that the complainant and other investors have obtained actual possession of land, have developed it and were enjoying the properties.

The government had issued notifications in 2009 and 2016 restraining illegal process of land measurement and still the complainant and others got the land measured, they stated.

A civil suit is also pending related to the matter, they said and added the entire case is based on documentary records and no custodial interrogation was required.

Title: Gujarat: Workers forced to walk back to native in Rajasthan; owners gave them Rs 500 & asked them to go home
Content:
Sabarkantha police offering food to the labourers in Himmatnagar

PALANPUR: Thousands of labourers working in Ahmedabad have been forced to walk back to their natives in Rajasthan after their employers shut down their establishments in wake of the state-wide lock down.

Labourers carrying their belongings as well as children were seen going by foot on the highway in Sabarkantha district on Wednesday. Many of them arrived in Idar, Himmatnagar and Prantij on Wednesday afternoon, totally exhausted due to blistering heat.

“I was working in Ranip area of Ahmedabad and my employer asked me to leave. He gave me bus fare, but all public transport is closed so we were forced to walk back to our villages,” said Tejabhai, a labourer from Rajasthan.

The families found it hard to find food and water as all highway hotels are shut due to prohibitory orders. Most of them them having received a paltry Rs 500 as compensation from their employers.

However, they found help from Sabarkantha police who distributed food to them.

“I have assure these labourers that some help will be provided in the form of transport to reach their villages in far away Sirohi, Udaipur or Dungarpur in Rajasthan” said Chaitanya Mandlik, superintendent of police, Sabarkantha.

Mandlik said, “We provided them with food, biscuits and water in cotton bags. These labourers have taken an uncalculated and grim risk but they have no option.”

The labourers have been asked to walk in a group of four as prohibitory orders ban assembly of more than four people. Heavy vehicles going towards Rajasthan will be asked to give transport them home, said Mandlik.

Title: Cops illegally shut down non-veg shops, bakeries
Content:
Even chief minister Uddhav Thackeray had made it clear that shops selling all types of eatables, including tho... Read More

Nagpur: Nagpur police, which is doing a good job of enforcing curfew in the city, has, however, gone into an overdrive by not allowing meat, poultry and fish shops, bakeries , etc to remain open. As a result, these items are not available in the city since the last few days.

Talking to TOI, home minister Anil Deshmukh said that he did not issue any such order. Even chief minister Uddhav Thackeray had made it clear that shops selling all types of eatables, including those selling meat and fish, will be allowed to remain open. Deputy resident collector Ravindra Khazanchi also said that no order was issued to close these shops. “Any shop selling eatables can remain open,” he said.

Police officials, however, said that they had not received any orders from the district collector to allow these shops to operate.

“We have been told to allow only grocery, medicine, fruit and vegetable shops to function. If we receive the order from the collector, we will allow meat and fish shops, bakeries, etc to remain open,” said a police officer.

Clearly it is a case of miscommunication between the two departments due to which Nagpurians are suffering.

Activist Anil Wadpalliwar slammed the officers of the two departments for the mess. “Many people are advised by doctors to have non-vegetarian food for their health. The cops are damaging the health of such people. Even otherwise when the CM has allowed non-vegetarian item shops to remain open, who are the local police officers to order them to close down? Same is the case with bakeries. Why should people be deprived of bakery items when the government has not banned them,” he said.

Tauby Bhagwaghar, who runs a chain of bakery shops, said that the cops were interpreting the order in their own way. “I read in the newspapers that all factories manufacturing food products are to be allowed to function. However, cops came to my factory in Civil Lines on Tuesday morning and harassed me for making bread. They refused to listen to my contention that bread is a food item. Similarly, our outlets are not allowed to function, which is depriving people of bread,” she told TOI.

Revti Patil, a resident of Bajaj Nagar, slammed the cops for restricting the sale of eatables. “Why do the cops want us to eat only dal chawal? Bread is a staple item for breakfast for many people but they are not getting it. Similarly, many people cook non-vegetarian items at home frequently. Why should they not eat meat and fish due to the wrong interpretation of orders by cops. The police commissioner should immediately instruct the field officers to not go overboard,” she said.

Title: 16 on police radar for ostracizing 30-year-old man in Pune
Content:
Representative Image

PUNE: The Baramati city police on Monday booked 16 people — trustees and office-bearers of a Madrasa — for ostracizing a 30-year-old man from the community after he raised his voice against fudged account statistics and illegal constructions on the premises of the facility.

A member of the Madrasa, the man lives at Bhigwan-Baramati Road and runs a photocopy shop in his village.

The FIR stated, the man came across a few incidents of corruption in the accounts of the Madrassa in December 2019. He brought it to the notice of trustees and other office bearers of Madrassa, but to no avail.

The man urged Madrassa office bearers to demolish an illegal wall which had been constructed a few months ago without seeking permission from Baramati municipal council and other authorities, police said.

Then the man approached government authorities with his complaint against the trustees and office bearers for constructing the wall illegally and sought to have the Madrasa’s account examined, police said.

The trustees and office bearers were not happy with the move and called a meeting in February. The the meeting was attended by the 16 trustees and office bearers of the Madrassa. They then decided to ostracize the man from the local community. The man was upset and approached the trustees but they did not listen to his plea. As the community members stopped talking to the man and inviting him to social gatherings he decided to approach police.

Title: Pune: Couple booked on charge of harassment
Content:
Representative Image

PUNE: A Kharabwadi resident and his wife were booked on Monday on the charge of harassing the man’s mother and ejecting her from the house.

The woman (60) lodged a complaint against her son and his wife with the Chakan police on Sunday, following which the duo were booked under the relevant sections of the IPC and Maintenance of Parents and Senior Citizens Act.

“The woman said her son and daughter-in-law had been harassing the entire family since 2004. The duo used to beat up and verbally abuse the mother and her spouse,” an officer from the Chakan police said.

The woman alleged that her son threw her out of the house with her other son and his family a few days back. “The woman also alleged that the duo seized documents related to her property,” the officer said.

“The woman said she does not have any shelter and the duo are not allowing her in the house. We are yet to make the arrests,” the officer added.

Title: Bhopal: Will fight corona together, says CM Shivraj Singh Chouhan
Content: BHOPAL: Madhya Pradesh government has released two toll-free numbers 104 and 181 for the public to get immediate help or share information about the coronavirus . Chief minister Shivraj Singh Chouhan in his appeal to the public said that curfew imposed in affected cities of Madhya Pradesh will be strictly followed.“I appeal to the public to put maximum effort to do away with the coronavirus crisis in the country and Madhya Pradesh. Curfew has been imposed in Bhopal and Jabalpur in view of the severity of the coronavirus; and lockdown has been declared in 36 cities by the district administration ,” said Chouhan on Tuesday.The chief minister further said, “In case of any problem, people can dial toll-free helpline numbers 104 and 181 to contact concerned authorities for assistance. We will provide all possible help and would jointly fight against the coronavirus. But, I humbly appeal to the public not to come out of their homes and follow the instructions issued by the administration to save precious lives.”Chouhan also said that arrangements have been made to ensure proper supply of essential commodities and medicines to the public. He said instructions have been issued to the district administration to immediately provide help and take necessary precautionary measures to prevent the infection.“The only way to prevent coronavirus is to break its link. The state government is fully capable of dealing with this worldwide crisis through public cooperation. Completely follow the administration's lockdown orders. Do not get out of homes unnecessarily. All necessary services for public convenience have been exempted from this,” he reiterated.The chief minister also held discussions with the district authorities through video conferencing on Tuesday. He said public safety is his priority.

Title: Youth arrested for stalking 15-year-old girl in Pune
Content:
Representative Image

PUNE: The Yerawada police on Tuesday arrested a college student (22) for stalking and harassing a 15-year-old girl for over a year.

The police said the suspect first got friendly with the girl and then started stalking her while she was studying in a city-based school.

He would call her on her cellphone. He even proposed to her saying he would marry her after she was 18 years, an officer said.

Senior inspector Yunus Shaikh of the Yerawada police said, “The girl’s father shifted her to a school in the neighbouring Satara district, but the suspect managed to trace her and continued stalking and harassing her.”

Shaikh said the girl’s father took a call to lodge an FIR on Tuesday after the suspect continued to call the girl.

“We have arrested the suspect on charges of stalking, criminal intimidation and sexual harassment, under the relevant sections of the Indian Penal Code and Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act,” he said.

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme Court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

Title: Coronavirus Delhi News: How ‘isolated’ homes in Delhi are being sanitised
Content: NEW DELHI: The three municipal corporations in Delhi have made separate arrangements for the collection and disposal of household waste from houses that have been marked for self-isolation and quarantine by the district administration.Sanitation workers have also been provided with personal protection kits and the garbage is being taken out in twin-layered yellow sealed packs washed with sodium hypochloride solution. Moreover, this waste is not being mixed with other garbage from the locality.A senior South Delhi Municipal Corporation (SDMC) official said that one auto-tipper has been dedicated for this purpose in each zone. “The sanitation staff in protective suits will also be disinfecting the houses using sodium hypochlorite solution,” he added.Central Pollution Control Board had issued detailed guidelines about the handling, treatment and disposal of waste generated from such homes last Wednesday. The municipal bodies have been getting repeated reminders about their implementation.SDMC commissioner Gyanesh Bharti had chaired a high-level meeting with senior officials of all departments to monitor the situation. “The officials concerned have been asked to provide the list of homes where people are quarantined to the concessionaire for making the route plan for covering them. The collection has started,” the official said.After collection, the waste will be transported to the waste-to-energy plant at Okhla and incinerated. “There will be no human contact. The sealed packs will be burnt directly without being processed, treated or segregated,” said an SDMC official.Bharti said that personal protection kits, which include sodium hypochlorite solution, liquid soap and gloves, have been provided to the concessionaire for distribution to staff engaged in garbage collection. Apart from this, knapsack sprayers have been given for spraying 1% sodium hypochlorite solution for sanitising the domestic hazardous waste before receiving for final disposal.A team comprising the assistant commissioner, medical officer, nodal officer, district surveillance officer, district health officer, concessionaire, executive engineer and the sanitation department representative has been created for coordination and updating the list of quarantined households daily.An East Delhi Municipal Corporation official said there are over 1,000 such households across Delhi and approximately two tonnes of waste is being generated by them. “These people are not patients. We should not stigmatise them,” the official added.

Title: Exchange of fire between cops, ATM thieves; 5 held
Content:
Representative image

ALWAR: Police arrested a gang of five ATM thieves in Alwar district’s Kishangarhbas police station area on Tuesday. They were arrested after an exchange of fire between the cops and gang members. Two accused also sustained bullet injuries.

The injured were identified as Rahul Palla, the gang leader, and his accomplice Farooq, who was referred to Jaipur in a serious condition.

“The gang was involved in several theft cases. A day before the arrest, they had broken into two ATMs in Kairthal police station area. We received information that the accused were hiding in Chawandikala village and immediately a team was sent there,” said a police officer.

After finding the accused in a field in the village, cops surrounded them. The accused then started firing at the cops who also retaliated.

Police recovered three countrymade weapons, eight live cartridges, three ATMs and a pickup vehicle. All the accused had extensive criminal history and were also involved in petrol pump loot, firing at police constable and 15 other cases registered at various police stations.

“We are questioning the accused and will provide more details about their crimes which might have not have come to light. While Farooq has been shifted to Jaipur, Rahul is undergoing treatment locally. Till they are hospitalised, we will interrogate the other three who were arrested,” added the officer. A case under relevant IPC sections was registered against the arrested persons.

Title: No shows hit ‘Tamasha’ mandals & artistes hard in Pune's rural areas
Content:
There are about 350 Tamasha mandals in Maharashtra.

PUNE: Tamasha mandals in the rural areas of Pune are staring at huge losses in view of the Covid-19 spread, which has forced the district administration and panchayats to cancel annual fairs (Yatras) and events drawing large crowds.

Tamasha is a traditional form of Marathi theatre that involves singing and dancing. There are about 350 Tamasha mandals in the state, with each employing about 100 artistes, including women, from humble background.

The period between March and May is considered crucial money-making phase for Tamasha mandals every year. As per the tradition, the mandals set up their pandals at Narayangaon for fixing dates of their shows. However, much to the chagrin of the mandals, they are not getting any orders this time around due to the Covid-19 scare.

Avishkar Mule, the president of Akhil Bharatiya Marathi Tamasha Patishad , Maharashtra , told TOI, “The situation is not conducive in villages as many of them have cancelled our shows. We are not sure how to look after our people and get returns on money invested in buying new equipment before the beginning of the season. The state government should help us financially. Otherwise, many of our workers or artistes will be jobless in the coming days.”

Mule estimated the total loss to be around Rs 20 crore this year. “Many mandals don’t know how to pay their artists when no shows are being held. These workers and artistes completely rely on the shows for livelihood,” he said.

He said maximum districts in the state had suffered from drought last year, which hit the mandals hard. “Besides, we couldn’t get contracts due to restrictions imposed during the general elections on our shows. Because of this, it has become a question of survival for many of us now,” Mule said.

On an average, Tamasha artistes earn around Rs 2 lakh per annum each.

Senior artists Raghuvir Khedkar , who has been running a Tamasha mandal over three decades, said, “Many smalls mandals will shut down in the coming months, rendering thousands of Tamasha artistes jobless. Since they are completely dependent on shows to make their ends meet, what will they do for survival.”

Khedkar said people were asking the mandal for refund as shows were being cancelled.

Title: Aurangabad: City police register 45 offences so far for violating lockdown guidelines
Content:
Representative image.

AURANGABAD: Police across the eight districts of Marathwada resorted to force in order to send people, flouting the norms, back to their homes.

Scores of videos have gone viral on the social media showing policemen from Aurangabad , Jalna, Beed, Parbhani, Nanded, Latur, Osmanabad and Hingoli canning people on the road.

Initially, senior police officers did not pay any heed to these videos saying these videos would act as deterrent to those stepping out of homes for no reason, but later in the evening, instructions were passed to not record such videos as it may boomerang and fuel public sentiment against the administration and police.

Later during the day, authorities from different districts — through a series of communications — reiterated that curfew would continue to remain in place and except for essential services all the business would remain closed.

The authorities also appealed to the people to stay indoors unless in emergency situations. Aurangabad district collector Uday Choudhary said the administration is going all-out to prevent the spreading of this disease.

“People should understand that the outbreak of this disease would result into mass casualty. For us every life is precious and the orders are aimed at preventing the disaster from happening,” he said.

In Aurangabad city, 24 offences were registered by police against autorickshaw drivers and shop owners on Monday. Along with the 21 cases registered on Tuesday, the total has risen to 45.

With imposition of ban on sale and supply of country-made as well as foreign liquor, the number of cases involving local smuggling of liquor has also registered a surge.

Aurangabad commissioner of police Chiranjeev Prasad said, “Our ultimate aim is safety of the commoners. We are on the road so that unwanted people remain indoors.”

Police have also started helpline numbers so that in case of doubt or any emergency, people can get assistance without stepping out

Aurangabad rural superintendent of police Mokshada Patil informed that they have started a dedicated helpline number +91-7768932222 for the commoners to contact them for any assistance during the lockdown period.

She also said that even social media accounts of Aurangabad rural police are open for assisting the commoners. Beed district police led by Harssh Poddar on Tuesday registered 14 offences against those caught violating the curfew.

Beed police appointed a nodal officer and have appealed people to get in touch with him on +91-9921070690 for getting any emergency permission during the lockdown period.

Authorities informed that all district borders from across the region have been sealed for all vehicles except those catering to essential services. However, in case of emergency situation, relaxation may be granted by the administration. Osmanabad SP Raj Tilak Roushan informed that they registered 16 offences in their district for against those violating the lockdown orders.

Title: People rush to native places
Content: Even as the state government has sealed borders of all districts to contain the spread of coronavirus , people, who are settled in cities, are making all possible efforts to reach their native places, putting pressure on rural health infrastructure.While the government has suspended services of state transport buses and railways, people are resorting to alternate modes of transport to reach their villages. Though vehicles are stopped on Mumbai-Bengaluru and Mumbai-Hyderabad national highways at entry points of respective roads, people are seen using alternate roads, giving slip to the administration.Around 10,000 people are said to have arrived in Solapur city on the day when the state government proclaimed curfew.

Title: Two friends travel 700km on bike to reach home in Wardha
Content:
The youths were stranded at their respective locations in Pune and Jalna as transport services came to a halt

Nagpur: After spending days in isolation without proper food and water, two youths from Vidarbha took a leap of faith by riding around 700 kilometres on a two-wheeler to reach home in Wardha. Since the whole state is currently under lockdown, the youths were stranded at their respective locations in Pune and Jalna as the bus and trains services were at halt.

Two friends — Anurag and Pratik--- hailed from Wardha and were working at different companies in Pune and Jalna. They went through several hiccups along the way including being stopped by cops but in the end managed to reach home.

Speaking to TOI, Anurag, who works in Pune, stated he was living as a paying guest and all of his roommates had left for their home. “I wanted to come home too, but my seniors told me to wait till Monday. However, since Sunday all transportation was closed, including buses and trains, and I was left alone. In initial days, I was ordering food online but after Janata Curfew on Sunday, I went without proper food. I had bought some fruits which were the only things I had left to eat. Finally I decided to ride home on bike,” he said.

“Initially I was worried as there were reports that district borders are closed for private vehicles too but I had no choice as I wanted to go home. So, I contacted my friend Pratik who was also stranded in a hotel in Jalna since last few days and we decided to ride all the way to Wardha,” he added.

Anurag left his PG accommodation in Pune on Monday at around 12pm for Jalna where Pratik was waiting for him.

“I had come to Jalna on Saturday for some company work, but as soon as I reached most shops closed down. I was staying in a hotel but there was no room service. I was dependent on outside food but all restaurants too closed down. I was only eating biscuits and chips for three days, so I decided to ride along with Anurag,” said Pratik.

Anurag reached Jalna on Monday at around 8pm where he rested for the night at the same hotel where Pratik was. The duo started their journey towards Wardha early Tuesday morning.

“We crossed several police check posts but were not stopped until Karanja where they asked us to go back to Jalna. We explained to them we need to go home as we don’t have any place to stay at Jalna. Finally the police let us go. We reached Wardha on Tuesday around 4pm,” said Pratik.

“It was a journey of a lifetime as we travelled from so many places and went through hiccups to reach our home,” added Pratik.

Title: After Prime Minister address, Bhopalis spill out to stock up
Content:
BHOPAL: Soon after the lockdown was announced by the Prime Minister, Bhopalis came out in large numbers to stock up on the essentials.

Ever since the ‘janata curfew’ was announced, people have been on a buying-spree — which has led to exhausted stocks in supermarkets and grocery shops. This rush has also led to black marketing of essential goods. Worse still, it has also led to to crowding in front of super markets and grocery shops , defeating the very purpose of lockdown in the city.

At a supermarket at Mandakini colony of Kolar, over 200 people had gathered following PM’s Tuesday’s address. The super stores have already stopped selling anything else other than food.

Prices of fruits and vegetables have shot up during the lockdown period. Tomatoes, which were selling for Rs 15 a kilo till a few days ago, disappeared from the market on Tuesday.

To allay the fears of people, patrolling cops began announcing in the evening that grocery shops and those selling essential goods will be open during lockdown.

Title: Plan availability of pvt hosps: Patil
Content: Guardian Minister Satej Patil , in a review meeting at the district collectorate on Tuesday, instructed the administration officials to plan availability of private hospitals and ventilators in the district. He asked the officials to map the travellers from Pune and Mumbai coming to villages.“Preference should be given to cleanliness and regular supply of drinking water. Apart from the travellers from Pune and Mumbai, the ones having foreign travel history, too, should be mapped. Private hospitals should be kept ready and the available ventilators can be shifted together too should be checked,” he said.Rural development minister Hasan Mushrif, district collector Daulat Desai, MP Sanjay Mandlik, Kolhapur Municipal Corporation commissioner Mallinath Kalshetti, superintendent of police Abhinav Deshmukh, among others, were present for the meeting.District collector Daulat Desai said that via Gram Samiti for rural areas and Prabhag Samiti for urban areas, a check on travellers’ information can be implemented.
