IGIMS microbiology head Dr S Shahi said seven samples were collected and tested on Tuesday and their results were awaited. He said they have got one kit as of now and at least 200 tests can be done from that.

Title: Techies adapt to work from home
Content: Thiruvananthapuram: On a normal day, around 60,000 IT professionals reach Technopark . On the first day of lockdown , around 98% of techies opted for work from home and thus became part of the efforts to check the spread of Covid-19 . Though the state government has included IT sector as an essential service and exempted them from lockdown, IT firms and employees decided to work from home to break the chain of the novel coronavirus, which has infected over 100 in the state so far.IT parks CEO Sasi P M said that only around 950 IT professionals turned up at Technopark and Kollam campuses on Tuesday.“Infopark campuses at Kochi and Koratty saw 750 IT professionals while the Cybercity Kozhikode had an attendance of only 15,” he said.Sasi said that only persons who had to perform critical works came to the office on Tuesday. He said that companies were prepared in advance and that helped them manage the situation. “When the issue of Covid-19 was developing, I had sent a letter to CEOs of all companies to device business continuity plans and arrange more work-from-home options. Companies were ready to face the lockdown situation. There were measures to address shortage of laptops,” he said.One of the major IT firms, UST Global has provided work from home option to majority of its employees. Chief operating officer of UST Global Alexander Varghese said that the steps were taken considering the safety of employees. “UST Global continues to monitor the Covid-19 situation very closely, utilizing the guidance of government, international and local health authorities. Given the sharp spread of the virus in various locations, our top priority is the health and safety of our employees and we are taking all precautionary measures to reduce their risk of exposure. We have more than 90% of our employees working from home while continuing to operate productively across several locations,” he said.“In order to ensure that our employees are well informed, we are providing regular updates on coronavirus and precautionary measures, and assisting in the physical and mental well being of our employees through various online programs. We have set up toll-free numbers and email id for UST Global employees to contact the Covid-19 helpdesk,” said Varghese, who is also the chairman of Group of Technology Companies.Rajeev Krishnan, executive member of Pratidhwani, a socio-cultural organization of Technopark, said that only some business process outsourcing firms operated from Technopark and that too with skeletal staff.“Some firms procured laptops on rent, while some allowed employees to take desktop to home,” he said.

Title: 47-year-old in isolation dies in Patan
Content:
Palanpur: A 47-year-old man, who was under treatment as suspected COVID-19 patient, died at Dharpur Medical College in Patan on Tuesday.

However, his samples have been sent to BJ Medical College in Ahmedabad for tests and the report is awaited.

In-charge chief district health officer (CDHO) Dr Bharat Goswami said that the man was admitted with complaint of breathlessness and cough on Monday. “He had been to Mumbai a couple of weeks ago where he had met some people. He has no history of foreign travel,” said Goswami, adding that we are tracing the people the deceased had met before coming to Patan.

Title: Shaheen Bagh News: How Delhi cops end 100-day Shaheen Bagh protest
Content:
Police said a dozen people were detained from Shaheen Bagh for violating prohibitory orders

NEW DELHI: The colourful tent that once was a symbol of “resistance” against the Citizenship Amendment Act was dismantled on Tuesday, 100 days after it was set up. As police personnel cleared the Shaheen Bagh protest site due to Covid-19 outbreak, the women said it was a “pause” not a defeat.

“Shaheen Bagh has become a thought process. It isn’t a neighbourhood anymore. The protest will continue. We will first fight novel coronavirus and then come back to defeat hateful and divisive politics,” said Hena Ahmad.

On December 15, shaken by images of violence against Jamia Millia Islamia students, a group of women had taken over the streets, determined to raise their voices for the country’s children and to register their protest against Citizenship (Amendment) Act, NRC and NPR. They sat through the harshest Delhi winters, didn’t budge when it rained and remained undaunted despite the risk to their safety when a man opened fire. Over the days, the canopy under which hundreds of women sat, changed colours, speeches from the makeshift stage became more measured and public address systems became more sophisticated. But the aim of the protest remained same — “to fight for the Constitution”.

Ahmad said that police officers removed everything within an hour. “They gave a clarion call in the beginning that they were following orders to impose curfew conditions. But there were just five people sitting under the tent then. We were following the rules,” she said.

Although the eviction led to disappointment, it was soon replaced by new-found stamina by the first-time protesters, who resolved to continue the protest on social media till the health crisis got over. “We will win the fight against novel coronavirus and against CAA, NPR, NRC too,” said Ritu Kaushik, at the forefront of the resistance.

In the weeks since the gravity of Covid-19’s spread was realised, protesters at Shaheeen Bagh had discussed whether to call it off or continue on low-key — following all directives. “Shaheen Bagh’s stature was such that if the protest was held in abeyance, perhaps, just perhaps, police would not have dared touch the tent,” said Shaheen Kauser, a mature voice whose firm reasoning had brought many disparate views together over the last three months.

Many said that no matter whatever precautions are taken, “all the blame will be heaped on Shaheen Bagh”. In the last few days, just five women at a time were present at the tent, wearing masks and carrying sanitisers.

“What the Shaheen Bagh protest has become in 100 days was beyond imagination when we started. Similarly, the threat of Covid-19 is beyond imagination. Our constitutional fight will continue, but we always held that in such a healthcare crisis, we stand with all and heed all directives. We have been doing that. I am very sad today. There was no need to remove the tent. The women were following all precautions,” said Kauser.

“Police took advantage of the protesters paying heed to the fight against coronavirus and forced eviction,” said one of the protesters, while discussing on social media plans to ramp up the fight online till the lockdown is over.

Kaushik said, “Delhi Police came to the spot at a time when the case of the road was still in Supreme Court. They removed not just the tent, but the library, posters, everything. It was evident that the government was not only fighting Covid-19 but also the Shaheen Bagh protest.”

Title: NDMC keeps tab on state guesthouses
Content:
Representative image

NEW DELHI: After hotels and restaurants, New Delhi Municipal Council (NDMC) has started checking arrangements at state guesthouses to stop the spread of infection by novel coronavirus in addition to verifying details of guests.

It is also sensitising staff at MPs, judges and bureaucrats’ bungalows and servant quarters about coronavirus. An NDMC official informed that all precautionary measures are taken from their side and staff is regularly submitting action taken report to senior officials. “Though footfall has decreased in state guesthouses, to be on the safe side, two teams are checking these areas and contacting RWAs,” said the official.

On Delhi government’s direction, civic agencies have set up a facility to quarantine suspected Covid-19 cases at Bakkarwala, Kalkaji, Malka Ganj and east Delhi areas.

The NDMC on Monday sanitised its newly constructed complex at Bakkarwala for quarantine. “The complex has around 240 flats and was constructed for economically weaker families living jhuggi clusters,” said an official from NDMC health department. The department had earlier dedicated six isolated beds for keeping infected patients at Charak Palika Hospital in addition to reserving four ambulances for carrying such patients.

The South Delhi Municipal Corporation has developed a similar facility at Purnima Sethi Hospital and North Delhi Municipal Corporation at Hindu Rao.

In east Delhi, Municipal Corporation has converted the private ward at Swami Dayanand Hospital for infected cases.

Title: Feed stray animals too, says AWBI
Content:
Kochi: The Animal Welfare Board of India has asked the state to ensure feed for all animals , including strays .

The board recommended the state to direct the district administrations to allot specific time slots in the morning and evening to allow individuals or volunteers to provide food and water to street animals and birds.

“This is a valuable service consistently provided by compassionate individuals. The absence of it may cause many animals and birds to suffer and die, and the carcasses may further spread different diseases,” AWBI director Dr O P Chaudhary, said in the communication.

The AWBI also sought a directive to authorities concerned to create awareness among the public to take care of stray animals during the Covid-19-triggered lockdown.

“The law enforcement authorities may also be directed to see that animals and birds do not suffer,” the communication said.

Veterinary as essential service

The ministry of fisheries, animal husbandry and dairying, meanwhile, said it was necessary to ensure continuous emergency services in the animal husbandry and veterinary sector.

It also demanded the inclusion of veterinary services in the list of ‘essential services’.

Animal husbandry department officials said all veterinary clinics would function from 10am to 2pm.

“We are disappointed that the state is not treating veterinary in the essential services category. There are several dairy and poultry farmers, needing veterinary support,” said M N Jayachandran, member, state animal welfare board.

Title: Govt lays out protocol for handling corona suspects
Content: Amaravati: The state government has directed district collectors to follow protocol while handling suspected Covid-19 cases reported under their respective jurisdictions. Instead of hurriedly rushing the patient to the hospital or summoning him, the government has asked collectors to constitute nine special teams in each cluster to handle emergencies. The emphasis will be on keeping suspected cases in home isolation and exercising caution while handling positive cases.All patients who have so far tested positive for Covid-19 have come forward and admitted themselves to hospital and undergone screening. However, the government has issued detailed guidelines to handle suspected cases in order to effectively contain the spread of the virus. All teams, except the rapid action team, will work simultaneously and take decisions.Of the nine teams, team 1 will be the public addressing team headed by a PRO/senior official of a local body. The team will visit the area where a suspected case of Covid-19 is reported and start announcement through public addressing system asking residents not to venture out.Team 2 will comprise police personnel. It will impose traffic restrictions in the area by setting up barricades.Team 3 will be headed by the administration secretary of the ward/village panchayat secretariat. The team will closely coordinate with the field team and get reports from the field on an hourly basis.Team 4 will be headed by a medical officer. It will also have staff from the health department, make rounds of an area and segregate risk and high-risk zones. It will also conduct door-to-door surveys to identify high risk patients in the area where a suspected Covid-19 case is detected.Team 5 comprises sanitation workers and officials and will operate depending on the feedback provided by the medical team and undertake cleaning operations.Team 6 will include police, tax and labour authorities which will visit a area and close down commercial establishments.The isolation team is team 7 and will be prepared with an ambulance to shift the patient to a designated hospital. Two ambulances will be part of the team.Team 8 comprises doctors who will visit the residences of those with overseas travel history and displaying Covid-19 symptoms such as fever, cold and cough, and collect samples. The team will keep suspects in isolation till the test report is received.Team 9 is the rapid action team comprising a doctor and nurses who will visit the residence of a Covid-19 positive patient.

Title: Health workers stigmatised for working in isolation wards
Content:
Medical shops use ropes to distance customers in Bhopal on Tuesday

New Delhi: In his address to the nation on Tuesday, Prime Minister Narendra Modi once again lauded the work of health workers out in the trenches battling coronavirus. Yet in certain parts of the country, these soldiers of humanity are facing social stigma. Fresh reports from Kerala, Bengal and Karnataka highlight cases of discrimination against them.

Union health Minister Dr Harsh Vardhan too acknowledged the problem posting a tweet on Tuesday evening. “I’m DEEPLY ANGUISHED to see reports pouring in from Delhi, Noida, Warangal, Chennai etc that DOCTORS & PARAMEDICS are being ostracised in residential complexes & societies. Landlords are threatening to evict them fearing #COVID2019 infection. Pls don’t panic!”

In Kerala, three young male nurses, who had voluntarily opted for duty at the isolation wards for Covid-19 patients in the Government Medical College Hospital, Kottayam, had to leave their rented accommodation after the landlord voiced his concern. More shock lay in store. None in the locality were ready to rent out their homes as they were associated with the Covid-19 patients.

“We had voluntarily come forward for this duty. We have been extending all support to the state government in its fight against this disease. But there is nobody with us. We are in a helpless situation,” a nurse said. Following the intervention of collector P K Sudheer Babu, the hospital superintendent agreed to allot an unused quarter on the campus on March 13 for two weeks. The quarter was handed over to them four days ago. “We don’t know when might be asked to move out from this temporary home,” wondered one of the nurses. In Kolkata, it was a similar story for some nurses attached with hospitals where Covid-19 patients are either getting treated or have died. They too were asked to vacate their rooms by their landlords.

A male nurse who shared a flat in Salt Lake with two other colleagues faced problems when the neighbours came to know of the death of a 57-year-old Covid-19 patient. Another nurse from the Infectious Diseases and Beliaghata General Hospital, the apex hospital for Covid-19 in the state, was asked to leave her rented apartment. A government doctor from the Murshidabad Medical College and Hospital (MMCH) was thrown out of his rented accommodation in Behrampore by the landlord on Monday.

In Karnataka, three private medical colleges in Devanahalli, who had joined hands with the state government to provide quarantine facilities to suspected Covid-19 patients, are facing an acute shortage of housekeeping staff. Reason: Fellow villagers come do not want the health care staff to work in the quarantines. Those who do are barred from coming back home. “We have about 100 housekeeping staff to maintain a 400 bed hospital. Since the time we started admitting senior citizens returning from Covid-19 affected countries in quarantine, the housekeeping staff have stopped coming. They come from the neighbouring villages. We are working with just four members to clean the hospital,” said the spokesperson of a private college near the city.

It’s a different story in Jharkhand and Bihar. Health workers in Jharkhand haven’t faced any kind of ostracisation. Instead they are being appreciated for their hard work. Doctors and nurses working at major government as well as leading private hospitals said that they are being applauded for their work from common people.

“I stay in a rented accommodation in Bariatu with my family and visit RIMS daily but neither my landlord nor the neighbors have raised any objections due to my profession. On the other hand, they always inquire me on the situation on COVID-19 and ask me about the preventive measures,” said a senior surgeon with RIMS.

IMA Bihar member Dr Harihar Dixit said he had not heard of any instance of doctors or nurses being ostracized in the state. Dr Neeraj Agarwal, posted at community medicine branch in AIIMS-Patna, gave a similar reply.

(Inputs from Kottayam, Kolkata, Patna, Ranchi and Bengaluru)

Title: Apartment bldg introduces toothpick system in lift
Content:
UPLIFTING MOVE: Orchard Apartment at Arya Samaj Road in Mangaluru has drawn inspiration from an apartment in V... Read More

Mangaluru: Inspired by an apartment in Vietnam , Orchard Apartment at Arya Samaj Road in Mangaluru has introduced the “toothpick system” for lift buttons to curb the spread of Covid-19 .

“Drawing inspiration from several videos that we received on various social media platforms, and a report that stated that an apartment in Vietnam has introduced the toothpick system in lifts, we have placed a thermocol board inside the lift, on which toothpicks have been placed for single use, to press the lift buttons. A plastic bottle to dispose of the toothpicks, and sealing the lift button with cling foil has been undertaken,” stated the Orchard Apartment Owners Association.

In addition, the apartment has issued several guidelines to curb the spread of Covid-19. A washbasin has been placed at the entrance, making it mandatory for all to wash their hands before entering the apartment. The entrance has been restricted to one door only so that everyone adheres to the guidelines. The association stated, “Delivery partners have to report to the security counter only.”

Some of the guidelines include restricting only four passengers at a time in the lift and encouraging people to use the staircase without touching the railings, if possible. Residents will have to collect their parcels themselves from the security counter, and have been requested to avoid inviting guests’ home. Residents have been asked to strictly avoid conduct any civil work or work on the interiors of their apartments, or any sort of renovation involving labourers, until further notice. No labourer will be allowed inside the building to carry out any kind of work, except the electrician and plumber who do routine maintenance works of the building. No shifting of any kind of household items are permitted where labourers are involved. However, if there is an unavoidable circumstance, for shifting of an item, the building manager has to be contacted, who in turn will make suitable arrangements.

Residents have been asked to relieve their domestic help and housekeeping staff, and to segregate and dispose of waste at the designated area. The 16-floor building has 92 apartments.

Elevators are considered as a high-risk place for the spread of viral diseases as they are in a confined space where buttons are pressed with bare fingers numerous times a day.

Title: Confusion prevails on first day of lockdown, police register 402 cases
Content:
Thiruvananthapuram: Confusion over the term ‘essential goods’ prevailed widely on the first day of state-wide lockdown, with many trying to find loopholes and police trying to enforce the lockdown order. On day one, police registered 402 cases across the state for violations, with Thiruvananthapuram city leading the chart with 121 cases. As many as 47 cases were registered in Ernakulam city.

In the capital and many other parts of the state, people came out citing purchase of essential goods , while several shops opened for customers including roadside tea shops, citing that they are selling essential goods like fruits and milk.

Though state police chief Loknath Behera came out with clarifications about the instructions laid out in the order, the ambiguity over which shop would be categorized as those selling essential goods and which are not, prevailed in many places.

However, he clearly said that the use of autos and taxis will be limited only for procurement of essential goods. "There are several instructions laid out in the order including social distancing, opening of certain shops alone. There are several exceptions also. But use of taxis and auto for procuring essential goods or medical requirements alone can be permitted as said in the order," he said.

Behera said that police will issue passes for those who are working in the essential category, which will permit them to go to their respective work places. "For exempted category, we are issuing a pass which is not required for media persons and government servants. Objective is to reduce the possibility of transmission (of Covid-19)," he said. The passes will be issued by all the district police chiefs in their respective districts.The police have also introduced a condition that those using their own vehicles for going out will have to give a declaration. "We are issuing another order, using private vehicle, coming out of the house has to give a declaration that I am going out on such a specific purpose. We will verify it, and if it is found false, there will be action against them," he said.

Later in the day, the state police chief asked all the police officials across the state to come out in the public to strictly enforce the lockdown that has been declared by the state government. He also said that no public should come out in the public without any specific purpose, violating which strict action will be taken against them.

Title: Daily wagers on brink of unemployment
Content:
Visakhapatnam: The coronavirus outbreak has added insult to injury for daily wage labourers, especially construction workers, in the Port City, who have been recovering from the aftershocks of sand crisis.

Around three lakh daily wage labourers are on the brink of unemployment following most businesses being shut down and construction work being suspended as precautionary measure against Covid-19.

There are allegations that GVMC staff have been closing down shops, including eateries, as against the higher officials’ instruction to only shut shopping malls and multiplexes. Moreover rumours have only compounded the problem.

A large section of the three lakh daily wagers are from neighbouring districts of Srikakulam and Vizianagaram. Many of them stay at Allipuram, Jnanapuram, Thatichetlapalem, Kailasapuram, Isukathota, Venkojipalem, Arilova, Chinnagadili, Thotagaruvu, Madhurawada, Akkayyapalem and One Town areas.

But since the coronavirus positive case was reported in the city, people are hesitating commissioning work.

“My employer told me that till March 31, there will be no work as the virus threat is looming large. We came from Palasa in Srikakulam district to Vizag for livelihood eight years ago. We can survive if we do not have work for one or two days, beyond that we will not manage,” said a construction worker K Ramunaidu of Isukathota area said.

Men usually earn Rs 400 to Rs 450, while women get Rs 300 to Rs 350 per day. “Although there is no instruction to suspend construction work, we have decided not to take risks. So we will slow down our work till March 31,” a builder, on condition of anonymity, said.

Speaking to TOI, district joint collector Venugopala Reddy told TOI that there are no instruction to close small shops and eateries. “We are urging people to minimise their routine travel and practice social distancing as part of precautionary measures against COVID 19,” he said.

Title: Chennai: Patients receiving live-saving treatments in a fix
Content:
Representative image

CHENNAI: Thousands of patients in Chennai, who visit hospitals periodically for life-saving treatments, are in a fix as all public transport options will be shut from Tuesday evening.

This included treatments like dialysis for kidney patients, chemotherapy and radiotherapy for cancer patients.

These are patients, who need not be hospitalised for a longer period, but face the risk of losing their lives if they miss out a single session. Even if some patients can afford to get admitted for long, not all hospitals have enough beds to accommodate them.

There are around 50,000 dialysis patients in Chennai and many depend on autos, buses and taxis.

“Not sure if hospitals are equipped to pick up and drop patients at their doorsteps. Also, 108 service can be availed only during emergencies. So they should be exempted and allowed to engage private taxis or autos,” said Rajan Ravichandran, director of MIOT Hospital, Manapakkam. The government can set up a helpline for these patients so that transport can be arranged on request, he said.

Some patients travel from suburban areas to hospitals in city because of the demand, quality and their personal conditions. For instance, those with hepatitis B, C or other viral infections can only visit hospitals which have specialised kits.

These patients can neither opt for nearby hospitals as an alternate option temporarily, nor can they be treated at home. as the procedure is still not popular in Indian cities.

R Saraswathy, an elderly woman from Valasaravakkam who visits a private hospital in Vadapalani at least twice a week, said she is more scared to step out after watching videos of police forcefully dispersing those coming out.

“We request the government to sensitize police not to stop vehicles transporting patients,” said Latha Kumaraswami, managing trustee of Tanker Foundation, which runs three centres in Chennai in association with Greater Chennai Corporation .

Not only these centres, but many other hospitals have provided authorisation letters to their patients explaining their condition and need to reach hospitals without delay. This might help them in convincing the police at checking points and district borders.

A dialysis session takes four hours and costs somewhere between Rs.1,500-2,500. Since demand is high, patients can’t afford to miss their slots. So any delay en route to hospital will put their lives at risk.

“Until now, patients have reached on time. Wednesday will be a litmus test. We have deployed vans for staffs without own vehicles and increased their travel assistances. Because their safety is also equally important,” Latha added.

Title: Ostracised by society RWA: Crew member
Content:
NEW DELHI: Days after Air India had stated that its cabin crew was being ostracised by RWAs for flying abroad and being involved in rescue operations of those stranded in other countries, an IndiGo crew member alleged that people in her locality were not allowing her to stay, while her family member, too, was facing humiliation.

In a video that went viral on the social media on Tuesday, the IndiGo crew said she and her mother were being harassed by the RWA and even groceries were not being provided to them, in the fear of her spreading the novel coronavirus.

“My job requires that I be there for duty, and my company is taking complete precautions for me to be safe from Covid-19,” the crew member said in the video. “When I’m not at home, they (RWA members) come and harass my mother. She cannot go to the market to buy groceries, because people are telling her that ‘your daughter has corona and you might also have it’,” she said.

IndiGo, in a statement on Monday, said: “...there are some instances when our employees have been ostracised from their communities as a result of their line of duty and travel history... Please support our operating colleagues in such a difficult time."

Title: Indians stranded in Malaysia find food, shelter
Content:
Visakhapatnam: Although a number of Indians who were stranded in Kuala Lumpur arrived in India on Monday, nearly 300 Indians, including 70 people from Andhra Pradesh and Telangana, are still stranded in Malaysia .

No flights have been operating from Malaysia to India from March 17 due to travel restrictions to contain the spread of Covid-19. Meanwhile, Indians stranded there approached the Indian High Commission for help. While they were awaiting help, a few NGOs came to their rescue.

In order to ensure that those from the Telugu states find accommodation until a special flight can be arranged for them, Praveen Prakash, principal secretary to the chief minister made a representation to the ministry of external affairs and to the Indian High Commission in Malaysia.

“Please assist students and professionals to come back to their native places in Andhra Pradesh as they have been asked by university authorities to vacate hostels. Until they are brought back, arrangements must be made for their stay,” the principal secretary said in his letter.

When TOI contacted those stranded on Tuesday, they said all of them have been given accommodation.

Kantha Rao, president of Telugu Foundation of Malaysia said, “Officials of the Indian embassy contacted us to help the people stranded in the airport. We have been providing shelter, food and transport for the last three days.”

Title: DSP, cook test positive for virus
Content: Hyderabad: Bhadradri Kothagudem deputy superintendent of police (DSP), whose London-returned son tested positive for Covid-19 recently, has tested positive for the infection. The DSP’s cook also tested positive, while his wife and two Home Guards, who were in contact with the patient, have tested negative. The police officer have been quarantined.On Monday, Kothagudem police registered a case against the DSP and his son, who returned from London via Dubai on March 18, for hiding his son’s travel histroy and violation of home quarantine rule, after the latter tested positive for coronavirus . After the DSP’s son tested positive, health officials carried out contact tracing and zeroed in on the people whom he came in contact and started the isolation process.Earlier, Bhadradri Kothagudem superintendent of police Sunil Dutt had said that among those who have been isolated, the DSP’s wife and two home guards tested negative for the coronavirus. The SP had also said that four others, including his relatives and staff working for DSP, are still in isolation as their results are yet to come.Meanwhile, Abbayya, inspector of Aswaraopet in Bhadradri Kothagudem district, was transferred on Monday and attached to the district police headquarters for hosting a dinner for several people in the town, violating the restrictions over mass gathering of people and social distancing.

Title: Shaheen Bagh: Lawyers say viral fight priority
Content:
Shaheen Bagh protest site was cleared by Delhi Police on March 24

NEW DELHI: The Supreme Court-appointed mediators, who had urged the anti-Citizenship (Amendment) Act protesters at Shaheen Bagh to move to an alternate site, said the country was facing a “grave pandemic”, which was a matter of everyone’s priority.

Reacting to the clearance of the protest site on Tuesday morning, lawyers Sanjay Hegde and Sadhana Ramachandran pointed out that while some rigours of the blockade were relaxed by the protesters by clearing peripheral roads, the remaining few Shaheen Bagh protesters were finally dispersed “peacefully with minimal force”.

Owing to the communal riots in northeast Delhi, the apex court had adjourned a plea to shift the Shaheen Bagh protest to an alternative site to March 23. Following their first round of dialogue, the mediators had submitted their report in the court in February. During the second round of dialogue on March 3, they praised the protesters for maintaining peace and calm despite tensions surrounding other parts of the city.

The lawyers, on Tuesday, requested people not to perceive the clearance as a question of “winning or losing” while urging both the administration and the protesters to not do anything that could aggravate the situation. “The country has a grave pandemic threatening it and currently that must receive priority in terms of everyone’s attention,” the interlocutors said. They also requested the administration and the protesters to not do anything that would “exacerbate the underlying tensions that culminated in the street protests”.

According to the mediators, the process of interlocution had reinforced a number of valuable lessons, including the need for continued dialogue at all times. “We believe that the Supreme Court mandated interlocution kept the protests at Shaheen Bagh peaceful even while violence erupted in other parts of Delhi,” they added.

The interlocutors have, until now, submitted two reports to the SC detailing their efforts and the situation prevailing in the area. They have also held several dialogue sessions with the protesters following the direction from the apex court.

In all their meetings, the lawyers urged the protesters to find an amicable solution and lauded them for carrying out peaceful protests. They had, however, raised concerns over public inconvenience. During one such dialogue, they told the crowd that “Shaheen Bagh barkarar rahega” (Shaheen Bagh will survive) but it was necessary to ensure that others were not inconvenienced. “Nobody should be troubled. We live in this country to help one another and not trouble each other” they had said.

Title: Other anti-CAA protest sites in Delhi also removed
Content:
As the cops were getting the Shaheen Bagh site vacated, action was also taken to clear the other sites at Jami... Read More

NEW DELHI: Delhi Police vacated all the anti-Citizenship Amendment Act sites , including the one at Shaheen Bagh in south-east Delhi, where protests have been going on for over 100 days. On Tuesday, as police enforced the lockdown announced to check the spread of Covid-19, they also cleared these places. At Shaheen Bagh, some people were detained for violating prohibitory orders despite being warned against it.

The cops moved in with cranes to remove the temporary structures erected by the protesters in these places. The massive tents under which the sit-ins were held were dismantled in Shaheen Bagh, Seelampur, Hauz Rani and other areas. Police had earlier requested the protesters at these sites to disperse to avoid infection by the novel coronavirus.

At Shaheen Bagh, police officers arrived with paramilitary personnel at 6:45am, having asked the protesters late on Monday to vacate the site on the road to Kalindi Kunj. The officers once again directed the protesters to move out of the area. However, some protesters were reluctant to give up, and a few tried to push away the cops. This forced police to detain nine people, including six women, for violating Section 144 CrPC banning assembly of more than five persons.

Eight trucks and two trailers, hydraulics and cranes each were pressed into service to clear the site, helped by around 300 labourers. The hydraulic cranes dismantled the tents and removed the other structures from the protest site. The materials and structures removed will now become case properties.

RP Meena, DCP (South-East), disclosed, “We have been requesting the protesters for some time now to leave the site to prevent the spread of the coronavirus and due to the lockdown. At this time the movement of essential goods and services is crucial and this road is an important stretch connecting Noida with various parts of Delhi.”

As the cops were getting the Shaheen Bagh site vacated, action was also taken to clear the other sites at Jamia Millia Islamia, Turkman Gate, Hauz Rani, Sadar Eidgah, Bara Hindu Rao, Inderlok, Seelampur and Nizamuddin. At most of these places, there was little resistance from the locals. In fact, the eviction drive on Tuesday was supported by the locals of all the affected areas.

While clearing the Seelampur protest site, 17 people, including five women, were taken in, while a lone woman was detained at Inderlok and released later.

Soon after, police approached the civic bodies to re-construct the damaged portions of the roads where the protest sites were located. At Shaheen Bagh, DCP Meena said, “We have requested the municipal corporation and PWD to assess the damage and fix the road.”

At Jamia, the cops removed the nails dug in the road and dismantled the tents and banners put up on the road. Some labourers were later seen whitewashing the walls that had graffiti painted by the protesters.

Title: Covid-19 cases cross 100, nurse tests positive
Content: THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: The number of Covid-19 cases in the state has crossed 100. On Tuesday, 14 more positive cases were reported. With this, 105 patients are undergoing treatment in various hospitals in the state for the viral infection.A medical worker involved in prevention activities was among those who tested positive on Tuesday. The nurse, who was working in Kottayam district, is the first health worker to contract the disease.Chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan said of the 14 persons who tested positive on Tuesday, eight had travelled from Dubai. Three fell sick after coming in contact with Dubai returnees. One person had flown in from Qatar and another from the UK.The CM said that, so far, there is no threat of community spread but several people who had come in direct contact with Dubai returnees have tested positive. He called for special caution in Kasaragod.Of Tuesday’s new cases, six are in Kasaragod, two in Kozhikode and one each in Thiruvananthapuram, Alappuzha , Kottayam, Palakkad, Ernakulam and Malappuram.At present 72,460 people are under observation in the state. Of these, 467 are admitted in the designated isolation wards of various hospitals. Of the 4,516 samples sent for testing, 3,331 have returned negative. The remaining results are awaited.The CM announced more restrictions as part of the lockdown in the state. He said no private vehicles will be allowed on the roads, unless in case of emergencies. Even so, occupants will have to furnish details of purpose and place they want to visit to police. People defying police directives will be arrested, Vijayan said.He said shops -- and only those -- supplying essential commodities will remain open from 7am to 5pm. More than five people will not be allowed to assemble in any area.On restrictions in Kasaragod, the CM said he had interacted with local MLAs, who have been asked to contact local-body heads under their constituencies for a list of people who need food and other support. They have also been directed to find out the number of elderly living alone. Local bodies have been directed to provide food and medicines to such people.

Title: ‘Life near normal despite testing positive’
Content: Thrissur: “I am leaving the hospital happily realizing that I had not been the cause of infection to anyone. All those who had come in contact with me have been tested negative.” These were the words of a 21-year-old Covid-19 positive patient who was discharged on Tuesday evening after he was tested negative for two consecutive times.He had come from Qatar on the same flight which had brought the Covid-19 patients of Ranni in Pathanamthitta on February 29. He was in the isolation ward of the general hospital in Thrissur since March 8, when the passengers hailing from Pathanamthitta were tested positive.He was also later tested positive.Talking to the TOI over the phone just before leaving the hospital, he said he has been asked to continue home quarantine for 28 more days.He said life was near normal even after being tested positive for Covid-19.Even though he has been tested positive he had not developed any other complications.“I was taking normal food and was able to sleep well, there was no temperature. I had some stomach pain and diarrhoea in the initial days, but I don’t have any problems now,” he said.“I was getting excellent support from all sections, including doctors, nurses, staff, from the DMO office, and I am thankful to all of them,” he added.From Cochin airport, he went to his home in Kodungallur. However, he was contacted by health officials soon after the patients from Ranni were tested positive on March 8. He was then brought to the general hospital and was put under hospital quarantine. He had gone to a mall and had also attended a marriage engagement in between.“I was not at all aware that I have been infected, and that is why I was moving around freely,” he said.What troubled him the most was that numerous fake news about him was being circulated when reports about him testing positive came into the public domain. “I was not able to deny those reports. That is why I decided to post a video on my condition on social media. Also, I wanted to send out a message of relief to people,” he said.

Title: Junior docs asked to vacate hostels
Content: Visakhapatnam: In view to control the spread of Covid-19 , the district administration and authorities of medical colleges have asked junior doctors in the state to vacate their hostels The hostels will be converted into quarantine centres, to be used if the need arises. Andhra Medical College ( AMC ), Vizag has planned a quarantine centre with a nearly 200-bed capacity in the old block of the UG men’s hostel.Representatives of AP Junior Doctors Association (APJUDA) have expressed apprehensions about the lack of alternative accommodation in some medical colleges. They have also pointed to the difficulty of getting rented rooms under the present scenario.A house surgeon at a medical college has written to the district collector expressing fear at staying alongside persons in quarantine.Principal of AMC, Dr P V Sudhakar, clarified, “KGH-AMC house surgeons or internees can stay in the rooms in the new block of undergraduate hostel and make the old block available to the district administration to use as quarantine centre if required.”“Some UG students have locked their rooms in the old block and left. They have been asked to vacate these rooms, otherwise the locks would be broken. The quarantine centre will have nearly 200 rooms, with a single person in one room though washrooms have to be shared just like in other quarantine camps across India. The house surgeons can stay at the new hostel block, which has a separate entrance and will have no connection with the quarantine centre,” added the principal.

Title: Some Shaheen Bagh locals say thank you with roses and garlands
Content:
Delhi Police clearing Shaheen Bagh protest site

NEW DELHI: Many people living in and around Shaheen Bagh came out on the road on Tuesday to thank Delhi Police for clearing road number 13A where the protests against the National Register of Citizens were going on since December 15, 2019. Many of them offered roses to police personnel and even garlanded the area deputy commissioner of police (DCP).

Mohammad Riyaz, president of the Shaheen Bagh residents ’ welfare association, said, “I am grateful to police for clearing the road. In these times of the novel coronavirus scare, it was an important step. Even if one person was infected, it could have spread and worsened the situation. In these tough times, we need to be together to fight this out.”

As police officers, including DCP R P Meena and area assistant commissioner of police Jagdish Yadav, went into inner lanes, many residents came forward to thank them.

Most residents said they were supportive of the police move as the road was vital in connecting the rest of the national capital region to Delhi and other states. Even essential items can be supplied to several bordering cities and states through this route now, one of them said.

Tanvir Jahan, a social worker and a resident of Shaheen Bagh, said, “We were only worried whether the protesters could be removed easily, especially after the recent violence in northeast Delhi. But it went on smoothly and no one showed any resistance.”

The flowers and garlands were given to the policemen as a mark of respect and to show them that local residents were grateful that the site was vacated peacefully, he added. “We’ve had sleepless nights fearing if anything would go wrong. The rising scare of the virus only added to our worries,” he added.

Title: 14 quarantined for contact with Nellai Covid-19 patient
Content: MADURAI: Fourteen people who had come in contact with the 43-year-old male Covid-19 positive patient undergoing treatment at the isolation ward in Tirunelveli Government Medical College Hospital (MCH), have been quarantined, district officials said on Tuesday. “We identified 14 persons, including staff and those at the hotel where the patient had been staying. They have been quarantined. We are doing our best to not miss out on anyone who may have been in contact,” said a health official.The official added that the patient was stable and responding well to treatment. On Monday, it came to light that the patient had not given accurate information to health officials about his location prompting district officials to probe his whereabouts and movement before admission to the hospital.Meanwhile, a two-year-old girl with travel history to Kerala was admitted to the isolation ward at Kanyakumari Medical College Hospital on suspicion of having Covid-19 symptoms on Tuesday. Her samples have been sent to the Tirunelveli MCH for testing.Two other suspected Covid-19 cases - a 60-year-old woman and a 26-year-old man - are in the hospital. On Tuesday, the samples of the 60-year-old woman sent for testing returned negative, while the test result for the 26-year-old man is expected on Wednesday.

Title: Medical college hosps implement 3-tier working system for doctors
Content:
Thiruvananthapuram: Amid increasing work stress and more Covid-19 cases being reported in Kerala, a three-tier working system was implemented at all government medical college hospitals, where most of the Covid-19 positive cases are admitted, to avoid putting all doctors at risk.

A Covid-committee was constituted in all government medical college hospitals, which split doctors from each department into three teams. From Monday onwards, each medical college is functioning with two teams of doctors, while the third team is ready on standby mode.

The first team –comprising doctors from all departments – are working on Covid-19 cases and isolation wards. The second team is attending cases in OP and emergency departments. Meanwhile, the third team will be at home on leave and will swing into action only if need arises.

"When the first team, attending Covid-19 cases, completes one full week of work, they are sent home. This team will again report for duty (Covid) only after two weeks. This will help them maintain a quarantine time of one week at home. The functioning of the teams has been fixed on a rotation basis," said state secretary of Kerala Government Medical College Teachers Association (KGMCTA) Dr Nirmal Bhaskar.

When the first team goes home, the second team will take over Covid-19 duty and the third, which was the standby team, will take over the mantle of other emergency departments.

The present three-tier duty system is helpful since the entire team of doctors will not be put under risk.

KGMCTA has been asking medical education department to put doctors on rotation duty ever since Covid-19 was reported in state.

Apart from this, for the one week duty, three shifts have also been put in place so that one team is not put under strain.

"This is the best practice that can be adopted. This would lessen the burden for the doctors and prevent the risks involved," said state secretary of Kerala Government Medical Officers Association Dr G S Vijayakrishnan.

However, doctors are of the opinion that this rotation system will not work if at all there is a community outbreak and there is an increase in the number of patients.

At present, this system works since each hospital is having a limited number of cases. When there are more patients, all doctors will have to be pressed into service.

Title: 100 among 3,800 foreign returnees showing Covid-19 symptoms: Odisha
Content: Bhubaneswar: The state government on Tuesday projected that at least 2,345 people in Odisha would suffer from Covid-19 by May 31. This, they said, was the best possible scenario.The government’s Covid-19 spokesperson, Subroto Bagchi, said the number might increase up to over 36,000 Covid-19 positive patients in the state. The figure for the country was projected to be at least 58,000 people and a maximum of 10 lakh, Bagchi added.The spokesperson said 3,861 foreign returnees had registered on the 104 helpline and the government portal. Of them, around 100 have shown symptoms of coronavirus. “The government is monitoring their condition,” he said.Bagchi said 45 people — both foreign returnees and their close contacts — were in hospital isolation. The other foreign returnees and their close contacts are in home quarantine.The number of confirmed Covid-19 patients in the state remains two. Their condition is stable.Chief minister Naveen Patnaik announced launch of a new programme — ‘Mo Jeebana (My Life)’ — in which people were encouraged to swear in the name of their family that they would not step out of home. In an emotional appeal, he said, “In the last 20 years, whatever requests I have made, you have responded positively to them. The request I am making today is the most important of all. Do swear in the name of your family not to venture out. If it is urgent, ensure 20 seconds hand-washing on return. Make a video of your pledge and share the same in social media,” he said.Bagchi also asked people to take the lockdown seriously, saying it would be impossible to manage the situation if there was a spurt in corona patients. “In India, there are an average of 70 hospital beds per one lakh population,” he said.During the lockdown, patients needing emergency treatment, healthcare professionals and those involved in essential services can move around. The government will curb all non-essential travel. To ensure compliance with the lockdown, the government has stopped all construction works across the state and closed all parks and non-essential commercial establishments. Banks, fuel filling stations, milk booths, groceries, fruits and vegetable outlets would remain open, Bagchi said.

Title: Long queues persist even after HC order
Content:
Kochi: Almost three years after HC asked Bevco ( Beverages Corporation ) to take steps and avoid long queues in front of its outlets, customers stand within ‘sneezing distance’ of each other even today.

This is happening when administration has issued prohibitory orders under Section 144 to curb the spread of Covid-19. A research by Massachusetts Institute of Technology found that coughing spreads droplets up to 6m, while for sneezing it is 8m and they stay suspended in air for 10 minutes.

In the judgment (WP-C No. 12881/2017) delivered by justice Devan Ramachandran on July 5, 2017, the court had said the failure of Bevco in providing adequate space for customers to buy liquor results in long queues. It is a public nuisance and excise authorities are bound by law to act, the court had said.

The court had said in the judgment, “The singular reason why such long queues are formed and why such queues spill over on to public roads and streets is because Bevco does not retail liquor through shops into which customers can walk in and wait, if required, but through counters which are created by barricading and grilling the entrance area of the licensed shops, effectively forcing the customers to stand outside even on roads and streets on which such shops are situated, thus causing long queues and resultant pandemonium in public space including streets. These queues often cause traffic snarls, brawls and several times unrestrained disorder on public roads and streets.”

The court ordered that Bevco would be the best authority to take remedial measures because it is aware of the logistics involved, the demand and the number of customers.

Title: Migrant labourers arrive in droves in Bundelkhand districts
Content:
Bhopal: Health officials in several districts of Bundelkhand are busy tracking migrant labourers who arrived by trains and buses to their hometowns till lockdown was clamped down in these districts. They fear that many of these labourers, who work in big cities, could be potential carriers of Covid-19.

“Tracking them down from remote villages is a huge task. A bigger exercise is to convince them for screening,” officials said.

Village-level committees comprising patwaris, panchayat employees and rozgar sahayaks (employment assistants) in Chhatarpur, Tikamgarh, Panna, Sagar and Damoh are busy identifying labourers and compiling a list of their names and family members.

For years now, people migrate in droves to Delhi, Mumbai, Punjab, Haryana, Gujarat and Uttar Pradesh in search of livelihood. They work at construction sites, agricultural fields, ride rickshaws and autos besides working at brick kilns. Due to this mass migration, many villages only have elderly and children.

“Officials of the district administration are compiling lists. The process of compilation is on. Many of those who have been identified have already been screened and follow up actions are being taken,” said Sheelendra Singh, district collector of Chattarpur.

“Many villagers, who were identified, have been screened for Covid-19 symptoms,” said Saurab Sonwane, SDM of Jatara tehsil in Tikamgarh.

Arrangements are also being made quarantine individuals who test positive for the virus, Sonwane added.

Title: Tech edu dept ties up with int’l online learning platform
Content:
Hyderabad: The Telangana department of technical education has tied up with global online learning platform, Coursera, to provide free access to its courses to students in wake of the closure of institutions due to the coronavirus pandemic. All 400 colleges affiliated to various state universities have been given access to over 3,800 courses on the online platform.

“Principals of all constituent and affiliated colleges offering professional courses in engineering, pharmacy, MBA, MCA in Telangana state to sign-up to Coursera (www.coursera.org), to provide their enrolled students with free access to more than 3,800 courses and 400 Specializations from Coursera’s top university and industry partners,” read a circular issued by the Jawaharlal Nehru Technological University ( JNTU ), Hyderabad to all the college managements.

While all colleges will be given free access till July 31, Coursera plans to provide monthly extensions thereafter. Following instructions from the technical education department, all universities have asked colleges and their staff members to enrol and continue learning and teaching through the online platform over the next few months.

Title: No staff, restaurants may remain shut in Chennai
Content: CHENNAI: It will be bad news for those depending on restaurants for food from Wednesday when a majority of standalone restaurants will be shut as part of the lockdown . A few neighbourhood eateries may function. Chennai Hotels Association secretary R Rajkumar said a sizeable number of the staff employed by restaurants had left the city. “As per government orders, dine-in facilities will not be allowed as there are very few staff members left,” he said.In a notification, the state government said the operation of app-based food delivery aggregators such as Swiggy, Zomato and Uber has been halted, adding that no one can be engaged in this task. “We expect at least 90% of all standalone restaurants to shut. A few neighbourhood eateries may be opened,” he added.With a majority of the 8,000 eateries in the city and its fringes shut, city residents began feeling the pinch of closure from Tuesday evening. Madipakkam resident R Siddharth said many had jacked up prices. “Many were closed in our area except for two. However, food was very expensive,” he said. For instance, chicken fried rice, normally priced at Rs 120 a plate, cost Rs 160 a plate on Tuesday. “We don’t know if this eatery too will be shut on Wednesday.”A majority of those who left the city said they made the decision as they realized getting food would be a problem. “To avoid all this confusion, I left for my hometown on Monday evening. I didn’t mind paying Rs 12,000 for the,” S Nagenthiran, a resident of Guduvanchery, told this reporter over phone.A few bachelors, who have decided to remain in the city, said they had decided to test their cooking skills at home.

Title: Home evaluation for state board papers
Content: Nagpur: Maharashtra education department has permitted valuation of SSC and HSC papers from home in wake of the coronavirus scare and lockdown by the state.Teacher associations had been demanding the same ever since the virus was declared as a pandemic by WHO. The order finally came on Monday. All papers of HSC are over, while just one paper of SSC (Geography) is now pending. It now seems that by the time Geography exam is held, all papers would have already been evaluated. The state board however clarified that the decision is only for this year.Ashok Gavhankar, general secretary of Vidarbha Junior College Teachers Association (VJUCTA) said, “During a time like this, paper evaluation work should definitely be given to the teachers to finish from home. Right now, containing the outbreak is the priority. Few years ago, the system was like that only but due to certain malpractices, evaluation was mandated from school premises,” said Gavhankar who is also principal of Rao Saheb Thawre High School and Junior College, Nagpur.Madhusudhan Mude, president of Headmasters Association (Nagpur district) said state government’s latest move is a good one. “This will ensure that board results will be declared on time which is extremely important for student to make future plans. Teachers will also remain productive in such a time. However, I don’t feel that this should be made into a norm for the years to come and correct way to evaluate papers is to come to the school and do it,” said Mude who is also principal of Major Hemant Jakate School and Junior College.Dilip Bose, secretary of School Headmasters Charitable Association said the board made a wise decision. “Moving out of home was a dangerous thing to do for teachers. This decision will now protect them from the wrath of coronavirus. Working from home is the need of the hour,” said Bose. Principal of Bhola High School Premlata Tiwari said “It is important to announce the results on time so that there are no hindrances for the student’s future education.”Ashnarayan Tiwari, principal of Adarsh Vidya Mandir said the problem will be to procure answersheets in times of a complete lockdown and hence wants evaluation to be delayed. “If teachers go out to collect papers won’t it be violation of curfew. Not only that, it will make the teachers and school staff vulnerable to the virus. Even though, timely evaluation is important, the situation is a matter of life or death,” said Tiwari.

Title: Hydroxychloroquine pills fly off pharmacy store shelves
Content:
Bhubaneswar: Almost all stocks of hydroxychloroquine, a relatively safe and widely used variant of malaria pill chloroquine, were exhausted in pharmacies across Bhubaneswar on Tuesday, following media reports that the medicine might work as a vaccine for Covid-19. People have not only started buying the medicine for immediate use, they are also hoarding it.

The Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR) has recommended hydroxychloroquine as a preventive medicine for high-risk population such as asymptomatic healthcare workers involved in the care of suspected or confirmed cases of Covid-19 and asymptomatic household contacts of laboratory confirmed cases.

It has also issued an advisory that the drug should be given to customers only on prescription by a registered medical practitioner, but that has not stopped people from getting the medicine at stores.

“The recommendation of hydroxychloroquine by ICMR is based on pre-clinical trials and in-vitro study results. It has been tested with success on animals in laboratories but no human trial has taken place,” said Hyderabad-based pharmacologist M R Singh, who works with a company that deals with clinical trial of drugs. “In the current situation, in which no other effective option is available and human trials are not possible with scientifically accurate results, hydroxychloroquine is one of the very few options available to the people. However, it is only recommended for healthcare workers and first-hand exposure cases,” he added.

Though a few medicine stores are turning away customers asking for the pills, many stores said they were almost out of them. Prakash Sahu, owner of City Medicine Store, said, “We have exhausted our stock of hydroxychloroquine over the past two days. We don’t know why people are buying this medicine. They are showing prescriptions too.”

Similarly, stocks of hydroxychloroquine pills in most of the Apollo Pharmacy stores have been exhausted. “Some genuine patients, who regularly take the pill for treatment of arthritis and lupus, had to return empty-handed as we are out of the pills,” said a salesman at the Apollo Pharmacy store in Unit-IV.

Title: GGH shuts OP service, cancels leaves of staff
Content: Guntur: Authorities of Government General Hospital ( GGH ) have decided to shut outpatient (OP) screening to tackle Covid-19 cases in case of an emergency.GGH superintendent Dr S Babulal held an emergency meeting with various department heads late on Monday night and discussed the measures to be taken to handle the issue. Government Medical College (GMC) principal Dr Subbaraao was also present at the meeting.A majority of HoDs felt it would be better to do away with regular and non-emergency outpatient screening to reduce workload on medical officers, nurses and technicians. Following the feedback from doctors, superintendent and medical college, the principal decided to temporarily suspend regular outpatient screening.GGH handles the highest number of outpatients in the state with a daily footfall of nearly 3,000 patients. “We appeal to people not to rush to the GGH for regular and non-emergency ailments as the entire medical fraternity is getting ready to handle emergency cases, including COVID-19” said Babulal.It was also decided at the meet to suspend all leaves of the medical officers and staff in the GGH till the situation eases out.Meanwhile, a dedicated block was readied to screen suspected cases of Covid-19.

Title: Samples of first patient test negative, re-test today
Content:
Tuesday was the 8th consecutive day that no suspect was tested positive from Vidarbha region

Nagpur: The first Covid-19 positive patient of Central India, who is admitted in the isolation ward of Indira Gandhi Government Medical college (IGGMC), completed 14 days of isolation period successfully on March 24. His samples were tested negative on Tuesday. As per protocol, one more test will be conducted in next 24 hours. If this test comes negative, the patient will be allowed to discharge.

However, as district collector Ravindra Thakare has said earlier, the administration will not discharge the patient for next seven days even if he become free from Covid-19 as they want to monitor the patient for one more week.

Doctors collected his swab samples on Tuesday afternoon and they were sent for testing the same day. Sources at the lab facility at IGMMCH informed that the samples were tested negative late in the evening.

Earlier on Tuesday, the patient, who is doing well now, messaged TOI that he was also excited about the test results. “I will let you know,” he messaged.

Meanwhile, Tuesday was the eighth consecutive day on which no suspect was tested positive from Vidarbha region. All 34 samples tested in the morning batch were tested negative. While 26 of these samples were from Nagpur, others were from Chandrapur , Wardha, and Yavatmal .

Three presumptive cases from Yavatmal were tested negative and two of them have been sent to 14 days home quarantine . One of them has been retained in the isolation ward as he has symptoms. Interestingly, one of the three is a nurse in isolation ward who was nursing three positive patients. Now, she has also tested negative.

In Chandrapur, six new suspects were home quarantined on Tuesday. Now, total 44 foreign return persons are under quarantine and observation, while eight have been discharged from quarantine after completing 14 days.

In Nagpur, 36 persons were identified as suspects on Tuesday. Seven of them are admitted in the isolation wards of two government hospitals. As on Tuesday, 744 people are home quarantined in Nagpur. Flyers coming by domestic flights are also being checked now. Four such travellers were sent to MLA hostel quarantine facility while one person voluntarily got admitted after showing symptoms.

At present, 150 people are admitted in the MLA hostel facility. Eight suspects were admitted in the GMCH. Sources at GMCH said that 15 samples were sent from the hospital on Tuesday including these eight.

Lab coming to Yavatmal

A source confirmed that the government has sanctioned a lab along with the test kits for coronavirus testing in Yavatmal and the order would reach shortly. If it finally materializes, the testing of coronavirus samples can be done locally which will minimize the long wait for the test report from the lab at IGGMCH Nagpur, a senior doctor said.

Chinese national living in Umred since Dec last year detained

A Chinese national was detained by Umred police on Tuesday from a hotel and was sent to Indira Gandhi Government Medical College & Hospital (IGGMCH) where he is currently under observation. According to police, the Chinese national had come to India on December 10 for a business trip. He was living in an Umred-based hotel since March 15.

PI of Umred police station Vilas Kale said, “We were checking hotels in the area when we came to know about a Chinese national living there. Since Covid-19 outbreak happened in China. We informed health officials of Umred who later took him to IGGMCH. He was checked there but no symptoms were found. However, he has been kept at the hospital under observation.”

Title: NMC seeks NGOs’ help to provide ration, food
Content:
Nagpur: The Nagpur Municipal Corporation ( NMC ) has started seeking help of NGOs and social organizations to distribute ration as well as meals to families who are depended on daily earnings and have now become helpless due to lockdown in the city.

Additional municipal commissioner Ram Joshi said, “Rotary Club of Nagpur Ishanya has come forward and showed willingness to distribute ration to 5,000 families. A meeting was organized with representatives of the club on Tuesday. They have started preparing parcels comprising rice, wheat flour, dal, salt and chilli powder which will be enough for a family for a week. Plan is to start distribution from March 27. We will provide NMC staff and police for smooth distribution of ration. Planning will be done in such a manner that none will come out for collecting it and parcels are distributed at doorsteps,” he said.

Joshi appealed to all NGOs, social organizations and interested persons to approach NMC for help. “There are large number of slums across the city. The need is to cover over 1 lakh houses,” he said.

Joshi said planning is also under way to provide meals in some slums. “It is a huge task and requires proper planning. Representatives of ISKCON came and met me today. They offered help to provide meals if needed. I also talked to representatives of Akshay Patra Foundation. We will need to pay a minimum charges to NGOs for material and distribution. We will have to explore sources of funds for this initiative,” he said.

Title: Gujarat: Despite government assurance, people throng shops
Content:
Representative image

AHMEDABAD/VADODARA: Even as the lockdown remained successful throughout the day on Tuesday, minutes after the Prime Minister’s address, people rushed to grocery stores, milk booths, and chemists. Such crowds were seen in Ahmedabad, Baroda, Surat and other cities of Gujarat.

“What was a weeklong lockdown has now extended up to three weeks and since it is monthend, we don’t have enough essentials at home,” said Sheetal Sheth, who was waiting in a queue outside a grocery store in Prahladnagar. “What if the three-week shutdown is extended further?”

At the main vegetable market in South Bopal just opposite Sobo Centre, people stood in a half-a-kilometre queue for groceries. Similar queues were seen at a milk parlour near Tejas School.

A police official deployed at Vastral said that many people caught breaking the curfew said they were out to buy medicines. “When I asked them to show a prescription or even recall the medicine’s generic name, they were speechless,” said the cop.

At Bhairavi towers in CTM, residents have decided to prevent the entry of all visitors. “We have been distributing herbal medicines in the evening so that other diseases can be prevented,” said Minesh Patel, a resident of the towers.

Following the customer rush, a number of grocery stores and chemists in Prahladnagar and Anandnagar shut shop within minutes, saying that they would reopen the next day.

Barodians too came out in large numbers to shop. At vegetable markets in Sama and Gorwa and other places it was like an everyday scene. Citizens were seen buying vegetables in bulk to ensure the stock lasts them for at least another week. Chaos prevailed despite shopkeepers ensuring everyone that shops will stay open even during the lockdown of 21 days.

In his address, Prime Minister Narendra Modi had assured citizens that essential items will remain available during the lockdown.

Title: Societies ban entry of maids, delivery boys as corona bites
Content:
Nagpur: With number of coronavirus cases increasing in India, many citizens have joined hands with central and state governments to enforce the lockdown. A large number of apartment schemes have banned the entry of housemaids, courier delivery boys, food delivery personnel, car washers, etc. Some are not even allowing newspaper delivery boys. Only the milkmen are exempt. Many of these societies are home to millionaires, who have decided to do domestic chores themselves than take the risk of exposing themselves to the pandemic.

Godrej Anandam, a mini-township in Ganeshpeth, which has very rich occupants, has banned the entry of outsiders except the relatives of flat owners. Even family friends are not allowed.

The executive body of Rachana Sahil Apartments, Subhash Nagar, on Monday banned entry of domestic helps, car washers, delivery boys, etc. Only those delivering newspapers and milk will be allowed entry. They will have to sanitize themselves before entering the premises. There were some flat owners who opposed the decision but they were overruled by the majority.

Monali Mudholkar of Narhari Residency, Mangaldeep Nagar, Besa Road, said her society had banned entry of outsiders to reduce the risk of coronavirus and help government in battling the pandemic. “Household helps do not come under essential services. Most flat occupants are at home as schools, colleges, offices and factories are shut. Hence we decided to do domestic chores ourselves. The government is doing its job and we citizens must also contribute,” she said.

Suchitra Mange of Tech-Op Laxmi Apartment, Tirupati Nagar, Koradi Road, said that her society office-bearers had also decided to ban entry of outsiders. “I am facing problems because I am not well and I have small kids. However, these are not normal times.”

Dhiraj Khandelwal of Rachna Srushti Apartments, KT Nagar, said that the decision had been taken for the safety of the flat owners as well as that of maids. “We told the maids how to keep themselves safe when they are at home,” he said.

Some other flat schemes where maids and delivery boys are no longer allowed are: Rachana Aangan (Jaitala Road), Capitol Heights (Imambada), Pioneer Regency (KT Nagar), Shiv Society (Besa), Patrakar Colony (Civil Lines), etc.

The ban on maids is causing problems for many people. A female media personnel had to take leave as her mother recently had an operation and her daughter is very young. Both the nurse and child’s maid were not allowed entry. A lady doctor’s husband, who is now at home, is having difficulty handling their two small kids. There are several senior citizens living alone who depend upon domestic help for everything from cooking to purchasing essential items.

Title: Govt orders home delivery of pension and PDS items
Content:
Bhubaneswar: With the state government bringing all districts under lockdown from midnight on Tuesday, 48 lakh beneficiaries will receive four months’ old-age pension and 95 lakh families will get three months’ ration under the public distribution system (PDS) in their houses. The government has asked collectors, municipal commissioners and executive officers of all 114 urban local bodies (ULBs) to make arrangements accordingly.

In an order, Vishal Dev, OSD to chief secretary Asit Tripathy, asked the authorities to involve field-level functionaries of various departments for smooth delivery of ration and old-age pension to the people. The state government had earlier said beneficiaries under the National Social Assistance Programme and the Madhu Babu Pension Yojana would get four months’ (April-July) pension. The government had also said both urban and rural beneficiaries would get three months’ ration (5 kg of rice/wheat at Re 1 per person per month).

“People don’t need to come to fair price shops or panchayats/urban local bodies to collect their ration or pension. The collectors have been asked to make arrangements so that beneficiaries get them at their houses. There should not be any overcrowding at the distribution points,” said a senior government official.

With announcement of the lockdown, the state government on Tuesday ordered immediate stoppage of all construction work across the state, except those of healthcare facilities or related to Covid-19.

Chief minister Naveen Patnaik, in a recent video-conference with Prime Minister Narendra Modi, had asked for a relief package for construction workers. On Tuesday, Union labour minister Santosh Gangwar asked all chief ministers to provide financial aid to construction workers from construction cess.

Title: Nagpur markets deserted, prices of fruits & veggies skyrocket
Content:
NAGPUR: With the entire state under curfew, most of the markets in the city wore a deserted look on Tuesday. “The markets are not the same any more in the light of social distancing advisory to prevent the spread of the coronavirus. Sales have drastically dropped due to virtually no footfall,” said Dilip Yadav, who owns a wholesale grocery shop on Koradi Road.

In the wholesale grain markets in Itwari , which are usually packed with people, the narrow lanes were uncharacteristically deserted. Streets that are usually swarmed by people had hardly any customers in sight.

The sale of fruits and vegetables has drastically dropped even in local vegetable markets like Khamla, Gokulpeth, and Itwari as a result of the low footfall. Many shopkeepers sold vegetables at discounted rates fearing that these would rot and turn into waste, said vegetable vendor Rajnath Sahu.

To maintain social distancing at local markets, the Nagpur Municipal Corporation has used chalks and demarcated lines outside every unit in almost all markets.

Amit Hoshing, a resident of Trimurti Nagar, said the prices of vegetables have increased sharply. He, however, admitted that there was no choice left and appreciated the efforts of district & civic administrations and city police for allowing shops of essential commodities like vegetables, grocery etc to remain open during the lockdown period.

Akash Hubalkar, a fruit vendor, said the demand for fruits has gone down drastically. “From Monday itself, we stopped bringing fruits from Kalamna wholesale market,” he said and claimed to have spotted wholesale vendors dumping tonnes of oranges and watermelons as garbage.

Shalu Gupta, a vegetable vendor from Khamla Road, said, “As we could not afford sanitizers and masks, we are using clothes as masks,” he said. Like Gupta, most vegetable vendors here have started covering their face with cloth.

Even orders at food chains, especially kitchen restaurants, have dropped drastically. Owner of a kitchen restaurant from Sadar, requesting anonymity, said that online food orders have dropped since Monday. Prashant Sahare , a professional and a bachelor staying in an apartment in KT Nagar, said that he continues to get food online since his firm has asked him to work from home.

Title: Gujarat police to form special control room for lockdown
Content:
Shivanand Jha

GANDHINAGAR: Gujarat DGP Shivanand Jha announced formation of a state control room for effective implementation of lockdown and address issues faced by the citizens.

Jha said that the lockdown of the state from March 23 midnight is successful so far and appealed to citizens to adhere to the rules to make fight against COVID-19 effective.

Jha told media at Gandhinagar that in past 24 hours, the state police have registered 238 cases for violation of CrPC Section 144 (prohibition on assembly of more than four persons at a spot) whereas 127 cases have been registered for violation of home quarantine rules. A total of 426 persons were detained and were later released during the lockdown.

“A few complaints about the problems faced by the citizens have come to our notice and we are trying to resolve it. I want to appeal to the people of Gujarat to avoid going out unnecessarily and adhere to the social distancing even when you are out to get essential goods and services. Societies should form groups to ensure that there is no crowding,” said Jha.

The DGP announced formation of a special control room to keep an eye on the lockdown conditions and redress any issues arising during its implementation. “The entire initiative would be supervised by two ADGP-level officers. If the citizens face any unnecessary issue, they can contact respective police stations or police control room numbers,” said Jha.

Jha said that there were a few reports of stopping media and a few trucks of essential supplies in Ahmedabad. “We will discuss the issues with city police commissioners and district SPs during our video conference today,” he said.

He said that police on duty are also taking adequate precautions including wearing masks and washing hands frequently. From midnight of Monday, multiple check posts have been created at police station levels across Gujarat as except essential staff for running a police station, the entire staff is put on state roads to ensure effective lockdown.
