Title: Gujarat: Students of classes 1 to 9 and 11 promoted en masse
Content:
Representative image

AHMEDABAD: The Gujarat government has decided to promote all students of Classes 1 to 9 and 11 to higher standards without examinations. The decision was taken because of the uncertainty brought by the lockdown and the spread of COVID-19 in Gujarat.

Ashwani Kumar, the secretary to the CM, told the media on Tuesday: “The decision has been taken to ensure students’ safety.”

Examinations in primary schools were scheduled in March and April. The state government had earlier this month announced the closure of all educational institutes including schools, colleges, and tuition classes across the state until March 29.

The state government cancelled the final examinations after pressure mounted on it to do so in the wake of the coronavirus pandemic. The president of the School Management Association, Bhaskar Patel, said: “We had been telling the authorities not to insist on exams and exempt students from this formality.” Patel went on to say: “Any kind of gathering has become dangerous. It is good that the administration has finally heeded our demand.” More than 70 lakh students in nearly 55,000 schools across the state have been exempted from the final exams.

In Gujarat, this will be the fifth instance of school students being given mass promotions. It happened in 1974 during the Navnirman agitation; in 1985 during the anti-reservation riots; in 2001 after the earthquake; and in 2002 after the post-Godhra riots.

The state government has also withheld its plan to start the new academic session in April and said that it will roll out the plan from next year.

The circular issued by the education department also exempts all teaching and non-teaching staff from going to schools, unless they are specifically assigned work either by the state government or by the local administration. They will have to strictly follow instructions issued to them in future by the administration.

The teaching and non-teaching staff in self-financed schools has been exempted from school duties as well.

Sources said that a section in the education department wanted an early vacation for teachers and wanted them to resume their duties much before the summer vacation concludes, but the state government discarded the proposal.

Title: In open letter, Digvijaya Singh blames Jyotiraditya Scindia for fall of KamalNath government
Content:
Digvijaya Singh, Senior Congress leader

BHOPAL: Senior Congress leader Digvijaya Singh on Tuesday trained his guns on former Union minister Jyotiraditya Scindia whose supporters including 22 MLAs resigned bringing down the 15-month Kamal Nath government.

Singh tweeted an open letter for the people of Madhya Pradesh . “Recently, Jyotiraditya Scindia defected to BJP causing the fall of Congress government in Madhya Pradesh. I am sad that he joined BJP at a juncture, when its divisive agenda is exposed to all,” he said in the open letter.

“Ït is being said that he had lost hope of a suitable post and honour within the Congress party. But this is untrue. If he indeed wanted to be the MPCC president, then he could have taken over in 2013, when this post was offered to him. But he preferred to remain a Union minister,” Singh said.

“Ïn 2018, he was offered post of deputy CM, but he declined and instead, proposed the name of Tulsi Silawat .”

Singh also took on the RSS and said: “Today Congress politics is not just about power, it is also about confronting Sangh ideology. These two ideologies visualise India differently. The future of India now depends on the victory of one of these ideologies. That is why, the loss of Congress government has pained not just Congress workers but all the common citizens also, who are struggling against the hegemony of RSS philosophy,”the Congress leader wrote.

Title: Animals relieved as this zoo in Tamil Nadu shut for visitors
Content:
Vandalur Zoo

CHENNAI: The animals and birds at the Vandalur zoo have never been seen in such a relaxed mood, say their keepers.

From K Chellaiah, who is in charge of the white tigers’ enclosure, to M Nagammal, who takes care of the enclosures for deer and the regular tigers, almost every staff member says life for the animals has been most peaceful since March 17 when the zoo was shut over Covid-19 fears.

This is the second time the facility has been closed for a long time. The first time was from January 23 to February 23 in 2002, when a wild leopard strayed into the zoo and the authorities trapped it after a month.

The present situation, though comfortable for the animals, could prove costly for the zoo in terms of revenue, say officials. They, however, admit that the behaviour of the visitors, some of them unruly, causes a lot of strain for the animals.

From 9.45am, when the gates are opened and the first visitors stream in, to when the zoo is closed, the animals are subjected to almost continuous noise. Some try to get as close to the enclosures as possible to take selfies; others shout and clap to draw the attention of the animals. A few others even throw stones at the animals, sometimes hurting them and causing a lot of stress. All this, says

renowned veterinarian N Kalaivanan, leads to loss of natural behaviour for animals and their stress levels go up.

A good example is the Sariska reserve in Rajasthan where the huge number of vehicles affected the reproductive system of tigers and their numbers in Central India fell significantly, he said.

“When animals in captivity are not disturbed, their wild behaviour is restored. Their physiological behaviour is also good and helps in better functioning of their reproductive system,” he said.

Now, Chelliah says, with no visitors to disturb them, the white tigers have been frolicking with their cubs happily.

Nagammal agrees and says the sambar deer, in particular, react instantly to noise and sometimes abandon their feed. No such instances have occurred in the past one week, she says.

It is not only the carnivores such as tigers and leopards that are stressed. Even small mammals such as mongoose and palm civet among a host of animals too get affected badly, Kalaivanan said. That may return when the zoo is ultimately opened, he added.

Title: Gujarat police to form special control room for lockdown
Content:
Shivanand Jha

GANDHINAGAR: Gujarat DGP Shivanand Jha announced formation of a state control room for effective implementation of lockdown and address issues faced by the citizens.

Jha said that the lockdown of the state from March 23 midnight is successful so far and appealed to citizens to adhere to the rules to make fight against COVID-19 effective.

Jha told media at Gandhinagar that in past 24 hours, the state police have registered 238 cases for violation of CrPC Section 144 (prohibition on assembly of more than four persons at a spot) whereas 127 cases have been registered for violation of home quarantine rules. A total of 426 persons were detained and were later released during the lockdown.

“A few complaints about the problems faced by the citizens have come to our notice and we are trying to resolve it. I want to appeal to the people of Gujarat to avoid going out unnecessarily and adhere to the social distancing even when you are out to get essential goods and services. Societies should form groups to ensure that there is no crowding,” said Jha.

The DGP announced formation of a special control room to keep an eye on the lockdown conditions and redress any issues arising during its implementation. “The entire initiative would be supervised by two ADGP-level officers. If the citizens face any unnecessary issue, they can contact respective police stations or police control room numbers,” said Jha.

Jha said that there were a few reports of stopping media and a few trucks of essential supplies in Ahmedabad. “We will discuss the issues with city police commissioners and district SPs during our video conference today,” he said.

He said that police on duty are also taking adequate precautions including wearing masks and washing hands frequently. From midnight of Monday, multiple check posts have been created at police station levels across Gujarat as except essential staff for running a police station, the entire staff is put on state roads to ensure effective lockdown.

Title: Gujarat: Students of classes 1 to 9 and 11 promoted en masse
Content:
Representative image

AHMEDABAD: The Gujarat government has decided to promote all students of Classes 1 to 9 and 11 to higher standards without examinations. The decision was taken because of the uncertainty brought by the lockdown and the spread of COVID-19 in Gujarat.

Ashwani Kumar, the secretary to the CM, told the media on Tuesday: “The decision has been taken to ensure students’ safety.”

Examinations in primary schools were scheduled in March and April. The state government had earlier this month announced the closure of all educational institutes including schools, colleges, and tuition classes across the state until March 29.

The state government cancelled the final examinations after pressure mounted on it to do so in the wake of the coronavirus pandemic. The president of the School Management Association, Bhaskar Patel, said: “We had been telling the authorities not to insist on exams and exempt students from this formality.” Patel went on to say: “Any kind of gathering has become dangerous. It is good that the administration has finally heeded our demand.” More than 70 lakh students in nearly 55,000 schools across the state have been exempted from the final exams.

In Gujarat, this will be the fifth instance of school students being given mass promotions. It happened in 1974 during the Navnirman agitation; in 1985 during the anti-reservation riots; in 2001 after the earthquake; and in 2002 after the post-Godhra riots.

The state government has also withheld its plan to start the new academic session in April and said that it will roll out the plan from next year.

The circular issued by the education department also exempts all teaching and non-teaching staff from going to schools, unless they are specifically assigned work either by the state government or by the local administration. They will have to strictly follow instructions issued to them in future by the administration.

The teaching and non-teaching staff in self-financed schools has been exempted from school duties as well.

Sources said that a section in the education department wanted an early vacation for teachers and wanted them to resume their duties much before the summer vacation concludes, but the state government discarded the proposal.

Title: 38 Quick Response Teams to prevent spread of Covid-19
Content: Nagpur: The district administration, in association with Nagpur Municipal Corporation NMC ) and Homeguards Department, has constituted a Quick Response Team (QRT) for each of the 38 wards. The QRTs will be on the ground, assess exact situation prevailing across the city and submit reports daily, which would be beneficial for implementing various measures to control spread of Covid-19.It is the initiative of divisional commissioner Sanjeev Kumar and collector Ravindra Thakre in association with municipal commissioner Tukaram Mundhe and CP Bhushan Kumar Upadhyay Deputy collector Ravindra Kumbhare told TOI, “QRTs will start their work from Wednesday. Each QRT comprises of five members — employee from revenue department, homeguard, staffers from NMC solid waste management, NMC malaria and filaria department, and Auxiliary Nurse Midwife (ANM). They were given necessary training and formats on Tuesday at the collector office as well as NMC,” he said.QRTs will visit houses of all 744 home quarantines once in a day. ANM will report to concerned doctors in case of any symptoms in home quarantine. Also, those not complying with home quarantine orders will get two warnings, followed by action in the third instance.QRTs will check whether any grocery or dairy or any other shops where people are coming together does not maintain social distancing. They will inform NMC as well as collector office following which necessary steps will be taken.QRTs will also check whether any area lacks stock of grocery and other essential commodities. All concerned departments will swing into action if any such area is identified.QRTs will also identify areas facing other problems like menace of mosquito etc.QRTs have been also given responsibility to talk to people and identify persons, especially lone senior citizens or females, who are unable to come out and need grocery or any other essential products . QRT will alert about such persons and necessary help will be provided.Kumbhare said, “QRT is a medium to reach the people as lock down is implemented in entire city. It is a way to ensure people do not come outside for any help. We can come to know problems being faced by the people and resolve it in time through QRTs,” he said.Probably, the city is the first in the state to launch QRTs.Kumbhare also said QRTs will be compulsorily in their respective wards during working hours. “All five members of QRTs will have to submit reports to respective departments in the evening,” he said.

Title: Five truckloads of debris removed, graffiti cleared from Shaheen Bagh protest site
Content:
The graffiti had come up on the Jamia wall after the violence on December 15

NEW DELHI: Delhi Police on Tuesday morning removed more than five truckloads of debris, broken furniture and other installations from the kilometre-long Shaheen Bagh protest site with the help of earthmovers.

Senior police officers said that the goods have been seized as case property and South Delhi Municipal Corporation (SDMC) and public works department (PWD) have been asked to start the repair work of the damaged stretch. A survey will be conducted for restoration work to begin.

Meanwhile, the graffiti on the walls at the anti-CAA-NRC protest site outside Jamia Millia Islamia were whitewashed by some unknown people on Tuesday. While no organisation claimed to having done it, Jamia students alleged that it was done by policemen who had gone there to remove the tents.

A senior SDMC official said a team of 35 people used five auto-tippers to carry the waste and debris from Shaheen Bagh. Another 15 people and three tippers were used at the Jamia protest site. “These roads are more than 60-feet wide and belong to PWD, so the repair work of signage, central verge and road furniture will be carried out by them,” he added.

Rajpal, deputy chairperson of SDMC standing committee, said penalties would be imposed on people responsible for causing damage worth crores to public property.

A senior PWD official said that police have asked them to wait till Thursday to start work in case some retaliation occurs on Wednesday. “The money spent on restoring the stretch will be used from the maintenance fund of Delhi government,” he added.

The graffiti had come up on the Jamia campus walls after the violence on December 15. The Jamia administration denied having any knowledge of the whitewashing. “The proctor told me that 40-50 people came in the morning and without informing us started to paint over the graffiti,” said Ahmed Azeem, Jamia media coordinator.

Jamia’s Joint Coordination Committee member Alameen Kabir said, “The protest has been called off temporarily. We will be back after the Covid-19 pandemic ends and so will the graffiti.” JCC, in its press statement, also alleged that police took away the relief material kept for riot victims.

Delhi Police, SDMC and PWD denied having any knowledge about the whitewashing.

Title: Delhi Rain: Rain surprises Delhi, more likely over next few days
Content:
The increased wind speed and light rain have further aided in decreasing city’s pollution levels (Photo: PTI)

NEW DELHI: Gusty winds ranging from 30-40 km per hour, accompanied by a spell of light rain struck the capital on Tuesday evening, bringing down the mercury by several notches. Till 5.30pm, while Safdarjung recorded 0.6mm rain, Palam saw 2.1mm, Lodhi Road 1mm and Ayanagar 1.4mm.

Track the pollution level in your city

Met officials said a western disturbance is influencing parts of north-west India, which could bring a spell of very light rain in the next few days too. The maximum temperature on Tuesday was 33 degrees Celsius, two notches above normal, while the minimum was 18.6 degrees Celsius, a notch below normal.

“Light rain along with thunderstorm is likely in Delhi-NCR in the next couple of days due to the western disturbance. The wind speed would be around 25-30 km per hour. Dust storm or thunderstorm accompanied with light rain is expected on Friday along with wind at a speed of 30-40 km per hour. The temperature will remain around 31 degrees,” Kuldeep Srivastava, head of regional centre at the India Meteorological Department (IMD), said.

The increased wind speed and light rain have further aided in decreasing Delhi’s pollution levels, which, despite remaining in the ‘moderate’ range, are expected to drop to ‘satisfactory’ in the next 24 hours.

The AQI on Tuesday was 122, similar to Monday’s 124, categorised as moderate according to Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB)’s index.

As per CPCB, Delhi-NCR’s average PM2.5 levels were recorded at 61.1 micrograms per cubic metre at 9pm on Tuesday, just above the safe standards. The average PM10 levels were recorded at 122.2 micrograms per cubic metre the same time. The “emergency” benchmark for these pollutants under GRAP is, respectively, 300 and 500 micrograms per cubic metre, while the safe standards are 60 and 100 micrograms per cubic metre.

“The AQI is likely to be at the higher end of satisfactory to lower end of moderate category on Wednesday. The satisfactory category is forecasted for Thursday and Friday, too,” a SAFAR report stated.



In Video: Rain, thunderstorm bring down temperature in Delhi-NCR

Title: Govt’s 104 helpline a bulwark in virus fight
Content:
Bhubaneswar: The state government’s 104 helpline number has become a major shield to stop spreading of novel coronavirus in the state. It is not only registering names of the persons returning from Covid-19-affected countries, but is giving medical advice during their quarantine or isolation period.

According to state government’s chief spokesperson on Covid-19 Subroto Bagchi, 104 is like a moat around a fort. “It helps us fight against the spread of coronavirus,” he had told mediapersons while discussing about the helpline two days ago. This helpline, launched in 2015, has been receiving around 500 calls per day, but now the call centre is getting more than 7,000 calls a day. It may increase further.

Works secretary Krishan Kumar, who is overseeing the helpline, said, “The 104 helpline number is helpful in storing database of people returning from Covid-19-affected countries. There were around 45 people in the call centre, but now we have strengthened the centre by engaging 150 people.”

As many people ask for doctor consultation, the government has created a team of doctors, led by retired director of health Saroj Nayak. To assist him, 14 doctors have been deployed in the centre to provide consultation over phone to people under home quarantine or isolation. The doctor team and 150 members of call centre sit at Smart City office. The government has also set up an outbound call centre to act on the information received through the 104 helpline. It has been set up at Odisha Computer Application Centre (OCAC).

“Main purpose of the centre is to call the people in quarantine or home isolation twice a day and take feedback from them. More than 150 persons are handling the calls and seven doctors, including senior professor Braja Das, are giving medical advice to the people, an official said.

If any person wants to talk to a doctor about symptoms or anything related to Covid-19, the professionals at the centre forward the call to a doctor. They also suggest the people, who return to Odisha from other states, to talk to the local administration and report if they find any symptoms of infection.

The number of calls made to 104 helpline from 7am on Monday to 7am on Tuesday was 11,187. A total 3,816 persons returned from abroad have registered with the state government through the 104 helpline and ‘covid19.odisha.gov.in’ portal by 7am on Tuesday.

Besides, people can report to state control room (0674-2390466) or to state surveillance officer (9439994857, 9439994859). The government agencies, including Bhubaneswar Municipal Corporation (BMC), have issued helpline number 1929 to address issues faced by residents during the lockdown period, but nobody picked up call in this number on Monday. This correspondent called this number eight times between 10.25am and 4.19pm on Monday. The response was either “Sorry, the network is congested’, or “Sorry, there is no reply from the number you have called”.

BMC deputy commissioner (sanitation) Subhendu Sahu had said, “The problem happens when many users call at a time. A caller should try more than once to get connected.” The number was found working on Tuesday.

Title: Anti-CAA protests ‘take a break’ in western UP, to resume after Covid-19 is defeated
Content:
Meerut/Agra/Bareilly: After Delhi and Lucknow, women protesters staging round-the-clock sit-in against CAA and NRC withdrew their stir in all cities of western UP, but with a rider that they will resume it once the novel coronavirus is wiped out. The “conditional break” was achieved after a lot of persuasion by police, authorities and religious leaders who termed large-scale gathering as unsafe amid the threat posed by novel coronavirus.

In Deoband, a town in UP’s Saharanpur district housing one of the world’s largest Islamic seminaries, a protest was going on for the last 57 days. On Tuesday, it was discontinued. However, the protesting women left their bangles and ‘burqas’ at the protest site, Eidgah ground, under the “guard of CCTV cameras”.

“We will resume the stir from April 5. Until then, no one will touch these burqas and bangles or else we would resume our agitation, then and there,” one of the protesters said. Over 500 women were at the sit-in site at any given time for the last almost two months in Deoband’s Eidgah, making it the largest protest site in UP.

According to Vidyasagar Mishra, Saharanpur superintendent of police (rural), “We had been talking to the representatives of this agitation for some time. On the day of janata curfew, the attendance became thin. And on late Monday night, they finally agreed with some conditions.”

Fozia Usmani, a member of Mutahida Khawatin Committee (MKC), the organising committee of the ‘dharna’, said, “We are leaving our bangles and burqas behind as our symbolic presence. We are only leaving the place for time being to mitigate chances of community spread of novel coronavirus.”

In Aligarh’s Shahjamal area, another major protest site in the state, the agitation was called off on Tuesday. The protesters were staging the sit-in for the last 57 days. They vacated the protest site after getting a “written” assurance from police that their tents and other items will not be removed from ‘dharna’ site, as they will resume the sit-in after spread of the virus is controlled.

City magistrate Vineet Kumar Singh, who was present at the site, said, “The protesters were told about the health issues and they agreed to vacate the site.” When asked about any kind of assurance given to the protesters, Singh refused to comment.

“Our priority is to check the spread of Covid-19,” the officer said.

“This is only temporary, and we will be back once the situation is under control,” said one of the protesters, adding that the protest against the government will continue till they accept their demand to withdraw Citizenship (Amendment) Act (CAA).

In Moradabad also, Eidgah was cleared of protesters. Additional superintendent of police (city) said that tents and other things have been removed from the sit-in site. Similarly, superintendent of police in Sambhal said that all protesting women have gone back to their homes calling off the protest there.

“Today, we reached among the protesters and interacted with them after which, except a few, everyone was ready to go back to their homes. Later, rest of them also vacated the spot and we cleared the ground after uprooting tents. An FIR was lodged against 12 named and 160 unknown people for their stubborn attitude,” ASP Amit Kumar Anand said. Earlier in the morning, the DM also gave the example of Shaheen Bagh of Delhi where anti-CAA protesters called off their protest on Tuesday morning.

Title: Noida couple without any travel history tests positive
Content: LUCKNOW: Four new coronavirus cases were reported in UP on Tuesday — three from Gautam Budh Nagar and one in Shamli. The state’s tally is now 37. Meanwhile, 68 suspected patients have been put under isolation at different government hospitals in the state.Of the three positive cases reported in GB Nagar, a couple is from Sector 137 of Noida while the third lives in Greater Noida. Sources in the health department said Noida patients are a cause of worry for health authorities as they had no travel history, though they hosted a friend who had returned from London. “The patients in Noida, a 47-year-old woman and her 50-year-old husband have no travel history which leaves us extremely worried about the infection entering the community. However, we came to know that the two had hosted a London based client at their residence recently. Chances are that the visitors were asymptomatic and could have passed on the infection to them. The doubt would be cleared only after we track the visitor from London,” said an officer in the health department.The patient in Greater Noida also a travel history. District magistrate GB Nagar BN Singh has ordered sealing of the housing societies in which the patients live.About the patient in Shamli, state surveillance officer Dr Vikasendu Agarwal said: “The patient is a 33-year-old man who returned from Dubai on March 15. He was under home isolation and was being tracked on a daily basis. Three days ago, he complained of sore throat and health team collected his sample. On Tuesday, KGMU declared him Covid-19 positive.” Officials in Shamli district said that the patient belongs to Chakki area of the district. Though the patient was following isolation strictly, teams have been sent to examine his contacts to identify any suspected cases. Family members have been told not to venture out of their homes.Health officials said all measures were being taken to limit the virus. “At present, testing is crucial to contain the situation. In wake of this, six labs are engaged in testing. Two more labs are also in the pipeline. These are Rural Institute of Medical Sciences Saifai and National Institute of Virology centre at BRD medical college of Gorakhpur. After permission from Indian Council of Medical Research, private labs will also be allowed,” principal secretary Amit Mohan Prasad said.

Title: Ahmedabad: Owners of meat shop and bakery booked
Content:
Representative image

AHMEDABAD: City cops continued to enforce the lockdown in Ahmedabad on Tuesday by booking more people for violating the police commissioner’s notification. The notification bars the assembly of more than four people under Section 144 of the Criminal Procedure Code (CrPC). A meat shop owner and a bakery shop owner in Gomtipur and Isanpur were among those booked.

On Tuesday, when Gomtipur police personnel were patrolling the area, they found people gathered around a meat shop.

Police said in the FIR that the two persons had defied the directive to keep all commercial establishments shut. The two are Bashir Ahmed Qureshi, 39, a resident of Kuvavad in Mirzapur; and Mohammed Arif Shaikh, 26, a resident of Rajpur in Gomtipur.

A bakery owner in Isanpur, Ramesh Prajapati, was booked for keeping his shop open. Police took action against auto drivers for providing shared services and increasing the probability of infections.

Title: ‘Dubai duo understated contacts’
Content:
Gandhinagar: It was a story that the state health department feared for long: the transmission of COVID-19 to local clusters. The four positive cases of Gandhinagar are of the same extended family — a man and his wife, sister-in-law, and maternal uncle. While the couple had travelled to Dubai, the other two got in touch with them and got infected.

“The couple initially told the health department that they had come in contact with about 54 persons,” said a health department official. “All the persons were tracked and their health was recorded. However, the couple had not mentioned a senior citizen, who is also a pharmacist at a government-run health centre. That case turned out to be positive.”

Due to the case, a special team has been formed consisting of officials from the collector’s office, police, and municipal corporation to track down all the persons who might have come in contact with the four. Sources said that the number could be about 100, given the vocation of one of the positive cases.

“We are tracking the calls they have made and the places they visited since the return of the couple on March 17 from Dubai,” said the official. “If the couple had followed quarantine rules, the other cases would not have happened.”

Title: Home quarantined woman ‘escapes’ to Uttar Pradesh
Content:
Nagpur: A woman, who returned from Sharjah in UAE and was home quarantined for 14 days, has allegedly fled to her hometown in Jaunpur, Uttar Pradesh . This is reportedly the first case of a person fleeing from home quarantine in the city.

She has been booked under the Indian Epidemic Acts as well as for causing risk to others under the Indian Penal Code (IPC). The provisions, under which she has been booked, can lead to a jail term. This is also the second such case in which a person has been booked for causing risk to others as part of the corona prevention action.

According to a press release issued by the police, the woman who returned from Sharjah was quarantined for 14 days. However, when the police reached her residence to confirm that she was indeed at home, It was learnt that she left for Jaunpur in Uttar Pradesh. She reached India on March 15.

Coincidentally, the person who has been booked, has her residence under the Sonegaon police station which also covers the home of a Germany returned student. The neighbours had filed a complaint that the German returned girl was seen roaming outside. However, no offence has been registered against her.

Based on the complaint when the NMC officials reached her residence, the girl was found at home. However, the officials later took her to the MLA Hostel quarantine facility where the doctors said that since it has been 10 days since her return, she cannot be taken in.

On Tuesday, the Germany returned girl was reported to be at home. Her neighbour Rama Mahesh , who had taken up the matter with the police, also confirmed that the girl was at home on Tuesday. Mahesh said she had approached the police because she was seen moving around during the quarantine period. The complaint was filed as a last resort.

Title: Agra: District administration to register FIRs against profiteers who raise prices of food items
Content: AGRA: With the lockdown against Covid-19 virus coming into effect on Monday, vegetable, fruit and grocery sellers jacked up prices of essential items as people rushed to markets to stock up for the days ahead. To check rampant profiteering and black marketing, Agra Municipal Corporation (AMC)authorities on Tuesday announced that FIRs would be lodged against the culprits under the Essential Commodities Act, 1955.Vendors selling vegetables in makeshift shops told TOI that the suppliers had raised prices of all vegetables and fruits but they have not increased their profit margin.As residents grappled with the high prices, at a few places in the city, AMC officials with the help of local councillors ensured doorstep delivery of vegetables and fruits.Pratapura resident Anil Goyal said, “On Monday, I had purchased papaya at the a rate Rs 40 per kg. On Tuesday, the same vendor is charging Rs 60. The prices of bananas, grapes and seasonal vegetables have also increased. Authorities must take suitable action to curb profiteering.”Talking with TOI, district magistrate Prabhu N Singh said, “We have constituted a team to check issues related to profiteering and black marketing of all essential products. In all such cases, legal action will be taken. In this regard, people can register a complaint on 056-2260550 or Whatsapp at 9454419029. There is no shortage of fruits, vegetables or any other essential item in the district.”Municipal commissioner Arun Prakash said, “We have started implementing a plan for doorstep delivery of fruits, vegetables and other daily use items. All the 100 wards of the city will be covered Wednesday onwards. Vendors have been assigned a specific area to operate. A team of 29 officials has been tasked to ensure residents get necessary supplies at reasonable rates. Municipal councillors have also been requested to check profiteering does not take place.”Meanwhile, the meat sellers alleged that police are not allowing them to function. Sultanpur locality-based chicken trader said, “Policemen are harassing us. They are also misbehaving with our customers. Meat is also a food item just like fruit and vegetable. We want the district administration to issue us passes to operate in a time-bound manner.”The lockdown on Tuesday was more effective in Agra district than Monday. Heavy police presence was seen of city roads throughout the day. Policemen dealt strictly with people, especially the youngsters, who were found on the roads or public places without a valid reason.

Title: Pet food to parental care were citizens’ excuses to beat curfew
Content:
Tuesday saw many

Nagpur: “Going to buy food for my pet” and “On way to take my parents to hospital”, were among the few excuses citizens gave to avoid police action when caught violating the curfew on Tuesday. However, most people stopped by cops claimed they were out because of a medical emergency or to buy medicines for family members.

On Tuesday, police kept a strict bandosbast across city. However, many could be seen roaming around the city claiming they were on some important work. TOI spotted several citizens carrying a medicine strip or a bottle with them, claiming they were out to buy the medicines.

Some cops also deployed unique tactics to discipline he violators. A video that also went viral on social media on Tuesday showed senior PI of Lakadganj police station Narendra Hiwre asking some violators to do sit-ups for violating curfew without valid reason.

A cop posted at Chhatrapati Chowk for bandobust said most people claimed they were going to buy medicine or some household items. “So many people are out on streets, we are turning away those roaming without genuine cause. We are also letting go government employees after seeing their credentials,” the cop said.

A biker stopped during nakabandi told cops his dog was hungry for two days and he was going to buy dog food for him. Cops initially stopped him but later let him go. Another citizen stopped at Chhatrapati Chowk claimed he was going to his parents house as they were not feeling well and he would take them to hospital.

One person stopped near Suyog Nagar square told cops he was on his way to a late relative's fourteenth day ritual.

“Some were carrying medical papers that sometimes seemed years old. The citizens are beating the curfew in the name of medical emergency, but we had to let them go even when we knew that some were lying,” said another cop at Sitabuldi Chowk.

“Several citizens were also carrying bags and claimed that they were going to buy groceries. We let them go,” said a senior cop.

Title: Hoax tantrics arrested
Content:
Rajkot: Two tantrics were arrested for stealing gold ornaments from the house of a couple living in Yograj Society near Ayodhya Chowk.

The tantrics — Sayarnath Rathod and Devayatnath Rathod — both residents of Padadhari, were caught on Tuesday on the basis of CCTV footages obtained from the society.

On March 20, they approached Vinod Panchasara and told him that he needs to ward off bad omen from his house. On pretext of rituals, they gave Panchasara and his wife water laced with intoxicating substance. When they fell unconscious, the duo fled with six gold bangles and earrings.

Title: Community kitchen to feed homeless, poor in the Madurai
Content:
Representative image

MADURAI: The Madurai Corporation will operate a community kitchen to ensure that homeless people and poor do not go hungry during the curfew. The corporation has also arranged four temporary shelters, one in each zone, to provide accommodation for the homeless, officials said.

As per the government order, all the 12 Amma canteens will be operating at nights for the benefit of the marginalized, officials said. Madurai Corporation commissioner S Visakan told TOI that Poonga Murugan Temple has been chosen for the operation of community kitchen. Food will be prepared for 500 people in the beginning. They can feed any number of people as per requirement. Food prepared will be taken out and delivered to people at various places. Essential commodities required for food preparation have been stocked.

Officials said that thousands will be benefitted from the community kitchen, which will be operational till March 31.Temporary shelter are coming up at Sokkanathapuram 2nd Street, Ramavarma Nagar 1st West Street (near K Pudur Amma canteen), Rani Ponnammal Salai in Keerathurai and nearby Harveypatti park, Visakan said. Arapalayam, Anaiyur, K Pudur ITI, Gandhipuram , Ramaraya Mandapam , Government Rajaji Hospital, New Ramnad Road, CMR Road, Sundararajapuram Market, Palanganatham, Thiruparankundram Bus Stand and Melavasal near Periyar Bus Stand are the places where canteens are being operated. Food prepared at these canteens was supplied to the homeless on Tuesday night.

The commissioner said that Amman canteens were operated on Sunday, the day when the nation observed Janata curfew.

Title: UP CM Yogi Adityanath cracks whip on hoarding and black marketing
Content: LUCKNOW: CM Yogi Adityanath has ordered a crackdown and strict action against those involved in hoarding and black marketing of goods, including sanitisers, face masks, medical equipment and consumables as well as essentials. Additional chief secretary home Awanish Awasthi said the government will not tolerate any kind of illegal activity and could even consider slapping the National Security Act on the accused.CM Yogi, who held a meeting with medicine dealers and market associations on Tuesday, directed them to ensure that supply of essential goods is not disrupted in the state. This direction pertained especially to masks, gloves and sanitisers.He also appealed to people to not spread panic. “People should stop hoarding masks as not everyone needs to wear them. Only those who come in contact with patients or those with symptoms should wear masks. For others, the use of handkerchiefs to cover one’s mouth would also suffice,” he said. Later, in an interaction with reporters, additional chief secretary Awasthi said, “The government will not tolerate any kind of black marketing or hoarding. We could even slap NSA against the guilty.”He also thanked the protesting women for calling off the ongoing protests against the Citizenship Amendment Act at various places in the state. He also urged the women to join the battle against coronavirus that has become a global epidemic.

Title: No cluster of Covid-19 patients around patients’ homes
Content: Nagpur: In a major relief, Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) has completed door-to-door containment drive in 3km radius of the houses of four positive patients, and confirmed there is no cluster of Covid-19 patients in these areas. NMC has claimed to be the first in the state to launch the drive, which is very important to control Covid-19.Municipal commissioner Tukaram Mundhe on Tuesday decided to extend the drive to the entire city as the civic body could complete the drive within three days in 3km radius of houses of four positive patients.NMC assistant medical officer health Dr Praveen Gantawar told TOI, “No cluster of Covid-19 patients were found in vicinity of houses of four positive patients. We covered 64,000 houses with population of over 2.30 lakh in three days. Around 30,000 houses were covered on first two days and remaining 34,000 on Tuesday. There were some issues in initial stages. We sorted it out so the drive could be completed quickly on Tuesday,” he said.NMC now has entire data of people residing in these areas, which covers two — Laxmi Nagar and Dharampeth — of the total ten zones. Gantawar said another random survey will be done again in these areas on Wednesday.NMC sources told TOI a few houses where NMC teams were not allowed to come for survey will be covered on Wednesday. “NMC gave letters to teams so that they can hand over these to houses who did not cooperate. NMC has explained in detail the importance of survey in the letters,” sources said.NMC will know if any suspected Covid-19 patients or those with severe acute respiratory illness are present in remaining parts of the city with the new drive. NMC is collecting contact numbers if they come across such patients. Also, NMC is spreading awareness among people about precautions as well as steps in case of any doubts about Covid-19.The drive will also check whether home quarantined people are following guidelines or not.On Tuesday, NMC also announced door-to-door diagnosis and medical treatment facilities. “If anyone falls ill and is unable to go to nearby hospital, such persons can call NMC’s control room. NMC will send a team of doctors to the home. If a suspect patient of Covid-19 requires admission, NMC will provide ambulance and ensure the concerned persons is admitted in hospital,” NMC said.NMC has also appealed to retired officials and employees of health department of NMC, state health department, army and other establishments to come forward and join in the drive to control Covid-19.The civic body has also started meetings with private hospitals to reserve beds for Covid-19 in case of any outbreak like situation.

Title: Dehradun: Leopard takes shelter in school building, rescued
Content:
Representative image

DEHRADUN: Amid the statewide lockdown to contain the spread of coronavirus, a leopard was found holed up in a vacant private school building in Rishikesh on Tuesday.

The animal, aged around three to four years, was tranquilised after an operation of around four hours. A forest department staffer was however injured in the process and admitted to AIIMS Rishikesh.

Meanwhile, forest officials have urged the state government to include the forests and wildlife department in the list of ‘essential services’ during the lockdown. A senior official told TOI, “This is the time when poachers will try to make money as they hardly have any other source of income. ”

Another IFS officer said, “Patrolling has reduced significantly in areas surrounding forests due to the lockdown. This is likely to cause a spike in human-animal conflict. Also, who will tackle forest fires in the coming days if the department is not exempted from the restrictions?” Notably, the Forest Survey of India has given out over 35 forest fire alerts to Uttarakhand this month alone.

Title: Saving the strays: Good samaritans feed furry friends in Chennai
Content: CHENNAI: M Neelagandan got married five months ago. But he will be next meeting his wife only after the lockdown period ends. For, the animal lover has volunteered to stay at the Blue Cross of India shelter during this time of need to help care for the voiceless.“They need us now more than ever and it gives me great satisfaction to be here for them,” says Neelagandan, who runs a few canteens in the city. “They are shut now, so I have the time to volunteer. My wife supports what I do.”The lockdown will affect not just humans but animals too. On Monday, Maneka Gandhi appealed on Twitter, requesting people to feed animals. “In the event of a lockdown, if they are not fed, many will die, creating another serious problem. I have asked all animal welfare workers to feed the animals during this period. I will be doing the same,” she wrote.Animal welfare activists in the city and other individuals have risen to the challenge. With hotels shut, stray animals in the city are finding it difficult to find food. If many starve and die, it will worsen the situation.At shelters, volunteers and staff are staying on to do their bit. “Twenty two of us, including two vets, two volunteers and Blue Cross staff will stay at the shelter to care for the sick and injured animals. We have 1,263 animals and have to ensure they are fed nutritious meals, and get exercise. We also have to attend to the upkeep of the shelter and go on rescues,” says Dawn Williams , general manager, Blue Cross.Dinesh Baba, who runs Cloud No 9 Kennel and Nursing Care, is providing cooked food to street animals. “On Monday, I cooked about 75kg of dog food, and fed strays,” says Dinesh, who commutes from Porur to Injambakkam every day.Sumita Pai, who lives in Alwarpet, has been regularly feeding birds and community animals but plans to make a more concerted effort during the lockdown. “I will follow all government guidelines and directives. I will feed the animals on my own and step out only for a brief period,” she says.Animal lovers say it is necessary to feed strays but do so in a responsible manner. “You can feed animals in your locality so you don’t have to step out much. Also, do not do it in groups, social distancing is must,” says Dinesh.In a related development, the Animal Welfare Board of India wrote to all the chief secretaries of all the states and UTs, saying that it had come to their notice that a large number of pet shops or animal breeding facilities where animals and birds are kept for sale are now shutdown. "The animals stranded in such places are likely to suffer and die without food, water, temperature control, etc. All such pet shops are to be evacuated by the State Animal Welfare Boards through SPCAs. Where there is no SPCA available, the district administration shall ensure to check and evacuate all animals," it said in the letter.

Title: Tamils working in Kerala hurry back home, crowd check post
Content:
Representative image

COIMBATORE: Walayar check post was crowded on Tuesday with several hundreds of Tamils returning to the state from Kerala, where they are employed, since morning following the announcement on imposition of Section 144 of the Code of Criminal Procedure. Similarly, there was an outflow of Keralites, who have been working in the state, to their hometowns through the check post. They were all allowed in or out only after screening.

A public health department official said the rural police and doctors were deployed at Walayar check post to screen the people who were travelling in and out. “People were allowed in only after verifying that they are the citizens of the state. The crowd was too large for the team of doctors, who were deployed there, to handle. They really had a tough time screening the people travelling in and out. People were advised to maintain distance, but they hardly paid heed to the doctors’ advice.”

The official said the crowd wasn’t aware about the seriousness of Covid-19.

Dr Azhagu Rajamani, assistant director, public health department, Coimbatore, said they had been screening people at Walayar check post for the past 10 days. “The government invoked CrPC Section 144 to avoid large gathering at a place. But thousands of people gathered at the check post on Tuesday. Some of them used ambulance to shift people to Tamil Nadu from Kerala. It’s an offence. People should stay at home.” He said all the vehicles were stopped at the check post and that they were allowed in or out only after screening.

Goutham, a native of Ooty, said the health department should have appointed more staff at the check post for screening. “I had to cross Mettupalayam, Coonoor and Ooty check posts to reach my hometown. The screening process was too slow.”

However, the district administration closed the border on Salem-Kochi bypass road exactly at 6pm and vehicles were not allowed to enter the district. Similarly, all roads leading to inter-state borders were blocked at 6pm.

The district administration, meanwhile, warned to book people, who violate Section 144, under the epidemic diseases act. It said the objective of imposing Section 144 was to maintain social distancing and take precautions to contain Covid-19.

City police commissioner Sumit Sharan said only a maximum of five people could gather at one place. “They have to tell us the purpose. If anyone is deliberately coming out of houses to roam around the city, we will book them under relevant sections of law.”

On his part, collector K Rajamani appealed the public to extent their cooperation to implement Section 144 effectively in the district. “Violators will be booked under the Epidemic Diseases Act, 1897. Medical shops should not sell face masks and hand sanitizers at a high price. If they do, shop owners will be booked under the act and their licence will be cancelled.”

Title: Madurai: Families bond over boards, cards to kill time
Content: MADURAI: As people are being urged to stay indoors to prevent the spread of Covid-19, the demand for board and card games has gone up. Enterprising shops too have seized the opportunity to cash in on the situation by keeping ready enough stocks in the last few days.``When we were kids, we would sit down for a game of cards after dad came back from work, mostly after dinner every day,’’ said T Kumar of Anna Nagar . But he rues that such habits had become forgotten today as children rarely find time to leave their phones and get family time.Parents say they are thinking of ways to ensure the participation of everybody at home. Poornima of Anna Nagar said they had bought board games such as scrabble, ludo and monopoly. ``This is the first time we are actually buying games which we can play together and not just gift them to others. Besides, these games are great stress-busters,’’ she said. Many young parents have found that they did not know the rules of several of these board games as well as their parents did. Hence, these games end up as contests between children and grandparents in many homes.Some small shops which opened on Tuesday saw people enquiring about cards such as UNO and the regular as well as ordinary cards. ``We don’t keep more than five packs at a time but they were all sold out last week,’’ said Thirupathy , a shopkeeper in K K Nagar. ``I didn’t know my grandfather could play games so well. He is a master at carrom and beat all of us on all the days we played,’’ said 16-year-old Sudhesh for whom his 80-year-old grandfather’s finger strength came as a revelation.Children are also into colouring together and pulling out jigsaw puzzles from their cupboards in many homes. Mohan Raj, owner of Freak Sports in Madurai , said he had sold 200 carom boards in three days.``Usually we sell about 30 boards per month but now there is a boom in sales. Since I also make boards, I have been able to supply them, but other shops have run out of stock,’’ he said.On Tuesday, a consignment of 60 boards came to the shop in the morning of which 58 were sold off like hot cakes by evening. There was also a demand for games like ludo, business and the traditional game of ‘palanguli’ according to him.

Title: Delhi News: Police car helps dialysis patient reach hospital in time
Content:
Ashok Goyal

NEW DELHI: It was a race against time for a 64-year old man who urgently needed to be taken to a hospital for a dialysis. Ashok Goyal, a resident of northeast Delhi’s Vijay Park lived alone. One Tuesday morning, he tried to catch a bus to reach the hospital but failed. After he was unable to get an ambulance either, a policeman helped him receive the treatment.

Speaking to TOI, Ashok Goyal said, “I have been a dialysis patient for the last six years. Thrice a week I need to go for dialysis to Rajiv Gandhi Super Speciality hospital in Tahirpur.”

He said that the patrol cops were asking people to stay indoors at the bus stop. “I was carrying my medical bag and showed my papers to them. However, in the meantime the bus left before I could board it,” he said. “I sat on the edge of a footpath and called 112 for an ambulance.

Goyal said he waited for over an hour but the ambulance never came. “As I can’t afford to miss my sessions, I panicked. Some media people also tried calling ambulance for me but to no avail,” he said.

A call to DCP northeast Ved Prakash Surya, however, showed results. Additional DCP Sukant Ballabh was patrolling the area and immediately reached Goyal. The patient reached the hospital in time in the cop’s car.

“I am grateful to police for saving me in this need of hour.” added Goyal. Chief minister Arvind Kejriwal also appreciated the efforts of the police officer and praised him on Twitter.

Title: Relief balm: UP government sends Rs 1,000 each to 20 lakh daily wagers
Content:
Representative image

LUCKNOW: As the lockdown in UP became more stringent and the administration strictly enforced closure of non-essential services, the government initiated the disbursal of Rs 1,000 as financial aid to more than 35 lakh daily wage labourers in the state under Shramik Bharan-Poshan Yojana.

On Tuesday, funds were transferred to the accounts of more than 20 lakh people, the account details of whom were available with the government.

There are 20.37 lakh people registered with the labour department and the government is in the process of collecting bank account details of the remaining 37,000. For the remaining 15 lakh who are not in the government’s records, like rickshaw pullers, street vendors, e-rickshaw drivers, hawkers among others, the urban development department has been directed to collect details. It will also help opening accounts for those who do not have accounts. A budget of Rs 203 crore has been sanctioned for the financial assistance project under the UP Buildings and other Construction Workers Welfare Board ’s Disaster Relief Assistance Scheme for registered construction workers.

Free ration, including 20 kg wheat and 15 kg rice, is to be provided free to over 1.65 crore beneficiaries of the Antyodaya scheme such as destitute old age pensioners, people with disability pensioners, construction workers and daily wage workers. The CM said the distribution of foodgrains should start at the earliest. He added that payment of the quarterly pension to be given to 83.83 lakh beneficiaries of the old age, disability and widow pension schemes should be started preferably by March end.

For those not covered by any of these schemes, the district magistrates have been asked to set up committees, both at the urban and rural level, to consider their cases individually for payment of Rs 1,000. Money from the disaster relief fund will be used for this scheme.

Title: Challenge is motivate people to stay indoors
Content:
District collector, Tarun Pithode

Bhopal: District collector, Tarun Pithode has his hands full ever since the surge of CoVID-19 in India and subsequent detection of a Coronavirus patient in Bhopal. His cellphone keeps ringing all the time - from superior officers to politicians to common man- he is responding to all with a hope that hard work by his team would be able to prevent spread of Coronavirus in Bhopal and in effect the entire state. Pithode took time off to talk to Ashutosh Shukla on challenges he is facing now and how he is coping up with it:

Q. What are the challenges you are facing while trying to contain spread of Coronavirus?

My biggest challenge is to motivate people to stay indoors and not to come out of their houses. They need to know it is for their safety that curfew or lockdown has been imposed and they must cooperate with the administration and the police.

Q. I am sure you have never been through this kind of situation before. How are you coping with it?

A. Yes. But it is our job. Monitoring so much of manpower and material being used to bring the situation under control is quite a task, but I am happy that people in place of talking to helpline no. are talking to me. You won't believe it, my mobile was charged seven times a day in the past couple of days.

Q. Do you want to say anything to people?

A. I want to tell people forcefully, "Don't ask for exemption. Stay at home.”

Q. Where do you see the situation heading from here?

A. I feel, if the people show self-discipline and observe the protocol they are being told, the situation may become normal soon. But if they are not serious about it, the situation may also worsen. I hope with the cooperation of people we shall be able to overcome the Coronavirus threat soon.

Title: Madurai corporation teams disinfect area
Content:
Representative image

MADURAI: Teams from the Madurai corporation disinfected public areas in Nellai Street in Anna Nagar , from where the 54-year-old man , who tested positive for Covid-19 , hails from .

Officials said that teams swung into action on Monday night onwards to gather details of events, where he and his family members attended and the places he visited in the last fortnight. Meanwhile, teams put in place on Tuesday morning disinfected the entire street consisting of around 60 houses. “Ever since the news broke out, people residing in the street became extremely anxious. They have now gone into self-quarantine. All the residents extended cooperation when we approached them and the front portion of all houses were disinfected using Lysol. Bleaching powder was sprayed on the entire street,” a health official from the corporation said.Apart from the street, all the mosques he visited, especially the one at Anna Nagar East Street, where he used to pray regularly, and his office have been completely disinfected, officials said.Meanwhile, around 200 places, including bus terminals, markets, hospitals and other crowded areas are being disinfected on a regular basis throughout Madurai.

Title: Uttarakhand HC, other courts in state to remain shut till April 4
Content: NAINITAL: As Prime Minister Narendra Modi announced a 21-day nationwide lockdown to combat Covid-19 pandemic, the Uttarakhand High Court HC ) as well as all the subordinate courts in the state will remain shut from Wednesday till April 4.Two notifications, signed by the registrar general, were issued on Monday. The first notification said that the HC has declared March 26, 27, 30, 31 and April 1 as holidays as a step to prevent the spread of coronavirus . While March 28 and 29 are weekend, the court already has April 2 and 3 as holidays for Ram Navami. The second notification, meanwhile, said that all the subordinate courts in the stage will be closed from Wednesday till April 4.“Having considered the safety measures already taken by High Court of Uttarakhand to combat the impending threat of Covid-19… and in view of requests of Bar Associations in this regard, Hon'ble High Court of Uttarakhand is pleased to close all the Subordinate Courts of the state w.e.f. 26th of March till 04.04.2020,” the second notification read.Meanwhile, the HC has said that cases of utmost importance will continue to be heard and it will be on the district judge to decide the urgency. The notification added that since the courts will remain closed during this period, pending work shall be completed during coming summer and winter vacations.The decision to completely shut the high court and all the other courts comes just days after the high court had issued a series of directions to be followed within the high court premises.

Title: Allow staff to come to work, rlys to cops, admin
Content:
Bareilly: With a curfew-like situation prevailing in most parts of the country to thwart spread of coronavirus, railway officials have asked district administrations and police to allow staff to come to work . It is a 24-hour service and requires all staff to report to work. While passenger trains have been cancelled, the freight trains are running to supply foodgrain, coal, milk, vegetables and other essentials across the country.

Freight trains are running faster than their usual speed, said general manager of North Central Railway (NCR) and Northern Railway (NR) Rajeev Chaudhary in video message on Tuesday. He said, “In order to keep services operational, hundreds of thousands employees of the Indian Railways are working day and night to ensure that movement of essential supplies are not hampered and life of common man is not made more difficult. Passenger trains have been stopped only to promote social distancing to curb the virus from spreading in the community.”

Additional divisional manager, Moradabad division of Northern Railway, Maan Singh Meena said he has written to district authorities, asking them to allow railway staff to reach their place of work without any hassles due to the lockdown in many districts. He said since all passenger trains have stopped running, police are under the impression that there is no work for the railway staff. “Railways is working 24x7. Goods trains are still running and in order to maintain traffic movement and other related work, all railway employees are on duty,” he clarified.

ARDM Meena said, “This is creating a problem at the field level as police and administration officials in the field don't get to read circulars and they believe that as all train services have been stopped so railways requires only a skeleton staff.”

Title: Rythu bazaars to sell veggies in open spaces
Content:
Visakhapatnam: To manage the rush of buyers at various rythu bazaars in the city, the sale of vegetables would be held at grounds adjacent to the bazaars. The decision is likely to help in maintaining distance between those who are standing in the queues.

K Kannababu , minister for agriculture, and M Srinivasa Rao , minister for tourism, said the government has asked the marketing department to shift the sales to grounds after reviewing the situation and looking at video footages.

The ministers told reporters that the government was looking at the feasibility of holding sales in only 50% of stalls to maintain social distance. “All essential commodities would be available for public. If anybody increases prices or hoards commodities, then the licences would be cancelled and action would be taken,” they said.

The city has 13 raithu bazaars, a wholesale market at Jnanapuram and a direct sale market at Anandapuram.

Title: Day 2 of lockdown in Uttarakhand sees strict implementation
Content: DEHRADUN: Day after witnessing lukewarm response to the lockdown order where people came out in large numbers on streets, state police on Tuesday swung into action and strictly enforced the prohibitory order as the hill state entered the second day of nine-day lockdown.Shops selling essential items remained open only for 3 hours from 7 to 10 am on Tuesday after which all vehicles were prohibited from plying on roads and people were not allowed to venture out without any pressing reasons.Private vehicles were off the roads while all business establishments, barring those dealing with essential commodities, remained shut. Police personnel were seen asking people who had come out to stay indoors.In Dehradun , police, on Tuesday, arrested five persons under section 151 of CrPC for violating the orders, while 47 have been booked under section 188 of Indian Penal Code (IPC). Besides, 236 vehicles were challaned under Motor Vehicles Act, whereas 77 vehicles were seized.Roorkee police also arrested two persons, including a senior official of Bhim Army political, in connection with disobeying the lockdown norms. Police did not allow by vehicular movement on the streets of Roorkee.According to Ashok Kumar, director general (DG) law and order, “the whole state has been distributed in 102 zones and 500 sectors for effective implementation of lockdown order. On Monday, the first day of the lockdown, police registered 55 cases and arrested 160 people across the state.”Kumar added that almost 6000 police personnel and additional 20 companies of Provincial Armed Constabulary (PAC) have been deployed in Uttarakhand for enforcing the lockdown order in true letter and spirit.(With inputs from Tapan Susheel)

Title: Bareilly traffic cops issue 2k challans, recover Rs 13k from motorists for violating lockdown
Content:
Bareilly: Police on Tuesday issued 2,468 challans to motorists for violating lockdown guidelines in the city, recovering Rs 13,400 as fines in the process. According to information received, vehicle users who were caught unnecessarily loitering on streets despite the curfew, were intercepted by police and issued challans on spot under Section 179 (disobedience of orders, obstruction and refusal of information) of the Motor Vehicles (MV) Act. On Monday, around 2,000 vehicles spotted plying on roads were checked by police and around 540 challans were issued.

Speaking to TOI, SP (traffic) Subhash Chandra Gangwar said, “Police has been deputed across the city to disperse people spotted venturing during the lockdown, while traffic police personnel have been deployed at prime locations to book violators. On Tuesday, a number of vehicle users were checked and 2,468 challans issued under Section 179 of Motor Vehicles Act, recovering Rs 13,400 as fine. On Monday, 540 challans were issued and Rs 21,000 recovered in fines.”

Residents found stepping outside without any concrete reason are being informed to adhere to guidelines issued for lockdown. Warnings are being issued to everyone that police will continue to initiate legal action against violators in case of non-compliance, said traffic police officials.

Title: Telangana govt departments to work with 20% strength
Content: HYDERABAD: The state has issued orders directing government employees to work on rotation during lockdown to ensure that the government’s efforts to control the spread of coronavirus goes on smoothly, while ensuring the safety of employees and all citizens.The decision may be subject to change with the Prime Minister calling for a complete lockdown until mid-April.Chief secretary Somesh Kumar issued the orders for preventive measures to contain the spread of Covid-19 in government offices.While all employees of police, medical, health, electricity, water supply and other essential services-related departments have to attend to their duties without fail, only 20 percent of employees of non-emergency departments will attend to duties daily on a rotation basis.However, the remaining 80 percent of employees should be available to the government on phone, mail, electronic and other possible means, and should stay put in their respective district headquarters, in case the government required their services at any hour. They should attend to their duties as and when called. And it would be ensured that these government employees maintain three to five feet distance between each other at work place and take all sanitisation measures to prevent spread of coronavirus. The chief secretary has directed senior IAS officers to ensure the rotation happens smoothly.

Title: UP MPs, MLAs join hands, donate development funds for prevention against Covid-19
Content: LUCKNOW: Joining battle against coronavirus , scores of public representatives across Uttar Pradesh have offered to donate from their local area development funds to support preventive measures.Some of them have specified that the fund could be used to support the poor and needy who have limited means to sustain themselves. Deputy CM Keshav Prasad Maurya and energy minister Shrikant Sharma pledged Rs 1 crore for preventive measures and procurement of gloves and sanitisers.Ambedkarnagar MP Ritesh Pandey announced Rs 50 lakh to the district magistrate contingency fund while Mirzapur MP Anupriya Patel and Unnao MP Sakshi Maharaj committed Rs 25 lakh each for relief work. Minister of state for basic education Satish Chandra Dwivedi provided Rs 25 lakh to CM’s relief fund and donated a month’s salary.Parliamentarian from Basti Harish Dwivedi and MLA from Saiyadraja seat in Chandauli promised Rs 20 lakh each.MLAs Gorakhnath Baba (Milkipur), Shailendra Yadav Lalai (Shahganj in Jaunpur), Sangeeta Yadav (Chauri Chaura in Gorakhpur), Chaudhary Amar Singh (Shohratgarh in Siddharthnagar), Ajay Kumar Lallu (Tamkuhi Raj in Kushinagar) and MLC from Amethi Deepak Singh donated Rs 10 lakh each to their districts.UPPCS Association has urged members to donate Rs 1,000 each to CM relief fund.

Title: Lockdown is for your own safety: DIG Wali
Content:
TOI Conversation D.I.G Irshad Wali PICS: Rajeev Sarathe

Bhopal: Just after hectic duty due to the high-voltage political crisis in Bhopal, which lingered on for around three weeks, city cops were pressed into relentless service to enforce restrictions amid the Covid-19 outbreak that led to the ‘janata curfew’, followed by a total lockdown and curfew.

TOI talked to DIG Irshad Wali over the extraordinary situation. Excerpts from the interview

Q: Although you are known to be a workaholic, what are your present working hours?

DIG Wali: My working hours are not fixed. I start working since 6am and am engaged till 2.30am at night. I monitor the situation across the city and give necessary instructions. People do not understand that the lockdown is for their own safety. Despite the lockdown, many Bhopalis are hell-bent on coming out and also seek every facility.

Q: You meet a lot of people during the day and are exposed to health risks. How do you manage yourself?

DIG Wali: One has to deal with it. I change my clothes and take a thorough bath as soon as I reach home.

Q: There are reports that you stayed at the police control room the whole night. Is it true?

DIG Wali: Yes. On Sunday night Bhopal district collector Tarun Pithode and I decided to stay at the police control room. If police and administration get information of a single coronavirus positive case entering the city by flight or any other route, they need to plan accordingly.

Q: What measures have been taken to avoid infection of the deadly coronavirus among the police force?

DIG Wali: We planned it around 7-8 days back, even before the advisories were issued before the lockdown and placed sanitizers at police stations. Masks have been provided to the police staff. Efforts are on to provide them sanitizers and masks individually once again. I myself briefed the force on precautions to be taken to avoid the deadly infection.

Q: Cops were already stressed due to the rigorous law and order duty during the recent political crisis in the state and are now enforcing a curfew. How do you plan to rotate the staff?

DIG Wali: Definitely, the staff is stressed, and we have asked for additional force from the police headquarters. Police is one department which only gets criticism. We try to motivate our staff. People try to find fault in us. If policemen enforce lockdown, ask for papers, they are severely criticised. People should take this unprecedented situation positively. It is a matter of life and death. People move out of their homes for silly reasons — just to take a glance at the empty roads during curfew. People should understand that the energy of police staff is also limited, and they get frustrated after a certain point of time.

Title: Covid-19: Pilibhit pvt docs suspend OPD service till further orders
Content:
Pilibhit: In order to control the spread of Covid-19, the district unit of Indian Medical Association (IMA) on Tuesday decided to suspend the OPD services at private nursing homes, clinics and hospitals owned by IMA associated doctors with immediate effect.

The IMA doctors would, however, tend to emergency cases.

A letter in this reference was issued jointly by IMA’s district president, Dr Tarun Sethi and secretary, Dr Deepak Gangwar.

“Our decision is in compliance with the state government’s directions. We feel that around 9,000 to 10,000 patients, who were being served by 80 private medical institutions of IMA doctors in district, may face difficulty due to suspension of OPD services, but we will be serving the nation by averting the gathering of thousands of people in a bid to prevent the spread of novel coronavirus at the same time”, said Dr Deepak Gangwar.

Title: Lockdown in India: 5,146 held in Delhi for defying lockdown, 1,018 vehicles seized
Content: NEW DELHI: Police enforced the lockdown in the capital strictly on Tuesday, detaining 5,146 people and registering 299 cases against them for flouting prohibitory orders. Cops said 1,018 vehicles were seized from across the city under the Delhi Police Act.Enforcement is expected to get stricter from Wednesday, after Prime Minister Narendra Modi announced a 21-day lockdown across the country. Besides detaining people, the cops had also been ordered to seize vehicles found running not only on the main roads, but also within the colonies.Police also conducted checks for speeding and dangerous driving after complaints that a lot of people speeding on empty roads in south and south-west Delhi. Police said most violators were youngsters out on twowheelers to “check the situation” around the city. They were stopped and detained at the check posts or apprehended during surprise checks in the colonies. A few shopkeepers in west Delhi were also detained for selling non-essential items. When detected to be driving aimlessly on the arterial stretches, people were forced to return home.Having announced that crossing the borders into Delhi from neighbouring states would require curfew passes, Delhi Police set up a single window at the offices of the designated deputy commissioners of police. By 5pm on Tuesday, 2,319 vehicle passes had been issued. An enquiry counter at the DCPs’ office cleared doubts about the curfew passes, which contain the name, designation, organisation and contact number of the holder.The applicants were made to sign a declaration that the passes allowing interborder movement would not be transferred to others. They were also informed that the passes would work in conjunction with their identity cards. Police officers said it was mostly media professionals and owners of food delivery companies and pharmacies that collected the passes on Tuesday. Enforcing the ban on entry of vehicles into Delhi, police carried out strict checks at the border posts and other check points.They used drones and conducted surprise patrols to swoop on people gathering at roadsides or near markets. In order to facilitate movement of vehicles carrying essential supplies, the cops created a separate lane on the roads entering the city, especially from Noida and Faridabad. Officers said there initially were problems about the passage of medicines, food items and newspapers, but these were resolved during the day.

Title: Fair at Pilibhit temple cancelled
Content:
Pilibhit: In a break from tradition, a fair held at Yashwantari temple, dedicated to Goddess Durga, during Chaitra Navratri, has been cancelled this year by the district authorities due to the outbreak of coronavirus. The chief priest of the temple, Mahant Rajesh Bajpayi, has also given his consent to decision.

More than four lakh devotees from across UP and Uttarakhand visit the Yashwantari temple during navratri to offer prayers to the Goddess.

“We have obtained the consent of temple management for the suspension of the fair for common welfare of the people,“ said DMVaibhav, Shrivastav.

Temple management’s Bajpayi told TOI that bookings of over 200 stalls, a giant wheel and swings were cancelled and the booking amount was reimbursed to persons concerned.

“The entire world is facing a crisis created by the novel coronavirus this time. Keeping in view the safety of devotees from this highly communicable pandemic, there was no other option but to cancel the fair,” Bajpayi added.

For the same reason, the gates of the 250-year-old Gauri Shankar temple of Lord Shiv were closed on Tuesday for devotees.

Title: Hyderabad: Flat buyers knock NCLT’s door, want Emaar to hand over villas
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: More than 100 flat owners have approached the National Company Law Tribunal (NCLT), Hyderabad, urging it to declare Emaar Hills Township Project Ltd insolvent by initiating corporate insolvency process against the company.

They believe this is the only way-out to make Emaar company deliver their villas and flats at Gachibowli as promised. The dream project of several home buyers a decade ago later turned into a major scam with CBI arresting several accused in the case, including IAS officers.

T Sudhakar, counsel for the home buyers, said the wait has become too much and they have now approached the tribunal seeking a direction to Emaar to complete construction and hand over the villas. CBI and the Enforcement Directorate unearthed the Rs 100-crore scam and narrated how the tainted money had gone into the hands of certain individuals with fictitious companies.

It may be recalled CBI, which probed the deal, filed a chargesheet in the trial court charging Emaar-MGF chief Sravan Gupta along with kingpin Koneru Rajendra Prasad with turning the project into a huge scam. Many of the buyers were NRIs, who invested crorers of rupees to own villas. The other accused were Vijay Raghava and Sunil Reddy of South-end Projects. Dubai-based Emaar PJSC had originally entered into an agreement with the then Andhra Pradesh government to develop villas, but later allowed firms like MGF to use its name. The charge against the IAS officers was that they allowed 500 acres of government property in Gachibowli to go into the hands of players like MGF which committed fraud. Gupta, who obtained a conditional permission from the CBI court to go abroad, has gone absconding in the last five years. Senior counsel P Venugopal, who appeared for Emaar, sought transfer of all Emaar cases to one bench.

With NCLT also beset with coronavirus scare, sources said the Emaar case is likely to be heard at a later stage.

Title: Government projects likely to slow down in Coimbatore
Content: COIMBATORE: Some of the government projects that are being implemented in the district is likely to slow down after the announcement of 21-day nationwide lockdown by the Prime Minister and enforcement of Section 144 of the CrPC by the state government till March 31 in view of Covid-19 pandemic.The highways department is constructing flyovers at multiple places including Ramanathapuram , Ukkadam, GN Mills, Kavundampalayam and Periyanaickenpalayam in the district.A senior official from the department said, “As these are major projects in the district, we would be continuing the construction work.
