Samarpal, a vendor in Laxmi Nagar, accused the cops, both of Delhi and UP, of asking for bribes to be allowed to sell vegetables.The owner of Kajal General Store in south Delhi’s Old JNU campus glumly said that he hasn’t been able to refill depleted stocks. “Forget about delivering supplies, the wholesale agents are not even releasing stocks even when you pay for them in advance. There is not one pack of flour in this whole area,” he said.SB Tripathi, a Supreme Court lawyer, grumbled, “Shopkeepers in Dwarka are selling vegetables at elevated price. Ladyfinger, earlier costing Rs 80/kg, is now selling for Rs 120.” Gaurav Singh, a resident of Shankar Vihar, added darkly, “People are hoarding and this is not how it should be.”Many have managed to buy essentials to last a few days, but are worried about the future. “Though we have adequate groceries at home, I thought of stocking up on meat and fish for the week,” revealed Sheikh Sarai resident Jayanta Ghosh. “But when I called the meat shop, the owner said supply had stopped and he wasn't sure when he could reopen his shop.”It’s not just grocers and vegetable sellers who are affected. Sandeep Nangia, who heads the Delhi Chemists’ Association, said members had complained of police beating them for being on the streets. He requested senior officers to instruct the policemen on the roads to check identity cards before taking action.Perhaps because of hassles of this sort, some medicine stores remained closed on Wednesday. Amrita Chugh in Karol Bagh said, “Uneasy about what would happen in the next few day, I decided to buy some medicines. But the shop nearby was closed. If it continues to stay shut, how will we make it through the lockdown period?”Deliveries of online orders of essential goods and food items have also been hit. Siddhant Wangdi, who runs an online meat business, stopped deliveries across the National Capital Region because of lack of clarity in the lockdown guidelines. “Ground staff have been sent home from the roads and delivery executives have also been hit,” he disclosed. Big Basket released a statement saying it was “not operational due to restrictions imposed by local authorities on movement of goods in spite of clear guidelines provided by central authorities to enable essential services”.

Title: Kerala: No decline in liquor sale, may overtake February figures
Content:
Excise officials said that with the closure of bars, the sale of liquor in Bevco outlets is expected to soar i... Read More

KOCHI: Even though people prefer to stay at home over the past few weeks due to the spread of Covid-19, the sale of liquor and beer in Ernakulam has not seen much of a decline.

Figures show that the Kerala State Beverages Corporation (KSBC) outlets and bars that take the supply from the three KSBC warehouses in the district — Tripunithura, Aluva and Vengola — have together sold 13.67 lakh litres of Indian Made Foreign Liquor (IMFL) and 10.62 lakh litres of beer during March 1-22 compared to 20.55 lakh litres of IMFL and 13.86 lakh litres of beer during February 1-29. As per the data, there is an average daily sale of 7,086 litres of IMFL and 4,779 litres of beer in February compared to the daily sale average of 6,213 litres of IMFL and 4,827 litres of beer in March.

This means there was only a decline of daily sale of around 800 litres of IMFL and an increase of around 50 litres of beer in March compared to that in February.

According to KSBC officials, with the new restrictions regarding queuing in front of outlets, closure of bars and the fear of possible shutdown of KSBC outlets in the coming days, people have started panic-buying of liquor and beer too, hence could easily overtake the overall sales of February by the end of March.

“Almost all outlets in the district witnessed steady sale even after the government brought in restriction in queuing. People are coming to outlets twice or thrice daily to buy bottles in bulk quantities. With seven more days to go in March, it will easily break the sales in February when there were no restrictions,” said a KSBC official.

Excise officials said that with the closure of bars, the sale of bottles in Bevco outlets will see a soaring high in the coming days. “Though government has asked people to stay at home, many are going out to buy liquor. Even police won’t stop them when they say they are going to the KSBC outlets,” said a senior excise official.

Meanwhile, officers said that many toddy shops have decided to stop operations. “Though toddy shops have not been asked to shut, many of the owners are closing them on their own,” said an officer.

Title: Lockdown-hit elderly struggle for groceries, medicines
Content:
Representative image

BENGALURU: Rumi Basu, 63, visited a bank on Tuesday morning only to be turned back. The staff advised her to use online banking as they have been instructed to minimise face-to-face interaction. “But I don’t know how to go about it. People of my generation are not tech-savvy,” said a clueless Rumi.

In the wake of the Covid-19 pandemic, senior citizens like Rumi are facing several concerns. Many who live alone are unable to keep up with the mad rush for groceries that the city witnessed on Tuesday and Wednesday.

“Several shops were closed. Those that were open were too crowded. Some of them like Hopcoms functioned during irregular hours depending on the arrival of fruits and vegetables. It became extremely difficult for senior citizens to get even basic necessities. Many pharmacies ran out of medicines . Many elderly persons can’t make rounds of shops, shoving crowds or walking long distances,” said Santhosh Abraham, who runs a social enterprise called ElderAid Wellness. Santosh said there’s a spike in calls seeking help from his organisation.

Senior citizens are among the worst affected, said Mahita Nagaraj, a digital marketing professional who is a caremonger now. “We have received calls from elderly patients who need to undergo dialysis saying they have been unable to arrange transport to hospital. There are others whose home nurses did not turn up,” said Mahiya.

“My domestic help has not been coming for two days now. It’s not easy for a healthy adult to run a home without the maid. So you can imagine my situation,” said 66-year-old Nalini V, who stays with her 70-year-old husband in Nandini Layout.

Susheela Venkat, who lives in an apartment complex on Cambridge Road, said the children of several senior citizens stay in different parts of the country and the world. “They are concerned not just about themselves but about their children as well. We are keeping a regular check on them. We have a group of youngsters running errands for them,” she said.

“Many senior citizens, including several of my friends, are worried about contracting the disease. We fear if there is acute shortage of medical facilities, we may not be top priority for doctors and will be left to our destiny,” added Rumi.

Even their routines have taken a hit. “It’s difficult to pass time now. We used to go for a morning walk every day, sit on the benches in the neighbourhood park, have coffee with friends at the local darshini and again get together for a chat in the evening. Now, parks are closed and so are darshinis,” said Siddappa Shankar, a retired medical officer.

Title: Karnataka: Session cut short amid Covid-19 scare; budget passed in absence of opposition
Content: BENGALURU: The budget session of the legislature was cut short on Tuesday in the midst of growing concerns about the Covid-19 pandemic. Speaker Vishweshwara Hegde Kageri adjourned the session sine die after the house passed the budget for 2020-21.The budget session was scheduled till March 31. However, members of the opposition and treasury benches urged the government to curtail it in the wake of the lockdown enforced in a bid to curb the spread of Covid-19. The issue was discussed in the business advisory committee (BAC) meeting convened by the speaker on Monday where Congress members urged the government to suspend the session immediately, but the ruling party stuck to its guns that it would be adjourned only after chief minister BS Yediyurappa replies to the budget debate on Tuesday.While the Congress boycotted the assembly session on Tuesday, members of JD(S) walked out protesting the government’s rejection to hold a discussion on an alleged scam in a cooperative society. The house passed the appropriation bill and approved demand for grants in the absence of the opposition after Yediyurappa replied to the debate.“It is undemocratic on the part of the ruling party, which chose to pass the budget when the entire opposition stayed away. We wanted the government to pass a vote-on-account for three or four months before suspending the session and seek approval for the full budget later when the house is reassembled. But the government did not heed our plea as it didn’t want to accommodate the views of the opposition,” said leader of opposition Siddaramaiah.

Title: 35,000 Amreli natives return home from Surat, Mumbai
Content:
Labourers who started from Ahmedabad on Monday morning reached Sabarkantha on Tuesday

Rajkot/Palanpur: Villages across Gujarat, particularly in Saurashtra is seeing a sudden back flow of people who are fleeing the cities in the wake of Coronavirus and more from the lockdown. As many as 35 ,000 people from Surat and Mumbai, those mostly engaged in the diamond industry, started to pour into Amreli in the past one week after businesses and industry started shutting down.

Talking to TOI, Amreli district collector Ayush Oak said, “Nearly 35,000 people returned to Amreli district in the past one week. We have created checkposts and screened everybody before they entered into the district.”

According to the district administration, 99 people had a travel history of foreign countries, while 38 had flu-like symptoms and have been ordered home quarantine for two weeks.

Kamal Patel, a diamond worker, who returned to Abhrampara of Savarkundla taluka on March 21 said, “We were jobless as the industry has shutdown in Surat. We are also scared of contracting Coronavirus. So we decided to come back to native for a few days.”

According to sources, with every taluka of Amreli district seeing people rush in, in private vehicles, there is a heavy traffic jam on the roads connected to Amreli.

A private bus operator who runs between Surat and Amreli said, “There was a heavy rush of people coming to Amreli last week. But even buses have stopped now.”

Bhupendrasinh Jadeja, sarpanch of Dhulia Domla village of Lodhika taluka in Rajkot district said that he hasn’t seen so many people during Diwali festival coming to their native. “I feel that it’s the rebirth of villages,” Jadeja added.

However, after the lockdown, all the districts have sealed their borders, even for private vehicles. This has actually made the scene pathetic for many unprivileged people, who had no option but to walk long distances as their employers shut shop asking them to leave at once.

Title: Lockdown: Bitter pill but better cure
Content:
Representative image

K Sri Sai, an electric engineer from Prakasam district, AP, who is currently in Hyderabad narrates his experience during lockdown

It is a strange experience for some of us students and jobholders from India, who were in Wuhan when the lockdown was first announced there. We have been experiencing lockdowns and a strict quarantine for 15 days in Gurugram (in February) when we returned from China. In a way, we have lived in isolation in the past two months and it is likely to continue for another 21 days. This is the time to maintain restraint and keep clam.

If China has controlled the virus, it is because of the public and government cooperation. People were not disturbed even though they were given the option of coming out of the house once in a week and one person in a family was allowed. The apartment main doors would be closed. We were confined to our rooms with no outside connection. Doctors used to monitor temperature twice in a week.

The isolation, in fact, brought many of us together. We were working from our rooms but built close bonding with many people. My roommate got into a depression, worried over the developments. All of us got together and consoled him. Now, we have become good friends.

The isolation definitely is a bitter pill but offers better cure. After attending to our office duty, we would chalk out a plan. We dowloaded many e-books and tried to gain knowledge on coronavirus.

(As told to Sribala Vadlapatla)

Title: Goa CM Pramod Sawant assures supply of essential items to those in need
Content: PANAJI: Hours before Prime Minister Narendra Modi announced that India would be under lockdown for 21 days as a precautionary measure against the spread of Covid-19 , chief minister Pramod Sawant extended the state’s curfew deadline from Wednesday to March 31.His announcement came a day after his government announced a relaxation of five hours every morning till March 25 for people to buy essential supplies. Sawant said that “although there is no positive case of Covid-19 yet, it doesn’t mean there are no coronavirus patients in the state”.“A 100% lockdown and 100% curfew is being ordered under the Epidemic Diseases Act,” Sawant said, adding that he expects the public to cooperate.“We can live without milk and food for some time, but we have to be united to fight coronavirus,” Sawant said. “Coronavirus is in Goa, but till date, it has not been reported...Only if we observe this lockdown till March 31 can we remain safe.” He also said that community transfer of coronavirus hasn’t taken place in Goa.The latest government decision was taken during an all-party meet.Sawant said that the government is concerned about the supply of essential commodities, and that within the next three days, arrangements would be made to supply the same to people in need. “The collector will put in place a system through which essential commodities like rice, dal and oil can reach people in need,” he said. He also said that ATMs of nationalised banks would be allowed to function, and that “if possible”, Goa Dairy’s milk centre would offer home delivery of milk.Speaking to reporters, Sawant said that no shops would be open from Wednesday onwards, and that only emergency services of the government would be operational. He also said that pharmacies would be kept open.“I know that people will be inconvenienced and face difficulties, but we have to bear it in the interest of our health,” Sawant said. He also said that people do not understand the severity of Covid-19 “When the market opened today (Tuesday), people did not maintain distance from one another,” he said.The CM also said that outpatient departments (OPDs) will be closed in primary health centres and other centres, but casualty facilities would be kept open. “I urge people not to visit hospitals to check their blood pressure and fever,” he said. “Only in emergency cases people should visit the hospital.”Sawant also said that police will act against those who do not adhere to curfew restrictions. “Police will stop people at various points,” he said. A high-level committee has been formed under the CM’s chairmanship, and the cabinet has given it all powers to take any decision with respect to Covid-19.Meanwhile, the government has received over 1,000 messages on the WhatsApp number it circulated so that the public could inform it about Covid-19 suspects in their locality, and over 500 people have already been home-quarantined. “I urge the people not to come out of their houses and stop the spread of community transmission,” Sawant said.The state government has already closed its border. However, the CM said that anyone who has entered the state, even if healthy, can spread Covid-19. “Those who travelled to Goa during the past eight days should home quarantine themselves,” he said. “They should visit Goa Medical College to check if they have any coronavirus symptoms. If they don’t quarantine themselves, we will force them to.”Sawant also urged people to inform the government about people who recently entered Goa. “One person can transmit Covid-19 to three persons,” he said.Meanwhile, the government has said that the state had three suspected Covid-19 patients, who were serious, but have recovered. “Doctors feel that they can’t be Covid-19 patients,” he said. People should not fall prey to rumours concerning coronavirus, Sawant said. “If we maintain community distance, only then can we stop the transmission of the disease.”

Title: Muzaffarnagar administration takes slew of measures to check Covid-19
Content: MEERUT: Muzaffarnagar police and administration swung into action and took a host of measures to check the spread of coronavirus in the district after a man tested positive for the contagious disease in neighbouring Kairana district.District magistrate (DM) Selva Kumari directed all village heads to immediately inform the authority about people who have come from outside the country. While SSP Abhishek Yadav has appealed to people to not to visit police stations for any case and register their complaints over phone.Speaking to TOI, SSP Yadav said, “We have issued a helpline number, 9690112112, on which any individual can call and register his complaint. He can also send his written complaint on WhatsApp . Proper action will be taken on that including police visit at the site. The whole exercise is to minimize assembling of people at one place.”Health department too has initiated a door-to-door exercise of checking suspect patients in villages. “We are not leaving anything to chance. Our 12 teams comprising doctors and paramedic staff are conducting door-to-door checking in villages to ensure there is no case anywhere. Special care is being taken of families where any member has recently arrived either from abroad or a different state.”

Title: Lockdown in UP brings some relief to sugar mills, farmers
Content:
Representative image

BIJNOR: In the wake of the coronavirus scare, UP government has given the nod to relax lockdown norms for sugar mills, distilleries and cane farmers .

Accepting some demands of the Uttar Pradesh Sugar Mills Association, UP government has permitted them to procure raw material like sulphur and lime from Rajasthan to process cane into sugar and deliver the products derived from cane to markets.

According to sources, most of the 119 mills in the state had virtually run out of raw material to process 2.5 crore tonnes of yet-to-be harvested standing cane crop. In this context, the sugar association had written to the government, demanding that cane harvesting should continue and labourers be allowed into the fields and sugar mills.

The association pointed out that due to the lockdown, sale of petrol had fallen and so would the sale ethanol. So it sought an increase in the amount of ethanol mixed in petrol from the present 10%. Besides, it would help in preventing accumulation of stocks. In case, the stock is not lifted, the mills would have to shut down their ethanol plants. However, government is yet to take a stand on this matter.

Reacting to government’s move, Bijnor district magistrate Ramakant Pandey said mills had been allowed to transport their product and purchase cane at assigned centres and sugar mill gates. Apart from this, labourers would be allowed to harvest the cane and farmers to bring their produce to purchase centres and mill gates.

At the same time, the administration has asked the farmers and labourers to take necessary precautions against the virus while working and transporting cane, raw material, etc.

According to officials, there are 119 sugar mills here in the state which crush around 70 lakh quintal cane per day. Around 46 lakh farmers supply their produce to these units.

Title: Construction labour in Delhi to get Rs 5,000 corona relief
Content: NEW DELHI: In a major relief to lakhs of people, chief minister Arvind Kejriwal on Tuesday announced financial assistance of Rs 5,000 to each construction worker hit by the coronavirus lockdown that has halted construction work, besides other non-essential activities, in the capital. Around 4 lakh construction workers are registered with Construction Workers Welfare Board (CWWB) of the Delhi government. All of them will be provided the financial assistance from CWWB Fund.According to sources, the government is also considering developing a mechanism for identification and fund disbursal for those construction workers who are not registered with the Board and other daily wagers who have lost their livelihood due to the unprecedented lockdown. The government is also increasing the number of night shelters so that those who have no source of earning now can get food. It will also distribute food at different places for people affected by the lockdown.In a digital press conference, Kejriwal said that no new case of coronavirus had been reported in the last 40 hours in Delhi. But, leaving nothing to chance, the Delhi government has constituted a team of five doctors which will review the city’s preparedness for handling the situation if we reach the third stage of community transmission. The committee will submit a report within 24 hours to the chief minister on the steps required to deal with this and suggest ways to strengthen the system. “We have started preparations to build a foolproof health system to combat the situation if we ever get into stage three of this pandemic. We have to be fully prepared in terms of medical support," Kejriwal said."In the last 40 hours, there has not been a single new coronavirus positive case in Delhi. Earlier, we had 30 such positive cases, and among them, many people are getting better and going home. Till now five people have survived and gone home. Currently, we have only 23 positive cases in Delhi,” Kejriwal said, asking people to observe the lockdown strictly since otherwise cases may increase.Kejriwal urged people not to discriminate against those who work in airlines, hospitals and other coronavirus sensitive jobs. “I have received complaints that somewhere in Delhi people did not allow a pilot to enter the colony because they thought he could be affected by coronavirus and the same has happened in some other cases. This is something absolutely unacceptable....doctors, nurses, pilots and air hostesses are our responsibility... These are the people who are working relentlessly to give you proper medical help and support and they should be welcomed,” he said.In response to another call by the chief minister, many landlords have announced waiving of rent for tenants for now. Kejriwal named several such people and appealed to others to do so. One such landlord, Raj Bainsla, and others have announced publicly that they will not collect rent for the month of March. Tens of thousands of tenants in Delhi work in the unorganised sector and their livelihood has been badly hit.Kejriwal urged people to send those who are unable to get food due to the lockdown to night shelters. "We have already started distributing food at all the night shelters where any person can come and eat. Many people have said that they will ensure not a single person in their area stays hungry,” said Kejriwal.

Title: Coronavirus Mumbai News: ‘Quarantined’ notices outside Navi Mumbai homes
Content: NAVI MUMBAI: Navi Mumbai police have pasted notices outside homes of quarantined individuals so that others do not come in contact with them till they complete their isolation period.Each notice mentions names of persons who have been home quarantined as well as the telephone number of Navi Mumbai police control room for others to inform them in case the isolated individuals step outside.Some photographs of these notices were posted on social media on Tuesday, following which the zonal deputy commissioner of police warned the culprits of stringent legal action. DCP (Zone I) Pankaj Dahane said, “As a pamphlet (notice) mentions the names of quarantined individuals, it should not be circulated on social media. Revealing their identities is illegal and will attract action.”Meanwhile, a retired government officer from Sanpada complained to the Navi Mumbai police commissioner about a list being circulated on WhatsApp that contains names, addresses and phone numbers of several persons and falsely claims they are Covid-19-positive; it includes his name too. The man said he has abided by a quarantine order after returning from Russia on March 16.

Title: Hyderabad: Drug production units face trouble despite govt order
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: Bulk manufactures of drugs in Hyderabad and surrounding areas have been facing trouble due to police action since the lockdown announcement by the state government. Buses transporting employees, vehicles supplying raw material for drugs are being stopped or seized at various police stations.

The Bulk Drug Manufacturers Association had written to chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao but despite principal secretary Jayesh Ranjan’s clarification, bulk drug units continued to face similar issues.

“The government had issued GO-45 wherein the pharma industry had been exempted from the lockdown keeping in view the essential service of making enough stocks of critical drugs and pharma products available. However, most employees and busses of drug companies are being stopped by local police officials. Some are also not accepting the clarification addressed to district collectors by the principal secretary,” executive director of Bulk Drug Manufacturers Association, P Eshwar Reddy told TOI.

“Bulk drug and pharma unit operations are continuous and work round-the-clock. An inspector from Dundigal is not allowing pharma employees despite them showing the principal secretary’s letter and other relevant documents. Cops at Dundigal also seized medical supply vehicles,” Eshwar Reddy said.

Meanwhile, police claimed that they only seized pharma company buses that were violating social distancing norms. “On the first day (of lockdown), around 20 buses of pharma companies were stopped, counselled and later released. They were violating social distancing norms during transportation and there were no sanitisers or masks in the buses. They were told to give it in writing that they would not violate the norms again,” an inspector from Dundigal said. “Today (Tuesday) we seized 18 buses carrying employees without following proper measures. We also booked cases. Out of 400 buses we checked, 18 are seized. We did not seize any trucks supplying raw material,” the inspector added.

BDMA national president VV Krishna Reddy has written letters to chief ministers of Telangana and AP in this regard. “Over 35% of bulk drugs and pharmaceutical production in India takes place in Hyderabad, Rangareddy, Medchal, Sangareddy and Kothagudem and three districts — Prakasham, Krishna and Vishakapatnam — in Andhra Pradesh. We are already under pressure to operate units at full capacity to mitigate the issue of shortage of essential drugs. As most operations in bulk drug processing are continuous, it would be difficult to abruptly stop the reactions which could lead to unsafe operation,” Krishna Reddy said.

“All our member units have introduced thorough checking of all employees, casual workers and indirect workers...There is a need to implement the exemption to the bulk drug industry,” the BDMA president added.

Title: Trenches and fences: Villages give it all to deter outsiders in Telangana
Content:
Hipnelli village in Nirmal district, which is located on the Maharashtra border, decided to seal their village... Read More

HYDERABAD: Several villages in the state have ensured that locals abide by lockdown guidlines and have stopped the entry of outsiders. Only those attending to emergency work are being permitted to go out.

In many districts, villages have temporarily sealed their borders by erecting wooden barricades, tree branches and stones on the roads. Some villages have even passed resolutions to impose a fine Rs 1,000 on violators.

Hipnelli village in Nirmal district, which is located on the Maharashtra border, decided to seal their village borders by erecting fences. Similarly, Jukkal villge on the border of Karantaka has also banned the entry of outsiders from the neighbouring state. In Khammam district, several villages have dug up trenches and placed thorny bushes to prevent entry of outsiders.

“We are allowing only daily needs such as milk and vegetables into their villages. We feel it is the responsibility of every villager to implement the lockdown and cooperate with the government,” said Rachannagudem sarpanch, K Ganapathi.

In some villages like Ibrahimpatnam, Polkampally and Yeliminedu, the panchayat has posted a guard to see no vehicle or person from outside enters the village. Similar steps were taken in Koyagudem in Tekulapalle mandal of Kothagudem district and Marlakunta village in Khammam. Since Nalgonda, Rangareddy, Kamareddy, Nizamabad and Mahbubnagar districts are close to Hyderabad, many villages are not even allowing their locals who are residing in Hyderabad to come back.

Chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao, during his press conference on Tuesday lauded the people who have been voluntarily implementing lockdown and maintaining social distance. The CM said that in Hyderabad, Rachakonda and Cyberabad, the situation was improving.

Title: Telangana DGP promises action against cops manhandling journalists
Content:
Mahendar Reddy

HYDERABAD: Members of the journalist association on Tuesday met Telangana director general of police (DGP) Mahendar Reddy following reports of scribes being manhandled by police across the state. The members asked the DGP to initiate disciplinary action against such officials. The DGP assured that he will look into the matter and take corrective action.

In one incident, the political bureau chief of a Telugu daily was allegedly assaulted by a sub-inspector on Monday night when the former was on his way home. “He was stopped by a constable. After he told the cop that he was a journalist, the cop let him go. However, the SI came from behind and hit the journalist without even asking him who he was,” said a member of the Telangana Union of Working Journalists (TUWJ).

In another incident, the bureau chief of an English daily was manhandled by Begumpet police. The incident was brought to the notice of senior police officials including the DGP.

“The DGP said what happened was very unfortunate and apologised. He also spoke to the senior officer of the city police and directed him to initiate corrective measures,” TUWJ general secretary Virahat Ali said.

In a video conference that was organised with Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Tuesday, Dr P Raghu Ram, president, The Association of Surgeons of India, brought to the fore how some healthcare professionals were being discriminated against by their landlords.

He said several junior doctors in Warangal were being driven out of their homes.

Title: Several stranded day before airspace closure in Hyderabad
Content:
Many were forced to cancel their flights owing to unavailability of cabs and Pushpak services.

HYDERABAD: With many airline operators cancelling services at the last minute, several passengers were stranded at the Rajiv Gandhi International Airport on Tuesday, the last day before domestic airspace is locked down. While some passengers were accommodated on alternate flights, many were rerouted to different destinations close to their original destination. A lack of cabs and public transport meant many even had to cancel their tickets on Tuesday.

“My parents, both senior citizens, were travelling from Dehradun to Coimbatore via Hyderabad, but their connection to Coimbatore was cancelled. They were stuck at RGIA for hours. Later, the carrier booked them on a flight to Chennai,” said Nikunj Rathi. “We have to manage to get them from there,” he added.

Similarly, a group of 60 passengers from Rajahmundry and Hyderabad, were told that their flight to Thiruvananthapuram was cancelled. “We were informed about it only after we checked into the airport. We felt helpless because we knew that all services would be suspended post-midnight. Fortunately, by late afternoon our flight was restored and it departed at 3.40 pm,” said Neetu Roy.

A last-minute cancellation of a Hyderabad-Mangalore service left four young doctors stuck at RGIA. “I am a worried father. My daughter left for Mangalore via Hyderabad at 7:30 in the morning and is still at Hyderabad. Please help four such doctors stuck at Hyderabad,” tweeted one of the doctors’ father.

Many were forced to cancel their flights owing to unavailability of cabs and Pushpak services. “My relative was supposed to travel to Chennai for a family emergency. In fact, he was initially booked for March 25, but we advanced his ticket after hearing about the lockdown. But we just could not get a cab, either from an aggregator or a private rental agency, to ferry him to the airport. We do not have a private vehicle,” said Jayaganesh.

Also caught in a helpless situation was CK Mishra, who was scheduled to travel to Ranchi by a 5.45 am flight. “I tried to book a cab from 4 pm on Monday (since the lockdown was to start at 7 pm). I even reached out to the police, but they could not help. I went around looking for help till midnight and then gave up. Later, I saw an email from the airline that the flight was cancelled,” she told TOI.

Title: Despite Covid-19 threat, Gadchiroli’s C-60 commandos continue anti-maoist operations
Content: Nagpur: The global outbreak of Covid-19 may have led to a major upheaval in the fate of the nations affected by the virus, including India, but the routine anti-Maoist operations of the elite C-60 commandos of the Gadchiroli police did not change a bit even when they too are not out of its pervasive threat.The operations were also strategically streamlined and strengthened as a precaution after the latest attack on the security forces by the Maoists leading to the deaths of 17 jawans.Gadchiroli police, apart from its crucial border sealing exercises with Chhattisgarh and Telangana, are also continuing its anti-Maoist operations on a regular basis whether input-based or random area domination exercises or short and long range patrolling along with community programmes like ‘grambhets’ or village visits. SP Shailesh Balkawade said operations cannot be discontinued or scaled down as the Maoists will regain ground or regroup. “Precautions are being taken to ensure that there are no incidents of infection or its spread. The jawans are screened for their health and if someone is found ill then he is rested,” said Balkawade. The SP said every patrolling party has a medical kit.Balkawade said that if any personnel or jawan of the state reserve police force or central paramilitary force is found ill with a cold or cough then he or she is immediately quarantined.“If we find that any jawan is not keeping well after travel or upon returning from leave then we are following a policy of immediately quarantining him or her,” said the SP.

Title: Hyderabad: Locals block access to their colonies
Content: HYDERABAD: With Telangana in lockdown to prevent the spread of coronavirus , people are devising their own ways to keep the infection at bay. Some colonies in the city put up barricades, while, elsewhere in the state, villagers used tractors, branches and even rocks to black entry into their habitations. At Rocktown and Indraprastha colonies at LB Nagar, locals have put up barricades at the entry points on the main roads into their localities.To bar entry of those who do not belong to the colonies, they arranged logs of wood, tied ropes and placed tree branches at entry points. Even during the day, the locals took turns to guard the entry points to disallow anyone from entering their colonies. At Indra Prastha enclave, the residents, who blocked the entry, directed motorists away from their place.In Karimnagar town, where 10 visiting Indonesian preachers and a local, who hosted them, testing positive, the authorities completely sealed the area, where the foreigners stayed and visited. Police put up barricades to prevent the entry of anyone into these areas, including Mukarampura, Kashirigadda and the vicinity of the Karimnagar collectorate. The authorities used drones to spray disinfectants in the areas.In Deshaipet of Choppodandi in the district, the locals, who have formed vigilante groups, are not allowing anyone into their village. “Please do not come to our village,” the villagers are telling visitors and asking them to go back. They also blocked the road with tractors.In Devarakonda of Nalgonda district, circle inspector Aadi Reddy made motorists take a pledge that they would not violate lockdown instructions. Several motorists, who were on the roads, were stopped and made to take a pledge that they would not venture out of their homes.Nalgonda SP Ranganath said police seized 282 two-wheelers, 85 autos, and seven cars for plying on the roads, disregarding the lockdown guidelines. Cases were also booked against 11 shops for selling vegetables at high prices taking advantage of the situation arising out of the coronavirus pandemic.

Title: Sample of Hapur man who committed suicide over corona-like symptoms tests negative
Content: MEERUT: Sample of Sushil Kumar , a 30-year-old Hapur resident who panicked and committed suicide on March 22 as he was depressed over novel coronavirus-like symptoms, tested negative on Tuesday. He has slit his throat using a shaving blade fearing that he would pass on the infection to his kids.Rekha Sharma, chief medical officer of Hapur, confirmed that Sushil’s samples have tested negative for novel coronavirus . “His samples were sent to Aligarh and the report arrived on Tuesday,” Sharma said.The incident occurred on March 22 when Sushil took the extreme step at his residence in Hapur’s Pilkhuwa town. A suicide note was also recovered from the spot.Sushil used to run a salon in Pilkhuwa and was distressed after he had developed some symptoms akin to that of novel coronavirus. Survived by wife and two minor children, Sushil was consulting a local private doctor in neighbouring Modinagar town but didn’t find any relief as his condition had started to deteriorate since last week.Last week, a man suspected to be infected with novel coronavirus had allegedly committed suicide by jumping off the seventh floor of Safdarjung Hospital building in Delhi soon after he was admitted to the facility by the airport authorities.

Title: Coronavirus in Telangana: Six new coronavirus cases in Telangana, tally reaches 39
Content: HYDERABAD: Telangana reported six new positive coronavirus cases on Tuesday, raising the number of such patients to 39. Among them, three patients have a foreign travel history and authorities said a massive tracing process has been initiated to quarantine all the people who had been in direct contact with the patients.A 49-year-old man from Kokapet, who returned from London, a 61-year-old woman, who is a resident of Begumpet with a travel history to Saudi Arabia and a 39-year-old woman, who returned from Germany to her Chandanagar home, tested positive and are in isolation.The fourth patient is a 64-year-old housewife and a resident of Manikonda who does not have history of foreign travel history but a family member, who had gone abroad had tested positive. A bulletin released late in the evening by the health department mentioned that her condition was said to be stable. The fifth and sixth patients on Tuesday are from Bhadradri Kothagudem and have no foreign travel history. They were infected by a primary contact with history of foreign travel.Chief Minister K Chandrasekhar Rao announced that one person has been discharged so far and all the remaining 39 patients could be released by April 7 as their condition was stable now. “The coronavirus spread is stable in the country, but preventive measures are needed. We have asked collectors to seize passports of foreign returnees who are flouting home quarantine,” the chief minister said.Lokesh Kumar, commissioner of GHMC, said they caught four coronavirus suspects, who violated home quarantine rules and were shifted to designated isolation centres. All four had returned from foreign counties and had ventured out of their homes, when they were caught by locals. So far, 77,045 passengers have been screened at the airports in the state.

Title: Lavelle Road residents pool in money for daily-wage earners on their street
Content:
TimesView It is during moments of extreme crisis that the gnawing gap between the haves and the have-nots becomes obvious. And it’s also at such trying times that little acts of sharing and caring can make a world of difference to the less fortunate. In their gracious gesture, the Lavelle Road residents have shown how empathy should be cultivated not just in words but in deeds too. With the country going under a prolonged lockdown and supplies fast drying up, living with a little less of everything but a little more of concern for others could help all of us stay afloat.

Free boxes for strays

BENGALURU: As days get tougher with the lockdown, small acts of kindness are warming hearts. In a touching gesture, around 100 residents of Lavelle Road came together to donate money to daily-wage earners on their street.Under the Living Lavelle Group, eight familiar faces in the locality, including the flower seller in front of the temple, the vegetable vendor, the laundry man and the chaiwala are being given Rs 6,000 and a mask each. Every resident of the locality has donated Rs 500-Rs 1,000.“When the lockdown began, we realised that the group which would be hit the most would be daily-wage earners. They have disappeared from the roads. The chaiwala who used to sell hundreds of cups to the neighbourhood offices is literally selling one or two to the security persons at the gate. We had to do something to help them. The least was to give them money so that they could at least have two meals a day for a month,” said Moumi Moola, an entrepreneur, who initiated the idea.And the daily-wage earners said they couldn’t be more thankful. Arun Kumar , 35, who has been ironing clothes on Lavelle Road for the last 10 years and earning a minimum of Rs 500 per day, has been struggling to earn Rs 100 a day for the past one week.“I have been at home for almost a week now. Even before the lockdown began, people stopped giving me clothes to iron. My earnings dropped to Rs 100 or less. I got calls from my regular customers, but when I stepped out of home to get to work, cops asked me to return. I will collect the money from the association on Wednesday,” he said.With the temple in the area shut, Sharada, a flower seller, is left without a job. The single mother of two said she was extremely worried about their livelihood and the donation is a major relief. Sharada and the vegetable vendor got the money on Tuesday.Meanwhile, Heads Up For Tails, a pet store outlet on Magrath Road gave away free food boxes for stray dogs on Monday. Some of these boxes were delivered to customers when they ordered food for their pets. “The worst affected will be stray dogs in commercial areas. With restaurants and offices closing, they will be out of food. These boxes can be kept around road corners where the dogs can find them. Around 30 boxes were delivered on Monday,” said Ritima Coelho , co-founder of the pet store chain.

Title: Five more coronavirus cases in Gujarat, tally stands at 36
Content:
Firefighters spray disinfectant in a street in Ahmedabad on Tuesday

AHMEDABAD: With six more positive cases of coronavirus registered in the state on Tuesday, the total number of persons who have tested positive for Covid-19 has reached 36. One person from Surat and Vadodara and two each from Gandhinagar and Rajkot tested positive on Tuesday.

One person has died so far in the state because of the pandemic. Even as a 21-day lockdown across the country has been announced, the state government assured people that supply and availability of essential commodities will remain uninterrupted.

FIR have been filed against four patients in Gandhinagar for violating quarantine norms. A couple who returned from Dubai, along with their relatives, have been booked by Gandhinagar police on Tuesday.

Local transmission now is close to one-third of all registered cases in Gujarat. By Tuesday evening, over 30 lakh persons have been surveyed across the state, according state government officials.

The Rajya Sabha election for four seats of Gujarat, scheduled to be held on March 26, has been postponed indefinitely by the Election Commission of India on Tuesday. New dates for the election will be announced at later, state chief electoral officer S Murali Krishna said.

Cops were seen enforcing the lockdown in all other major cities of Gujarat, even as the state government urged people not to venture out of their homes, except in cases of emergency.

Title: Goa: Date for excise licence renewal extended
Content: The excise department has extended the date for renewal of excise licences till May 31 in view of the Covid-19 threat. Excise licences are renewed annually, by March-end.The inspectors in charge of the taluka-level offices have been directed not to take up renewal of licences during the next ten days.Confirming this, excise commissioner Amit Satija said that the renewal date has been extended taking into account the rush that is witnssed at the taluka offices for renewing licences.“Due to the coronavirus threat, it is not possible to attend to renewals. The government has asked to avoid mass gatherings,” he said.He said they are also working with a skeletal staff.

Title: Bhironda sarpanch takes lead to create awareness on Covid-19
Content: VALPOI: As the people of the state gear up for lockdown, Bhironda-Sattari sarpanch Uday Singh Rane, took it upon himself to create awareness about the coronavirus.He mounted a public address system on his car and went around urging people to take precautions.Residents of the Valpoi municipal area welcomed his move and said councillors too should adopt similar means to make people understand the gravity of the situation.Responding to people’s feedback, Valpoi Municipal Council (VMC) organised a vehicle mounted with loudspeakers to go around all wards urging people to stay home.In Copordem, Sattari , a rickshaw was similarly pressed into service.Meanwhile, Tuesday saw people thronging Valpoi’s market to stock up on provisions as the government had permitted stores to remain open between 6am and 11am.The weekly Valpoi market, however, remained closed as chief officer of VMC, Rajesh Ajgaonkar , had issued a notice directing that it would not open as usual. Bagayatdars and grocery shops stayed open till 11am.

Title: As Kerala bars entry, doctor stuck at border for two days
Content:
Health workers in Pathanamthitta hospital watch suspected Covid-19 cases being moved to the isolation ward on ... Read More

KOLLAM: Even as reports about Karnataka government blocking patients from Kasaragod avail healthcare in the state had hit the headlines, a Malayali doctor has been left stranded at the border after Kerala authorities refused entry to her.

Over the past two days, the 23-year-old doctor from Kunnamangalam in Kozhikode who has been doing her internship after passing out from Subaiah Institute of Medical Sciences in Shivamogga, has contacted the Kerala chief minister, health minister, Wayanad district collector and SP to allow her entry to her home state but to no avail.

She was on her way to present herself to serve at Government Beach Hospital in Kozhikode as an intern but was blocked by Kerala police officers when she reached the checkpost at the border town of Kutta.

When she spoke to Wayanad collector and SP they explained that they need a government order to allow her in. She got in touch with health minister KK Shailaja’s office and told them that she was alone and stranded on the street and that the ministers’ office should intervene. She was told to contact the chief minister’s war room.

However, despite repeated efforts, she was not able to contact the war room. Subsequently, as advised by her parents, she requested the Karnataka police’s help to arrange her a conveyance to a friends’ house at Mysore.

Though the friend’s family allowed her to stay with them for two days they too expressed reluctance in allowing her to stay there for long in view of Corona scare.

She said on Tuesday too her efforts to get in touch with the chief minister’s office or the health minister’s office did not bear fruit.

As she has already vacated the college hostel at Shivamogga, she cannot return to there as well.

“I expected that the authorities would allow me to cross the border as I am a young woman and travelling alone. They could have quarantined me. I had sent all relevant papers to the health minister’s office and to the CM’s war room. How can they leave a girl alone on the road,” she asks.

Wayanad district collector Dr Adila Abdulla said she has been given strict orders not to allow anyone across the borders. “There is nothing I can do,” she said in a WhatsApp message.

When the issue was brought to the attention of the health minister’s office, an official said it was up to the authorities at CM’s war room to handle ‘interstate issues’.

Since the applicant is a doctor, the Kozhikode DMO could take a decision to help her, said an official at the war room.

“If the Kozhikode DMO writes to the government stating that she could be deployed as an intern, then the Wayanad collector could allow her across the border,” an official requesting anonymity said.

Title: Nirmala Sitharaman eases rules for bank customers, taxpayers, firms
Content: NEW DELHI: Finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman on Tuesday announced easier compliance norms for companies required to file under income tax, GST, customs and corporate laws, while allowing bank customers the flexibility to use their debit cards at ATMs without any fee, and waived the penalty for those who are unable to maintain the stipulated minimum balance in their accounts.The digital trade transaction charge will also be lowered, the FM promised, while clarifying that the benefits will have to be offered by pri vate and public sector banks. Besides, small companies were sought to be protected from insolvency action by raising the threshold under the Insolvency & Bankruptcy Code to a loan of Rs 1 crore, instead of the current Rs 1 lakh floor.The minister also said IBC provisions may be waived in case the coronavirus crisis persisted till beyond April. The announcements, which are a precursor to the much-anticipated economic package to aid industry and individuals facing income uncertainty, offer concessions of filings for a limited period and are not permanent.Sitharaman — who assured 24x7 customs facilities for exporters and importers — made it clear that the idea was to ensure that people stayed in lockdown and took care of their families instead of exposing themselves to the deadly virus by venturing out to be "honest taxpayers". As a result, the GST filing deadline for three months, starting February, has been deferred until June 30. Besides, companies with an annual turnover of up to Rs 5 crore do not have to worry about paying any late fee or interest.In case of the larger entities, the penal interest has been halved to 9%. On the income tax front, the last date for filing returns for the financial year 2018-19 has been extended from March 31, 2020 to June 30, 2020, which is also the new deadline for linking Aadhaar with PAN. But it will benefit only a small section of the population as the bulk of the returns have already been filed.There was a bigger gain for those looking to settle their direct tax disputes via the Vivad Se Vishwas scheme. Instead of the the March 31 deadline, no additional 10% amount will be levied if the payment is made by the end of June 30, the FM said. On the indirect tax side too, the payment deadline under the Sabka Vishwas scheme has been extended until the end of June and no interest will be levied. The move was welcomed by the industry, which had been pitching for the concessions as they were finding it tough to comply with the norms due to a majority of employees working from home.

Title: 81% parents want schools to be shut till May: Survey
Content: NEW DELHI: At least 81% of the parents responding to a survey feel schools across the country should be shut through April and May and reopened only on June 1.Till Tuesday’s lockdown decision till mid-April, most schools were to be shut down till March 31 and in some cases, even till the first week of April, while all examinations have been postponed following the Covid-19 outbreak.With the number of positive cases continuing to rise, parents are the most anxious lot and LocalCircles, a not-for-profit social media community group, has received thousands of posts from parents across India about keeping children safe. Many of them even wanted the schools to be closed when the first Covid-19 case was reported.Children, though the least affected group in China, are found to be the fastest transmitters of novel coronavirus and can have a devastating impact on the elderly in the family, who belong to the most susceptible group. Many experts have called children “super spreaders” as it is difficult to implement the social-distancing approach in their cases.To understand the public opinion, LocalCircles conducted the survey among parents and received 10,860 responses from 207 cities/towns. While 81% of the respondents were in favour of keeping the schools closed till May, 9% voted against it while 10% were unsure.The majority of the parents feel keeping the schools closed would largely minimise the risk of the virus spread. With the next session starting on June 1, there will be negligible loss of working days for the academic year, they claimed. The spring session starts in the first week of April in many parts of the country.LocalCircles will submit the findings to various stakeholders at the central government and the chief secretaries of all states.The statistics from the Chinese Centre for Disease Control & Prevention show 2,000 confirmed or suspected cases of the novel coronavirus infection among children. In the national capital region, the first school-related case was reported when a man, whose sons are students of a school in Noida, was found to be positive on March 2. On the same day, many children were tested and two schools were eventually shut for a week.

Title: Nagpur station shut for people, minimum staff present for maintenance
Content: NAGPUR: The Nagpur station has been shut with bare minimum staff manning the station for operating some non-passenger coaching and freight trains and for security.On Tuesday, around a dozen long distance coaching trains passed through Nagpur to reach their originating stations for primary maintenance. One reason for return of trains was lack of space at the end stations where these trains had reached before withdrawal of operations . “This was done for rake balancing,” says ACM (Goods) SG Rao.With suspension of train operations, mechanical department’s role now is crucial in maintaining trains that have been held up in the yard. Railway Board on Tuesday issued an advisory asking to avoid congregation of people and regulate working of coaching depots.Senior divisional mechanical engineer (SrDME) Akhilesh Choubey said, “Timings of most of the trains originating from Nagpur are in the evening. Hence, these can be maintained in morning the same day after orders to restart operations are issued. As of now all these trains have been locked and stationed in the yard.”“We are focusing on freight train maintenance now for which teams have been segregated for social distancing. In office also not more than 5% staff is working. Contractual staff has been sent home after sanitizing entire station, waiting halls and rooms etc,” he added.Officials said Indian Railways is working 24X7 to ensure uninterrupted supply of essential commodities across the nation. Commodities like foodgrains, salt, sugar, milk, edible oil, onions, fruits and vegetables, petroleum products, coal etc are being loaded at railway terminals.Nagpur being a coal loading division, no essential commodities are being loaded here.Due to coronavirus outbreak, passenger train operations across the country have been suspended till March 31, 2020. During the situation of lockdown in various states, railways staff deployed at various good sheds, stations and control offices is working to ensure the supply of essential items does not get affected.Officials said on March 23, 2020, 474 rakes were loaded for essential commodities like foodgrains, salt, edible oil, sugar, milk, fruits & vegetables, onion, coal and petroleum products.During the day total 891 rakes were loaded in the country, which also includes other important commodities like 121 rakes of iron ore, 48 rakes of steel, 25 rakes of cement, 28 rakes of fertilizer, 106 container rakes etc“Close coordination is being maintained with the state governments so that rakes of essential commodities are handled smoothly without any delay, amid various restriction imposed in the wake of Covid-19 ,” they said.Meanwhile, like administrative and other staff, trackmen have also demanded alternative day working considering the threat to them while working in groups. TOI found these trackmen sit together to have food during break and social distancing is not maintained.In another development, the All India Guards Council (AIGC) has demanded stopping of biometric attendance and start signing off by using ID and password, providing good quality hand wash, hygiene at lobby, isolating and disinfecting all beds at running rooms, sanitizing brake vans of goods train at every station.

Title: PMC redraws waste disposal plan as 25% workers leave for villages
Content: PUNE: The Pune Municipal Corporation has issued a time-table designating days when a particular type of dry waste will be lifted by wastepickers from the Solid Waste Collection and Handling (SWaCH) collective.Officials said the city generates about 2,100 tonne waste every day of which 250 tonne goes for recycling, and the remaining is processed.Since most of the workers have left for their native villages due to the coronavirus scare, the city is facing a shortage of sanitary workers who segregate the waste which have brought the new rules into effect.Wet waste, and biomedical waste like sanitary napkins and diapers can be disposed of every day but households must put a red dot on the cover wrapping the sanitary waste. Medical waste should be disposed of in the dry waste segment by households only on Wednesdays.Dnyaneshwar Molak, head of the Pune Municipal Corporation’s solid waste management department, said, “We have about 57 solid waste management plants in the city. Many workers engaged in these units hail from the villages. The Covid-19 scare has sent 25% of them home. Hence, there is a load on the system. But, we are managing with the remaining staff. In this time, we request citizens to be more responsible and dispose of waste as per the give schedule,” Molak said.Suman More, a SWaCH worker said they have some complaints from wastepickers about some societies not providing them water to wash their hands.“The PMC is providing masks, soaps and gloves in phases. But to wash hands, we need water. While a majority of the societies are nice to wastepickers, some have told the wastepickers not to use the water facilities. This hampers their work and can harm their health. They go to work at 6am or 7am and come home after 1pm or 2pm. So when there is no water, they can’t wash their hands, and hence cannot eat food. They can do so only after taking a bath after returning home, which is not good for their health,” More said.“Procuring soap, masks and gloves has become difficult due to the unavailability of many hygiene products. But we have placed the orders as we anticipate that the need will remain for some time now,” Molak said.Societies that have engaged individuals to clear garbage are in a spot.Many have no system to dispose of wet waste on their premises.Even those that have the facility said their housekeeping staf are not coming to collect the garbage as they are scared to leave theri homes in this period of lockdown.Some have engaged people from outside the state. Such employees have left for their homes and have no idea when they will be back.

Title: Societies tell maids to stay at home for one month, with no salary cut
Content:
PUNE: A paranoia about the coronavirus has prompted many housing societies to keep the maids out and view foreign-returned residents with suspicion.

Maids working in societies that have reported Covid-19 positive patients are being asked by many households not to report for a month. Residents are also wary of those who have returned from abroad.

Speaking to TOI, a resident said, “Our maid used to work in a society where a person tested Covid-19 positive. She did not turn up for work on the day the person tested positive, but we were not aware of it. It was when a video of the building started circulating on WhatsApp group that my wife spotted her coming out of it.”

“The maid remained at home for some days. We called her and asked her not to report for work for a month. Though we have decided to pay her full salary for a month, she said that she has lost a couple of jobs and not everyone want to pay her. In fact, she and her friend, who also works in the same society, are being discriminated against in their own community,” said the resident.

Many housing societies have in fact circulated messages in their society groups asking residents not to allow anyone inside their home. Even delivery boys are not allowed inside the society and residents asked to collect the parcels from the main gate.

With the news of a cab driver getting infected while ferrying a passenger from abroad, people are even reluctant to travel in auto rickshaws and cabs, thus affecting the livelihood of drivers, said activists.

Meanwhile, psychologists said that the moment an individual feels he or she is at risk, he/she stops behaving like a social animal and succumbs to an inherent behaviour of self-preservation. Psychologists also feel that the city might record an increase in cases of post-traumatic stress disorders, especially among health workers and those who were quarantined.

Anuradha Patil, senior professor, Karve Institute of Social Service, who has worked extensively with HIV positive people, said that more than racial discrimination it is fear of the unknown disease which causes discriminatory behaviour among people.

“We are on a vacation in a place where no incident of Covid-19 has been reported, yet we were looked at suspiciously. This behaviour is evident every time the society faces something unknown,” said Patil.

Psychologist Kinjal Goyal felt that the ongoing scare has brought us face to face with a basic human instinct for self-preservation. “It is this instinct of protecting oneself from harm that makes people turn against their neighbours. Checking on those quarantined at home over the phone is a basic step that can alleviate their feeling of loneliness and dread.”

However, she also stressed on the need for bringing back those who have faced quarantine into normal life. “Healthcare professionals, people who have tested positive and are recovering, those who have been isolated due to recent travel to foreign countries affected by the virus all are at risk of developing post-traumatic stress disorders. Providing counselling to all such individuals will help in minimising the coronavirus scare,” added Goyal.

Title: In government reprieve, non-charter tourists to return on charters
Content: PANAJI: For the first time director general of civil aviation (DGCA) has permitted foreign nationals who arrived on scheduled flights to India to return through charter flight.The 300-seater Dreamliner belonging to UK’s TUI Airways Ltd was scheduled to depart from Dabolim international airport at midnight Tuesday. Permission has been granted in view of the prevailing situation due to the Covid-19 scare.President, Travel and Tourism Association of Goa (TTAG), Savio Messias said a lot of travellers who came to Goa on scheduled flight are stuck due to the lockdown. “They are unable to return. We requested the government to step in, in view of an unprecedented situation. Chief secretary Parimal Rai, tourism secretary J Ashok Kumar and director tourism Menino D’Souza helped to get the permission from the DGCA,” he said.Charter flights are not permitted to book travellers coming through scheduled flights, but this is the first time an exemption has been made after the state government’s intervention, Messias said.He said that many UK nationals, who came for a long stay, are facing problem going back. More passengers could have benefited of this exemption had the permission been issued earlier, Messias said.Martin Joseph, chairperson at Freedom Holidays that represents TUI, said they have about 120 charter guests leaving tonight. Rest of the seats will be taken by travellers who had arrived on a scheduled flight. This, he said would not have possible without Goa government’s help.Joseph said he is willing to help any foreign traveller unable to return to his home country.“They can approach me if. I want tourists to visit Goa after the crises is over,” he said.

Title: 10 of 12 isolation patients in Margao’s hospital high risk
Content: MARGAO/PANAJI: A total of 12 patients are currently admitted at the isolation ward of the TB hospital, Margao , and the quarantine facility at the ESI Hospital, Margao, medical superintendent of the Hospicio and deputy health director, Ira Almeida told TOI.The media bulletin released by the directorate of health services (DHS) on Tuesday stated that 10 patients admitted in the isolation ward of the TB hospital are high risk patients. High risk patients are those who have come in contact with a Covid-19 positive person.To enhance its preparedness to handle Covid-19 cases, the DHS has opened a 15-bedded dedicated ward in the TB hospital for treating cases of respiratory illness. This special ward is apart from the 12-bedded isolation ward at the TB hospital.Meanwhile, the Candolim health centre is tracking about 150 travellers, including locals and foreigners. The travellers have been in home quarantine and mostly all have been cooperative, health department staff said.The Candolim primary health centre was in the news two days after a letter by its health officer Dr Roshan Nazareth addressed to the deputy collector went viral on social media. In the letter, Nazareth had mentioned names of four foreigners who they were having difficulty tracing.Nazareth told TOI on Tuesday that all four were tracked the same day. He clarified that letter was not leaked from his office.Names of seven passengers on the same Dubai-Bengaluru-via-Goa flight as the Bengaluru woman who later tested positive for novel Coronavirus last week were passed on to the primary health centre at Candolim.The seven passengers had given their addresses in Candolim, of which three were immediately traced.Nazareth said they have been checking on all passengers regularly and were assisted by police and the talathi in tracking travellers.All those are in quarantine have cooperated, otherwise it would have been a difficult task, he said. Some passengers, Nazareth said, have completed their 14-day quarantine period whereas 150 are in active quarantine.

Title: Special Pune flight to carry samples, lab set up at GMC in Goa
Content: Chief minister Pramod Sawant said a special flight has been arranged to send samples of coronavirus suspects to Pune. A team of four doctors will travel to Pune for training in virology, he said.With flight operations suspended, Sawant said the state was not able to send suspected Covid-19 samples to Pune.“After speaking with the minister of state for defence, Shripad Naik, a special flight has been arranged to take the samples to Pune,” he said, adding that 13 samples have already been sent.Meanwhile, health minister Vishwajit Rane said a virology laboratory has been set up at GMC. “We have procured a PCR machine through the malaria control centre. Real-time testing for Covid-19 will be introduced in a couple of days,” he said.

Title: Forces destroy iron ropes used for illegal movement at Indo-Nepal border
Content:
Forces destroy iron ropes used for illegal movement at Indo-Nepal border

PITHORAGARH: A joint team of police and Sashastra Seema Bal (SSB) destroyed the iron ropes on Kali river between Pangla and Tawaghat villages of Dharchula Tehsil on Tuesday. These ropes were used to cross the river and enter India illegally. The action has been taken to check illegal movement of people between India and Nepal amidst Covid-19 pandemic.

SP Pithoragarh Priti Priyadarshni told TOI that these iron ropes were destroyed at seven places — Ghasku Ghat, Barati Ghat, Malkatia Ghat , Dokat Ghat, Tintola Ghat, Jingati Ghat, and Tawaghat.

Notably, Kali river demarcates border between India and Nepal. In areas like Dharchula, Baluakot, Jauljabi, Dyada and Jhulaghat, there are suspension bridges which make legal entry points. However, cross border movement through such illegal and temporary routes is often reported in the district.

Title: Weather systems to bring lightning, hail & light rain in Maharashtra
Content:
Image used for representational purpose only

PUNE: The city and 18 other districts are likely to see their first spell of summer rain from Wednesday. Light rains, lightning, thunderstorm, gusty winds, and hail in isolated places, are expected in Pune, Satara , Nashik , Ahmednagar , Aurangabad and many other districts.

Light rain and thundershowers are also expected in Thane, Mumbai on March 26-27, but most of the activity will be in the interior of the state.

Anupam Kashyapi, head of weather, India Meteorological Department , Pune, told TOI that the heat load has been going up over Maharashtra. “Temperatures have been on the higher side since the past few days. Along with an upper air cyclonic circulation over South Madhya Maharashtra and north south wind discontinuity from south Tamil Nadu to north Madhya Maharashtra have created ideal conditions for summer’s first spell of light rain to isolated moderate rain, thundershowers, lightning and hail in isolated places in state,” he said.

Day temperatures in Pune shot up to the season’s highest at Shivajinagar and Lohegaon on Tuesday at 37.6 degree celsius and 37.8 degree celsius, respectively. In Akola, the day temperature shot up to 40.3 degrees celsius making it the hottest spot in Maharashtra on Tuesday. The heat load and moisture incursion have acted as a triggering mechanism in creating local level convection in Maharashtra and adjacent areas which will continue for a couple of days.

Kashyapi said two western disturbances have been approaching western Himalayan region, one being over Iran and another over Pakistan. “Also, an induced cyclonic circulation has formed over West Rajasthan and adjacent areas. The combined effect of these has been causing moisture incursion into parts western India including areas of Maharashtra. The availability of this moisture along with major moisture incursion from Arabian Sea and Bay of Bengal as well as the increase in heat load over the state is likely to result in adverse weather during the next 4 to 5 days in parts of Maharashtra,” he added.

During the next five days, Konkan is likely to receive very light to light rains including Mumbai on March 27 and 28. “We have forecast light rains at isolated places during the next five days in Madhya Maharashtra too with a chance of thundery activity, lightning. Rainfall will marginally rise and is likely to range from light to moderate at scattered locations in Madhya Maharashtra (including Pune city and Pune district ) on Wednesday as well,” he said.

The spell of light rains is likely to continue in parts of Maharashtra till March 28, he added.
