Title: 28 FIRs in PCMC area for defying orders
Content:
Police said people were out for no specific purpose in some places.

PUNE: Additional commissioner of police Ramnath Pokale said commuters on Tuesday came out on their two-wheelers and vehicles to see the ‘curfew situation’ in Pimpri Chinchwad. “We have registered 28 FIRs for defying the order of the district collector under section 188 of the IPC ,” he told TOI.

The Pimpri Chinchwad police commissionerate has set up 13 nakabandi points at vantage points, besides, beat marshal and day and night patrol teams are working to keep the situation under control.

“We have not stopped people from buying essential items like vegetables or grocery. Our personnel have been requesting people to maintain social distancing and adhere to guidelines issued by the government. One of the outlets in Pimpri has given coupons, with specific visiting time, to people. If a similar system is followed by others, people will not gather at one place. It would be easier for our personnel to function,” Pokale added.

On people being beaten up by the policemen, Pokale said people were out for no specific purpose in some places.

He said there is no need to panic and people must cooperate in these times.

“Essential services like grocery shops, vegetable fruit shops, banks and ATMs, pharmacies will be operational during the lockdown period," he added .

Title: Karnataka govt refers BBMP Bill to joint select committee
Content: BENGALURU: The state government on Tuesday referred the Bruhat Bengaluru Mahanagar Palike Bill to a joint select committee of the state legislature after ruling party MLAs urged for greater confabulations with all stakeholders.The bill seeks to fulfil the long pending need of a separate legislation for the governance of the BBMP. Currently, the city is governed under the provisions of the Karnataka Municipal Corporation Act of 1976 which many experts felt is inadequate to govern a city of international repute like Bengaluru.As soon as revenue minister R Ashoka tabled the bill in the assembly, ruling party MLAs stressed the need for a detailed debate stating the bill would decide the future of the city and it cannot be passed in a hurry.“The government must hold talks with all the stakeholders including civic experts and planners before getting it approved by the state legislature,” BJP MLA Aravind Limbavali urged.He was supported by Bengaluru MLAs Ravi Subramanya, Satish Reddy, Uday Garudachar, R Manjunath and others.Th absence of opposition parties also helped MLAs to convince the government to refer the bill to the select committee. The opposition had boycotted proceedings protesting the passage of bills other than money bill.“It is not right on part of the government to pass such an important bill when the opposition is not in the house,” Garudachar said.Heeding to the demand law and parliamentary affairs minister J C Madhuswamy said the government was ready to refer the bill to the joint select committee. Later, speaker Vishweshwara Hegde Kageri said the bill would be referred to the committee consisting of members of both the houses.

Title: ‘Use cotton bud to give Communion to sick, dying’
Content: PANAJI: The archdiocese of Goa and Daman instructed priests giving Holy Communion to the seriously ill and dying to use a cotton bud instead of bare finger, and use face masks.The priest “should first learn to put the mask properly, to follow necessary precautions while wearing it, and to dispose it appropriately after use; if not, the improper use of the mask could cause more harm than good,” the archdiocese stated, regarding the sacrament of anointing of the sick and the Viaticum (the Eucharist given to a dying person).Priests have also been asked to sanitise, wash their hands with water and soap immediately before and after the celebration , during which only very few family members are allowed to be present.Those below 12 and above 60, and those with various ailments cannot take part in the celebration.The archdiocese has also said that the sacrament of baptism should only be celebrated if there is a pressing need, with the minimal number of persons, and the priest will sign the baby with the cross without touching.Similarly, for the sacrament of marriage, the Church has recommended that it be postponed to a later date.

Title: Goa: Senior citizens bear brunt of panic-shopping
Content: PANAJI: Bhatulem-based senior citizen Mohan Rivankar walked around the Panaji fish market clutching his empty shopping bag on Tuesday. Sweat trickled down his forehead at 10.30am as he raced against the 11am market closure deadline, but to no avail.“I am very disappointed to see that there is absolutely no fish,” he said, helplessly.While senior citizens and persons with underlying health conditions are more susceptible to coronavirus , many were left in desperation as fish and beef stalls were stripped clean within hours by panic shoppers when the Panaji market briefly opened from 6am to 11am on Tuesday.Fish was sold out well before 10am while stock of beef was exhausted within a couple of hours of stores opening.“My family and I will have to make do with some dry fish at home,” an obviously worried Rivankar said, asking, “How long will this continue?”Messais Tavares, 71 and his wife Silvia travelled from Ribandar to shop for groceries. “We anticipated a long queue, so we rushed and purchased whatever we could,” said Tavares who picked up vegetables instead of meat.Reacting to the shortage, Panaji mayor Uday Madkaikar said, “Fish and meat vendors were not entirely sure that the market would be open on Tuesday which is why only a few showed up.”Fish sales started at 6am in the Panaji market after vendors picked up fish boxes from boat owners at 3am from the Malim jetty. They were selling three mackerels at Rs 300, kingfish at Rs 800 and sole fish (lepo) at Rs 300. “Boat owners sold us the fish at a slightly higher rate due to which we had to increase retail rates,” one vendor said.“For the first time in years, we sold off everything. All the fish was purchased by home consumers alone,” fish vendor Vijay Chauhan said.Chicken, too, sold quickly on Tuesday despite last week’s difficulties amid Covid-19 and H1N1 fears. Prices too shot up to Rs 150 per kg as opposed to Rs 100 last week.

Title: Passes not mandatory for people exempted from lockdown: Police
Content:
Bhubaneswar: Police on Tuesday said passes were not mandatory for people exempt from the lockdown. Police took the decision after officials of different departments engaged in emergency services were found crowding the DCP office for passes. Police introduced the pass system to ensure social distancing and not allow unreasonable people out in the streets.

DGP Abhay, who has sent letters to all the district SPs, DCPs and range DIGs, said police were working to develop a web-based system of passes for all exempted people. “Because of lack of capacity and other constraints, pass system during lockdown is not yet robust. Since a web-based system will take time to develop and stabilise, doctors, nurses and healthcare workers employed in government and private hospitals should be allowed to move during lockdown in their vehicles showing their identity cards,” said the DGP’s letter.

Taking a similar line, twin cities police commissioner Sudhanshu Sarangi said people need not panic because they don’t have passes. “People who need to travel because of medical or other emergencies are being allowed to move around if there is a patient or medical paper,” he tweeted. He further said police were cancelling the process of issuing passes to emergency workers as too many people congregated for it. “We will introduce an IT platform to automate the process of issuance of passes,” Sarangi said.

The government has exempted emergency service providers such as employees of health, police, urban local body, fire, bank, telecommunication, postal and hospitals among others from restricting the movement.

On Tuesday, the Khurda administration seized 36 vehicles, which included five cars, for violating lockdown norms. The government on Tuesday came up with the ruling that the movement of essential commodities will not be disrupted due to police check during lockdown.

The government said showing of trade licence will be considered authentic to allow a vehicle transporting essential goods. “Trade licence certificate is given to a trader by the respective urban local body. The trade licence should be photocopied and a copy should be available with the driver of the vehicle transporting the goods. The vehicle should be allowed to move freely without obstruction,” said the government order.

The East Coast Railway (EcoR), divisional railway manager (Khurda), Sashi Kant Singh, has also written to collectors of 12 districts seeking permission for free movement of vehicles carrying essential commodities and railway staff. Even after stoppage of passenger trains, the railways is operating goods train to transport essential commodities, said the letter.

Title: Lifeguards to continue to man Goa beaches
Content:
File photo of Goa beach

PANAJI: Life guarding agency Drishti Lifesaving said that as part of essential services their personnel will continue to be on duty though all beaches will remain closed for public during the lockdown period .

In the statement issued on Tuesday, Drishti Lifesaving said there were a few instances of people visiting beaches in their locality despite the curfew in force.

When lifeguards asked them to go away, some refused to obey their instructions, they said.

“In the morning at Calangute beach, a foreign national argued with lifeguards when they tried to stop her from getting into the water. She spat on their faces before walking away. The incident was reported to Calangute police,” Drishti Lifesaving’s statement read.

The agency has appealed to locals as well as foreign travellers currently in Goa to stay away from beaches.

Title: South Goa gets 5 Indian Reserve Batallion platoons
Content: MARGAO: South Goa’s police strength has been reinforced with the arrival of Indian Reserve Batallion (IRB) platoons at the South Goa police headquarters. Police said three of the five platoons sanctioned for the district have been deployed in Margao and surrounding areas.Nakabandis have already been put in place at various places across South Goa and vans making public announcements have been doing rounds in all towns across South Goa. Police patrolling has been intensified in areas identified as sensitive, such as Davorlim and Moti Dongor in Margao, police said.

Title: CM Pramod Sawant assures cover to Goa's homeless
Content: PANAJI: Homeless people will be kept in shelter homes during the lockdown period, said chief minister Pramod Sawant on Tuesday.Speaking to mediapersons, Sawant said the government is making adequate provisions for this segment of the society and the district collectors have been entrusted with the task.“The homeless will be kept in shelter homes identified by the collectors,” Sawant said.The decision comes a day after TOI’s report on the plight of this segment of the society in the face of Covid-19.The city’s homeless continue to live within Panaji ’s ecosystem devoid of medical aid while simultaneously being exposed to the potential viral infection.TOI had reported on March 24 that many of the homeless in Panaji don’t have access to basic sanitation nor are they fully aware of the consequences of the Covid-19. Most of them beg for alms or camp outside restaurants to feed on leftovers. The lock-down currently imposed upon the state has further made them vulnerable since they are left devoid of food.

Title: All maritime institutes closed in Goa, courses stopped
Content:
Representative image

The director general (DG) of shipping has said that all maritime courses will be suspended and all maritime training institutes will remain closed until further orders.

In an earlier order the DG had suspended all basic, modular, simulator, and competency or preparatory courses, but with the latest order, all pre-sea courses are suspended.

Meanwhile, founder of Goa seamen association of India (GSAI) Dixon Vaz dismissed reports that the shipping industry was “on the verge of collapse.”

Title: Aahaar centres to be closed temporarily
Content:
Bhubaneswar: In the wake of complete lockdown in 30 districts from Tuesday midnight to March 29 to contain the spread of coronavirus, the state government has decided temporary closure of Aahaar centres. However, the Aahaar centres operating inside or near hospitals will continue their operations.

Altogether 157 Aahaar centres are operating across the state with one each at all 114 urban centres. Besides, there are centres inside 56 hospital campuses where night meals are available.

People get subsidized meal of rice and dalma at Rs 5 per plate. Earlier, the state extended the time for serving food at Aahaar centres from 10 am to 4 pm to decongest the centres. These Aahar centres were witnessing very little footfall after the announcement of lockdown.

Title: Number of greengrocers comes down in markets
Content:
Bhubaneswar: Since Sunday, the once-crowded vegetable markets now see only a handful of greengrocers doing their businesses in all the big markets here. Even some traders, who come under essential services, have downed their shutters out of fear or to support government’s call for maintaining social distance.

Rajdhani Haata Byabasayi Sangha president Gayadhar Swain said the small farmers, who grow vegetables and come in small transporting vehicles, are not coming to the city for two reasons. One, the vegetable growers are afraid that they might contract the virus if they come to Bhubaneswar since two corona positive cases have been detected here. Two, the farmers are not coming because of restrictions. They don’t want to go through gruelling stages to sell the vegetables. Therefore there is limited stock of vegetables resulting in price rise, he said.

The Gandhi market and Unit-I market here are considered two big vegetable markets, which witnesses rush mostly in the evening. Since all the 17 markets have been asked to close down by 6pm, many vendors feel they will get less customers and their stock will rot.

“We will have to sit for hours waiting for customers even with limited stock of vegetable given the present situation. Still, the stock does not exhaust. The problem is with the tweak in timing. You don’t get rush of customers in the afternoon,” said Sridhar Khilari, a trader in the Gandhi market.

The city requires 250-300 tonne of vegetables, which are sold in the markets on a day. “Now we should ensure that there is less surplus of vegetable in the retail market,” Swain added. The Unit-I vegetable market witnesses a footfall of 6,000 every day.

Swain said with the government relaxing vegetable transportation norms by asking drivers to produce only trade licence certificate, the situation will improve. The traders, who now prefer not to come, will carry vegetables in small vehicles. The government has said the furnishing of trade licence will be considered authenticate to allow plying of a vehicle transporting essential goods. Trade licence certificate is given to a trader by the respective urban local bodies.

The Bhubaneswar Municipal Corporation (BMC) on Tuesday decided to appeal to people using different mediums and public address system to provide food to stray animals. A dedicated vehicle will also move in the city with the message. The stray animals, after lockdown, are suffering due to shortage of food source for them.

Title: Credai wants MahaRERA to push deadline
Content:
Representational image

PUNE: The Confederation of Real Estate Developers Association of India (Credai) has written to the Maharashtra Real Estate Regulatory Authority ( MahaRERA ) to extend the deadline for completion of projects by a month in the face of the nationwide lockdown.

“Developers cannot meet deadlines in the current pandemic situation,” Credai office-bearers said.

Developers from Pune said workers have left for their respective hometowns and that work had ground to a halt. “We cannot meet our deadlines as we cannot procure anything for the construction. In Pune city, the registration offices are closed, so there are no registrations too,” a builder said.

MahaRERA has, meanwhile, adjourned cases, scheduled for hearing between March 16 and March 31, except for “very urgent matters”, due to the spreading coronavirus pandemic.

Title: Delhi: Out to serve, delivery boys find policemen in the way
Content: NEW DELHI: Delivery executives of e-commerce firms trying to supply essential commodities were allegedly harassed or beaten up by policemen enforcing the lockdown on Wednesday. As a result, the deliverymen refused to provide the service until the issue was resolved and orders given by people on online stores like Big Basket and FreshToHome were cancelled.Later, Delhi Police met representatives of e-commerce companies to facilitate the supply of essential items. A WhatsApp group was set up to report any harassment. Companies like Big Basket, Grofers and MedLife were asked to provide identity cards to their delivery executives, who would also be issued curfew passes.Delhi Police spokesperson Mandeep Singh Randhawa said, “Curfew passes have been issued and police have assured the delivery agents of smooth movement. Delhi Police will be live on Twitter wherein a one-hour session will be held to report any issues.”Saptarshi Chatterjee (32), a resident of Vasant Kunj, said not only did his online delivery for groceries fall through, but his attempt at ordering food online also failed as the deliveryman returned after being allegedly thrashed by police. While the company refunded his money, he is now contemplating stepping out to buy supplies.For those who rely on tiffin boxes, the problem was severe too. A tiffin delivery person in Chilla Gaon in Mayur Vihar-I told TOI that he was unable to complete his deliveries to students and the elderly after being stopped by police. “Some cops stopped my scooty and roughed me up despite me telling them that food delivery was an essential service,” he added.Prakash, a delivery executive with Medlife, said despite having requisite documents, police in Todapur didn’t listen to him. Medlife CEO and co-founder Ananth Narayanan said in a statement, “Prakash was bringing back curfew passes and was hit by policemen on the way to the fulfilment centre. He suffered bruises on his face and body. We also have reports of similar incidents in Bengaluru.”A resident of South Extension-II said that vegetable vendors in her area were being harassed by police. “The vendor told me that cops took money from him,” she added. Others said meat shops were also shut down in their area as police didn’t consider them essential services

Title: In Bicholim, people come together to feed needy
Content: BICHOLIM: Citizens of Bicholim and surrounding areas have one less thing to worry about this week. The Bapuji Welfare Trust and other social groups have started supplying free food to the needy, poor and dependent people.However, Pradosh Amonkar , who heads the trust, is worried he may not be able to continue this service beyond Wednesday as they do not have government approval.Since Monday, the welfare trust has been providing free food to the needy in Bicholim. This includes daily wage workers, construction workers and also working people who have to stay home due to ongoing curfew. Amonkar, a caterer by profession, roped in different social clubs and volunteers to serve people.Currently, they serve 150 food packets a day. But ever since the curfew extension, a number of government and private working people have been roped in, taking the daily distribution to 250 packets.Amonkar has called on government authorities to permit those interested in starting ‘takeaway outlets’ on a no-profit no-loss basis through which anybody can provide free food to people.Those who require meals are requested to contact 9822981325 or 7350279988 at 9am for lunch at 1pm and at 3pm for dinner at 8pm.

Title: Goa police may take violators of curfew into custody
Content: PANAJI: With the state under the lockdown due to coronavirus , Goa police has stated that non-cooperation by members of the general public would be tantamount to defying the statutory orders and pave way for the custody of the violators.On Tuesday, the police issued an advisory to the public alerting them of consequences against the breaking of the curfew.Police asked the citizens to remain indoors. They said that if any member of the public was seen outdoors, he would be stopped, questioned and asked to go back.“Non-cooperation can lead to custody and the person concerned will be booked under section 188 of the Indian Penal Code (violation of order promulgated by government), section 270 (malignant act likely to spread infection of disease dangerous to life), section 271 (knowingly disobeying any quarantine rule) and section 269 (negligently doing act known to be likely to spread infection of any diseases dangerous to life),’’ police said.Police have intensified patrolling to avoid any untoward incident in the state. Additional police force has been deployed at borders to stop entry of vehicles, except those registered in Goa.Earlier, Goa police had appealed to the priests of all religious institutions to advise their followers to pray from home as a precautionary measure.Goa police said pandemic diseases do not restrict themselves to territorial borders, castes, religions and communities and hence precautions needed to be taken.The janata Curfew announced by Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Sunday was a widespread success. The state government extended it till March 25. However, on Tuesday, a total lockdown was announced by the central government.

Title: Real-time tracking for those under quarantine
Content: KOCHI: To collect details of comorbidities of people in home quarantine and other aspects, real-time tracking system has been implemented in Ernakulam. The facility envisages collecting details of comorbidities of the person, details of pregnant women, breastfeeding women and their kids in home quarantine. Details of people under quarantine have been uploaded on the Covid tracker software by health officials in each primary health centre (PHC).It will have details like age, address, ward number, panchayat, date of quarantine and the country from which the person arrived. The facility will help track the health condition of the people in quarantine and ensure that they get medicine on time.The medical team also noticed that some of the people in home quarantine show alcohol withdrawal symptoms. “They have been given counselling and medicine by the medical team at the PHC level. If they need more attention, they will be shifted to the psychiatric ward at Government Medical College, Ernakulam. Four or five people, who used to consume alcohol on daily basis, showed the symptoms,” said a health official.Agriculture minister V S Sunil Kumar said facilities have been arranged for people to buy vegetables and fruits online with the support of Horticorp and agriculture department in the district. He said the facilities at hospitals, which have been partially or completely shut down, will be used to strengthen preventive measures against the spread of Covid-19.Considering the emergency situation, the functioning of toll plazas at Kumbalam and Ponnarimangalam has been suspended till March 31.Doctors have started to address the concerns of people regarding Covid-19 via Facebook page of Ernakulam district collector. The facility will be available for the public for one hour every day.To meet the emergency situation in the district, as many as 4,482 rooms in 270 wards in both government and private hospitals are made available. A total of 8,734 beds, 1,337 ICUs, 390 ventilators and 400 ambulances are ready to meet any emergency.Minister said it has come to his notice that people are still gathering in various parts of the district. Strict action will be taken against them for violating Section 144 of the CrPc, which has come into force in Ernakulam. He added that stringent action will be initiated against those who sell essential products at exorbitant rate.District civil supplies office has constituted three teams to conduct inspection in shops to prevent merchants from selling products at excess rate.

Title: Police personnel caning motorists will face action, says Pune CP Venkatesham
Content:
Citizens in a spot

PUNE: Police commissioner K Venkatesham on Tuesday assured action against police personnel found caning motorists while implementing Section 144 CrPC orders in the city.“We will identify all such cases and take action if complaints are received. The policemen on the roads have been instructed to follow all the rules and directives issued under Section 144 CrPC. We have directed them not to use force, but the 144 Section orders are as clear as the writing on the wall. People are not to come out on the roads,” Venkatesham said.The assurance followed reports of policemen caning two-wheeler riders and autorickshaw drivers in the fringe areas of the city, including Sinhagad Road. As per motorists, vehicle users were made to hold placards proclaiming that they were ‘enemy of the society’ and they ‘won’t cooperate with the administration’ at some places.When asked about these instances, the police claimed that in most of these cases, the vehicle users were found moving around without any purpose and in defiance of the Section 144 orders. “We have also come across instances where people, who were not willing to go on their jobs or government employees not willing to go for emergency services, claimed that they were being blocked by the police. However, on verification, we have found such claims as incorrect,” Venkatesham said.The Section 144 orders, issued on Monday, have banned movement of all private and non-essential vehicles on the roads as a part of a state-wide lockdown for maintaining the social distancing norm to counter the massive health scare caused by the Covid-19 spread.When contacted, joint commissioner of police Ravindra Shisve said, “We have asked policemen to file cases under Section 188 IPC (disobedience of an order promulgated by a public authority) against the errant vehicle users defying Section 144 orders instead of caning them. If a policeman is using force, it is wrong. Inquiry will be ordered against such high-handed approach.”While the police have identified a list of essential services, which stand exempted from the ban, others have been directed to strictly stay at home or contact the grievance cell numbers for permission to ply their vehicles in case of emergencies like need for medical attention. People are allowed to visit their neighbourhood grocery/vegetable outlets for buying essentials. The police have installed barricades at several junctions for stopping vehicle users, moving around without any purpose, from going any further.Despite these measures, a significant number of two-wheeler riders and motorists ventured out on the roads on Tuesday morning. Senior inspector Anil Patil of the Pune traffic branch told TOI, “Many vehicle users came on the road for buying essentials, vegetables and even articles needed for Gudi Padwa (Marathi New Year) celebrations. We had to counsel them about the prevailing health scare and asked them to return, which they did,” he said.A large number of people were seen at market places like the Gultekdi market yard and on Satara Road, near Pune University chowk , Sinhagad Road, old parts of the city, Yerawada , Vishrantwadi and Deccan Gymkhana. This prompted the police to take “action”.The police chief insisted on optimum use of the grievance cell numbers (see box) by the people to seek clarifications regarding their queries and permission for vehicular movement in case of an emergency. “We are trying to be perfect, but things will take time to settle down. We are helping people in many other ways including blood donation, assistance for PG students and senior citizens,” Venkatesham said.Shisve said, “We are not issuing any fresh orders, but are focusing on the implementation of the Section 144 orders issued on Monday.”A resident of Kalyaninagar who had stepped out to buy some medicines said, “I saw policemen hitting some youngsters on the roads who had ventured out on their scooters and bikes. The police had sticks and they were stopping these men and hitting them. I noticed that they were not troubling women, but the solo riders who were young men were being targeted.”A resident of Shivane near Warje Malwadi said on Monday morning, a vegetable vegetable vendor had to bear the brunt of the police. “When the police noticed more than 10 people gathered near the stall, they first told everyone to leave the stall and then reprimanded the vendor. They also told the vendor to leave the area immediately,” he said.In another incident, the police stopped two youths who were driving the motorcycle. As the duo was not wearing the masks, the police told them to remove their shirts and cover their faces. The duo were then allowed to go.

Title: Uttarakhand HC puts stay on use of heavy machines for mining in Sarayu
Content:
Representative image

NAINITAL: The Uttarakhand High Court (HC) on Monday put a stay on the use of heavy machines for mining in the Sarayu river in Bageshwar district.

A bench of Chief Justice Ramesh Ranganathan and Justice Ramesh Chandra Khulbe gave the order while hearing a Public Interest Litigation (PIL) filed by Bageshwar-resident Pramod Kumar Mehta.

The petitioner had argued in the PIL that the state government, through an advertisement, had asked for public biddings for mining into the river. "By inviting open bidding, the administration has given approval to use of machines in the river but for years, the mining in the holy river has been done manually. The administration is trying to benefit the mining mafia with such an order and therefore, its illegal," Mehta said.

He added that the use of big machines will not only affect the local economy but also lead to environmental degradation. "The Sarayu river is of immense religious significance and therefore, it is necessary that it is protected," Mehta said.

The HC has given three weeks to the state government to respond to the PIL. The court ruled that the case will be heard next when the government files its affidavit.

Title: Panic-buying swamps Pune stores, strains stocks to survive for 21 days
Content: PUNE: Mere hours before the start of the nationwide 21-day lockdown on Tuesday night, chemists, groceries and stores in the city found themselves swamped by citizens rushing to stock up on essential supplies .Reports of long queues emerged from several neighbourhoods. Businesses said many were buying as much as a month’s worth of supplies. There were also concerns over the complete breakdown of the social distancing rule.“People panicked after they heard about the lockdown,” said Yuvraj Chaudhary, a resident of Wanowrie. “I saw people rush out of their homes to get to the nearest store. This has also led to overcrowding outside the shops, which increases risk of infection. In my opinion, the availability of essential items should have been an important point in the Prime Minister’s speech.”Savita Pawar, a homemaker, said many people feared shops were likely to run out of supplies soon.She said, “I rushed to the shops on Salunke Vihar Road at Kondhwa minutes after the Prime Minister’s address, which announced the lockdown. Most shops were shut because of a shortage of goods. The stores that were open had big crowds outside. But even they didn’t have enough milk, wheat flour, grains or pulses. I managed to buy enough for my immediate requirements. People rushed because it was not immediately clear if these stores would stay open on Wednesday.”Residents said goods were being sold at extremely high prices. Half a kilo of pumpkin was being sold at Rs 100. A kilo of potatoes was being sold for Rs 90. We have to eat. What if these shops don’t open again?” said one customer.At Sinhagad Road, many residents said they were unable to make purchases because police had shut down shops in the area by noon on Tuesday. “Shops did open later in the evening, but the situation immediately became worse around 8.30pm. I saw shopkeepers pleading with customers to maintain social distancing. Many ignored the requests,” one resident said.There were also reports of hoarding and bulk buying from Vimanagar, Kalyaninagar, Wadgaonsheri and Wakdewadi areas. Shopkeepers said some customers were buying supplies to last at least a month. Neighbourhoods in Pimpri Chinchwad too reported panic buying. In Pimple Saudagar, there were long lines outside several stores. “It’s going to be a long lockdown. We have to buy enough to suffice,” a resident said.

Title: JMC distributes free meals twice a day in city
Content: Jaipur: The Jaipur Municipal Corporation ( JMC ) has started distributing food twice a day to the needy after Annapurna Rasoi — the ambitious project of former CM Vasundhara Raje to provide cheap meals to the public — was discontinued on March 21.Niranjan Aggarwal, manager of Jeevan Sambal Charitable Trust, the contractors who were handling Annapurna Rasoi since the beginning said, “Our contract was supposed to end on March 31 but due to the epidemic and lockdown, we stopped functioning from March 21. It is up to the government to start the facility for cheap meals but nothing has been decided.”An official at Directorate of Local Bodies who did not wish to be named, said that no decision has been taken by the state government to reinstate the contract. Epidemic has affected the unorganised sector the most, who are dependent on daily wages. With all the businesses shut, arranging for two-time meals has become difficult for them, but JMC has taken up the responsibility of providing food to the needy.Under the scheme Akshay Kalewa, JMC has been distributing food one time a day i.e. in the evening, for the last 13 years in the city. This has been going on in collaboration with Akshay Patra in 13 places in Jaipur. As the pandemic has adversely affected the economic situation in the country, JMC has started it twice a day.An official at JMC said, that they are bearing complete cost of food being provided in Akshay Kalewa scheme. “We approached Annapurna Rasoi at first but as they are shut down, it has become necessary to have another food distribution facility ready in the time of crisis. Earlier, we were charging Rs 5 for every meal from the public given to Akshay Patra and additional expenses were borne by organization. Now, for both the time, we are giving food free of cost to the people. In the morning, from 11am to 12noon and in the evening, from 5pm to 6pm, the meals are distributed,” said one official at JMC anonymously.

Title: MSMEs decide to shut operations till March 31 in Coimbatore
Content:
Representative image

COIMBATORE: In view of Covid-19 pandemic, micro, small and medium enterprises (MSMEs) in the district have shut their operations from 6pm on Tuesday till March 31.

Representatives of 14 MSMEs met district collector K Rajamani and took the decision to shut their units.

With Prime Minister Narendra Modi announcing 21-day nationwide lockdown on Tuesday evening, the MSMEs, however, must decide on extending the shutdown period.

For non-working days, MSME associations have decided to pay their workers and provide them with food and other necessities.

MSME units in the district employ around 1lakh migrant labourers, mostly from northern states, said J James, district president of Tamil Nadu Association of Cottage and Tiny Enterprises (TACT).

“It is our responsibility to provide them with food and safety measures. We would support them,” he said.

While bigger industries have said they would offer full payment to their workers, micro industries, which have already been reeling under crisis, would ensure them at least half their pay.

To meet with payment necessities, MSME associations have sought that the Centre provide them with subsidies for the lock down period and exempt them from ESI and PF.

The associations have also sought that statutory payments such as property tax, water tax, licence fee and electricity bill be deferred for three months.

“The electricity board has asked us to pay the same amount we paid last month as personnel could not take readings. But it is not fair as this month we have operated very little. We should be charged only for what we have used,” said S Surulivel, state vice president of Laghu Udyog Bharati.

MSME representatives also said they would not be able to pay loan dues and EMIs and sought a nil interest on loans and cash credit till the end of the current situation. They also sought a moratorium for one year from now.

R Ramamurthy, president of Coimbatore District Small Industries Association (Codissia) said MSMEs were in no position to pay any dues as they had already been in a crisis and owing to the lockdown. He said the collector had asked the lead bank manager to consider and process their request.

Meanwhile, Union finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman on Tuesday announced that all GST returns for March, April, May and composition returns would be extended to June 30. For companies which have an annual turnover of less than Rs5crore, no late fee or penalty would be charged and for those with annual turnover above Rs5crpre, interest rate would be brought down to 9%.

Title: Nagpur: During corona crisis, khaki shows its humane face
Content: NAGPUR: The outbreak of Coronavirus has projected a different image of police among the public with the khaki department switching roles from being law enforcers to life saviours, tackling many responsibilities at the same time. Having to make sea-change in their approach, dealing with Covid-19 suspected cases or patients, cops are trying to adjust to their new ‘avataar’ foisted upon them overnight by the unprecedented crisis.The different roles assigned to the cops so far against the backdrop of the viral outbreak are ranging from being posted as guards outside the isolation Ward 24 at Mayo hospital where four positive patients are recuperating to avoid any untoward incident like the escape of suspect cases last week to accompanying health officials to track down such quarantine fugitives.Some suspected cases are unwilling to get tested or quarantined and are keeping the cops on their toes with district administration not yielding to their requests. Cops and health officials have been asked to follow such cases persistently and ensure they get tested.The cops have also been assigned the role of checking the persons quarantined at home on a regular basis. Every police station has been provided with a list of quarantined people. Every day cops are visiting their homes and themselves risking getting infected to see whether they are following the orders.Cops are also posted outside the MLA hostel which has been earmarked to quarantine people arriving from other places. They have also taken up the role of preachers and agents of social change through awareness drives and delivering messages for the masses.A senior cop said that it was scary to visit homes of the quarantined people and even worse when the person himself or herself opens the door. “We stepped back with apprehension when a quarantined person opened the door for us. Whenever we ring the door bell, we pray to God not to send the patient for opening the door. Even them peeping out of the window at us leaves us in cold sweat,” he said. “It’s more challenging and tricky when some suspects try to disobey or hide,” said the cop.The issue turned worse with police department delaying purchase and distribution of masks and sanitizers for want of funds for bulk orders following which the top brass had to intervene.City police chief BK Upadhyay said the responsibilities of being part of the fire-fighting team of the government to contain the epidemic had re-moulded their image and re-shaped their convictions. “This newer responsibilities transformed us to a new avataar where we are switching fro from being enforcers to preachers. Suddenly, we realized we were not chasing criminals but helping patients who are generally from common masses who has never dealt with us. We had to scale up our humane side, patiently listening to them and convincing them to follow the norms and save the rest of the society,” he said.Upadhyay said every police station was sending out updates, awareness messages and information to the alert citizens through social media regularly. “We are campaigning on our own and also channelling messages sent to us by the government,” he said. “We are enforcing the norms of keeping road vendors away, keeping paan and tea kiosks closed, shops shut as much as possible. We are also requesting the people to restrict house parties and programmes so as to avoid mass contacts,” said the top cop.Bajaj Nagar police, teamed up with NGO, are extending help to senior citizens and children. They are now compiling names and details of the senior citizens who have been advised to stay inside as safety measure. The cops and the NGO members are planning to help them get their daily supplies when they would not be able to access shops and outlets.

Title: Do not roam around city unnecessarily: Collector
Content: Kolhapur: District collector Daulat Desai has warned citizens against roaming around the city in groups.He appealed citizens with foreign travel history but are asymptomatic to self-quarantine themselves in their homes. “If these individuals are found to be roaming outside, they will have to face the action, including the institutionalized quarantine of 14 days,” he added.According to the district information office, a total of 619 citizens arrived in Kolhapur , who had foreign travel history in the last few weeks. A total of 23 suspects were admitted to the isolation facility and after their swab samples were found to be negative, 14 have been discharged. Nine swab samples are still awaited.It added that 194 citizens having foreign travel history have completed their 14-day quarantine period till date, while 442 are still home quarantined.

Title: Kerala: GIS maps to study Covid-19 spread
Content:
The map prepared by the university students

The map prepared by the university students

KOCHI: A group of research scholars in the department of Geography at Sree Sankaracharya University of Sanskrit, Kalady, is using geographic information system (GIS) to indicate the spatial distribution in increase/decrease of persons under Covid-19 observation in Kerala.The teachers and researchers are using sophisticated software in the department laboratory to maps of Kerala showing the spread of Covid-19 in all 14 districts using data provided by the health department. The research team said that interpretations from the maps, which gives easily comprehensible facts of the virus spread, can be used to develop holistic approaches in formulating preventive measures in the state for the coming weeks.“We have started creating maps using QGIS software with the help of data from the website of directorate of health service and also the Facebook pages of district collectors. We started making the maps from March 12. It will be easily comprehended by anyone as it shows the number of persons in hospital isolation ward, home quarantine, new cases, positive case, etc, with the help of color-coding. As part of our social responsibility, we thought it will be helpful for all to understand the spread better,” said Sajilesh K, a research scholar at the varsity.They said that the maps reflect the global process of the spread of the pandemic in the same order starting from China, Europe, America and the Middle East. “The first case was reported in Kerala after students from Wuhan came here. When the virus spread in Europe, mainly Italy, we reported cases in Pathanamthitta and Kottayam as these areas are home to many Keralites in Italy and other European countries. There were fewer cases then in north Kerala at that time. But now, with more cases being reported in the Middle East, the situation in north Kerala, which has more people working in the Gulf, has become grim. The trend shows that the spread is now towards north Kerala,” said SajileshAt present, three research scholars are working on the project and the department is planning to increase the number of research scholars in the coming weeks. But, with the varsity and labs shut down it is challenge for them.“We are planning to bring out a map on how the disease spread in each district in the coming days by marking it according to various local bodies,” said Dr T S Saju, head, department of geography, Sree Sankaracharya University of Sanskrit, Kalady.

Title: Buyers pick veggies over virus
Content:
Vijayawada: Panic buying continued across city markets on Tuesday morning. People in large numbers jostled with one another as they swept items off the shelves.

The Vijayawada Municipal Corporation (VMC), as it had announced, established makeshift vegetable markets at Indira Gandhi Municipal Stadium (IGMS), Gymkhana grounds, Patamata High school and other open spaces.

Officials permitted the sale of essential commodities from 6 am to 9 am. A soon as they opened the gates at IGMS stadium, thousands of buyers rushed to the stalls ignoring the announcements made on the mics by municipal authorities. Consequently, the police had to intervene to restore order. But that order lasted momentarily as buyers ignored social distancing and resumed scrambling to buy essential commodities.

Meanwhile, authorities have restricted bulk sale to prevent black marketing. “We have closed Swaraj Maidan Rythu Bazar as it is overcrowded, which increases the risk of the virus spreading. Makeshift market at IGMS is spacious and we have allocated stalls, which are at least three meters away from each other. We have urged buyers to maintain queues following the instructions on social distancing. But there is a poor response from the public. Our officials are planning to implement the rules stringently from Wednesday,” said Chandramohan Estate officer at Swarajmaidan Rythu Bazaar .

Police cleared the crowd after 9 am and directed the sellers to close the stalls. Officials are likley to set up barricades to prevent people jostling in front of stalls from Wednesday.

Title: Curfew sparks inter-, intra-state reverse migration in Tamil Nadu
Content:
Representative image

COIMBATORE: The curfew that kicked in from 6pm on Tuesday sparked off a major inter– state as well as intra-state reverse migration of people flurrying to get back to their native places.

With train services cancelled, the state transport machinery grappled with milling crowds in all the major transit points across Tamil Nadu, particularly Chennai, Madurai and Trichy. Scores of people started gathering at Walayar check post at Tamil Nadu–Kerala border in Coimbatore district from morning. They were natives of Coimbatore and adjoining districts working in various places across Kerala, anxious to return to their hometowns before the curfew was imposed.

As the health workers struggled to screen everyone and bring in order, there was occasional commotion since the crowd got restless due to the delay.

They were asked to produce documents to show that they hailed from Tamil Nadu. A team of doctors screening the people were taken aback by the unexpected crowd. Much to the disappointment of health workers, several of them failed to cooperate and did not maintain a distance of one metre among them. The health workers also spotted a few trying to bypass the queue to get across the border posing as patients in an ambulance. They were screened and let off with a warning.

“The health department should have appointed more staff for screening anticipating the crowd. Also, if someone is screened at one check-post they should be let off in the next instead of stopping them at every district border,’’ said Goutham, a native of Ooty in Nilgiris district who was travelling from Kerala to Nilgiris.

The chaos started from Koyambedu in Chennai where hundreds thronged the buses heading to cities and towns across Tamil Nadu. Those who managed to squeeze into the buses and reach Madurai had to face a tougher challenge there since transportation to smaller towns down south was not available.

Long distance private buses had one last run with their seats full before they went off road. Some private buses operated special trips from Chennai to Nagercoil, Coimbatore to Nagercoil and Chennai with all the seats booked.

Groups of friends shared their car rides from places like Chennai and Bengaluru to Madurai, Coimbatore and Trichy. “Seeing the crowd at Koyambedu we knew that we could not get a comfortable seat. So, we shared the fuel cost and the toll charges and drove in our car,’’ said Shiju of Nagercoil.

Tamil Nadu State Transport Corporation (TNSTC) operated around 550 special services in Trichy to clear the rush of passengers who descended from Chennai to head to various districts in Central and south Tamil Nadu on Tuesday morning. This was in addition to the 930 buses operated regularly every day.

“At least 2.5 lakh people travelled to their respective districts from Trichy till Tuesday evening. Most of them have come from Chennai,” said a TNSTC official in Trichy. The buses were gradually reduced towards evening and by the time the curfew set in, they were moved to the depots.

Even after the curfew was imposed many sought to step out into the streets. In Dharmapuri, the police resorted to lathi-charge to chase the crowd near the bus stand in Dharmapuri town on Tuesday evening around 7pm, an hour after the curfew was enforced in the state.

Title: Have not been provided safety gear: Doctors posted at Champawat borders
Content:
The doctors are forced to work without have running water or any other basic facilities

PITHORAGARH: Doctors who have been posted at the inter-state border in Champawat to check for Covid-19 patients are complaining of lack of protective gear. The doctors added that they are forced to work in makeshift camps which don’t have running water or any other basic facilities.

“The Champawat district administration had on Monday sealed the inter-district and international border with Nepal. At the seven entry points in the district, doctors and police personnel have been posted for screening,” said Champawat district magistrate SN Pandey. “Many persons come here from different parts of the country, which is why screening is necessary. Doctors check for symptoms like cough, cold or respiratory problems and ask them where they are coming from,” added the DM.

The doctors, who did not want to be named, said that they had been sent 40km away from their postings and transportation being restricted, they had received few medical equipment. “The district administration has sent us no masks or sanitizers. We have made makeshift camps with no facilities whatsoever. Work is not a problem for us as long as we get proper medical equipment and protective gear,” said one of the doctors.

District Aurvedic and Unani officer Umesh Chandra Pathak admitted that the doctors’ concern was genuine. “We have sent a demand for the equipment to Champawat chief medical officer. The gear should reach the doctors shortly,” said Pathak.

“Till now, the administration has been busy handling the issues of Nepal border and Purnagiri mela. The administration will shortly take care of the scarcity,” said the DM. “The district has four thermal guns. Some will be sent to Almora and Pithoragarh border points as per necessity. The administration will take over government vehicles and provide them to the doctors,” he added.

Title: Pune: Response time to WhatsApp travel request messages irks some people
Content:
Policemen enquire about a mototcyclist’s purpose behind venturing out.

PUNE: A section of residents on Tuesday supported the ban imposed on the movement of traffic by the police and hailed the release of WhatsApp numbers to address travel-related queries, but the response time was a sore point for a few.

The city police, on Monday night, shared two WhatsApp numbers for citizens who sought to travel. Two more numbers were added on Tuesday morning and the city police released a format for seeking permission to commute. The applicants concerned need to furnish name, phone number, destination, vehicle number and specific details related to the cause of travel in the WhatsApp message sent to the police seeking permission to travel.

According to a senior officer from the special branch of the Pune police, the WhatsApp numbers were flooded with travel requests. “The special branch, till 4pm, had received over 3,000 requests on WhatsApp and email,” the officer said.

Several citizens stated that they received permission to travel quickly. Twitter user ShashiM had sent a request to the police stating, “Will go to dairy twice a week and once a week to veggie/grocery shop, without bike, alone, walking to neighbourhood store.” The department replied to his request immediately with an “Ok Sir”.

Another city resident had messaged the police on one of the WhatsApp numbers seeking permission for another person to reach the airport at 11.52pm on Monday night. The resident got the approval within minutes.

Getting the travel permission was not easy for all residents, though. Ganeshkhind Road resident Deepti Pundale said, “I had sent a message on the mentioned numbers in the morning fir going to pick up a gas cylinder from the agency but did not get a response till the evening. If we delayed further, the agency would close for the day. My mother and I walked down to the closest junction and spoke to the policemen on duty there. He said cylinder was an essential item and fetched an autorickshaw for us to go and get the cylinder.”

Amee Parikh from the US sent messages to the Pune police WhatsApp numbers seeking travel permission for her father’s caretakers in Pune. “I sent WhatsApp messages on two numbers at 2.30am IST, but not in the given format. On reviewing the tweets, I sent another message as per the format at 7.17am IST. Another message for the second caretaker was sent around 9am, India time. I had sent the messages from both my US and Indian numbers but did not receive a response till Tuesday evening. Both the caretakers reached my father, but they were stopped on the way,” said Parikh.

Kharadi resident Nitin Kamath also tried to seek travel permission but did not get a response till late on Tuesday evening.

The special branch officer said, “We gave permission to many people after verifying their travel requests and a majority of them were still in pipeline on Tuesday evening. Many requests for trivial reasons were categorically rejected.”

Cell to handle commute issues

The city police on Tuesday constituted a dedicated grievance redressal cell to grant permission and exemption for vehicular movement.

The cell would comprise six personnel during the daytime and two at night. Deputy commissioner of police, crime branch, Bachchan Singh, would supervise the functioning of the cell.

“Grievances regarding serious ailments, hospital visits, urgent airport travel and emergency scenarios are being addressed on priority,” said a police officer.

“We are also working towards automating the whole process to smoothen the grievance redressal system,” one of the officers said.

Title: Pune: Plan to allow mobile hawkers’ entry into housing societies
Content: PUNE: Hawkers selling fruit and vegetables will be allowed entry into housing societies to help residents buy essential items without stepping out into the market in the wake of the nationwide lockdown amid coronavirus spread Confirming the development, Pune collector Naval Kishore Ram told TOI that the authorities were also readying plans in association with the Agricultural Produce Committee Markets (APMCs) to make the produce available to citizens at their doorstep.“We want to stop crowding at general stores. The only way to do this is by ensuring that essential items are available to people within their societies. We are drawing up a plan that will ensure that housing societies get their daily supplies,” the collector said.Sriram Gadve, a farmer from Pune market, said his vehicle carrying grapes was stopped by the police on Tuesday. “We are not even getting drivers to ferry these essential items due to fear of the police,’‘ he said, adding that essential goods would be provided and area-wise coordinator would be appointed to ensure that no citizen suffers.Kanhaiya, a vegetable vendor in Kondhwa, said he had not gone to the market to buy vegetables. “What is the use if I am not allowed to move around in the area. People are also not allowed to gather. I don’t know how much time this will take, but it has affected us big time and government should help us out,” he said.A flour mill shopowner was shut his shop for fear of police. “Will they provide us food too?’‘ he asked. “Aise baithe baithe ghar par muze kaun khilayaga?’‘ he says ( Will they give me food as well? How can I earn my bread sitting at home?)“ he asks. When told that the collector will be drawing up a plan, he says, the police have to agree otherwise it will be difficult to operate or fend their families.Housing societies that are allowing such farmers into their societies are seeing a rush when they come for selling the veggies. “It should be streamlined and people should show patience,” said a resident.

Title: RWAs impose restrictions on residents to fight virus
Content: Jaipur: Along with the district administration, many residents welfare associations (RWAs) in the city have started enforcing a set of rules to fight the spread of coronavirus.As a precautionary measure, many apartments have banned the entry of maids and drivers in the premises. To break the human contact chain, Rangoli Gardens Owner Welfare Society has prohibited the entry of all outside visitors including daily vendors. Bhawani Singh, a resident of the society said, “Since March 21, there has been a ban on the entry of maids, cooks, car cleaners in the premises. Only milk suppliers and newspaper hawkers are allowed. However, their access is till the ground floor of the blocks. Every society needs to take stringent measures likes ours to prevent the virus from spreading.”Though, many residents’ associations have not imposed restrictions on the movement of people, they have stopped allowing any doorstep delivery personnel inside the complexes and have asked the residents to either come to the reception and pick the order by themselves or to collect it later from the security personnel.However, there are many residential buildings where it is expected that the residents are intelligent enough to follow social distancing because of which no restrictions have been put in place. Anand Jain of Girnar Apartment said, “We have not imposed restrictions on people as they are educated and well-informed. Most of them have isolated themselves on their own, but there are a few elderly members in our society who cannot work without domestic help. It will be unfair to them if we make them do so.”Also, there are many apartments where the residents can be seen walking inside the premises without even wearing masks. A resident of Mahima apartment in Jagatpura on the condition of anonymity said, “Many elderly people are walking freely. They are the most vulnerable and restrictions should be imposed on them for their good.”While the RWAs have restricted entry of support staff in few areas, the domestic helps are also refraining from coming to work. Sunita Devi, who works as a domestic help in Chitrakoot area said, “It is difficult to travel as all public transport has been stopped. I used to take the bus but it is worrisome to do so with so much news about the virus. Even if I do not get paid, I’d rather not take the risk.”

Title: Will ensure essential commodities to public: Nilgiris collector
Content: UDHAGAMANDALAM: CrPC Section 144 came into effect in the Nilgiris at 6pm on Tuesday as part of the state government’s preventive measure to contain the spread of coronavirus In a press release, collector J Innocent Divya appealed the residents to avoid public gathering and not to come out of their houses if there weren’t any emergency case. “Gathering of more than five people and walking along in groups are prohibited. Strict action will be taken against the violators,” it said.Shops that were exempted by the government notification would, however, continue to function. They include grocery shops, medical shops and those selling other essential items. While hotels and small-time restaurants will remain closed, food parcel is allowed. Other commercial establishments, including Tasmac outlets, would remain closed during the period While services of private and govt buses, taxis and auto rickshaws would remain cancelled, ambulance and hospital vehicles would be allowed to operate, Divya said.District borders and state borders have been closed for vehicles, except for those carrying essential commodities, the collector said.According to the release, except the teachers and other education department officials who have been deployed for the ongoing public examination, others could work from home during the period.“The district administration has taken all the steps to ensure availability of essential commodities to the public,” the collector said.

Title: Pune wholesale traders to shut shop for today
Content:
PUNE: Vegetable traders at the Gultekdi wholesale market announced on Tuesday that operations will be shut on Wednesday, while the district administration and APMC heads were in talks with them to urge them to keep functioning in the following days. The final decision regarding the same is expected to be taken on Wednesday.

BJ Deshmukh, administrator of Pune APMC told TOI, “Discussions are on between the district administration, APMC chiefs and traders to resolve this issue. Traders are being convinced to continue the vegetable selling operations in Market Yard in Gultekdi. Commission agents and traders have left, fearing the spread of the novel coronavirus in Pune. But, we are trying to convince them. The issue will be resolved soon.”

The Chhatrapati Shivaji Market Yard Traders’ and Agents’ Association said supplies sent out on Tuesday to retail outlets would suffice for three to four days. Vilas Bhujbal , the association’s president told TOI, “Almost double the trucks (200) delivered supplies to Market Yard on Tuesday.”

Title: Stranded Telugus send SOS, want to be flown back home
Content:
Vijayawada: The Andhra Pradesh Non-Resident Telugu Society (APNRTS) is focusing its resources in aiding Non-Resident Telugus (NRT) stranded across the world to return to India.

According to APNRTS, it has received over 800 calls in the last five days which broadly includes family members as well as NRTs stranded in various places who are looking to return to India.

APNRTS officials said one flight with 113 passengers including 30 NRTs from Malaysia arrived on Monday night. This flight brought transit passengers who were stranded at the Kuala Lumpur airport.

These people have been kept at ITBP Quarantine Centre in Delhi. Representations were sent to foreign secretary, MEA and local Indian Embassies to bring students and travellers stranded in Italy, Philippines, Malaysia, Kazakhstan, the UK and Georgia. Some of them have been stranded in the airports.

As a result, one flight with 185 passengers flew from Malaysia to Visakhapatnam on March 18 despite travel restrictions which included 70% Telugus. One flight from Almaty, Kazakhstan, was allowed to fly on March 21st with medical students of whom tens of Telugu students came to India.

Another Air India flight from Rome arrived in New Delhi on March 22 with 263 passengers on board. Around 30 students from AP and 65 from Telangana returned and are at ITBP quarantine centre.

“We are asking all recent international travellers to put themselves into 14-day quarantine upon entry to the state. Anyone returned from a foreign country failing to comply with the guidelines of the government will be punished as per law,” APNRTS spokesperson said. Officials said that there are many other NRT students and visitors are stuck at various countries and that CMO and APNRTS at the instructions of CM YS Jaganmohan Reddy, are talking with the MEA and the embassies to find a way to bring them back after the travel ban is lifted.

Title: Egg and rice stock to be door-delivered
Content:
Amaravati: The state government has directed headmasters to deliver rice and eggs to the doorsteps of their students in the wake of declaration of sudden holidays. The ration will be distributed with the help of village and ward volunteers. TOI in a report on March 20

“Schools stuck with piles of eggs... As Suppliers Refuse To Take Back Stock” highlighted the issue of egg stocks piling up in schools.

The school education principal secretary B Rajasekhar said in a memo issued to headmaters that the decision to distribute rice, chikki (groundnut snack) and eggs to children was taken to prevent malnutrition during the holidays.

He asked officials to distribute at least 1kg rice, 4 ckikkis and eight eggs to each student of primary classes and 1.5 kg rice, four chikkis and eight eggs for each of the upper-primary and high school students. The ration quota was assessed considering that the schools would likely be reopened on April1. The present quota of ration was sufficient for eight days till the reopening of the schools.

A decision regarding further distribution of rice and eggs would be taken after making an assessment after March 31. The government has also directed women and child welfare department to supply rice and eggs to children studying in Anganwadi centres.

Title: Mother-son duo booked for not following home-isolation order
Content: Udaipur: Sukher police on Tuesday registered a case against a mother-son duo for non-compliance of home-isolation order.This is first such case in Udaipur as the son who had returned from Bangkok on March 20 was found socialising with people instead or confining himself indoors.SHO Sukher D P Dadhich told reporters that Jhamak Aggarwal, a resident of New Keshav Nagar and his mother Sunita, were charged under Section 188 of the IPC for disobeying goverment orders. The family had been isolated and were instructed many a times not to mingle with others in the neighbourhood. Police sent Jhamak and his father Chandan to an isolation centre at OTC here, while Sunita and her daughter were confined to their home.On Tuesday, too, police had to take strict measures to deter people commuting on the streets without valid reasons. Over 150 motorcycles and scooters were seized from such people while at some places police held a campaign by making people hold notices in their hands where in it was written that he was ‘an irresponsible person who didn’t follow rules and was least bothered of community spread of the virus ’. In Banswara, too, police caught such people and posted their pictures on social media.

Title: Tirupur patient’s wife tests negative for Covid-19
Content: COIMBATORE: Less than 12 hours after a 48-year-old businessman from Tirupur tested positive for Covid-19, public health authorities on Tuesday confirmed that his wife, who was transported to ESIC Hospital in Coimbatore, has tested negative for the virus.His daughter and driver have also been isolated and throats swabs were taken for the tests, though both remain asymptomatic. While his daughter has been home quarantined, the driver is quarantined at the Tirupur GH.The patient, who the health minister tweeted had tested positive, had travelled to London and flown down to Chennai on March 15. “We understand that he drove down from Chennai to Tirupur in his own vehicle the same night or early next day,” said Tirupur collector K Vijaykarthikeyan.“The patient suspected he had the virus and immediately quarantined himself. On 17th, he contacted the helpline number and the Tirupur GH team went to his house and collected his throat swab,” he said. “Though the results still weren’t out, on 20th, he got himself admitted in ESIC Hospital,” he added.The public health department in Tirupur have so far placed 197 people under home quarantine , including the patient’s daughter, and have allotted a team to track them. “Police and revenue officials have been stationed in front of every quarantined person’s home, to ensure no one goes in or out of the house,” said Vijaykarthikeyan. “Another team has been allocated to trace contacts of Covid-19 positive patients and even those with who are showing symptoms,” he said.Police home guards have also been sent to the 314-odd quarantined households in the district to keep them inside their homes. “We have already begun sticking the dark green quarantine stickers in front of the houses and stamping people’s hands too, so they can’t be missed,” said deputy director of public health, Dr G Ramesh Kumar Contact tracing of the Spain return patient who tested positive for Covid-19, continues. Officials identified people who travelled with her in the A1 coach of the Yeshwanthpur Express on March 14 and passed on contacts to Kerala.Another four people with travel histories have come to ESIC Hospital with symptoms of the virus. “Throat swabs of the new patients have been collected and they have been quarantined for now. We have another eight people already in quarantine despite them being tested negative,” said dean, Dr Nirmala.

Title: Govt package for poor,pensioners & students
Content:
Patna: Bihar CM Nitish Kumar on Monday announced a major relief package for the people affected by the lockdown in urban and semi-urban areas of the state in the wake of Covid-19.

Nitish said all ration card holder families across the state would be given one month ration free. “Rs1,000 per family will also be given to all ration card holder families residing in lockdown areas. This amount will be transferred directly in the bank accounts of beneficiaries under direct benefit transfer (DBT),” Nitish said in a video message released by his office this evening.

Besides, all government doctors and health employees would be paid an incentive equivalent to their one month’s basic pay, he said.

In an apparent attempt to help senior citizens, the CM announced three-month advance pension to all pension holders covered under the Mukhya Mantri Vridjan Pension, Dibyang Pension, widow pension and old-age pension schemes. This amount would be directly transferred in their bank accounts.

Moreover, the due scholarship amount of all students from Class 1 to XII would be sent in their bank accounts by March 31, he said.

The decision was taken at a high-level meeting attended by deputy CM Sushil Kumar Modi, health minister Mangal Pandey, water resources minister Sanjay Kumar Jha, chief secretary Deepak Kumar and several senior officials.

Main points:

All ration card holder families to get one month ration free

· Rs1,000 per family to all ration card holders living in lockdown areas

· One month basic pay to all government doctors and paramedical staff as incentive

· 3-month advance pension to state pensioners

· Scholarship amount to all students from Class 1 to XII will be sent in their bank accounts by March 31

Title: Private hospitals to set up flu clinics in Haridwar, screen Covid-19 suspects
Content: HARIDWAR: Flu clinics are being set up in Haridwar and other districts in the state “for free treatment of flu patients” as per an advisory issued by the Union government. As flu, which is common during change of weather, has symptoms similar to those of Covid-19, the clinics will screen suspected covid cases and refer them to government hospitals Government hospitals will decide whether the referred patients should be put in isolation wards or in home quarantine, or be given treatment, said Haridwar district government hospital chief medical superintendent Rajesh Gupta to TOI on Tuesday.In a letter written on Tuesday to private hospitals in the district, CMO Saroj Naithani directed all private hospitals “to set up flu clinics and start free OPD service at these.” In case a clinic comes across a case of suspected Covid-19 infection, it should ensure that the case is immediately referred to the isolation ward of a government hospital so that their test samples are taken on time,” the letter said. “Once operational, flu clinics will reduce the present load on government hospitals and help them provide better service to suspected coronavirus cases,” Gupta said. He added that “some clinics might start functioning from Wednesday as a few of the private hospitals have already agreed to implement the direction.”The CMO’s letter specified that “the clinics will operate as per guidelines mentioned in the government’s advisory.”

Title: In Udham Singh Nagar, 17 shopkeepers held for defying Covid-19 guidelines
Content: RUDRAPUR: As many as 17 shopkeepers were held by Udham Singh Nagar police on Tuesday after they were found to be flouting norms regarding Covid-19 during lockdown in the state. These traders kept their shops open even after 10 am despite the state government order that shops can remain open only between 7 am and 10 am.The state government on Monday had ordered that all ration, grocery, and milk shops can remain open only for three hours — 7 am to 10 am.Gadarpur SHO Jaswinder Singh told TOI, “On Tuesday at 9 am, police vehicles patrolled across the district and made the announcement that people have one more hour to make essential purchases. But even after 10 am, we found several traders violating the prohibitory orders.” The arrested shopkeepers also included former city president of BJP Harish Sukhija According to Rudrapur SHO Kailash Chandra Bhatt , the accused have been booked under section 188 (violating order promulgated by the government), section 269 (Negligent act likely to spread infection of disease dangerous to life), section 270 (malignant act likely to spread infection of disease dangerous to life) of the Indian Penal Code and section 81 of the Police Act.All of them were granted bail from the respective city police stations later, added the official.Assistant Regional Transport Officer (ARTO) Sandeep Saini told TOI that 30 vehicles were impounded and their drivers were challaned for flouting norms on Tuesday.Meanwhile, the police also impounded 183 vehicles. Reports of misbehaviour by police officials also surfaced from some areas of the district. The locals alleged that police bludgeoned people who were out seeking essential medical services."They were not even sparing women. I saw two policewomen beating an elderly lady near a petrol pump in the city,” said Sanjay Juenja, president of Rudrapur Traders’ Union.Sonu Naagi, a resident of Bazpur, said, "Police broke down a bike with sticks and also beat the rider. They could have impounded the vehicle but they resorted to unacceptable methods.” When asked about the allegations, SHO Bhatt denied any such manhandling by police officials.

Title: Class XII students in Madurai relieved as exams end before curfew
Content:
Representative image

MADURAI: The more than 36,000 Class XII students in Madurai district who had appeared for the state board exams this year breathed a sigh of relief as they completed their final exam on Tuesday just before Section 144 was imposed across the state.

A total of 34,869 students sit the final exam in Madurai on Tuesday. Amid the Covid-19 scare, the exams began half an hour late at 10:30 am and ended by 1:30 pm. All the 120 centres here were disinfected and students had to sanitise their hands before entering the exam hall. However, after the exams, students were seen celebrating and running out of the exam halls in groups, prompting police and teachers to discipline them.

Instead of the usual cheers and tears, all students were immediately sent home with many not even returning to their schools to say a farewell. “During our Class X board exam, the whole class celebrated in school with teachers. Today, we were just relived that exams are over instead of getting postponed,” said Sruthi R, a Class XII student of a private school.

Meanwhile, teachers and students said that the new syllabus, introduced for the first time across all subjects, was challenging but not too daunting. “The questions were asked from all chapters for all subjects. Students were quite happy since they did not feel cornered by one or two difficult topics. It may be difficult to get high scores because of everything being new but students can easily get pass marks. We are all hoping for the best,” said the headmaster of a government school.

The evaluation of Class XII board exam answer sheets, in view of the curfews imposed in the state has been tentatively postponed to April 7.

Title: Woman, son killed over open defecation dispute
Content:
Patna: At a time when the entire state machinery is on tenterhooks to prevent spread of conoravirus, a dispute over open defecation cost the lives of a 50-year-old woman and her minor son and left three others seriously wounded in Saran district on Monday. This happened despite the fact that there is 100% ODF coverage in Bihar.

The incident took place around 7am at Haranbadha village under the Maker police station area in Saran district, around 60km north of Patna. A 15-year-old boy was caught defecating in the field of Sanjay Thakur and his brother Sunil Thakur, which led to thrashing of the former on the spot.

When the victim returned home and narrated his ordeal, his mother Ranju Devi (50) went to Thakurs’ house to know about the reason for the assault on her minor son. She was attacked with a sharp-edged weapon causing grievous injuries on her head, which led to her instant death.

When Ranju’s minor son, Subhash, came to the rescue of his mother, he was again beaten up and assaulted with a ‘daab (a sharp edged weapon used to cut hard substance)’ by Sunil and Sanjay. Subhash suffered serious injuries in the process. He was rushed to the local primary health centre from where he was referred to the Patna Medical College and Hospital (PMCH). He, however, succumbed to his injuries on way to the PMCH.

Four other family members — Pana Devi (55), Etbari Thakur (57), Soni Devi (30) and Babli Devi (28) — were injured when they intervened and tried to save the deceased from the clutches of their offenders.

Marhaurha sub-divisional police officer (SDPO) Indrajeet Paswan said three of the seriously wounded have been referred to for better treatment. Babli Devi, who suffered minor injuries in the altercation, is undergoing treatment at the local government hospital.

The SDPO said the incident was fallout of an altercation over defecation in the field of Sunil and Sanjay, stated to be neighbours of the deceased. Saran SP Har Kishor Rai said two persons, including the main accused, have been arrested and the weapon used in the crime recovered.

While Sanjay was arrested, his brother Sunil is absconding. The incident has sent shock waves among the residents of the village.

Title: Govt may call CRPF if non-compliance continues in Vizag
Content:
Visakhapatnam: The district administration is planning to request for paramilitary forces if the public continued to violate the lockdown. Even after repeated requests and a stark difference to observance of the janata curfew, people on Tuesday roamed the streets and argued with police.
