Tourism minister M Srinivasa Rao and collector V Vinay Chand told TOI that they have given permission to depute minimum staff only to essential sectors, including pharmaceutical. “We are giving permission for minimum staff in all sectors. Essential commodities shops would remain open. If anybody is found on the roads who is unable to provide a convincing excuse for being there, they will be taken into custody,’ they said.

Meanwhile, Visakha rural police, who registered 32 cases on Monday, registered more than 100 cases on Tuesday. “The situation is little better than yesterday. But the sudden holidays have given youths the time to roam. We are not sparing anyone,’ Visakh rural SP Babujee Attada told TOI.

When asked about the deployment of paramilitary forces, district in-charge minister K Kannababu said, “We will review the situation and, if necessary, we will take a decision. Our cops are striving hard by putting their lives in danger. People should understand this,” he said.

In the city, police registered 58 cases against people for violating the lockdown; impounded 91 vehicles and collected fine worth Rs 7 lakh.

“We have given time to people to buy essential commodities and are allowing medical and other emergency services, but people are going out just for fun,” Madhurawada cone assistant commissioner of police Reddy said. He urged the public to be at homes.

Title: NGOs join battle to combat coronavirus in tigerlands
Content: Nagpur: Even as cities have geared up to tackle novel coronavirus (Covid-19) outbreak, NGOs working in the buffer zone of tiger reserves are also doing their lot to screen villagers for symptoms and to spread awareness about the dreaded infection.In a major awareness and health check-up camp for tribals, Satpuda Foundation, an NGO working for tiger conservation in Central India, screened 300 residents of six villages in the buffer zone of Pench Tiger Reserve (PTR), Maharashtra.A unique mobile health service (MHS) of Satpuda Foundation is helping tribal villagers of Pench by educating them about the dos and don’ts to save themselves from acquiring coronavirus infection. The MHS, which was launched to serve locals living around the reserve in January 2014, has come handy during the novel coronavirus outbreak.“Though Section 144 has been imposed in Nagpur and academic institutions have been closed down, health sector staffers are serving day and night in this critical situation,” said Kishor Rithe, president of Satpuda Foundation. Satpuda’s mobile health service has conducted health camps and offered medical assistance to 300 patients from six villages — Wagholi, Sillari, Khursapar, Sawara, Khapa and Ghoti.“Those suffering from fever and cough were particularly worried about the possibility of having coronavirus infection. However, it was found that people there suffered from routine fever and cough,” said Dr Manohar Khode , who is serving the tribals for more than 20 years in Melghat, after the health camps.“The MHS, which is also spreading awareness on dos and don’ts to prevent spread of coronavirus, has treated around 70,000 patients in the last six years and also offered further support for surgeries, eye operations and dental extractions. Medicine is also being distributed for free,” said Rithe.Satpuda’s conservation officer Mandar Pingle, Bandu Uike and Dilip Lanjewar informed that in the second phase similar screenings will be done from March 23 in six villages in the buffer zone of Pench on Madhya Pradesh side.Similarly, in the buffer zone of Melghat Tiger Reserve (MTR), Dr Ashish Satav ’s MAHAN (Meditation, Addiction, Health, AIDS and Nutrition), an NGO providing preventive and curative medical facilities to tribals, also screened many villagers for coronavirus-like symptoms in the last 20 days.Dr Satav said, “Our team is spreading awareness among tribals from 35 villages in the tiger reserve buffer. Two villagers having corona-like symptoms were referred to Amravati, but these patients tested negative.”“We are creating massive awareness on precautions to be taken as many villagers are still unaware about the repercussions of the deadly virus. They have also been told not to leave their homes or go outstation,” said Dr Satav.CapA tribal from Pench buffer being given medical advise

Title: Mortar found abandoned in Premnagar area of Dehradun triggers panic
Content:
Dehradun: A misfired mortar was found at Dehradun 's Premnagar area on Tuesday. The recovery of the weapon triggered panic among the residents.

"We recieved information on Tuesday morning from residents that a suspicious object is lying on the shore of a dried up river near Nanda Ki Chowki ," said an official of Prem Nagar police station.

Upon checking, the suspicious object was identified as misfired mortar by the police personnel. Immediately, Bomb Disposal Squad (BDS) was called for the preliminary investigation.

After an operation that lasted over an hour, the Bomb Disposal Squad managed to diffuse the mortar.

According to police, it appeared that some scrap dealer picked the particular mortar from the firing range and left it there.

Title: Four medical shops shut for selling overpriced goods in Tamil Nadu
Content:
Representative image

MADURAI: The Tamil Nadu Drugs Control Department has shut down four medical shops operating in the southern districts of the state for violations with regard to sale of masks and hand sanitisers . On Tuesday, 11 medical shops in Madurai district were raided by a team of police officials from Civil Supplies CID .

“One shop each in Theni and Madurai and two shops in Dindigul district were shut down after we received complaints of these shops selling masks and hand sanitisers at inflated prices. We have been regularly inspecting pharmacies to ensure they are not indulging in any malpractices,” said an official from the Drugs Control Department. Anyone with complaints of a pharmacies selling sub-standard or overpriced masks and hand sanitisers can approach the department.

Meanwhile, a team of police officials headed by inspector Alagarsamy, Civil Supplies CID, raided as many as 11 medical shops in Madurai on Tuesday to check violations of norms in sale of masks and hand sanitisers. Though no shop was shut down, all shop owners were issued warnings.

Days after masks and hand sanitisers were declared as essential commodities by government, pharmacies in Madurai are grappling with shortage of hand sanitisers. They continue to be priced high. However, Drugs Control department officials said that price will soon come down. “The price of masks has been capped at Rs 10 while the price of 200 ml hand sanitiser has been capped at around Rs 100. The shops are in a transition phase. In a few days, the prices will be back to normal. We are doing our best to ensure there if no shortage of supplies as well,” added an official.

Title: Veterinary polyclinic at Thallakulam is still working, but under vigil
Content:
Representative image

MADURAI: The government veterinary polyclinic at Thallakulam in the district continues to function as an essential service amid Section 144 being imposed due to the Covid-19 scare. The veterinary hospital is currently seeing about 100 visitors a day and has implemented various preventive measures.

“The polyclinic will remain fully functional and we are trying our best during these difficult times. Sick animals must be cared for. We have ample preventive measures in place and have even put up banners and posters creating awareness about Covid-19,” said Dr K Vairavasamy , clinician at the polyclinic.

The veterinary doctor said the first thing emphasized is maintaining cleanliness.

“We have our staff continually sanitising the hospital with Lysol and hypochlorite formulation as recommended. We are also providing the public with hand sanitizers and hand wash liquids to cleanse their hands when entering the hospital,” added Dr Vairavasamy.

The visitors while waiting with their animals have also been asked to maintain a distance of 1 metre between themselves.

The staff are particularly careful in handling sick animals, sanitising their hands before and after handling them. They have been given masks, gloves and caps as well.

“Though we have been asked to not handle any animal which is too sick and seems infectious, taking precautions, we put in our best efforts to save it,” said Dr Vairavasamy.

Around 150-200 animals undergo treatment at the hospital every day, including around 80-100 pet animals. The doctor added that even anti-rabies vaccination for pets would continue to be done since only less than 20 pets are brought for vaccination a day.

Regional Joint Director of Animal Husbandry, Suresh Christober advised pet owners to maintain social distancing with animals too as a preventive measure when especially under home quarantine.

Title: Doctor tests positive for Covid-19 in Ahmednagar
Content: Nashik: A doctor tested positive for Covid-19 in Ahmednagar city on Tuesday, taking the total number of those infected with the contagion to three in the district.According to district administration officials, the male doctor who tested positive does not have any history of overseas travel unlike the other two patients, who had travelled to Dubai.“The doctor, who had cold, cough and fever, was admitted to a private hospital. His swab sample was sent to the Pune-based NIV (National Institute of Virology) and the report came today,” said the officials.District health department sources said the doctors, nurses and para medical staff who were in close contact with the patient at the private hospital, would be examined by the district health authorities.“Since the patient is a doctor, we are also gathering details of the patients he had examined over a period of time. We are also ascertaining if the doctor came in contact with Covid-19 patients,” the sources said.Ahmednagar district collector Rahul Dwivedi reiterated the need for people to remain indoors and avoid any kind of gathering. “Take all precautions advocated by central and state governments to prevent yourselves from being infected by the virus.”Ahmednagar is among the 75 districts in the country identified by the Centre with Covid 19 positive cases. The Centre had advocated complete lockdown in these districts even before the PM announced a lockdown of the whole nation during his speech late on Tuesday evening.The district administration had already closed down all commercial establishments across Ahmednagar district, barring those selling essential items.It has also restricted operations of petrol pumps in the district from 5am to 9am and police have been deployed to prevent movement of people on roads, except those in emergency situations.

Title: Shops selling essential goods to remain open in Salem
Content:
Representative image

SALEM: Shops providing essential commodities such as vegetables, milk parlours, medical stores and grocery shops will remain open in Salem .

However, the Salem municipal corporation (SMC) officials have asked the supermarkets and commercial establishments (marriage halls, malls etc) in the city to be closed from on Tuesday onwards. Any shop with a housing capacity of more than 10 people has to remain closed.

The state government has imposed section 144 of CrPC across Tamil Nadu as a preventive measure against Covid-19. The state also directed the hotels to provide only ‘take away’ parcels and not to accommodate customers inside the hotel.

Meanwhile, the Salem district administration and the corporation officials have started inspecting the city since Tuesday evening. They shut down supermarkets and commercial complexes that were seen operating after 6 pm on Tuesday.

The corporation officials warned that, they will permanently seal the shops if owners violate government order.

Title: Covid-19 samples to be tested at AIIMS-Rishikesh, IIP-Dehradun
Content: DEHRADUN: The testing of Covid-19 samples will now also be done at AIIMS Rishikesh and Indian Institute of Petroleum Dehradun . Till now, the testing of the samples was being done only at Government Medical College Haldwani. The new testing facilities were announced by the state government after an approval by the Centre.Meanwhile, the health department announced that reports of 22 suspected Covid-19 patients were received on Tuesday and all of them tested negative. Around 31 new samples were sent for Covid-19 test on March 24. So far, 237 samples have been sent for testing of which 180 samples were found negative while four have tested positive and results of the rest are awaited.The department has further announced that maternity and women wing of Government Doon Medical College and Hospital (GDMCH) would be shifted to Gandhi Shatabdi Hospital The health department will also be identifying two hotels near GDMCH which would be used as rest houses by the doctors treating Covid-19 patients at the hospital.

Title: Latecomer corp faces hurdles in fight against virus
Content:
Kochi: Kochi corporation , which has failed to act fast, is now unable to find places where sanitization facilities for the public as part of Break the Chain campaign can be set up. As per the decision, the local body should have set up the facilities at 50 places.

The local body is unable to set up the facility even in 20 places. “At many places we identified for setting up the facilities, other agencies have installed it. Moreover, there is shortage of wash basins as well. Wash basins are being hired by many agencies,” said corporation health standing committee chairperson Prathibha Ansari. The plan was to set up the facilities at places like market, bus stations, railway stations, etc. Wash basins, soaps and sanitizers are being provided there.

Another plan was to procure one lakh face masks and distribute it among vulnerable persons like vendors at markets who contact many persons every day, autorickshaw drivers, passengers heading to railway stations, taxi drivers, etc. But the local body is unable to procure adequate face masks. “Due to shortage of masks, we were finding its procurement very hard. Now, we have managed to procure an additional of around 25,000 masks. We are distributing them,” said corporation secretary Anu R S. Though the local body planned to buy two infrared thermometers, it could purchase only one. “We are using the thermometer for testing temperature of those visiting the corporation office,” Anu said. “As per the decision, we are distributing food packets to the needy,” she said.

Shortage of staff for cleaning and other activities as part of fighting Covid-19 is another hurdle faced by the local body. “Our health staff like junior public health inspectors are going to the streets and imparting awareness to the public,” Anu said. On Tuesday, corporation staff, along with fire and rescue personnel, visited an apartment complex where 43 persons have been quarantined. As part the efforts to prevent community spread, the entire apartment complex and its surroundings were cleaned using bleaching powder and phenyl. Fogging was also conducted in the area. “Shortage of staff for carrying out the activities in this regard is a problem for us,” Anu said.

Corporation authorities said they are taking measures to ensure that public places like market are clean and hygienic. If a vendor is found to be adopting unhygienic practices, his or her licence should be cancelled. “We are doing the bare minimal work so far as our office administration is concerned. We have turned the entire focus on activities related to the measures to fight Covid-19,” corporation secretary said.

Title: Police rope in volunteers to restrict movement of motorists
Content:
Nashik: The Nashik police on Tuesday roped in volunteers in different parts of the city to stop movement of vehicles in their area. Police personnel along with volunteers were seen halting motorists and demanding reason for stepping out of houses.

Volunteers were seen in the Bhaba Nagar and Sarda Circle areas of the city. Police has also asked the Bhaba Nagar area volunteers to keep a watch on the movement of vehicles in the Mumbai Naka area as well.

A volunteer said that they had put up a rope across the junction so stop the movement of motorists crossing the road. “We ask the motorists where they are proceeding to and the reason behind it. When we realise that the motorist is trying to fool us, we bring it to the notice of the police personnel who are present at the spot. The policemen then instruct them to return home. If the motorist has a genuine reason, we lift up the rope and let the vehicle pass by,” the volunteer said.

A senior officer of the Mumbai Naka police station said, “Some youths are proving handy to deter motorists from using the streets. We are also available on the spot if the motorists argue with them.”

The volunteers said that police may also give them passes in future if in case they need any help.

Title: Ensure smooth ops of print, electronic media to check fake news: Centre to states
Content: NEW DELHI: With the country under lockdown to rein in the spread of the coronavirus pandemic, the ministry of information and broadcasting on Tuesday directed chief secretaries of all states and Union Territories to ensure uninterrupted supply of all print and electronic media The order , which comes in the backdrop of misinformation and fears over newspapers being carriers of infections, emphasises the need for “robust and essential information” networks to disseminate “timely and aut hentic information”. It says, “The proper functioning of these networks is required not only to create awareness among people and to give important messages but also to keep the nation updated of the latest status. False and fake news need to be avoided and good practices need to be promoted and these networks play a pivotal role in ensuring the same.”To ensure the “uninterrupted operation” of these networks at “this critical juncture”, the government order lists “printing presses and distribution infrastructure of newspapers and magazines”, news agencies and TV channels among “critical infrastructure”.The order asks states and UTs to facilitate the “operational convenience” of media by permitting them and their intermediaries to keep functioning, and to allow the movement of accredited staff and their vehicles, as well as ensure “uninterrupted electric supply and other logistics as requested”. And in any case any problem is faced by the media in providing uninterrupted service, they should “coordinate with the local authorities”.Ensure smooth ops of print, electronic media to check fake news: Centre to states

Title: Hyderabad: Residents show camaraderie in hard times
Content: HYDERABAD: As the city continued to battle the Covid-19 outbreak, heartening stories of camaraderie poured in from various corners of Hyderabad, with residents reaching to help each other and also those in need. Right from sharing vegetables and essentials with neighbours and distributing ‘care packages’ among the poor, to ferrying medicines for elderly people living alone in Hyderabad, citizens were found doing all they could to extend a hand in support.“This is a time when every Indian should realise that if they have two rotis on the plate, they should share one will someone who has no access to food,” said Shaaz Mehmood, one of the three people who coined the #helpthehungry initiative. As part of this, the team is distributing provision packages, comprising dry groceries, soaps and medicines, among the poor.“We are particularly targeting construction workers, windows and single women running small stalls in the city. In the first phase we hope to reach out to distribute about 2,500 such packets in the city,” he added. The initiative is simultaneously being launched in Chennai, Bengaluru, Delhi and parts of north Karnataka as well.Created in 2016, the Sainikpuri Garden Club has come out to help local residents. The group was formed so that members could exchange seeds, saplings as well as self-grown fruits and vegetables. Beyniaz Edulji is among the members who offers fresh produce. “I started planting fruits and veggies at my organic mango and lime orchard in Nandyal a few years ago. I later realised that I could offer what I had to others as well. We don’t use pesticides and fertilisers.”Others in the group with home gardens just offer the extras they have. Jayashree Uppal said, “I grow all the green vegetables and don’t need to buy them. In addition, there is jackfruit, lettuce and coconuts. I often give the extra fruits and vegetables to neighbours and friends.”While city developer, Ashwin Rao, started with a social media post to reach out to parents of friends living abroad, he is in the process of creating a network of volunteers. “It was my way of doing my bit for the elderly – mostly deliver medicines and basic essentials to them. Since we have movement restriction now, we are trying to create a network of volunteers – alumni of HPS, Ramanthapur to reach out to as many people as we can,” Rao said.

Title: Salem collector urges contacts of Covid-19 patients to approach health department
Content: SALEM: District collector S A Raman has urged the public to come forward for self-declaration if they had any contact with 11 Indonesians who had spent their time in the city for nearly 13 days. The collector said the Indonesian team went to five mosques in the city and attended religious meetings there.Raman said the Indonesian Muslims came to the city on March 11 from New Delhi. They went to a mosque at Rahamath Nagar in Suramangalam police station limit on the next day.Later, they had visited Para Market mosque in Shevapet police station limit on March 13 and stayed there for two days. “They had given religious preaching in the mosque for three days,” he said, adding that, later they had stayed from March 16 to March 18 at Sheik-Umar mosque in Ammapet police station limit, Buharia mosque between March 19 and 21 and Janadul Firdhouse mosque at Kitchipalayam on March 22.“They went with another five people, including one person from Chennai and the rest from Salem,” the collector said, adding that all the 16 people were admitted to the quarantine ward in Salem government Mohan Kumaramangalam medical college and hospital for treatment.He urged those who attended the sermons held by the Indonesians to reach the health department officials at the earliest. “People can contact the officials via 1077 – the toll-free number, 0427-2450022, 2450023 and 2450498 telephone numbers at the earliest,” he added.

Title: Salem region shuts down; violators warned of action
Content:
Representative image

SALEM: As the clock was ticking towards 6pm on Tuesday, five district administrations in the Salem region were in the process of checking the arrangements for the implementation of the lockdown. Not only isolating their concerned district from neighbouring districts, they were also working to isolate it from neighbouring states too as Dharmapuri, Krishnagiri and Erode districts share borders with other states.

Salem district S P Deepa Ganigar told reporters that the district police have set up 21 checkposts along the district border. “Police personnel will monitor the vehicle movements until further orders at these checkposts. They will stop other state vehicles trying to enter into the district. They will insist drivers and passengers to wear face masks, maintain social distancing as well as follow other guidelines prescribed by the state and the central governments,” she said, adding that “Vehicles and people will be allowed only after sanitising them.”

Salem city police commissioner T Senthil Kumar warned that people who violate Section 144 will be booked under Section 188 (disobedience to order duly promulgated by public servant), Section 269 (negligent act likely to spread infection of disease dangerous to life), Section 270 (malignant act likely to spread infection of disease dangerous to life), Section 271 (knowingly disobeying any quarantine rule) under the IPC. “A total of 850 police personnel has been deployed in the city to enforce the lockdown. We have set up 10 checkposts along the city border and they will monitor the situation round the clock,” he said.

Namakkal SP R Arularasu warned that criminal case will be registered against vehicle users especially bikers if they violate Section 144 of the CrPC during the lockdown. “People should not travel on bikes or any other vehicles including cars in the town without any valid reasons,” he said. “People are allowed to use the road only to buy essential commodities such as vegetables, milk, food items and medicines. Violating vehicles will be confiscated, if any cases are registered. Parents will face criminal action if their minor son or daughter violates the government order.”

Erode district collector C Kathiravan said the district administration has taken all the steps to enforce Section 144 in the district. “We have asked vegetable vendors to open their shops only between 6am and 10am. Farmers and merchants those who have identity cards will be allowed in the Uzhalavar shandies during this period. Street hawkers and vendors will not be allowed to set up shops,” he said.

Title: Police raid two pvt firms, book people violating curfew
Content:
Nashik: The Nashik city police booked approximately 150 people under section 188 (disobedience to order duly promulgated by public servant) of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) on Monday for violating orders of the city police commissioner with respect to restriction on assembly of four or more people.

Two firms in the city that were found operating were also raided by the police. The managers and owners of these firms were also booked under section 188 of the IPC.

On Monday, when prohibition of assembly of four or more people in an area, people were seen violating the prohibition orders. There was a rush at market places, grocery stores and a general rush of motorists on the roads.

A senior official of the city police commissionerate said, “The zone 1 of police took action against 80 people in their zone. Similarly, the zone II police took action against 73 people in their jurisdiction.”

The Sarkarwada police booked an IT firm, where approximately 200 people were working. The police said they were continuously making announcements on their public address system that other than establishments of essential services, no other services should be functioning when section 144 of the CrPC was in force.

The Sarkarwada police took similar action against two people of one more firm for violating the government orders. With the police coming down heavily on those violating the prohibition orders on Monday evening, there were fewer people on the roads all through Tuesday.

Police nakabandi was seen in various parts of the city. Those travelling by their respective four-wheelers had to take long de-tours to reach their respective destinations.

Title: Udupi Big Bazaar in soup for violating govt order
Content:
UDUPI: A complaint was lodged against retail chain Big Bazaar in Udupi on Tuesday for allegedly flouting government guidelines on containing the spread of Covid-19 .

Deputy commissioner G Jagadeesh, superintendent of police N Vishnuvardhan and team were on a surprise inspection when they discovered the Big Bazaar outlet was selling essential items at higher rates. There were over 25 staff working at the outlet and they were operating air conditioner despite the warning from the district authorities. Further, the customers were allowed to enter the outlet without any precautionary measures, said the DC.

Tahsildar Pradeep Kurdekar on Tuesday lodged a complaint against the supermarket and a case was registered at Udupi City police station.

Malpe port to be shut

The DC visited Malpe Harbour on Tuesday and instructed the Malpe Fishermen’s Association to suspend all activities immediately. However, association president Krishna Suvarna urged the DC to give them some more time to wind up the business and sell the catch arriving on Tuesday evening. The DC gave them the time to wrap up business by Wednesday.

Title: ‘Gudi Padwa will offer an escape from corona negativity’
Content:
Nagpur: There will be some cheer on Wednesday amid gloomy lockdown and work from home. Balconies and terrace of the will look more beautiful as decorated gudhis prop up on the occasion of Gudi Padwa , the pious and positive beginning of Maharashtrian new year.

Artistically decorated gudhis, with printed sarees and flower garland will stand atop the houses. Gudi Padwa is a spring-time festival that marks beginning of traditional New Year for Marathi and Konkani Hindus. It is celebrated in Maharashtra and Goa on the first day of the Chaitra month according to lunisolar Hindu calendar.

The festival is observed with colourful rangoli, a special Gudi flag (garlanded with flowers, mango and neem leaves, topped with upturned silver or copper vessel), and festive food. “The celebration of Gudhipadwa this year will be at home. We are going to celebrate with full enthusiasm along with family but no relatives and friends. Greeting each other on phone and social media will cheer up our day. In my family of artists, we have decided to paint on canvas and start new year with hope and pray for all human beings, especially for the doctors and police and all those giving their service in fight against the coronavirus,” said Milind Limbekar, a painter.

Colourful rangolis, leaf and flower garland at the door and making delicious shrikhand with saffron are the highlights of this unique festival. Mugdha Tapas, who is very excited to celebrate this New Year with her family, shared some insights about its importance. “We usually visit Ram Mandir and offer prayers, but this year we will celebrate it at home. We will wake up early and prepare the gudhi, decorate it and do a small pooja. Then the entire family will feast on traditional Maharashtrian food such as shrikhand, puri etc,” she said.

Although the temples and roads will wear a deserted look, citizens are excited and optimistic to celebrate the festival with their loved ones. Aditya Sawarkar, a budding classical vocalist, is urging the citizens to stay at home and avoid going to grocery shops, so crowd can be avoided to buy sweets or prasad. “People should cook prasad at homes and celebrate it with zeal,” he said.

“We will perform Gudhi puja and chant some powerful mantras and do ‘upasana’ with family and pray to god for the well being of whole world,” he added.

Writer Arundhati Vaidya feels occasion of Gudhipadwa will be an escape from the negativity and corona fear in the form of small happy celebrations at home. She is looking forward to the festival. “We will celebrate at home by waking up early and putting on fresh clothes, as it’s New Year. We make prasad at home and offer gathi to the gudi,” she said.

Title: HC Madurai bench restricts functioning
Content: MADURAI: The Madurai bench of the Madras high court has begun restricting its functioning from Tuesday for three weeks as per guidelines issued by the Madras high court Chief Justice A P Sahi, in an attempt to prevent the spread of Covid-19.A notification issued by the registrar (judicial), said that in view of the emergent situation which has arisen on account of Covid-19 pandemic, it has become imperative to adopt the guidelines issued by the Chief Justice at the principal seat, with slight modifications, for the restricted functioning of the Madurai bench. The lawyers are requested not to operate from their chambers and they are requested not to invite the litigants inside unless it is absolutely imperative either for their personal presence that may be required on orders of the court or for such personal verification as per the directions of the registry. Lawyers are requested to limit filing of cases as far as possible except only in extremely urgent matters. As per the notification, changes have been made to the sitting arrangement in Madurai bench as follows.A division bench of justice P N Prakash and justice S S Sundar will hear urgent motions and admissions in writ petitions, writ appeals and habeas corpus petitions.After the division bench sitting, justice P N Prakash will hear urgent motions and admissions in criminal original petitions (under Section 482 of Cr.PC) and justice S S Sundar will hear all single bench appellate side matters. Justice G Jayachandran will hear criminal original petitions - bail and anticipatory bail petitions.tnn

Title: Kolkata: Supply of milk, atta, oil faces lockdown heat
Content: KOLKATA: The government has kept food and grocery items on the exempted list during lockdown, but production of edible oil, milk, soap, handwash and biscuits have already started suffering a serious jolt.All leading manufacturers are witnessing shortage of packaging material , workers and transporters since Monday itself. Most units have already cut down on production and some others may follow suit in the next few days, which is likely to lead to a shortage of food and other items.Sources in FMCG industry indicated that ITC’s production of food items like biscuits, packaged atta, noodles and items like handwash, soap, sanitizers has been affected nationally, including West Bengal (for last one day).The ITC factories in Panchla and Uluberia, which mainly manufacture food products , have been shut down since Monday evening. It is now waiting for clarification before resuming work at these facilities.An ITC spokesperson said: “While it is extremely critical to ensure adoption of precautionary measures, including hand hygiene, social distancing and isolation during this period, it is also important that during such challenging times, essential products are made available to consumers. As various state governments issue notifications, we are in discussions with them to ensure that manufacturing and distribution of essential products are streamlined.”“In many states, production of noodles, packaged atta have been stopped. Some noodle plants in West Bengal, that supply to big multinational brands, have stopped production following lack of packaging material and non availability of workforce,” an official from food industry said.He explained that number of people going to factory has also gone down drastically in the state from Monday. “The workers are saying no public transport is available to come to factory.” According to the official, the distributors are also facing it difficulty in bringing products to their warehouses.The director of Emami Ltd, Aditya Agarwal told TOI that it has three edible oil plants in the country. Out of which, Rajasthan plant was shut following this lockdown.The West Bengal plant is working since we have got permission as essential supply but at 20% of the capacity.“The problem is lack of labour force and transportation. Edible oil not only needed for cooking but is the raw material for biscuit, cake, breads,” he added. The production of processed milk in the state have also been affected due to lack of packaging material and workers.Incidentally, Indian Chamber of Commerce (ICC) has appealed to both centre and state government to find ways of extending the ‘support products and services list’ of non-essentials to ensure availability of essentials.

Title: 2 people shifted to isolation ward
Content:
Hyderabad: Two people who travelled from abroad have been sent to isolation centres in the city because they were not following the home-quarantine.

A person from the US travelled via Singapore and reached the city on March 10. A resident of Avanti Nagar, she was checked by a GHMC team, but she was not following home-quarantine. On the instructions of GHMC zonal commissioner, a medical team and police shifted her to an isolation centre.

Similarly, a resident at Gayatrinagar came from UK on March 15 and was also found violating home-quarantine guidelines. He was shifted to isolation ward . TNN

Title: MHT-CET exam pushed back
Content: Mumbai: The state government has postponed the MHT-CET exam, scheduled from April 13 to 23, till further orders. The state’s CET cell released a circular on Tuesday after a three-week nationwide lockdown was announced. It had already postponed MCA entrance. LLB entrance exam may be suspended soon. tnn

Title: Plea to conduct re-poll to panchayat vice-president post
Content:
MADURAI: A woman ward councillor has filed a petition seeking to conduct re-election to the post of vice-president of S Melapatti village panchayat in Madurai district .

The petitioner, M Tamilselvi stated that she was elected as ward councillor of ward six of S Melapatti village panchayat. She stated that subsequently she decided to contest for the indirect election conducted for the post of vice-president of the village panchayat. Though the indirect election was scheduled on January 11, the election was postponed by the authorities without mentioning any reasons to the ward councillors. On January 30, a rival candidate Mahalingam was declared as elected without even disclosing the number of votes which was polled in his favour.

She stated that the authorities have colluded with the rival candidate and declared him as elected. Since the election was conducted with several irregularities, the petitioner moved the high court Madurai bench seeking to conduct re-election. Hearing the plea, a division bench of justices S S Sundar and C Saravanan sought a response from the state government and adjourned the case to a further date for hearing.

Title: In UP cities, Yogi Adityanath government to deliver food at doorsteps
Content:
File photo of Yogi Adityanath

LUCKNOW: Minutes after PM Narendra Modi imposed a three-week nationwide lockdown, asking people not to cross the ‘laxman rekha’ of their homes, UP chief minister Yogi Adityanath said his government would deliver essential commodities like fruits, milk, vegetables and medicines at the doorstep in the cities across the state.

“We have arranged 10,000 vehicles, including 4,500 police response vehicles, 4,200 ambulances and other official vehicles, to ensure delivery of essential items. From Wednesday, these vehicles will carry vegetables, milk, fruits, medicines and other necessary items to all areas of cities in the state,” Yogi said, adding that no person should leave homes unless allowed by the administration of the concerned district.

“Volunteers, who could be drawn from civil defence committees and Nehru Yuva Kendras , should be healthy and below 55 years of age. Volunteers can also deliver essential items like medicines. With Navaratra starting Wednesday, I have also issued directives for availability of puja material in colonies,” the CM said.

During the 21-day lockdown, the UP government has decided to encourage restaurants to provide home delivery. or the supply of essential food items, control rooms will be established in all districts and supply officials of mandis, milk, agriculture and animal husbandry departments will be deployed to ensure coordination among departments.

With Navaratra starting Wednesday, I have also issued directives for availability of puja material in colonies,” the CM said.

Title: Namaz at home: Decree issued to devout
Content: HYDERABAD: Amidst hints by Saudi government that Haj 2020 may not be held due to novel coronavirus threat, Muslim religious scholars in Hyderabad cutting across sects on Tuesday issued a fatwa (decree) urging Muslims to offer daily prayers at home. This is perhaps the first time in many centuries that Muslim leaders in Hyderabad have appealed to Muslims to keep indoors and offer the five daily prayers at home.Muslim leaders from various schools of Islamic jurisprudence held a meeting at the 144-year-old Jamia Nizamia, Islamic deemed university in the city, and decided to restrict congregational prayers in mosques.After the meeting Jamia Nizamia vice-chancellor Mufti Khaleel Ahmed announced that though mosques will not be locked, people must offer prayers at home.“Those staying in the mosques will give the call for prayer (Azaan) and offer prayers. People in the neighbourhood should offer prayers at home. The decision was taken in view of the grave threat posed by coronavirus. Stay safe and make others safe by not leaving homes,” Mufti Khaleel Ahmed said. He said Friday congregation will be limited to a few people. Those leading the Friday congregation will cut short the ‘Khutbah’ (sermon) and wind up prayers in the shortest possible time. For better sanitation, all carpets in mosques will be removed and mosques will be cleaned after every prayer.Senior Muslim scholar Moulana Abdul Kareem told TOI that it is rare that decrees are issued to offer obligatory prayers at home. It was done during the period of Prophet Mohammad, 14 centuries ago when there were largescale floods or infectious diseases. Moulana Mufti Anwar Ahmed of Jamia Nizamia said there is a provision in Islamic jurisprudence to offer obligatory prayers at home during times of distress or calamities.”

Title: Lucknow command centre set up to monitor coronavirus battle
Content: LUCKNOW: UP medical education minister Suresh Khanna opened a command centre at Jawahar Bhawan on Tuesday for efficient monitoring of coronavirus outbreak and the preparedness in Covid Hospitals in state’s medical colleges and announced a slew of measures for upgrading the medical infrastructure and preparedness for handling corona cases. Khanna told TOI that personal protective equipment (PPEs) and ventilators are being procured on emergency basis and the government has relaxed its procurement policy and specifications to ensure their availability in good numbers.The government has also decided to hire doctors from private nursing homes and ex-defence personnel of medical wing for manning the isolation wards in Covid Hospitals. The department is also engaging tent suppliers for setting up makeshift Covid hospitals if required.The command centre set up at the directorate of medical education in Jawahar Bhawan would be headed by an IAS officer as coordinator and would take feedback from Covid Hospitals and medical colleges treating coronavirus patients.Hailing PM Narendra Modi ’s declaration of a 21-day lockdown across the nation, Khanna said, “Prevention is the best cure in this case so people should follow PM’s directions in true letter and spirit.”Khanna also announced to give his one month’s salary for the battle against corona and said the state is fully prepared to face any situation and there is no need to panic.Khanna, who also holds the portfolio of finance ministry, also assured there would be no paucity of funds in facing coronavirus challenge. He said the stiff target of having 11,000 isolation beds has almost been achieved in private and government medical colleges.Principal secretary, medical education, Rajnish Dube said integrated committees have been set up at district level to monitor situation.In view of shortage of anesthetists and other experts, Khanna granted permission for hiring trained and experienced professionals from private nursing homes and hospitals, Dube added.

Title: Railway hospitals call for more masks, kits
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: Railway hospitals in Secunderabad are facing a shortage of masks and personal protection kits.

“We were informed that the state all necessary equipment to keep staff safe, but we are not receiving adequate supply of masks,” a source told TOI.

Hospital staff from railway hospital in Mettuguda have alleged that the number of beds in the isolation ward is significantly lower than required. “We also do not have enough hand sanitizers. We were promised Personal Protection Equipment (PPE) kit withmasks, goggles, gloves, gowns, head covers and shoe covers. But we have not been provided these yet,” the source added.

The total number of staffers is pegged at 650 including doctors, nurses and workers. Sources from the hospital revealed that there are 10 quarantined railway employees in the hospital. Four of the patients were advised isolation due to their recent foreign travel history and one was transferred to Gandhi Hospital. The other six were quarantined since March 19 because they were suspected to have come in contact with one of the Covid-19 positive cases.

Doctors working in the OPD wing of the railway hospital in Lallaguda have also registered their complaints with South Central Railway (SCR) authorities. “We deal with patients who have flu, cough and fever everyday and we don’t have proper preventive practices in the wing,” a hospital staffer reported on condition of anonymity.

The divisional railway managers (DRMs) in the SCR zone had earlier informed that when the train services were running, there was an acute shortage of face masks for their frontline staff dealing with passengers everyday.

“We have provided 1,000 isolation beds in the zone and will increase the number if required. Preventive measures are being taken while dealing with Covid-19 cases,” a senior SCR official told TOI.

“The staff is also being quarantined after their services on a rotational basis. We are currently fully equipped to handle the cases we are getting,” he said.

Title: UP Chief secretary R K Tiwari: No student to be evicted from hostels
Content:
R K Tiwari

Chief secretary R K Tiwari has directed all state training institutes not to evict a single student from hostel till further instructions even if no training is taking place.

Meanwhile, UP government has sanctioned Rs 13.5 crore as one time fund for purchase of essential medical consumables and equipment as required by each district. The funds are to be spent only on those items which have been cleared by government .

Title: Govt staff offer help to combat pandemic
Content:
Hyderabad: Government school teachers and other employees have come forward and offering their services to the state government as it attempts to contain the spread of coronavirus.

The employees have requested the state to avail the services of government employees, teachers and pensioners till March 31.

“The state is already utilising services of employees of several departments like police, municipal, revenue, electricity. If needed, the state can also use our services in preventing the spread of coronavirus,” said United Teachers Federation (UTF) general secretary, Chava Ravi

He added that in the past, teachers and employees have played a crucial role while dealing with natural disasters.

Meanwhile, some teachers took to Twitter to reach out to their respective collectors and offer their services.

The teachers said that rather than sitting at home during the lockdown, it would better for them to help the state by doing voluntary work.

Title: Grocery supplies running short: Shop owners in Lucknow
Content:
Representative image

LUCKNOW: The stock in grocery stores is also drying up due to decline in supply, mainly because many wholesalers have shut shop due to restrictions imposed to check the spread of coronavirus. Many said that they will be left with no stock of wheat, oil, rice, pulses and other essential items over the next 10 days.

“Since all supermarkets and big provision stores are closed, people are flocking to small grocery stores in their localities. This has resulted in increase in demand. However, the supply is short as many wholesalers and dealers have closed down following the lockdown. Though these services are exempted, employees at many places have stopped coming in view of the corona threat,” said Tarun Jaiswal , a grocery shop owner in Aliganj .

Ramesh Ahuja, a store owner in Gomtinagar, said that there has been no major shortfall in supply of big brands through authorised agencies, but supply of local brands and loose wheat, rice, flour, pulses and oils have stopped.

“For me, stock of branded products is exhausting at a rapid pace. If this continues, we will neither have branded nor local ration to sell,” said Mohd Naaem , a grocery shop owner in Jankipuram .

ADM civil supplies RD Pandey said, “Supply of ration will not be stopped. We will come up with a solution within next five days.”

Title: WHO: India’s corona battle will make or break global war
Content: NEW DELHI: India may well determine the future trajectory of Covid-19, declared a global pandemic by the World Health Organisation (WHO), especially in the manner India handles the unprecedented crisis from here. Dr Michael J Ryan, executive director of WHO health emergencies programme, said this on Monday while commenting on Covid-19: “India, like China, is a hugely populous country.The future of this pandemic, to a greater extent, will be determined on what happens in very large and densely populated countries.” “So, it’s really important that India continues to take aggressive action at the public health level and at the level of society to contain, control, suppress this disease and save lives,” Ryan said.He added that India led the world in eradicating two silent killers — smallpox and polio. “Smallpox killed more people on this planet than all wars together. India, through targeted public health interventions, ended that disease and gave a great gift to the world. India also eliminated polio, another silent killer, and did tremendous job on surveillance, on finding cases, and vaccinating and doing all the things that needed to be done,” Ryan said at a media briefing on the Covid-19 crisis in Geneva, Switzerland “The pandemic is accelerating,” Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, director general of the WHO, said as he called for world leaders to stop the highly contagious viral ill ness in its tracks, where possible, while also mitigating its effect on vulnerable populations and slowing its spread in communities where the virus has already gained a foothold.As on Tuesday, Covid-19 has spread to 196 countries causing illness in nearly 4,00,000 people and claiming the lives of 17,250 people. India has seen 10 deaths due to Covid-19 till date.

Title: Use labour welfare fund to compensate trade, industry workers: FTCCI tells T
Content: Hyderabad: Following the lockdown due to the coronavirus outbreak, Federation of Telangana Chambers of Commerce & Industry ( FTCCI ) on Tuesday told the Telangana government that it would be difficult for trade and industry to pay salaries to workers by taking additional loans while foregoing production and revenues and urged the government to utilise the funds of the labour welfare fund to compensate workers for the loss of livelihood in the lockdown period.This will ease the financial stress caused by the lockdown on both, employers and workers, FTCCI president Karunendra S Jasti said in a memorandum submitted to Telangana chief secretary Somesh Kumar.The apex trade and industry body in the state has urged the state government waive for three months, the payment of penalties and interest on delayed payment of power bills, water bills, property taxes, license fee and other statutory payments that were to be made by March 31.Jasti has sought extension of time for the payment of GST without penalties and interests for three months till June 2020 as also for claim of industrial incentives under various schemes for the first half of 2019-20, for which the last date is March 31, 2020.FTCCI has also asked for extension of deadline for the 14-year sales tax (VAT) deferment that was extended to many industrial units under the state’s industrial promotion policy.“The deferred sales tax (VAT) amount of FY 2005-06 becomes due for payment by March 31, 2020. This deadline must be extended till June 30, 2020, without imposing penalties or interest,” it said.It has also urged state government to create a fund for MSMEs and extend working capital loans at no interest or minimal interest (2-3%) to tide over the financial crisis.The pending sanctioned industrial incentives should be released at the earliest before March 31 or by April end, it said.

Title: Need more workers, better training, say health staffers
Content: Hyderabad: With more coronavirus cases being reported in the state, hospital staffers have called for better training of sanitation and class-IV workers in institutions handling such cases. While there is already a shortage of such workers in hospitals, even existing workers are turning up in lesser numbers due to either fear of infection or a lack of transport facilities.Presently, there are around 300 ward boys and 200 sanitation workers at Gandhi Hospital, according to Telangana Medical Contract Workers Union. A union member confirmed that fewer workers were on duty. “After the curfew, fewer members are turning up, due to lack of transportation or fear of infection. There is an estimated shortage of 30%,” said union general secretary, M Narsimha.According to a staff member at Chest hospital, only 50 ward boys are managing 50 isolation wards. “We need more sanitation workers and ward boys. Some are not showing up for work fearing infection. Existing workers need training on how to sanitise and handle equipment in the wards,” the staffer said.“There is a dire need to train workers about donning and doffing personal protective equipment (PPE) and handling equipment in Covid-19 wards. They need proper training for their own protection as well,” said Narsimha. According to Narsimha, there are around 30 nurses working in the Covid-19 ward every day out of a total of around 400 nurses. All nurses are working in shifts at Gandhi Hospital.

Title: Stuck in UK, Kol docs seek visa extension amid fund crunch
Content: Kolkata: More than a dozen doctors from Kolkata who had been to the UK to take the PLAB 2 exam on April 17 are now stranded in Manchester and London, desperately trying to get their visas extended even as they run out of funds to pay for their accommodation. With UK going into a Covid-19-triggered lockdown , many have been asked to check out of hotels and homestays by March 31. Since flights between UK and India were suspended on March 18, the young medics have been left in the lurch, trying to get in touch with the Indian High Commission in London seeking visa extension and alternative accommodation. But till Tuesday morning, they have got no response from the Indian authorities. PLAB 2 — taken by medical graduates from all over the world to join the national health service in UK — has now been postponed to July.Calcutta National Medical College graduate Priyadarshini Bhattacharjee had landed in Manchester on March 10 along with several other doctors from Kolkata. They had no idea that the exam could be postponed till they received a mail on March 16 from the General Medical Council, which conducts the exam, that PLAB 2 has been cancelled. “We were not ready for this and tried to return immediately. But a scamper for tickets had already started and most of us failed to book a berth on any of the last flights. We have mailed to the Indian High Commission in London but did not get a reply. Some of us have our visas expiring soon and others have accommodation issues,” said Priyadarshini. Even though she has got July 22 as her new exam date, Priyadarshini is not sure if she will return.While she is lucky to be hosted by a ‘kind family’ which has allowed her to stay back, many of her fellow examinees are in trouble. “I know of 5-6 candidates from Kolkata who will run out of funds if they can’t return by March 31. Also, some of them have been asked to move out of their hotels once their booking expires on March 31,” she said.Sayantan Basu and Sharodia Mitra — both NRS graduates — are stuck in Manchester. “We are in a fix and will be in deep trouble if we can’t return by the end of the month. It has become difficult for us to fund our stay since we had expected to return by March 22 and are now left with very little money. We hope that the high commission will arrange an accommodation for us,” said Sayantan. He added that one of his friends from India — a doctor from Delhi — has been served a notice by his landlord asking him to vacate his rented apartment by this week.Priyadarshini was booked on an Emirates flight in late-March that got cancelled. “I tried for a berth on March 18 — the last day that flights operated from UK — but they were full. Now, I plan to return in mid-April, provided my visa gets extended. I have no idea what’s going to happen if it doesn’t. It is difficult for us to cope up in foreign land during a worldwide crisis such as this, with little support from our country. I understand that the high commission and the government of India must be overwhelmed with the sudden pressure from all spheres. At least few timely responses and messages of reassurance will help ease our tension,” she said.

Title: Officials must gear up: KTR
Content: Hyderabad: Municipal administration minister KT Rama Rao on Tuesday instructed officials to be proactive while tackling coronavirus cases. He said the IT companies should utilise their CSR funds for activities to prevent the spread of coronavirus.He instructed the district collectors to ensure those who have been advised home quarantine to strictly remain at home and asked them to keep a watch on them. Since most of the roads are empty due to the lockdown, the minister asked the officials to repair the damaged roads in the cities and municipalities.KTR said Annapurna canteens serving meals at Rs 5 would continue. Responding to complaints from medical staff, he urged home minister Mahmood Ali and DGP Mahendar Reddy to issue clear guidelines to police to not harass medical, health staff.

Title: Provide treatment, food to labourers in Dubai: Norka
Content: Thiruvananthapuram: Pointing out that a majority of the Covid-19 cases which were confirmed positive in the state were persons who returned from labour camps of Naif Street in Deira area, Dubai , the Norka (Non-Resident Keralites Affairs) department has written to consulate general of India in the Arab Emirate to ‘look into the matter urgently’.The letter sent by the Norka principal secretary to the consul general in Dubai on Tuesday morning attained more significance as eight out of the 14 latest confirmed cases too turned out to be persons who had reached the state from Dubai, as pointed out by chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan in the evening.“Recently the state has identified and confirmed that the majority of Covid-19 cases reported in the state are from the NRIs, who came from Dubai and were residing in the labour camps of Naif Street, Deira. Hence, keen observation and precautions for the safety of labourers of the camp is highly necessary,” the letter said, calling the attention of the consul general, Dubai.“In this circumstance, I would like to request to look into the matter urgently and also to take steps for the protection of these labourers and to provide sufficient food and treatment for them,” the letter said.

Title: Ahmedabad: Vegetable prices rise by 20%
Content: AHMEDABAD: Vegetable prices in the wholesale market may not have seen much of an increase over the past week, but with the lockdown situation prices have risen by over 20% in the last two days.Deepak Patel, secretary of the Ahmedabad Agricultural Produce Market Committee (APMC) said vegetable supply was adequate to meet the needs of the city. For Tuesday and Wednesday, sale of onions and potatoes has stopped most traders are from the Sindhi community and they were staying away due to the Cheti Chand. On Tuesday, 15,000 quintals of green vegetable arrived but there were few buyers for cauliflower and cabbage. The lockdown has not affected trading or supply, he said.Another trader said that vegetables such as brinjals, cauliflower, cabbage and bottle gourd had very few takers. Traders had to incur losses on them.A retailer in Satellite said, “Due to the lockdown situation, supply is low, and hence prices are increasing in retail. Prices in the last couple of days have increased by 20% to 25%.”Bhagwati Patel, a homemaker, said instead of going to the market she prefers app-based sellers, but since the janata curfew these apps have no delivery slots. “On Sunday, the delivery slot was available for January 26, but today there was no slot available at all and I had to buy from a local vendor.”Shital Shah, a homemaker, said, “I have been trying to get vegetables from malls but they have been closed since Monday. We were told that the stock of vegetable was over and they were forced to close.” Shah said that with malls, local vendors are charging whatever they fancy, citing supply problems.

Title: IOC forms committee to deal with Covid-19
Content:
Nagpur: The Indian Oil Corporation (IOC) has formed a high-level committee to deal with all matters related to Covid-19.

The committee has streamlined the working at the corporation’s non-critical locations with work-from-home norms to ensure proper social distancing. “Adequate workforce is also being deployed at critical refining, supply and distribution locations, with all health, hygiene and safety measures in place,” said a press release issued by the company

Manning has also been rationalized in round-the-clock shift operations. “Deployment of contract workers is being done only in essential and critical services at a bare minimum level, with adequate Covid-19 prevention and precaution measures such as hand-sanitisers and masks in place,” the release said.

Care is also being taken with respect to the tank-truck drivers transporting petroleum products to petrol pumps. Video-conferencing is being used extensively for meetings with internal as well as external stakeholders, said the press release.

Title: From chaos to uneasy calm: How Chennai went into curfew
Content:
A police patrol vehicle moves arround Broadway in Chenni on Tuesday evening

CHENNAI: Grocery stores, bus stands and Tasmac shops -- that’s where most of the city congregated on Tuesday before the lockdown came into effect. As the day dawned bright and clear, people rushed to neighbourhood stores to stock up on provisions. People crowded stores in Anna Nagar, Choolaimedu , Saidapet, Triplicane, Royapetah, Mylapore and T Nagar.

“I was not planning to stock up but many people were coming and buying things. I realised the seriousness when I found out that the packet of milk powder I picked up was the last one in the shop,” said P Anusuya, a resident shopping at a store on Ellis Road.

The sense of hurry was palpable – whether it was on the busy road or in the shops and small businesses that continued to function. By noon, a few shops started to run out of supplies such as milk powder. Along with noodles, biscuits figured high on the list for customers, who feared stocks may be scarce in the coming days.

Despite the heat and humidity, Zam Bazaar market was bustling with activity at noon and also later in the day when the 6pm deadline drew near. People rushed to buy fruits, vegetables, rice, wheat flour, coconut oil and milk products, with many buying provisions in bulk. They feared that the neighbourhood grocer or supermarket may not get supplies during the lockdown.

“I have stocks but I am not sure whether I will be getting fruits and vegetables from tomorrow. Everything that we sell here comes from Andhra and a few other districts in Tamil Nadu . I do not know how long it will take for the supplies to arrive,” said Mahesh , a fruit shop owner.

With people as well as retail outlets rushing to stock up, vegetable prices in Koyambedu market soared. For the first time, wholesale prices of some of the vegetables were higher than the retail prices. Tomato was sold at Rs 25 per kg in retail outlets while it was priced Rs 40 per kg in Koyambedu. While onions and potatoes sold at Rs 30 and Rs 33 at retail, sellers at Koyambedu charged Rs 10 more.

The Koyambedu bus terminus also saw a lot of activity as people hailing from southern and western districts desperately looked for buses so that they could reach their hometowns before authorities locked the borders. Auto drivers made a killing fleecing passengers who wanted to reach the stand.

Yet another place saw people jostling with one another so that they could stock up for the dry days ahead – Tasmac outlets were crowded from the moment they opened at noon. People with bags in hand waited patiently throughout the afternoon but as the 6pm deadline neared, there was a mad rush. In Choolaimedu, the staff had a tough time dealing with people when it was time to down the shutters. People even prised open the shutters and demanded that they continue to sell booze.

In Zam Bazaar, as the lockdown began, police asked all shop owners, and also restaurants to close. Only medical shops and pushcarts selling fruits were spared. People quickly converged on the vendors to buy the last of their produce.

“They told us in the afternoon that we can function but now they say that it is better to close when the shutdown begins. The police said that we can open in the morning,” said N Mani, who runs an eatery.

Post 6pm, police patrolled the city, asking traders to shut shops. Just as quickly, silence fell over the city, and the main thoroughfares looked deserted. The busy city settled down for the night, and braced for the long fight ahead. 21 days.

(With inputs from B A Raju and A Prathap)

Title: CAIT hails package for poor
Content:
Nagpur: The Confederation of All India Traders (CAIT) has appreciated the social welfare package announced by finance minister Nirmala Seetharaman for the poor.

“Such a move will ensure dignified life of poorer srata of the society during this troubled period. The social welfare package was much required at this point of time as the poor were worried about their livelihood,” said a press release issued by the CAIT.

CAIT president BC Bhartia said he hoped that similar announcements will also be soon made for those like traders, transporters, small industries and self employed persons.

The government first ensured safety from health hazards by announcing the lockdown, which was followed by deferment of all statutory and tax compliances and now a package of Rs1.70 lakh crore to provide support to the poor like daily wagers has been announced. “The package will result in circulation of money into the retail markets as it will bring extra disposable income in hands of the people,” said the CAIT press release

Title: Grocery, essential products selling shops to remain open for 3 hours in Uttarakhand
Content:
Representative image

DEHRADUN: To ensure that people of Uttarakhand are not deprived of essential products, the Uttarakhand government has decided to keep these shops open for 3 hours on Wednesday as well.

"People need not panic and have faith on us. Our government will ensure that the essential products are provided to people. Strict lockdown will be ensured but at the same time, we will ensure that these shops are open from 7am to 10am on Wednesday as well," the CM said, adding that "people need to follow the guidelines as staying at home will help the state and country fight Covid-19."

Senior IAS, IPS and PCS officers have been assigned additional duties to handle responsibilities related to Covid-19. IAS officer S Murugesan and IPS officer Ridhim Agarwal have been given charge of logistics and supply chain management. IAS officer Chandresh Kumar and IPS Janmejay Khanduri have been given charge for control room and contact tracking, Secretary tourism Sonika will be looking into arrangements for more isolation centers.

Title: Stop biometric attendance: ESIC staff
Content: Hyderabad: Employees of ESIC Medical College and Hospital, Sanathnagar, are a worried lot as authorities refused to suspend biometric attendance system despite increase in coronavirus cases in the state.According to ESIC Nurses’ Union, over 2,200 employees, including doctors, nurses, sanitation and class-VI workers, both in-house and outsourced, work at the facility, which works under the Union ministry of labour and employment. “At the time, when people are being advised social distancing, the hospital dean has refused to suspend biometric attendance system,” Union general secretary Prakash Babu said.Amid Covid-19 cases surge in India, all central government employees were exempted from marking attendance through Aadhaar-based biometric system as a preventive measure. The Union has sent a letter to ESIC headquarters in Delhi. TNN

Title: Ordnance Factories to make ammunition against corona
Content: Nagpur: The Ordnance Factory Board (OFB) is being looked upon for support in the war against Covid-19 . This comes as a shot in the arm for the organization that was facing plans to corporatize to improve its functioning.Now with Covid-19 threat looming large — which has led to shortage of sanitisers , masks and other protective gear — OFB has been asked to to take up the production of these items in its manufacturing facilities. Even the heavy vehicle factory (HVF) in Chennai that makes battle tanks has been roped in for the job. Chemical factories making TNT and RDX are gearing up to make sanitisers. In the wake of lockdown the factories have already closed production of the regular defence items.Sources said since the sanitisers will have to be made in chemical factories under OFB, there are chances it may be taken up at factories in Chandrapur and Bhandara in Vidarbha also. The masks will be made at the clothing factories spread throughout the country. There are plans to take up manufacturing of ventilators also which are also in short supply in the country. A decision about ventilators is yet to be taken.The request has come from the government to the directorate general of OFB.In turn, a letter has been sent to the factories. There are plans to make 2 lakh masks and 10,000 overall covers, and 5000 litres of sanitisers. A source in the board said this will be an intial quantity to establish that the factories can make these items too. In fact, the ordnance factory at Khamaria that makes a wide range of ammunition from aerial bombs to hand grendades has already prepared the initial quantity of sanitizers.A letter in possession with TOI states the material may be needed for people living in the factories’ estates, but sources said it may be provided to general public too. This is because the request has come from the government, said a senior official in the OFB.“We have among the biggest capacities for both clothing and chemical manufacture. It is a warlike situation and the government is once again looking forward to us as it happened during Kargil war and other conflicts. The factories have already geared up to start the production,” said a senior official in the board.The source, however, said that certain practical difficulties will also need to be tackled. For example, it would be a challenge to procure cloth to make the masks. The factories will be able to make sanitisers in bulk, but getting containers to transport it, smaller packaging for retail distribution etc may be the issues that need tackling, the source said.Shriram Batwe, a senior leader of Bharatiya Pratiraksha Mazdoor Sangh (BPMS) — a workers’ union in the factories, said the unions will always rise to the occasion and accept the challenge.

Title: 15L screened at airports, says Kishan
Content: Hyderabad: Union minister of state for home affairs G Kishan Reddy on Tuesday said that 15 lakh foreign returnees have been screened at various airports for novel coronavirus . He said 519 people have tested positive for the virus in the country.Talking to reporters in Delhi, he said that 39 persons who tested positive have been discharged, while 69,336 people are under home quarantine. So far, 20,707 samples have been tested. He said 118 new labs have been set up to test the virus.“At present, 94,963 beds are available in quarantine facilities,” he said.The government has brought back 2,400 Indians who were stranded in other countries. “Five lakh equipment kits and 10 lakh masks are available in all states,” he said.

Title: Be on guard, fraudsters may cash in on virus fear: Cops
Content: Kolkata: The cyber cell of Kolkata Police CID and cyber experts have advised people that they should be careful while downloading information about the coronavirus . They have also warned people of opening any SMS that claimed to be sent by the Government of India, asking users to download “necessary documents”. The advisory came from the police on Tuesday when some people reportedly received texts from unknown numbers, which asked them to download mobile apps to get details of coronavirus. Cops said that fraudsters used this trick to get access to the mobiles of those whom they had sent the texts.Though no specific case has been registered yet in this regard, cops have come across such texts, where they found some fraudsters from Jharkhand tried to dupe people worried about the Covid-19 outbreak.“The fraudsters keep changing their modus operandi. Last year, they had used the World Cup frenzy while they had played the same trick in the name of a popular game show in 2018. Since everybody is on the tenterhooks for the coronavirus scare, the fraudsters are trying to make the most out of the situation,” said a police officer. According to cyber security experts, the spam texts include offers on masks, survival guides and even medically-unsupported Covid-19 treatments like CBD oil. Links within the spam SMS take people to other fake sites where they fall into the traps of the fraudsters and lose money. A CID officer said the risk of organized crime was most likely from the virtual world as the state had been in lockdown and people were not stepping out of their houses.Cops said that it is virtually impossible to trace the money once it is siphoned off. “The gangs use the details of their targets to hack into their accounts. They start recharging mobile numbers over the internet. Each of these mobile numbers used to send SMS is directly connected to different accounts of ‘mobile money’. These mobile money providers earmark one ‘wallet’ against each cell number. The gang transferred the victims’ money to such wallets over internet. This makes it difficult for cops to trace the money,” said a police officer.The recharge operators kept around 30% as commission. Police said no one should divulge personal details over phone.“We have been continuously telling people that banks don’t deal with customers over phone. No bank asks for PIN or CVV number over phone,” said joint CP (crime) Murlidhar Sharma.

Title: Ahmedabad: Hydroxychloroquine flies off shelves
Content:
Representative image

AHMEDABAD: Even after instructions from the Gujarat food and drug control administration (FDCA), to not sell hydroxychloroquine and azithromycin without prescriptions, several chemists across Ahmedabad have run out of stock of hyrdoxychloroquine. After a social media message went viral that these drugs are effective for treatment of Covid-19, several people bought these drugs as a preventive measure.

“A lot of people bought hydroxychloroquine till the government imposed restrictions on its sale without prescription. We have run out of stock for the past two days and are not sure when the new stock will arrive. Due to the lockdown, supply of medicines and all other items has fallen,” said Arvind, who manages the franchise of a chain of pharmacies on Anandnagar Road.

Manish Shah, the manager of a standalone medical store in Makarba also said he had run out of stock of hydroxychloroquine as well as azithromycin. “A lot of people bought these medicine in the past week. We have placed an order for more stock and are likely to receive it in a few days. However, now there will be restriction on the sale by the state government.”

Industry sources said that despite warnings, many people bought these medicines as a preventive measure. Gujarat principal secretary (health) Jayanti Ravi on Monday said that the state received guidelines from the central government for use of azithromycin and hydroxychloroquine for treatment of Covid-19 patients.

“The mix is found to be effective and the state has adequate stocks of these medicines. These medicines are not for preventive or prophylactic use and will be available only against prescription,” Ravi told reporters on Monday evening.

According to the Federation of Gujarat State Chemists and Druggists’ Association (FGSCDA), these medicines are rarely used and therefore may not be readily available, but this doesn’t mean there is a shortage. “These medicines are used for specific purposes and are procured in limited stock. There is no shortage in the market and these drugs will be made available with prescriptions at chemist stores,” said Alpesh Patel, president, FGSCDA.

Title: After an anxious day, relief for colleague
Content: Kolkata: After daylong tension, a 55-year-old colleague of the first person to die of Covid-19 in the city tested negative for the disease at NRS Hospital on Tuesday evening.The news came as a much relief for the employees at the Eastern Railway ’s Fairlie Place office, where the deceased had worked before being hospitalised. The condition of the colleague, however, remained serious, hospital sources said.The swab samples of the deceased’s mother, who is currently in isolation at MR Bangur Hospital, too, tested negative.Once the 55-year-old started suffering from symptoms of influenza, he was put under the Covid-19 suspected list as there was a possibility of him getting infected by the deceased. He was taken to NRS Medical College and Hospital with severe respiratory distress. His swab samples were sent to ICMR-NICED for confirmatory tests. The south Dum Dum neighbourhood, where the deceased lived, had also been living in fear ever since. “The patient was admitted to the isolation ward as he had all the symptoms of the virus. His respiratory problem is severe. Though he does not need ventilation, he needs oxygen support for breathing. His condition is serious,” said an official at the hospital.Being asymptomatic initially, the deceased, an Eastern Railway employee, had gone to work for almost a week before being hospitalized. After he was diagnosed with Covid-19, the Eastern Railway issued a notice, asking all the 21 employees at the efficiency cell of the accounts department, where the deceased used to work—to go into home isolation for 14 days. “It is understood that the said staff was working in his department during incubation period of the virus... in view of the present guidelines regarding home quarantine, it is recommended that all staff working in the same section should be sent on home quarantine for a period of minimum 14 days,” the notice read. A railway officer pointed out that the entire department was scared. “This man had been a friend of the deceased and had even helped his family admit him to a nursing home. Since others who worked with the man in the same room might have come in close contact with him, they were all scared,” he said.Similar fear seemed to stalk the neighbourhood—Ward 23 of South Dum Dum Municipality—where the patient lived. Cleaning measured were stepped up on Tuesday, when roads in the area were washed and disinfected with bleaching powder. “We are especially concerned about the elderly couple who live next door and the homes where their domestic help worked. It’s a relief that his wife and mother have tested negative. But we cannot rule out other contamination,” said Keya Das, councillor of Ward 23.

Title: Kolkata: Airline cabin crew member harassed over travel history
Content: KOLKATA: Horror stories of citizens being harassed in the name of corona threat refuses to die down in the city.
