In the latest incident on Monday evening, an Indigo cabin crew member alleged that she was being harassed by neighbours who are claiming she was prone to the disease as she often flew to West Asia, especially Dubai. Such has been the harassment that the flight attendant, residing at Silpara in Behala, claimed that she was being asked not to leave her residence. Even her mother who lived with her was not being allowed to go to shop for essentials.The air hostess recorded her ordeal on Twitter, where she was seen breaking down. Her clip was shared by a journalist on the Kolkata Police wall. The complaint stated that the local Thakurpukur police had not listened to her ordeal.The video, that went viral along with another incident in Delhi, led to prompt response from Kolkata Police commissioner Anuj Sharma. “We will take legal action against persons discriminating against such heroes who fight for us! I have asked for a report in the matter and action will be taken if any police personnel is found wanting,” Sharma tweeted tagging Kolkata Police joint CP (crime) Murlidhar Sharma. Senior Kolkata Police officers, including DC (Behala) Nilanjan Biswas, directed ACP Behala and OC Thakurpukur to the spot, who then sorted out the version of both sides. The officers spent considerable time in the neighbourhood explaining to locals that the air hostess was absolutely fine and harassing her would call for legal action. “Please rest assured,anyone discriminating against heroes, discharging their duties risking their own safety will be dealt with strictly,” Kolkata Police later tweeted about the incident.The twin incidents led Union aviation minister Hardeep Singh Puri to reply: “Deeply distressed to know that some aviation professionals who have been at the forefront of India’s efforts to prevent and contain the spread of coronavirus and even rescue fellow citizens from Covid-19 around the world are being harassed by their neighbours and others.”IndiGo in a statement, said the instances of employees being ostracized as a result of their line of duty and travel history was extremely unfortunate, coming after the standing ovation that the nation gave to the heroes for their fight against the pandemic on March 22.“Aviation is an essential service and our colleagues in IndiGo are supporting passengers who have to travel during these days. We have taken every possible precaution for our crew to be protected from infection during their duties. We have adequate protocols for self-quarantine in place in case it’s required. Our colleagues have been working selflessly to serve the country at this critical juncture. Our employees have been the front-runners in bringing our citizens back to the country and enabling them to reach their hometowns even during restricted movements,” the company spokesperson said.

Title: Gujarat: Power demand declines as industry downs shutters
Content:
Representative image

AHMEDABAD: Consumption of electricity across Gujarat has fallen with industrial units closing due to the state government mandated shutdown to curb the spread of Covid-19 in the state.

Gujarat’s peak power demand has declined by around 4,600MW in the past week.

Maximum power demand on Tuesday was at 11,800MW around noon. Demand was as high as 16,447MW at the same time last Tuesday.

Consumption of power has steadily declined for the past week. Peak power demand of 16,816 was registered in Gujarat on March 21, one day before the nationwide janatacurfew on March 22. With industrial units joining the pan-India shutdown on Sunday, demand dipped to 13,564 MW, shows data from the Western Region Load Dispatch Centre (WRLDC) operated by the Central government’s Power System Operation Corporation Ltd.

“Reduction in demand from industry has brought down the electricity consumption in the state. Thousands of industrial units are closed, resulting lower power consumption,” said an official of the State Load Dispatch Centre (SLDC), which is responsible for operating the power system in Gujarat.

“The demand from agriculture and residential consumers has not been affected and there is no reduction in consumption by these two class of consumers,” the official added.

Title: Complete newspaper distribution, buying of essential items before 8.30am in Kodagu
Content:
MADIKERI: Kodagu deputy commissioner Annies Kanmani Joy on Tuesday issued an order mentioning specific timings for distribution of newspapers and purchase of essential items like milk.

The order states: Segregation of newspapers shall be done between 5am and 7am and distribution of newspapers to houses till 8.30am. Further, people are allowed in small groups to purchase essential items like milk and newspapers between 6am and 8am. No restriction is imposed on the public distribution system (PDS). Shops delivering essential commodities, like groceries and vegetables , are allowed to open between 12 noon and 2pm. Those going to shops must be in a group of less than five persons.

Earlier, journalists and newspaper distributors in Kodagu met the DC complaining that newspaper distributors were threatened by some police officers in Madikeri , Virajpet and Gonikoppal . The milk distributors were also lathicharged in Madikeri. The DC’s order mentioning the timings were issued on the basis of the complaint.

Meanwhile, work in coffee estates is banned till March 31.

Title: 20 held for lockdown violation in Kota, vehicles seized
Content: Kota: The city police came down strictly to enforce lockdown and Section 144 on Tuesday and arrested nearly 20 people from various areas, including six from Mahavir Nagar and five from Kunhari police station area of the city. Police also seized several vehicles and slapped challans. However, most of the areas and markets across Kota and Bundi districts remained deserted throughout the day on Tuesday, with only emergency services being functional.The situation of compliance of the lockdown improved on Tuesday in the city as the people stayed at their homes. However, police teams were deployed at various points to ensure people stay indoors and strict action was taken against those who ventured out in the markets unnecessarily or violated the lockdown, said Kota city SP Gaurav Yadav. Police arrested nearly 20 people from various areas of the city under Section 151 of CrPC for violation and slapped challans over several vehicles, he added.“The compliance was nearly 100 per cent in the city on Tuesday and action was taken and challans were slapped in the areas where it was necessary,” the SP said, adding that the exact number of violators arrested and challans slapped is yet to be reported from various police stations of the city.Almost complete compliance was observed in the district as the markets remained closed and people stayed indoors. However, challans were slapped on movement of personal vehicles in some areas, yet none was arrested in Bundi, said Bundi SP Shivraj Meena.The vegetable markets were open in the morning till 10am when people, hardly half of them masked, thronged the markets, which charged Rs 5-10 higher than the usual prices on almost every item. Emergency services, outlets for essential commodities, including milk, flour mill, grocery remained functional, however face masks were not available in most of the medical stores of the city.[Pics 1 - people purchasing necessary items at a grocery shop in Kota on Tuesday2. violation - Grain trader in Talwas town of Bundi district unloading trolley on Tuesday3. Five persons held for violation of lockdown and section 144 in Kunhari police station of Kota city. ]

Title: UoH: T students ask for ride home
Content: Hyderabad: Students from parts of Telangana studying in UoH were unable to return home owing to restrictions on public transport. Although UoH allowed those from other states to stay back, local students were asked to vacate hostel by Tuesday noon.Students urged the dean of students welfare (DSW) to make arrangements. The DSW has ought permissionfrom the Cyberabad commissionerate to drop all students to their hometowns. TNN

Title: Fighting loneliness and anxiety in the time of Covid-19
Content:
Ahmedabad:Nayanesh Patel (name changed), a resident of Satellite, had a tough time adjusting to quarantine routine for the first few days – waking up and getting ready, having breakfast in bed, catching up with work, having a meal, watching a movie, catching up with friends – and trying to sleep. What he’s incapable of doing is stopping thinking about the next day and what the future holds for him and his family while in his solitary self-confinement.

As the state today has 11,108 persons under 14-day home quarantine, their mental health is a growing concern for not only their families but society.

Dr Kalrav Mistry, a city-based psychiatrist, said individuals have difficulty dealing with uncertainty. “As Covid-19 is a new phenomenon, we don’t know what to expect. It leads to anxiety. Its different how different individuals cope with it. Thus, along with the physical well-being of these individuals, their mental well-being is equally important for their recuperation and assimilation in society,” he said.

Thus, the Government Hospital for Mental Health (GHMH) on Tuesday conducted a special session for health workers and caregivers with emphasis on coping with Covid-19.

Dr Ajay Chauhan, medical superintendent, GHMH, said those who are termed positive and those who in quarantine have a lot of questions and apprehension. “They are influenced by images in the media and have fears about what can happen to them.

Thus, it’s important that immediate caregivers understand this condition and try to quell their distress,” he said.

He added that in some cases, epidemics can also lead to post- traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). “Mental health professionals will provide telephonic counselling and also visit these persons if necessary. We will also follow up with patients after they are out of quarantine,” said Dr Chauhan.

Title: Communities to fight the pandemic
Content:
Ahmedabad: In middle of March, when the discussion on COVID-19 was at its peak but Gujarat had not recorded its first case, Knowledge Management and Innovations for Change (KMIC) at IIM-Ahmedabad (IIM-A) organized an online meeting. On the lines were not business honchos or thought leaders, it were the municipal councillors of Ahmedabad city and the outcomes were not elaborate plans but simple and implementable solutions.

Prof Ankur Sarin, part of Public Systems Group (PSG) at IIM-A, said that KMIC – a collaboration of IIM-A and UNICEF – has been working with municipal councillors for past two years in several ways. “This time, we identified the socially active ones and engaged them in pushing sanitization practices such as washing hands,” he said. Shahnawaz Shaikh, a councillor from Jamalpur ward, distributed kits containing soap, sanitizers and masks. About 300 kits were distributed in the first phase where there are no COVID-19 cases.

Hiren Jadav, another councillor from Odhav, prepared posters for creating awareness in his area, said IIM-A officials.

Title: Polls for 4 Rajya Sabha seats postponed in Gujarat
Content:
Congress MLA arrive Ahmedabad airport atfer Rajya Sabha election postpone on Tuesday

GANDHINAGAR: Two days before the scheduled elections for the four Rajya Sabha seats of Gujarat on March 26, the Election Commission of India (ECI) on Tuesday postponed the polls till the next annoucement.

Chief electoral officer, Gujarat, S Muralikrishna, said, “The ECI in a new order deferred the Rajya Sabha polls in view of the COVID-19. Fresh dates will be announced by the commission later. We have communicated to all the concerned parties. Necessary directions to halt the process have been passed.”

Cong MLAs were in resorts while people needed them, says Vaghani :State BJP chief Jitu Vaghani alleged that Congress MLAs of Gujarat stayed at a resort in another state when the state is passing through a crucial phase in its fight against coronavirus. “It is unfortunate that in times of crisis, Congress MLAs were not with the people of Gujarat,” Vaghani said.

Cong MLAs return from Jaipur : All Congress MLAs camping in Jaipur for the past 10 days or so, returned to Ahmedabad on Tuesday evening. Leader of opposition Paresh Dhanani said that the MLAs underwent self-quarantine during their stay in Jaipur and will return to their constituencies now. “They had been shifted to Jaipur to prevent the BJP from using unethical means before the RS elections. All will now go to their respective constituencies,” Dhanani said. State Congress chief Amit Chavda said his party was in favour of conducting the RS election as per schedule, but the Congress respect the ECI decision of deferring the poll.

Title: Step towards coronavirus hospital: Medical College Hospital Kolkata discharges patients
Content: KOLKATA: As a first step to convert the hospital into a Covid-19 facility, Medical College Hospital Kolkata (MCHK) started vacating the premises by discharging patients on Tuesday. The hospital is waiting for the green signal from Swasthya Bhawan to suspend OPD and emergency services for now.“We started discharging patients who were waiting for planned surgery and those whose care can be taken at home with medication. We will shut down our emergency and OPD services once we get the written order from the health department,” said an official at MCHK.On Monday, the health department officials had told the hospital authorities to start working to make it a dedicated Covid-19 centre for the state. The hospital currently has 2,200 beds and if the need arises, 800 more beds can be added.“Nearly 60% of the hospital bed is now free after patients were discharged on Tuesday. Among the rest of the patients, there are some who are in critical condition. We are having talks with other hospitals on shifting these patients,” said an official.The newly constructed superspecialty building that has 300 unutilized beds has been earmarked for treatment of confirmed patients. Sources said the building has patients of some departments like endocrinology, urology neurosurgery. They are making arrangements to make this building vacant before the rest of the buildings and other departments.The other department heads have been asked to work on the second lists of patients who can be discharged and those who need to be shifted to another hospital. Talks are on with hospitals like NRS Medical College, SSKM, RG Kar and Calcutta National Medical College on how many patients each hospital can take in.“On Monday, doctors told us that we have to take our patient back home or take him to another hospital because the hospital had to be vacated. Doctors checked on my brother today and said he can be kept on medicine at home for now,” said Poltu Das of Liluah, whose brother Tarak is suffering from cancer and was admitted 18 days ago. The doctors are yet to start chemotherapy as the patient is suffering from jaundice. Das was on treatment for jaundice.“My daughter underwent surgery for deformity in her right hand few days ago. Doctors said we can take care of her with medication at home,” said Abhjit Chakraborty of Shyambazar.The hospital authority during the day had a meeting with director of medical education, Debasis Bhattachayya, and Rogi Kalyan Samity chairperson, Nirmal Maji, to expedite the preparations. Buildings that had major chunk of patients being discharged on Tuesday included the Green Building, Eden Building and MCH Building.

Title: Now, free access to online courses
Content: Hyderabad:Telangana department of technical education has tied up with global online learning platform, Coursera, to provide free access to its courses to students in wake of closure of institutions. All 400 colleges affiliated to state universities have been given access to over 3,800 courses. While colleges will be given free access till July 31, Coursera plans to provide monthly extensions thereafter. TNN

Title: Kolkata: CM Mamata Banerjee visits hospital, boosts morale of doctors and health workers
Content:
Chief minister Mamata Banerjee and police commissioner Anuj Sharma interact with doctors and health workers at... Read More

KOLKATA: Chief minister Mamata Banerjee on Tuesday made the rounds of all the major government hospitals in the city, asking after the doctors , paramedics and health workers in the frontline of the battle against the novel coronavirus and advising them caution. The CM’s visit, which included Beliaghata ID Hospital , where all the Covid-19 patients are being treated and New Town’s quarantine centre, where several of the corona suspects are housed, came as a moral boost for the health workers.

“Apnara bhalo thakle amrao bhalo thakbo (Our well being is in your safety and good health),” the CM told health workers, whom she gave masks and sanitizers. She promised more personal protection equipment from the health department to ensure safety for doctors and all others handling Covid-19 patients.

Accompanied by Kolkata Police commissioner Anuj Sharma, Banerjee first went to R G Kar Hospital, where she urged officials and health workers to be extremely cautious during the treatment of patients. Even as she advised all health staff, including those involved in cleaning the hospital, to strictly observe safety norms, she requested the doctors and nurses to don masks and repeatedly wash hands to stay safe. Given that many were finding it difficult to commute to the hospital from far during the lockdown, Banerjee told the principal and superintendent of RG Kar Medical College & Hospital that the state government was in the process of hiring hotels, where doctors and nurses living far would be accommodated during the period. Apprehensive that the number of patients might rise, R G Kar is set to have a 50-bed quarantine facility.

Banerjee’s next stop was at Medical College and Hospital, where she enquired about the progress of work in converting the entire hospital into a Covid-19 treatment facility. The CM had earlier asked state health officials to evacuate all patients from the hospital and prepare it exclusively for Covid-19 patients. The hospital authorities told her they had started discharging the non-critical patients and trying to shift critical ones to other hospitals. The facility would be ready to handle 3,000 Covid-19 patients by next week, Banerjee was told. Next, she visited NRS Medical College and Hospital, where she discussed the health conditions of doctors and nurses as well as interns. It is the latter who are now serving corona patients at the hospital. She advised repeatedly caution to all.

At SSKM Hospital, she asked the authorities how the infrastructure could be improved immediately to handle more corona-affected patients whose numbers are expected to multiply in the weeks ahead. She also enquired about the testing facility at SSKM Hospital and patient turnout.

Around 5pm, Banerjee reached the quarantine centre at New Town, where she discussed how to step up the infrastructure further. Several corona-suspects are currently housed there. Banerjee asked after their health status and wished them speedy recovery. She donned the N95 mask at the centre and asked everyone around her to maintain social distancing norms. The CM also asked the health workers to be very careful about the health status of their family members as the virus could spread easily. “Your moral health and well-being will help us fight this challenge,” she said.

Her penultimate stop was the Beliaghata ID Hospital, currently the ground zero in the state’s efforts to fight the virus. Praising health workers for their professionalism, she discussed how the existing resources could be used even better. “We have a long battle on our hands,” she said and thanked the staff for their dedication before heading to MR Bangur Hospital to inspect its 150-bed isolation facility. Here, too, she had words of encouragement for health professionals.

Title: Gujarat: Cops help stranded passengers at airport
Content:
With no cabs and private vehicles available at the airport, a number of passengers who did not have someone pi... Read More

AHMEDABAD: Ever since a partial lockdown has been imposed in Ahmedabad to curb further spread of COVID-19, the movement of all public transport vehicles including cabs and autorickshaws has been strictly restricted. The restricted movement of vehicles would have hampered movement of scores of travellers who landed at Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel International (SVPI) airport in Ahmedabad on Tuesday, however, Ahmedabad city police officials came to their rescue by issuing special permission to private cabs to ferry passengers.

With no cabs and private vehicles available at the airport, a number of passengers who did not have someone picking them up, were left hassled and confused on how to get home. “We saw several passengers walking hassled around the airport when we realized that they are unable to move due the restriction on movement of cabs as well as other modes of public transport. The ACP and DCP took a decision to issue special permission to cab drivers to ferry the passengers,” said K C Rathwa, police inspector, Airport Police Station.

“We contacted a few cab drivers who are regularly visiting the airport and they later informed other cabbies to help passengers move to their destinations. A special letter was issued to each cabbie by the police station, enabling one to move in the city only to drop the concerned passenger and return to the airport, based on which several passengers were sent home,” Rathwa further added.

At least 350 passengers who landed at the city airport on Tuesday, were facilitated by the city police officials by issuing special permission to cab drivers. To prevent further spread of COVID19 pandemic, the Union government has announced discontinuing of all commercial passenger flights from 11.59pm on Tuesday and therefore, airport saw unprecedented rush of passengers who arrived in Ahmedabad on Tuesday.

Title: West Bengal Transport Corporation runs skeletal services to and from hospitals
Content:
After every ride, the interior of every bus is being sanitized

KOLKATA: The state transport department is running a skeletal bus services for frontline health workers, hospital staff, patients’ relatives, security personnel and employees of medicine shops so that these citizens working in emergency services are not stranded during the lockdown.

West Bengal Transport Corporation, the state transport undertaking that serves the Kolkata metropolitan area, has deployed buses to and from all major hospitals since early on Tuesday so that health workers and patients’ relatives did not face commute problems.

According to an order of the chief secretary, these emergency routes were chalked out, based on demand. “But we are ensuring that no crowding takes place and commuters can maintain safe distance from each other. A hourly frequency is maintained and identity card or hospital admission tickets are being checked before allowing them to board the buses,” said a WBTC official.

WBTC, officers said, was maintaining safety protocols. All bus crew have been given protective gears, like gloves, masks, aprons and sunglasses. After each ride, the interiors were being sanitized. The sterilization workforce are also given personal protective equipment to safeguard themselves against possible infection. Each and every commuter is being given hand sanitizer. “We are trying our best to support emergency services in this demanding time,” said RVS Kapur, managing director WBTC.

Title: Cities under lockdown, many skip the last flight
Content: Jaipur: It was expected that fliers would throng the airport on Tuesday before the suspension of domestic flights takes effect from the midnight of March 24 to 31. On the contrary, there were not many to catch the last flight to their homes.In the eerie silence, a dozen of passengers who had reached Jaipur from Hyderabad in the afternoon flight could be seen haggling with a taxi driver at the outer entry gate of the city airport. He was asking Rs 2,000 to drop them at Tonk Phatak and there was not a second taxi around to turn to.On the road to airport from Jawahar circle, where on normal days cars would zip through, the emptiness was overpowering. A few people could be seen walking down towards the airport with their bag and baggage. It’s hard to notice taxis or private cars.“The airport handles around 55 flights a day but today we have only 25. Despite the reduction in number of flights, not many passengers are there. That's why the level of activity has declined in the airport,” said airport director Jaideep Balhara.With the city under lockdown and transport services having been shut down for travelling from Jaipur to other towns and villages, the demand for air travel has also come down significantly.“We don't know how to reach Sikar. We came from Hyderabad but now the challenge is to go to Sikar. One of our friends is coming in a car to pick us but he said he is having to plead with police who don't allow him," said a youth in another group of seven sitting at a bus stop.He said this is another reason why people are not travelling because it is tough to travel to home towns from the airport.The police manning the checkpoints to restrict movement of people at Jawahar circle said they allow people who show air tickets. But family members or friends going to receive those arriving are not allowed by the police."As such it is very hard to control people. They give you false excuses to move around. That's why if there is a proof behind the travel and if it merits a permission, we allow. Otherwise, we don't entertain the requests," said the police officer.Even though the suspension on air travel has been declared up to 31, the resumption of flight services would depend on how the country is able to contain spread of the corona virus

Title: PIL seeks to take steps to prevent spread Covid-19 in prisons in Madurai
Content: MADURAI: A public interest litigation (PIL) was filed before the Madras high court seeking to take steps to prevent the spread of Covid-19 in all prisons in the state.P Thangaraj, coordinator of Prisoners Reform Intervention Support Mission (PRISM), a registered charitable trust which was formed by few advocates to provide free legal services to jail inmates, in his petition stated that following the outbreak of Covid-19, the World Health Organisation (WHO) had declared it as a pandemic and have asked the people to follow precautionary measures. Though the people have been asked to follow social distancing, the same would be not be possible in the prisons due to overcrowding.Steps must be taken to address this issue immediately by reducing the arrest and remand of petty offenders and enlarge them on bail in their own bond. Parole of prisoners who are already on parole can be extended and applications for leave could be considered leniently.The petitioner stated that since prevention is the most vital, prison cells should be sanitised periodically. Hand sanitisers, masks should be made available to the prison staff and inmates who are newly brought inside the prison should be screened. He further stated that quarantine and isolation wards should be provided at the prisons where new admissions must be quarantined for 14 days. Testing kits should also be made available at the hospitals in prisons.Since the visitors would not be allowed to visit the prisoners, steps should also be taken by the authorities to provide telephones to them for them to speak with their relatives.The petition is likely to be taken up for hearing soon.

Title: Flyers throng airport just before domestic flights are grounded
Content:
The city airport witnessed crowd for the entire day on Tuesday

Nagpur: From urbane frequent flyers to rustic workers, everyone reached Nagpur airport on Tuesday to reach their homes before even the last flight was grounded. Still low by normal standards, yet the number of passengers reaching Nagpur went up significantly compared to last one week. TOI inquired with travellers who said flights were nearly full as this was the last chance to reach their destinations.

The last flight of Indigo Airlines scheduled to reach Nagpur at 8pm and supposed to take off for Bengaluru in half an hour reached by 10:10pm. It quickly turned around and took off for Bengaluru by 10.35pm. The turn around could happen fast as there were only 59 passengers and there was no rush at the airport. It takes an hour and thirty five minutes to reach Bengaluru. Four aircraft that could not fly further due to the timings will remain parked at Nagpur, said a source.

The counter of a private airlines was thronged with flyers buying tickets just before they boarded, a scene resembling railway ticket window. As against 34 flights normally scheduled on Monday, the Nagpur airport had only 20 flights operating. The rest were cancelled.

TOI reached the airport in the noon and could find passengers coming from Mumbai and Ahmedabad as well as those leaving for Delhi and Chennai.

A group of young boys engaged as labourers and other work at mobile tower sites waited for their contractor, standing near the departure terminal. The contractor quickly bought tickets for Delhi from the counter. They had to reach their villages close to the national capital.

Soon a group of Tamil speaking workers and site engineers alighted from an SUV. Engaged by a sugar factory here, they were rushing to catch the flight to Chennai. They were followed by Kartik and Singanayakan who move door-to-door selling utensils, even they had to reach Chennai due to an emergency.

Despite the rush, inquiry at the airlines’ counters showed that there was no spike in ticket rates. Many travellers who bought last minute tickets paid Rs3600 to 4,000 which is the normal fare, they said.

However, the taxi operators were seen making a killing. The fares charged by the operators designated by the airport had gone up to Rs1000 to 1,200 per person. Some autorickshaw drivers were offering motorcycle rides for Rs500 to 400 per person. “Just keep your boarding pass ready to show the cops if they stop,” said Ramesh Thakre who was offering bike rides.

Manish Patidar, who had came in GoAir’s flight from Ahmedabad, said he had gone to Anand in Gujarat to meet his sister who had also come from abroad. He has to fly back to London in April, so he reached back in time. “As the flight was nearly 80% full, passengers were sitting close by but there was no scare as such and the scene remained normal all through the journey,” said Laxman Patel from the same flight. Of course, the flight attendants were also wearing masks, added another.

The fight from Ahmedabad was the last of GoAir’s flight to reach Nagpur on Monday. The pilots went back as passengers in a different airlines’ aircraft. Swapnil Suryawanshi had to wait for nearly three hours before he could start his further journey for Chhindwara in Madhya Pradesh. As no transport was available, his relatives came down from Chhindwara to pick him up.

Kalwant Singh who reached the airport from Parseoni was stranded after his flight to Delhi was cancelled.

After the shutdown, minimal staff will remain at the airport to carry out essential services. Even the Central Industrial Security Force (CISF) personnel will be partially returned for the airport’s security. The air traffic control tower will continue operations for international flights overflying Nagpur. The airport will be ready for emergency services and operations of government and defence aircraft.

Title: Kolkata: Last flight lands at 11.50pm, but going home is an ordeal
Content: KOLKATA: An Air Asia flight (I5-592) with 124 passengers from Bangalore was the last aircraft to touch down in Kolkata at 11.50pm on Tuesday, barely 10 minutes before the ban on domestic air travel across airports kicked in. With international flights already off the radar since Sunday, Kolkata airport has shut down completely and will reopen only when the DGCA makes a fresh assessment on Covid-19 threat.“The last set of departures were over by 9.30pm and we had intimated airline officials to wrap up their proceedings and staff as and when their operations got over so that we can shut down the airport as per the government mandate at the stroke of midnight,” said airport director Kaushik Bhattacharjee. Following the shutdown, the airport authorities will take up a massive decontamination and disinfection drive in the terminal, similar to the one that had been carried out in international wing of the terminal on Monday.Meanwhile, passengers making a final dash to return home before the flight ban had a harrowing time on landing at Kolkata airport as they struggled to find a transport back home at a time when the city is under lockdown.Marketing consultant Satyajit Mukherjee had reached the airport from Bangalore on Tuesday but failed to find any transport to Garia. Finally, he called his brother who came all the way to the airport to pick him up, that too, with an “airport emergency” handwritten sticker pasted on the bike.Hired cabs that operated also made a killing. While Rishra resident Ranjit Kumar Singh said he had to pay Rs 1,600 for a ride to Hooghly from airport, another elderly couple said they had to pay Rs 1,200 for a ride till Belghoria. “I had no option but literally beg before the driver to take us home and that too for steep price of Rs 1,600,” said Singh, who returned from Guwahati. Several stranded flyers also took to social media to vent their frustration against the lack of transport options. The only help was from a few government buses that left the airport at long intervals and travelling to fixed destinations like Howrah station.“Passengers to please note, #Kolkata is under lockdown & taxis/cabs are not available at the airport. Skeletal city bus service has been arranged. Private vehicles have been allowed. Please make travel arrangements accordingly,” the Kolkata airport tweet read.

Title: Nagpurian proud to be part of team behind India’s first Covid-19 test kit
Content: Nagpur: Finally, India is all set to get the first batch of indigenous testing kits for Covid-19 on March 25. This could be the biggest turning point in the fight against coronavirus outbreak as our testing capacity will increase significantly. Interestingly, one of the brains behind development of this ‘Made in India’ diagnostic kits is Dr Gautam Wankhede, a Nagpurian.An alumni of Government Medical College and Hospital (GMCH), Dr Wankhede is trained in the United Kingdom where he specialized in transfusion medicine. He is the son of Dr Ravi Wankhede, who pioneered the preparation and use of blood components in Central India in 1989 and later led the Zonal Transplant Coordination Center (ZTCC), Nagpur, as its secretary for many years.“Mylabs is planning to supply first batch by Thursday. Currently, we have manufacturing capacity for 15,000 tests per day and we will increase it up to 25,000 soon,” said Dr Wankhede. He is credited with launching some pathbreaking concepts in India such as molecular blood grouping and antenatal red cell antibody screening.“We already have raw material and been in the molecular diagnostics manufacturing for the last three to four years. So, we can start supplying kits immediately. Majority of components used in our kit are from India,” he said. They import a very few components from other countries, but not from China.Apart from Mylabs , German company Altona Diagnostics has also applied for an import licence from the Drug Controller General of India. But, this company cannot start supplying kits to labs before next week.Speaking to TOI, his proud father Dr Ravi said, “Gautam got inspired to take transfusion medicine as he watched our blood bank activities quite closely. After coming back from the UK, he worked with Fortis-Escorts Hospital and later moved over to the industry side,” he said.Dr Gautam was involved in the development and patenting a transfusion safety system ‘Haemovigil’ that is now being used in leading hospitals across India. Many reputed laboratories in the country are using ID-NAT screening kits for blood banks/hospitals, quantitative HIV, HBV and HCV kits, all developed under his supervision.Mylab is aiming to manufacture up to 1 lakh tests in a week. Further, the company claims that its test kits can test about 100 patients with one kit. An average lab with automated PCR can test more than 1,000 patients a day.Matter of prideMylab is first Indian company getting commercial Covid-19 PCR kit approved by CDSCOMylab Covid-19 test kits costs nearly one-fourth (up to Rs1,500) of currently procured kitsIt uses advanced protocols which can reduce testing time by 65% and give results in 2.5 hoursThis kit can detect coronavirus with least chances of false positivityMade in India kits will reduce our dependency on Germany and SwitzerlandNagpurian Dr Gautam Wankhede is medical affairs director of this company

Title: 1,800 going north given food, sent back to Ahmedabad
Content:
By 5pm, the district police had distributed 1,800-odd food packets.

AHMEDABAD: On Tuesday, the first day of the state’s lockdown, the Gandhinagar police officials were surprised as hundreds from the direction of Ahmedabad were seen in areas such as Nana Chiloda, Mota Chiloda and Adalaj.

When the persons were questioned and were asked reason for flouting CrPC Section 144 – related to ban on assembly of more than four persons – the groups told cops that they were daily wagers especially working in small units and construction sites and as the work was closed indefinitely, they don’t even have a day’s meal.

Mayur Chavda, Gandhinagar SP, said that the persons were stopped and district police along with volunteers were mobilized. “Our staff supervised making and distribution of food packets when we realized that the groups intend to cover distance of over 100km on feet as all public transport is suspended,” he said. “Makeshift counters were created as a few teams even tracked many down on the roads and supplied them with food packets and water bottles.”

By 5pm, the district police had distributed 1,800-odd food packets. When Gandhinagar police contacted Ahmedabad administration, the officials advised not to allow the persons to go northwards and asked police to send them back to Ahmedabad. Police officials said that the district administration would take care of the groups now.

Title: On first day, cops arrest 1,003 for violating lockdown rules
Content:
Kolkata: Kolkata Police arrested 1,003 people on the first day of the lockdown for not adhering to restrictions imposed to contain novel coronavirus and sent home the message that they meant business while implementing the shutdown order.

The police adopted a carrot-and-stick policy from early Tuesday morning as they went about implementing the complete safety restriction. Among those booked was a man driving a luxury car at Esplanade and another drinking in the open at Convent Road in Entally. But it was the south division that had the maximum arrests — 271 — followed by the south suburban division.

Lalbazar received clippings from markets like Gariahat and Garden Reach where people not only defied the lockdown but also challenged the cops over ‘right to free movement’. Several shops were kept open, prompting cops to forcibly shut them across several pockets of north and south Kolkata. A middle-aged man on Rashbehari Avenue even questioned why he could not enjoy a walk in a desolate street when he had no recent travel history of visiting a coronavirus-affected country.

In the densely populated north Kolkata, police entered a locality at a time and challenged anyone who was found outside his home. “This is not an easy place to enforce a lockdown. Hence, we have to do it with a firm hand,” said an officer.

A majority of the arrested comprised youths aged 20 to 27, who had ventured out for a chat with friends or had taken their bike out for a spin. In several pockets of the city like Tiljala, Topsia, Park Circus, Rajabazar and Maniktala, police had a tough time enforcing the lockdown as bike-borne youths sped past the checkposts that had been set up. Youths were also found gossiping by the roadside or crowding around teastalls. Cops, armed with batons, went on an overdrive in some localities, chasing violators and arresting those who refused to disperse.

“We have deployed all our officers on the road who have been pleading and at times forcing people to get back to their homes. But there are instances when the men were back on the road the moment our team left the area. They need to understand that we are trying to implement the lockdown for their safety,” said a senior officer of Topsia police station.

The scene was similar at Rajabazar and Park Circus where residents called up police stations, urging cops to take action against shops selling non-essential items that had opened and about men loitering in the road. On VIP Road, too, men were spotted moving in herds atop mini-trucks and in ambulances. When the violation was pointed out, the cops gave a chase but didn’t arrest anyone.

In Salt Lake, youths were seen riding bikes and driving cars around PNB crossing. When police stopped them to ask what they were doing on the road, they cited flimsy reasons. Councillor Anindya Chattopadhayay joined the cops to explain the urgency for them to return home and follow the lockdown rules.

At checkposts in Kolkata, police did let people through if they cited valid reasons for being out during the lockdown. In Santoshpur, cops asked those who were outside to stop making excuses and go in. “We don’t want to use force. Please abide by the law,” a policemen told a group.

But there were odd allegations about police excesses too. A youth in Baguiati claimed he had been beaten by cops when he had stepped out to buy medicines. In the morning, the Vidyasagar traffic guard stopped six vehicles — coming from as far as Delhi, Andhra Pradesh and Bihar — on the second Hooghly bridge. Coming to know that they were migrant labourers, the cops shifted them to a quarantine centre.

In Howrah, police had to canvass on the lockdown with loudspeakers. “Don’t treat this like a bandh. The consequences of staying out can be serious and can affect your entire family,” a policeman said over a louspeaker.

Back in Kolkata, police commissioner Anuj Sharma tweeted: “I appeal to all citizens to #StayHome and cooperate with the administration. @KolkataPolice will continue the drive against violators. #CoronavirusPandemic.”

(With inputs from Dwaipayan Ghosh, Tamaghna Banerjee, Jhimli Mukherjee Pandey, Suman Chakraborty & Priyanka Dasgupta)

Title: Amara Raja Group to shut down all 18 manufacturing units till month-end
Content: Hyderabad: Batteries maker Amara Raja Group on Tuesday said it is shutting down operations at all its manufacturing facilities till March 31, 2020, except for essential services, in light of the Covid-19 spread. The group has 18 plants spread across Andhra Pradesh.The Tirupati-based group said it has commenced steps for shutdown as most of its manufacturing operations are continuous process in nature and will be reviewing the situation continuously.It said it has put in place a Group Corporate Task force for COVID-19 with senior leadership and medical professionals to scan the entire operating environment, internal and external, to review the operating guidelines released by the central and state governments and to formulate and execute the action plan devised to mitigate against the pandemic.“Based on the GO from government of Andhra Pradesh, the Amara Raja Group has decided to shut down the manufacturing operations of all its manufacturing units till 31st March 2020, except for essential services,” it said in a communique.“Considering that most of the manufacturing operations are continuous processes in nature, steps for safe shut down has commenced. The group will be reviewing the situation continuously and will take all necessary steps as required from time-to-time,” it said.It said that on March 22, 2020, Amara Raja had ensured that all its operations across all locations were scaled down significantly for 24 hours following the Janata Curfew call given by Prime Minster Narendra Modi.“As an ongoing commitment, Amara Raja Group will continue to explore all the possible support to the state and central governments in running essential services like telecom infrastructure, data centres, transport of essential services, and supply of electrical equipment required by power utilities, agricultural produce etc,” it said.The Rs 8,700 crore turnover Amara Raja Group manufactures lead acid batteries under the Amaron brand, power conversion products, sheet metal products, precision components, electronic products, and is into infrastructure development, as well .

Title: Stocked up, but chemists face acute staff crunch in Kolkata
Content:
TimesView We are going through difficult times and there must be numerous logistical problems in keeping medicine shops open. But these stores are part of emergency services exempted from the lockdown; every household would have people who need their daily dose of medicines. There should be some way to keep at least some chemists’ stores open in every area/neighbourhood.

KOLKATA: Supply of medicines may be impacted in the coming weeks not because of stock deficit but due to the suspension of trains and buses that is making it difficult for staff members to commute.On Tuesday, the first day of lockdown, many medical stores operated with skeletal staff as those who come from far-flung areas were unable to attend work as there were no local trains and buses. Several medical stores around the city were also shut because either the owner or the workers could not commute.Medical stores can remain open during the lockdown as it falls under the essential supply category.Anirban Mitra of College Street Blueprint said he was in the shop for the whole day with only one employee. “We have adequate stock for the next seven to 10 days. Since this is an essential supply, the stock will be replenished soon. But we are facing problems of a different kind. We do not have enough staff to run the shop. Many of them stay in the suburbs and have not been able to come to work today. If the situation remains like this, we do not know how we will keep the shop open for such a long time,” said Mitra.“We ran out of masks and sanitizers a week ago and that has not been replenished. People are buying a lot of paracetamol, medicine for common cold and oral rehydration salts. But we have enough supply,” he added.A representative of Apollo Pharmacy on GC Avenue said: "There is no reason to panic as we have adequate stock to last two weeks and our employees have come to work as they have identity cards.”Suresh Goel, who owns Medical Plus on Mahatma Gandhi Road, did not open his store on Tuesday as local trains are not plying and other modes of transport were not available. “I stay in Belur and commute on local train and bus to reach my shop on Mahatma Gandhi Road. I could not go to my shop because trains and buses are not plying. Even if I manage to reach my shop, I will face immense difficulty in returning home at night,” said Goel.The news from the stockists is not as good. In Kolkata, the stockists keep medicines for up to 15 days. Sajal Gangopadhyay, secretary of the Bengal Chemists’ and Druggists’ Association, said the companies have not supplied any consignments since 3pm on Monday. “They said they do not have the staff. If this problem is not resolved, the stock will start depleting and we won’t be able to replenish it. There may be a crisis after 15 days,” said Gangopadhyay.Many stockists said they do not requisition big consignments just before the end of the financial year. “We have to clear payments and reconcile the stock before the ending of the financial year on March 31. The orders are placed much in advance and we did not know we will be facing such an unprecedented situation. But we do have enough stock for the coming days, but the problem is there are no staff members, goods vehicles and even the retailers are not coming,” said Chandresh B Sanghvi, general secretary of the Calcutta Wholesale Medicine Market Area Committee of Bengal Chemists’ and Druggists’ Association.

Title: Pennar Inds shuts plants till March 31
Content: Hyderabad: City-based Pennar Industries Ltd on Tuesday informed the bourses that it has suspended operations in all its manufacturing plants across the country till March 31, 2020, in light of t coronavirus outbreak. The company also said it has closed its business office in line with local government guidelines.The company has seven manufacturing facilities, including five in Telangana and one each in Chennai and Tarapur in Maharashtra. The five plants in Telangana are located at Patancheru, Isnapur, Sadashivpet, Velchal and Mallapur. The company said it is taking various measures to ensure the health and safety of its employees and to comply with the directives regularly being issued by the central and the respective state governments, besides the local authorities.“We further inform that the company is monitoring the situation for taking timely action based on the guidance from governments and the authorities,” it said in the regulatory filing.

Title: Kolkata: Respite from panic buying short-lived
Content:
Koley market wears a nearly empty look on Tuesday morning

KOLKATA: Following the announcement of a 21-day nationwide lockdown, panic buying returned to the city markets on Tuesday evening. Immediately after the announcement by Prime Minister Narendra Modi , people rushed to buy staples. The grocery stores in the city had long queues of buyers wearing masks. Within an hour, items flew off the shelves.

Shankar Adhikari, owner of Annapurna Bhandar of Behala, said, “I exhausted my stocks in the last one hour. People were confused. If delivery does not come tomorrow, I have to shut down my store. Hopefully, things will normalize in a day or two.” A similar situation prevailed across the city. In some areas police had to intervene to maintain the queue in front of grocery stores.

Senior bureaucrats of food and civil-supplies and agriculture marketing department assured that there is no dearth of staples and vegetables in the state. Since, we are already under lockdown, the same restrictions will apply for next few days. People must keep their cool and purchase things judiciously,” said the officers.

A semblance of normalcy returned to the markets briefly across the city on Tuesday when prices of perishable commodities dropped a little. Those who burnt holes in their pockets in panic buying on Monday regretted as prices plunged nearly 50%. However, the gap between the wholesale and retail prices is yawning and enforcement agencies have a role in reducing the gap.

The crowd in the city markets thinned considerably on Tuesday. However, some vendors who come by trains, could not reach the markets. Most of the stalls had limited stocks of varieties of fish other than Rohu and Katla.

“Yesterday, we had limited supply, but a huge number of buyers. This automatically spiked the price of each vegetable. Customers bought double or triple of their daily requirements. Today, the opposite happened. There is enough supply yet fewer customers,” said Gautam Rakshit, a vegetable vendor at Behala market.

There was a steady supply of vegetables and fruits to the city wholesale markets and prices dropped. However, the sharp drop is wholesale prices of vegetables did not reflect proportionally on the retail prices. The difference between the wholesale and retail prices should not be over Rs 3-4 per kg. But on Tuesday it was much higher than that, said market experts.

Title: Kolkata Municipal Corporation launches drive to disinfect areas of mass gathering
Content: KOLKATA: The Kolkata Municipal Corporation (KMC) launched a major disinfection drive for roads, hospitals, bus terminals, housing complexes, markets and other places of mass gathering to minimize the chances of infection from novel coronavirus. The solid waste management department of KMC has joined hands with its parks department for the drive.While the solid waste management department workers used specially crafted machines to spray sodium hypochlorite solution on the premises of hospitals, housing complexes, market places and bus terminals, the parks department has banked on water sprinklers to clean the city’s major thoroughfares.The special drive began on Monday from a large housing complex on Panditiya Road. On Tuesday, the civic body brought large parts of south Kolkata under the drive, which started with Chetla market and then covered Alipore Road, Harish Mukherjee Road, Harish Chatterjee Street, Bhowanipore, Asutosh Mukherjee Road, Rashbehari Avenue and Sarat Bose Road among other areas. The disinfection drive ended in central Kolkata, including Chowringhee.The team also entered SSKM, Shambhunath Pandit, Chittaranjan Seva Sadan, Chittaranjan Cancer hospital during the drive. But, an official said that the civic body’s infrastructure and manpower were not adequate to bring all vulnerable city areas under the disinfection programme within a short span of time.According to a KMC official, the drive with limited infrastructure has become an uphill task, considering frantic calls from the ruling party councillors requesting for it in their respective wards. He added that the drive would continue for the entire week and include more neighbourhoods.

Title: Kolkata: Work from home tough to handle, find young parents
Content: KOLKATA: As the city went into a lockdown and most corporates and IT firms closed their doors to reduce infections, working from home has become the new reality for many professionals in Kolkata. For young parents, this reality comes with the challenge of balancing a 10-hour job schedule, managing hyperactive kids and basic home chores.“I had initially thought it would be fun. But staying at home and working remotely for the last few days has taught me a lifetime lesson. First, in the absence of maid, I need to help in the daily chores and then comes the kid who seeks attention almost always and with that, comes the real challenge of meeting the work deadlines and the conference calls keeping out the distractions around. It’s a tough life. I am just waiting for my office to reopen and rush back to my cozy cubicle,” said Satarupa Chakraborty, who works at a top accounting and consulting MNC.Jadavpur resident and techie Soumya Bandyopadhyay said he hated to handover digital screens to his son, but such is the situation with both he and his wife working from home, often he has no other option to keep the child engaged. “I have done work from home on several occasions before. But this time, with the schools closed and the child stuck at home, it has become a major issue. I am trying to make him read as much books as possible but at times, I have no other way than to hand him over the tablet,” said Bandyopadhyay.A web graphic artist from Baguiati said such is the situation that he had to lock himself in the balcony of their 2BHK flat on Tuesday for three hours to finish an assignment even as his three-year-old daughter kept banging the door, pleading to allow her watch rhymes on his laptop. “I am feeling crazy at times and am also losing my cool. I know I shouldn’t but I can’t help,” the designer said.Doctors and psychologists said it’s a situation Indians are not very used to and is an extremely challenging situation for all the family members, including the elderly and the children. “Staying for two days at home with all the family members is a different ball game but to stay back for an indefinite period is a pressure cooker kind of situation. In a scenario like this, one has to accept the situation. It has to be clearly discussed with all the family members and ask everyone to keep calm. Everyone should have their own pursuits at home. Also, the positive aspect is, a family can come together and solve much of their existing problems during this period,” said Siladitya Roy, clinical psychiatrist.Neuro psychiatrist Baidyanath Ghosh Dastidar said: “The outbreak can be stressful for people. Fear and anxiety about a disease, coupled with people working from home with the entire family locked together at home, can be overwhelming and cause strong emotions in adults and children. Take care of yourself and follow normal routine, eat well, exercise regularly, have six to eight hours of sleep and avoid alcohol or sedatives.” Dastidar has even opened a 24x7 helpline number (9830177145) asking people to speak to him and his colleagues to seek free counselling on coping with the situation.

Title: Pune: Three test positive for Covid-19, two without travel history
Content:
60% medical staff go on mass leave

PUNE: Three individuals, including two critically-ill patients with no history of recent international travel and proximity to close contacts of infected persons, tested positive for novel coronavirus (Covid-19) at private hospitals in the city late on Monday evening and Tuesday. This has pushed the Covid-19 case tally to 31 in Pune district The two critically patients with no apparent history of foreign travel developed viral pneumonia, following which their throat swab samples were sent to the National Institute of Virology (NIV) for testing as per the latest testing protocol set by the Union health ministry. Both are currently on ventilator support.Another person down with the contagion is a 25-year-old Kothrud resident had returned from London on March 12. He was subsequently quarantined at the Naidu hospital when he developed flu-like symptoms. “One of three patients found positive for Covid-19 is a 51-year-old man with viral pneumonia. He is currently on ventilator support at a private hospital in Erandwane. He has no history of travel abroad. He also did not come in contact with any known patient of Covid-19. We are tracing the link. His contacts are now being tracked and quarantined. We do not think it is a case of community spread,” a civic health official said.A resident of Wagholi, who also has no apparent history of foreign travel or proximity to known contacts of Covid-19 positive persons, is on ventilator support at a private hospital on Ahmednagar Road in Pune. “He is a 48-year-old man. He tested positive for the contagion on Tuesday morning. His condition is currently critical,” the official said.In the state, the MMR remains on top of the chart with 58 positive cases, of which 41 are from Mumbai. The rest are from Kalyan, Thane and Navi Mumbai, among other places.Civic officials in Mumbai said the 65-year-old patient had died on Monday evening within hours of admission at Kasturba Hospital near Saat Rasta. The Dubai-based man had gone to a hospital in Ahmedabad on 15 March with a complaint of back pain and came to Mumbai a few days later. He developed fever, cough and breathing difficulty on March 20 and went to a private medical practitioner. As his condition worsened, he got admitted to Kasturba on Monday in a critical state and passed away the same evening. “He was a patient of uncontrolled diabetes and hypertension,” said Dr Daksha Shah, BMC’s deputy executive health officer. She added that the patient’s ‘positive’ report came after he passed away.BMC officials confirmed that the patient’s final rites were performed at the Shivaji Park electric crematorium. Maharashtra’s public health minister Rajesh Tope said that of the total number of Covid-19 cases now under treatment (104), two patients are critical.Over 60% of the medical staffers, mainly paramedics like nurses and attendants, at Bharati hospital have stopped coming to work after a 41-year-old woman admitted at the hospital tested positive for Covid-19 on Friday morning.

Title: Despite night shelters, homeless forced to sleep on footpaths
Content:
Nagpur: Noor suddenly found himself helpless from last Sunday when the road, which had become his home, was deserted after Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s janata curfew call. The mentally deranged man, who strayed on the road outside Laxminarayan Institute of Technology (LIT) for nearly a year, used to feel at home on the footpath.

Barely able to tell his name, Noor had became a known face for street vendors who not only provided him with food, clothing but also arranged a bedding for him at the footpath. However, things changed after the lockdown was extended.

Since Sunday, a puzzled Noor was seen spending his time alone, hoping for his friends to help. Many such homeless persons like him would be seen spending their lives on the footpath at Khamla Square, Sitabuldi, Alankar Square and other places. Ironically, the pavement dwellers continue to be on road despite nearly half of beds at the Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC)-operated five shelters for homeless remaining vacant.

As per NMC officials, only 112 beds are occupied at all the five shelter homes, which means 108 are still vacant.

Some NGOs, however, complained that these shelter homes allow entry only for men while families were prohibited, which was precisely the reason these migrants were seen wandering on roads with their wives and children.

“As the entire world is caught in the coronavirus pandemic, we’ve conducted an awareness drive related to the deadly disease at three places — University Library Square, Yeshwant Stadium and Santra Market — where such families usually stay,” Kiran Kalantari, a member of a city-based NGO Upay, which has been working for homeless kids for the last many years, told TOI.

A group of 10 to 15 families, staying near University Library Square earns livelihood by selling home decoration items. The NGO’s help came as a timely boon for them, as they had lost their only source of income after the lockdown was imposed. “The NGO members are helping us out by not only providing food for at least three days, but also supplying liquid soaps and masks to all of us,” said Shankar Chakar, one of the pavement dwellers.

Kalantari said Upay was in touch with many other NGOs for providing ration and other daily needs products to the homeless people in the city.

In a communiqué, the NMC directed its officials to provide free food to the shelter home inmates. Moreover, if any of them was found with symptoms like cough, cold, fever and difficulty in breathing, they should be provided with proper medication and sent to the testing centres if the condition is serious.

“The inmates have already been guided on how to maintain hygiene and wash hands with soap at regular intervals to protect themselves from contracting the disease. Masks have also been distributed after apprising them of its importance,” the communiqué informed.

Title: Biometric authentication for ration shops suspended in Karnataka
Content: MYSURU: The Karnataka government ’s food and civil supplies department has decided to suspend biometric authentication for the public distribution system (PDS), popularly known as fair price or ration shops, in all districts.The distribution will be taken up with a one-time password (OTP)-based authentication on the mobile number linked to the Aadhaar number of the head of the family.The department has also launched token system to ensure the beneficiaries will maintain minimum distance with others. “This new system has been introduced to allay all the fears among our beneficiaries,” explained an officer from the department.P Shivanna, deputy director, department of food and civil supplies, said beneficiaries are being distributed foodgrains by generating OTPs for the last 10 days. “We also launched the token system to ensure that the beneficiaries do not stand in queue in front of the PDS shops. They are distributed tokens to come and collect their quota of grains,” he said.2-month quota of grainsAccording to the deputy director, all beneficiaries will receive two months’ quota of foodgrains in April. “All beneficiaries will get foodgrains for the month of April and May together in April itself. We are making all the arrangements for this... We have enough stock of foodgrains and other essentials, including LPG cylinders, and other petroleum products,” he said.The biometric system requires fingerprint authentication on electronic devices before the beneficiary get the ration quota for the month. Many believe the process could spread Covid-19

Title: E-grocer apps and sites refuse orders in Kolkata
Content: KOLKATA: Owing to ‘ unprecedented demand ’, online grocery service providers, such as Grofers and BigBasket have restricted their websites to existing customers only. Most of the e-grocers are now showing “please try again in a few hours” message to the new customers.Social distancing, quarantine, lockdown and janata curfew — the four major remedial measures to combat Covid-19 — have posed new challenges for the online grocers. Bulk purchase, demand-supply mismatch and paucity of logistical support have put e-stores and buyers in a fix.Online supermarket BigBasket said, “We have shortlisted and prioritized essential items such as atta, dal, canned food, ready-to-cook food and spices. We are in touch with our manufacturing partners and supply chains to ensure quick arrangements in case we face momentary gaps.”The online stores are at a loss trying to address operational challenges. Confused with the delivery delay, Nanda Dutta, a homemaker in Behala, placed orders on two e-grocery mobile apps simultaneously. “I can’t take a risk at this hour. Both the apps have scheduled delivery for the weekend. I doubt that I will get it at all.”Allaying consumers’ concerns, BigBasket clarified: “The orders for non-essential items placed earlier will be delivered while keeping essentials a priority. We are not facing shortages in FMCG products, barring sanitizers.” It had earlier notified that deliveries may be delayed or some items may not be delivered.E-grocery giant Grofers requested its customers to opt for “considerate shopping”. The company’s co-founder and CEO Albinder Dhindsa said, “We are discouraging hoarding of essential items and discontinuing promotions.” Tamal Kumar Paul from Shovabazar, however, justified hoarding. “It is not a crime to gear up for a constant lockdown. A stock of flour , lentils and rice is important,” he said.“We saw around 80% growth from Kolkata, Mumbai, Bengaluru, Pune and Ahmedabad until now,” Dhindsa added. Grofers has distributed masks and sanitizers for their supply chain professionals.Spencer’s acknowledged delivery slots on its app were choked. “We are trying to open slots but they are immediately getting filled up as more people are opting for online delivery. We shall open up additional slots in the next few days to increase the capacity,” said Spencer’s regional head Kaushik Ganguly.Consumers are finding it difficult to connect with Future group’s Big Bazaar chain over phone. The group’s regional head Manish Agarwal advised customers to leave WhatsApp messages. “We will revert to customers who leave a message and give service,” he said.

Title: 66-year-old man from Mangrol tests positive
Content:
Surat: The first case of COVID-19 in rural area was reported from Mangrol town of the district on Tuesday with a 66-year-old resident testing positive.This has taken the total positive cases in Surat city and district to six.

The man had a travel history to Abu Dhabhi and was admitted in the isolation ward of the New Civil hospital after he developed severe cough, cold and fever two days ago. He had travelled to Abu Dhabi 17 days ago.

Deputy municipal commissioner (health and hospital), Dr Ashish Naik said that about 27 close contacts of the 66-year-old patient from Mangrol have been shifted to the government quarantine facility at Samras Hostel of the Veer Narmad South Gujarat University (VNSGU).

Surat collector, Dr. Dhaval Patel said in a statement, “Doctors and their team are treating this patient and necessary precautions have been taken.''

Health officials said that four new patients with suspected virus symptoms were admitted in the isolation ward of New Civil Hospital on Monday, while the report of four others are negative.

A 19-year-old girl from Dabholi with travel history to Delhi, a 28-year-old male from Yogi Chowk with no travel history, a 21-year-old male from Varachha with who had visited Czech Republic and Sharjah and a 76-year-old woman from Gopipura with no travel history were admitted in the isolation ward of NCH with the suspected symptoms of the virus. The samples of all the patients have been sent for testing and reports are awaited.

On Tuesday, collector Dr. Dhaval Patel, municipal commissioner Banchhanidhi Pani and police commissioner RB Brahmbhatt visited Anand Mahal Road, Palanpur Jakatnaka, Kapodra, Puna and other areas to ensure that people stay at home and there is maximum lockdown in the city.

"On Tuesday, less people were out on roads and they obeying the instructions, which is good,'' Pani said.

Title: Police harrass stock brokers unaware of the exemption directive
Content:
Kolkata: Brokers and officials of the Calcutta Stock Exchange ( CSE ) and national exchanges like NSE and BSE alleged that they were stopped by police on Tuesday though they have claimed that there was a clear order later on March 23 and 24 exempting them. The original order was issued on March 22 where the exemption for stock related activities were not mentioned.

However, subsequently the chief secretary had issued an order on March 24, where the exemption was inserted. The new insertion said hat Sebi regulated stock market entities and the essential staff related to stock market services are exempted from the lock down. When contacted, state chief secretary Rajiva Sinha confirmed the development. The original order was issued following complete safety restrictions that has been devised to fight the Covid -19 outbreak. The restrictions that came into effect at 5 pm on March 23 will be in force till March 31. Modt of the brokers and officials claimed that with no clear directive to the policemen on duty from Lalbazar, at least three of their officials and even cleaners were stopped from attending office on Tuesday.

According to Sankar Lal Singh, the administrative officer at the Calcutta Stock exchange, one Rajesh Routh, a sweeper by profession and residing at Narendrapur was stopped at Patuli and detained by cops while he was on his way to report to office. "He is an integral part of our backup team in the IT department. We had issued a letter stating that he is a bonafide employee and he even flashed his ID card. But he was not allowed to proceed on his own bike. Similarly, Samik Bhaduri, an IT officer getting picked up in a SUV was stopped twice. Sitesh Agarwal, a broker of NSE was also stopped when he was going to his central Kolkaa office. “We cannot stop my server somebody has to be in the office,” he added.

The police said that they went by the rulebook. " Now, going by the rulebook, we have not received any communication from Lalbazar regarding exemption. Even if thery have received the exemption, they need to contact either Lalbazar traffic wing or the deputy commissioner (traffic)'s office there and get the requisitioned pass with the car registration numbers. There has to be a method followed to ensure they can commute freely to office. We cannot allow too many private vehicles as that would disturb its very purpose,"explained an IPS officer at Lalbazar.

Title: Crackdown on violators in Bharuch
Content:
Surat: Police came down heavily on commuters and pedestrians for violating prohibitory and lockdown orders of the state government to contain spread of COVID-19 in Bharuch district on Tuesday.

At many places in Bharuch and Ankleshwar town, police made commuters to do sit-ups on roads, issued memos and resorted to mild lathicharge to disperse crowd. More than 150 vehicles were detained in Bharuch town and commuters were Issued regional transport office (RTO) memos. Owners can claim their vehicles after RTO becomes functional after March 31.

Rajendrasinh Chudasama, SP, Bharuch, told TOI, “Policemen have been given free hand to take stern action against those violating prohibitory orders in the district. We are strictly implementing lockdown orders and people are not allowed to move out.”

Chudasama said, “People have not understood seriousness of COVID-19. We have shut down all vegetable markets, including APMC market, in Bharuch after residents thronged them to purchase vegetables and fruits.”

Sources said police forced closure of Tusidham Vegetable Market on Tuesday. In Ankleshwar town, police had to resort to mild lathicharge to disperse the crowd.

Title: Coronavirus in Karnataka: 8 new cases in Karnataka; CM says essential supplies won’t be hit
Content:
BS Yediyurappa

BENGALURU: A day before Ugadi, Karnataka on Tuesday slapped fresh restrictions on movement beyond the confines of the home and said its March 24-31 lockdown will be extended till April 14 in sync with the Centre’s announcement.

During the day, eight Covid-19 cases — the highest in a day — were detected in Karnataka, taking the total in the state to 41. A 37-year-old daughter of a Karnataka MP tested positive in a preliminary test and was admitted to a hospital in Davanagere. She had travelled from Guyana to Bengaluru via Delhi. The MP, who accompanied her from Delhi, tested negative.

Soon after the Centre announced the 21-day lockdown, thousands of people in several parts of Karnataka queued up in front of provision stores to buy essential items. Chief minister BS Yediyurappa, in a late-night statement, said his government will ensure supply of essentials, especially for the poor.

Title: Covid-19: Realty sector urges govt for sops
Content: Kolkata: The real estate industry in the state has sought some sops under the West Bengal Housing Industry Regulatory Authority ( WBHIRA ) Act following the coronavirus pandemic (Covid-19) and subsequent lockdown in the state. Credai , West Bengal, has written to state housing miniser Chandrima Bhattacharya in this regard.Credai West Bengal president Sushil Mohta said that it has written to both minister and secretary and got encouraging response. “We have got some relief and the government would examine the others,” he added.Mohta pointed out that there is also a huge impact on the continuity of all technical service providers, including architects, structural engineers, electrical engineers, PHE and other consultants owing to social distancing and lockdown. The supply several goods and raw materials critical to construction — such as tiles, electrical fittings, switches, pipes, construction chemicals, Malaysian sawn timber, hardware items, glass Lifts, has impacted both at inter-state and international level.“In view of the above facts, the entire real estate industry is threatened with complete collapse. We are at a complete loss as to how we will be able to keep our commitment to the customer of timely delivery/possession, as notified under the WBHIRA registration document,” Mohta added.When contacted, housing secretary O S Meena said that it has examined the representation and intering ,easures have taken. “Normal hearing under WBHIRA has been deferred and no application for registration will be cancelled till April 30. We have also agreed to give more time for the return of annual accounts of the project. For the rest we asked for supporting documents,” he added.

Title: Units facing manpower, raw material shortage
Content:
Bharuch/Surat: Many industries at Ankleshwar, Dahej, Panoli Vilayat and Jhagadia in Bharuch district are facing raw material and employee shortage due to the ongoing lockdown in the state.

Some workers have preferred to stay at home while others were not being allowed by police to go to work. ONGC Petro additions Limited, Reliance Industries Ltd, Birla Copper, Grasim, MRF, Meghmani, Indofil, Nocil , Heubach color and Jubilant are among the affected companies. Many industrialists met Bharuch district collector on Tuesday to discuss the current situation.

Bharuch district collector Dr M D Modiya told reporters, "Sub-divisional magistrate and director of industrial safety and health will analyze the requirement of the industries and take appropriate decision with regard to critical units. All other units across the district should stop their operations for a few days."

Dahej Industries Association vice-president Sunil Bhatt said, “Many units were forced to

shutdown in the absence of workers and raw material shortage . Quite a few of them are critical units because of their operations and that they should not be allowed to shutdown. The managements of these critical units have requested local authorities to issue passes for their employees.”

Vilayat GIDC Industries Association president Mahesh Vashi said, “Because of continuous processes in these critical industries, they always need manpower and raw material. We have requested authorities to permit them to run their operations if they have accommodation for their employees within the premises of the units.”

Ankleshwar Industries Association president Mahesh Patel said, "Ankleshwar and Panoli industrial estates have many pharmaceutical units. We have urged the authorities to not disrupt their operations because they are doing important function for the nation.”

Title: Covid-19 positive patient dies in Tamil Nadu, country's virus toll rises to 11
Content:
#update: Despite our best efforts, the #COVID19 +ve Pt at MDU, #RajajiHospital, passed away few minutes back.He had… https://t.co/80yUt5Rj92 — Dr C Vijayabaskar (@Vijayabaskarofl) 1585081920000

#coronaupdate: 3 new cases for #covid19 in Chennai. 65Y M return from New Zealand at Pvt.Hosp, 55Y F Saidapet at… https://t.co/4tKsCJ2YOB — Dr C Vijayabaskar (@Vijayabaskarofl) 1585065786000

MADURAI (TAMIL NADU): Tamil Nadu health minister C Vijayabaskar on Wednesday said that a COVID-19 positive patient passed away at a hospital here."Update: Despite our best efforts, the Covid-19 +ve Pt at MDU, #RajajiHospital, passed away few minutes back. He had a medical history of prolonged illness with steroid dependent COPD, uncontrolled Diabetes with Hypertension.@MoHFW_INDIA @CMOTamilNadu," Vijayabaskar tweeted.Earlier, the minister said that three new cases of COVID-19 were reported in the state and patients were kept in isolation."Coronaupdate: 3 new cases for #covid19 in Chennai. 65Y M return from New Zealand at Pvt.Hosp , 55Y F Saidapet at #KMC. 25Y M return from London at #RGGH. Patients are in isolation & under treatment.@MoHFW_INDIA @CMOTamilNadu," Vijayabaskar tweeted.Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR) has earlier reported ten deaths due to Covid-19 in India and about 536 confirmed positive cases.

Title: India Lockdown for 21 days: All of India under lockdown for 3 weeks due to Coronavirus in India
Content:
More on Covid-19
