NEW DELHI: Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Tuesday ramped up the fight against coronavirus by announcing that the entire country was being placed under lockdown — he called it as good as curfew — for 21 days starting midnight in order to break the chain of Covid-19 transmission and save India from a massive outbreak that could overwhelm the healthcare system.Saying there was no other way to save the country from coronavirus, the PM said nations were facing a growing challenge and even the health care systems of developed countries like the US and Italy were struggling to respond to the unprecedented situation resulting from the rapid global spread of Covid-19.“At 12 midnight... listen carefully, at 12 midnight, all of India will be under total lockdown. This is being done keeping in mind the experiences of other nations. This is the only way to save India. Save you and your families. No one steps out of their house. No one steps out. All states, all districts, all mohallas, will be locked down. It is a curfew. It is much more than a janata curfew. It is tougher. It is a decisive fight. It will indeed come at an economic cost but every life is important,” the PM said in a televised address, his second on coronavirus in a week. Drawing what he called the “lakshman rekha” for people, Modi bluntly said, “Forget about venturing out. For the next 21 days, you have to do just one thing, stay put at home, stay put at home and stay put at home only.You don’t have to take a single step beyond the ‘lakshman rekha’.” Modi acknowledged that the country would have a huge economic cost to pay, and that the poor would suffer the most. But he suggested it was time for the nation to choose its priorities and, clearly, saving people’s lives took precedence.“Jaan hai to jahan hai (If there is life, there is the world)... We must strengthen our resolve at every step and also be restrained,” he said. He added, “Come what may, you have to observe social distancing. From the common man in villages to the Prime Minister, nobody should breach this lakshman rekha.”As reports came in of panic buying after his speech, Modi tweeted, “By converging around shops, you are risking the spread of Covid-19. No panic buying please. Please stay indoors. I repeat— Centre and state governments will ensure all essentials are available.”The 21-day lockdown is arguably the first measure taken by any country to deal with the threat and Modi, like his address on Thursday, minced no words in underlining the gravity of the challenge facing the country and even people, citing the opinion of WHO and public health experts that a 21-day lockdown could break the chain of transmission, and by pointing to the tragic experience of developed countries reeling under the global pandemic.“Even the most capable nations have been rendered helpless. Not that they do not have resources or are not making efforts. But the virus is spreading so fast that despite efforts, these nations are facing a mounting challenge,” he said.However, he suggested that India could still find a way out of the crisis by exercising social distancing. “India is at the stage where our actions will decide the extent to which we can mitigate the crisis. We have to renew our resolve. This is the moment to exercise restraint and maintain discipline. We will come out victorious if we maintained utmost restraint,” the PM said. “There is only way one way to effectively combat this disease. It is social distancing. That means we have to stay away from each other. Stay indoors. There is no other way to save yourselves, your families and friends from coronavirus,” he added. Modi said there were misconceptions that social distancing was only for patients.“That is not correct. Social distancing is for everyone, for every person, including thePM.” The unprecedented step of placing the entire nation under lockdown comes days after more than 500 districts were put under such restrictions. There is a list of exempt services such as healthcare workers, media, sanitation staff and police that the PM mentioned, but he plainly suggested that implementation would be rigorous. “Treat your doorstep as your ‘lakshman rekha’ that you will not cross for the next three weeks,” he said.Hinting at the lack of seriousness with which lockdowns and restrictions have been observed, the PM said, “The carelessness and wrong thinking of some people could endanger yourselves, your families, friends and finally the nation will be in a big trouble. If such carelessness continues, India will have to pay a heavy price of which is not even possible to estimate.” While the rules about how the lockdown was to be observed and exemptions were notified by the home ministry, crowds were seen at grocery and convenience stores.The PM appealed to people to keep in mind the sacrifices being made by healthcare professionals, sanitation workers, media personnel engaged in reporting the situation without caring for their own safety and the police that was sometimes having to deal with unruly public. “I am appealing with folded hands, whereever you are, stay there. It will be for three weeks. I had said recently when I spoke to you that I am asking for a few weeks... To break the cycle, we will need 21 days. If we don’t control this, the country and your families will go back 21 years. Many families will be destroyed forever. I am speaking, not as a PM but as a member of your family. So forget what it is to step out,” PM said. He reminded people that the illness could be deceptive, and in the early stage of infection there was nothing to distinguish that coronavirus had struck.“Many times a person is quite healthy. No evidence of illness is apparent. This is need to stay alert,” he said and held up a sign doing the rounds on social media which said no one should come out on the roads in Hindi, spelling out“Co-ro-na”. The PM pointed that the number of infected persons had climbed steeply. It had taken 67 days to reach 100,000 people, 11 days to add another lakh and the third lakh came in only four days. The experience of countries that beat back the threat was that citizens needed to remain indoors. “Follow the directives of the central and state governments 100%. We are not to step out of homes. Come what may, from the PM to villager. Only then we can save ourselves,” he said.Modi said steps would be taken to ensure supply of essential materials and the problems of the poor would be attended to. “The highest priority will be given to repairing health facilities and working with WHO and Indian institutions. Efforts will be made to ensure we have ICUs, ventilators, beds, medical and paramedical staff.” He said that wittingly or unwittingly, rumours get around and asked people not to believe in them. He particularly asked people not to indulge in self-medication. “A 21 day lockdown is a long time but it is for all of you, for your safety, it is important that every Indian face this successfully.

Title: Surat: Demand for home deliveries of vegetables by APMC spikes
Content: Surat Municipal Corporation had tied up with the APMC for home deliveries to prevent residents from leaving... Read More SURAT: Over the past two days, the Agriculture Produce Market Committee (APMC) has delivered vegetables, groceries, and fruits to the homes of 800 residents in various parts of Surat. The strict implementation of the lockdown has spiked online orders. Two days ago, the Surat Municipal Corporation (SMC) had tied up with the APMC for home deliveries to prevent residents from leaving their homes. Surat reported its first death due to COVID-19 on March 22. Talking with TOI, the secretary of the APMC, Nilesh Thorat, said: “The response to the online delivery service is overwhelming.” Customers place their orders on the APMC website. “We deliver the orders within half-an-hour,” Thorat said. “We have a team of 30 delivery persons,” Thorat said. “The majority of the orders are coming from posh areas including Vesu, Parle Point, Athwalines, Adajan, and Pal.” Thorat said customers must place an order of at least Rs 500. “We are not taking a single penny extra from customers,” Thorat said. “Our vegetable and fruit prices are lower than wholesale rates.” The director of the APMC, Babu Shaikh, said: “We will continue online deliveries till March 31. On average, we are catering to about 400 people in the city a day.” Deputy municipal commissioner (health and hospitals), Dr Ashish Naik said, “When people are getting their essential supplies delivered home, there is no need for them step out of their homes and risk their lives.”

Title: DTC makes ID card must for passengers
Content: NEW DELHI: With nearly 2,000 buses of Delhi Transport Corporation (DTC) on the city roads on the second day of lockdown, there was less crowding inside the buses compared with Monday. However, to ensure only those involved in essential services are allowed to travel, DTC has now made it mandatory for all passengers to show identity cards. An order in this regard was issued by DTC managing director on Tuesday.“This was necessary as even those who were not involved in essential services were roaming around in buses, putting other passengers and our staff in danger,” an official from DTC said.“Our buses are being thoroughly sanitised, but with unnecessary crowding, maintaining social distancing becomes difficult,” he added.“With more DTC buses in place, vehicles were comparatively less crowded today. The situation will improve on Wednesday with only those with official identity cards allowed to board buses,” he asserted.While barring all types of public transport from operating on Sunday, Delhi chief minister Arvind Kejriwal had allowed only 25% buses of the DTC fleet to operate from Monday. Due to the overcrowding witnessed on the first day of the lockdown, DTC was asked to operate 50% of its fleet. With the number of buses in DTC’s fleet being 3,756, around 2,000 buses operated on Tuesday.“The frequency of buses was significantly better on Tuesday and all passengers were able to maintain a comfortable distance,” said a central government employee who didn’t wish to be identified.

Title: Coronavirus Karnataka Update: Village shuts itself for two months
Content:
M Golahalli in Kolar has locked itself out

KOLAR: With the threat of Covid-19 spreading to rural pockets running high, 800 residents of a village on the Karnataka-Andhra border have initiated extreme measures: Cutting contact with the outside world for two months by sealing all roads leading to the village.

M Golahalli, 110km from Bengaluru and in Kolar district, took this decision as residents don’t want any of them to get infected and spread it to others. The village has mainly agricultural workers who depend on farms for their livelihood.

According to M Gopal, a progressive farmer and national secretary of All India Kissan Manch in the village, the villagers are unanimous in their decision and 100 volunteers will oversee the arrangements. There are four committees on health, sanitation, security and communication. Checkposts have been set up to prevent entry or exit of any person.

KV Jagganath, president, district Primary School Teachers Association, said villagers will keep vigil at these checkposts. He said over 700 litres of milk is being produced in the village every day and this will be filled in cans and be placed outside the border and vans that collects milk should lift the cans from the border itself. The excess vegetables would be placed in boxes after subjecting them to sanitisation and would be placed outside the border.

N Rajgopal, former ZP member said: “In a bid to prevent shortage of groceries and other food stuff, villagers were asked to get required groceries and other items which can last long for two months, including medicine. All those who have gone out of the village have been asked to come back. There are four temples in the village and rituals are being allowed. This morning, villagers swept the village and sanitised the roads using cow dung and cow urine. The villagers decided to clean their village regularly. This self-isolation will be in place for two months.”

In case the situation eases, farmers will rethink the period of isolation. Interestingly, a young man from the village who lives in London as been asked by villagers not to return till this crisis is over.

Title: Govt in talks with automobile firms to make ventilators
Content: NEW DELHI: The Centre is in talks with leading automobile manufacturers exploring the possibility of producing ventilators and other equipment in their factories to meet the surging demand for critical care for Covid-19 patients, sources said.Two high level meetings — one each on Monday and Tuesday — have taken place with top executives from five companies — Maruti , M&M, Hyundai , Tata and Honda. These meetings were also attended by officials from the cabinet secretariat, health ministry, Indian Council of Medical Research and department of pharmaceuticals.“These firms have expressed concern about the current situation and said they have required infrastructure and technology to produce ventilators. Certain modifications to their existing model are required and for that they will seek the drawings and prototypes from other foreign companies,” a DoP official told TOI.The automobile companies have told DoP that they will come up with a detailed plan and timeline of production within two days, he said.

Title: Homes of patients, kin sanitized
Content:
Vadodara: Vadodara Fire and Emergency Services started disinfecting houses of those who tested positive of coronavirus and are under home quarantine on Monday night.

Monday night onwards, houses of all six persons, who tested positive were sanitized by the authorities. “The chemical has been provided by the health department of Vadodara Municipal Corporation,” said a fire official.

The liquid was sprinkled on the walls of their houses and compound walls. “Besides their house, we have also sanitized the area around their house and other places wherever the patients visited,” the fire official added. On Tuesday, the fire department started sanitization of houses of all those persons who had come in contact with the affected patients and are currently in home quarantine.

“As of now we have only sanitized houses of those persons who had come in contact with the isolated patients. In coming days we will be taking up more places,” the fire official said.

Title: India, China discuss joint Covid-19 fight
Content:
Discussed with State Councilor and FM Wang Yi of #China our working together in combating #COVID19. Agreed to build… https://t.co/0OXuGEzS7j — Dr. S. Jaishankar (@DrSJaishankar) 1585048047000

NEW DELHI: Amid the growing Covid-19 threat, India and China on Tuesday discussed cooperation to jointly fight the pandemic which has killed more than 17,000 worldwide.Foreign minister S Jaishankar tweeted that he and his counterpart Wang Yi discussed working together and agreed to build further on bilateral efforts. The two also spoke about the upcoming G20 summit. India had earlier sent a planeload of relief supplies to coronavirus-hit Hubei province as a mark of solidarity with China.Chinese ambassador to India Sun Weidong on Twitter said the two ministers expressed sympathy and solidarity with India in its fight against Covid-19 and that China was ready to share its experience, provide assistance within its capacity and “open its channel for procurement to India”.He tweeted that Wang said in his conversation with Jaishankar that “it’s not acceptable and detrimental to international cooperation to label thevirus and stigmatise China, hope India opposes such narrow mindset”.

Title: 26 booked in Vadodara for flouting IPC Section 144
Content:
Representative image

VADODARA: Despite warnings, hundreds of Barodians ventured out on the city roads on Tuesday only to face police action. The cops detained 190 vehicles of citizens who were found travelling on the road without any valid reasons. Also, 11 persons were booked for flouting Section 188 and legal action will follow against them soon.

Soon after the state government announced lockdown to contain Coronavirus outbreak, the police had on Monday put barricades across the city to ensure that people don’t come out in large numbers. “We continued with the drive on Tuesday and put barricades at main roads in Dandia Bazaar, Alkapuri, Old Padra Road, Mandvi, VIP Road, Rajmahal Road, Makarpura Road and Akota. We stopped all people and asked why they have ventured out,” said a senior police official, adding that the ones who didn’t have satisfactory answers faced police action.

The police said that most of the commuters said that they were out to buy medicines or groceries. The cops also collected penalties worth Rs 17,100 from those who violated the police notification. In some areas, locals were hanging out in a group of more than four persons following which the cops booked them for flouting Section 144.

Fifteen persons were booked by Vadodara rural police too for violating public notification prohibiting gathering of more than four persons at a place and keeping shops of non-essential items open. At Savli an offence was registered against five persons as they had gathered at a paan shop on Monday night. Similarly at Vadu, five more persons were booked for sitting in a group in market area and chatting.

Offences were also registered against those who kept their establishments open despite the lockdown. If an ice-cream shop owner in Vadu was booked for keeping his shop open and selling ice-cream and soft drinks to people, FIR was filed against a snacks shop owner at VUDA circle in Padra for the same reason on Monday.

Title: Coronavirus cases in India: 8 Covid-19 patients recover across India, slight dip in new cases
Content:
More on Covid-19

NEW DELHI: The Covid-19 outbreak claimed two more victims, a 65-year-old Mumbai resident and another one in Delhi, even though the rush of new infections slowed a bit to 64 on Tuesday, from 99 the previous day.The total number of Covid-19 cases reported from the states so far is 562. Apart from the lower number of fresh cases, there was also some cheer on the recoveries front. Trust the newspaper for your daily verified news How to quarantine yourself at home 21-day lockdown: What will stay open and what won't Coronavirus pandemic: Complete Coverage As many as 48 coronavirus patients have so far been discharged from hospital after treatment, a sharp rise from 35 reported till Monday. As many as eight patients were discharged in Maharashtra. The health ministry recorded a death in Delhi, although the state government denied any knowledge of it.Sources said a person suffering from acute respiratory distress and heart-related ailments died at Rajiv Gandhi Super Specialty hospital on Tuesday. Mumbai recorded its third coronavirus death Monday night, Brihanmumbai Municipal Corporation said. The victim was a Dubai-based man who had reported to an Ahmedabad hospital on March 15 with a complaint of back pain, and later came to Mumbai.Meanwhile, there were indications that the virus had spread to the northeast. A 23-year-old girl in Manipur, who had recently returned from the UK, tested positive in the initial test. The result of her confirmation test is awaited.If confirmed, this would be the first Covid-19 cases in the entire northeast. Kerala recorded the highest number of fresh cases on Tuesday, 14. It overtook Maharashtra as the state with highest number of cases at 109. Maharashtra reported 10 new cases, Karnataka 9, UP 4, three each from Telangana and Tamil Nadu, two each from Bengal and J&K and one from Andhra Pradesh.The MP government imposed a curfew in Gwalior after two people tested positive, one in the city and another in neighbouring Shivpuri, taking the state’s count to nine. As many as four coronavirus positive cases were reported in UP on Tuesday, taking the state’s total to 37. Three cases were reported in Gautam Budh Nagar and one in Shamli district, officials said.Of the three Covid-19 positive cases reported in GB Nagar, acouple is from Noida while the third lives in Greater Noida. Health department sources said the Noida patients had no travel history, though they hosted a friend who had returned from London. The patient in Greater Noida had a travel history.

Title: Bengaluru: Friends trade blows over coronavirus prank
Content: Bengaluru: Two friends thrashed each other over a coronavirus prank near Jayanagar on Saturday evening. Siddapura police said they have registered a case and a counter-case.According to police, a 24-year-old labourer, Preetham R Makam, visited a clinic accompanied by his wife following a health problem he was facing on Saturday evening.He later rushed to a nearby medical store to buy medicines. His friend Naveen DS, 34, who owns a textile shop in the vicinity, noticed Preetham near the medical store and asked him what had happened to him. "Naveen asked Preetham if he had loose motion or coronavirus. Preetham lost his cool over Naveen's coronavirus joke and for making fun of him in front of his wife. The duo got into a heated argument and later hit each other," police said.Police registered a case of assault and criminal intimidation against Preetham on Sunday based on a complaint filed by Naveen. Officers summoned Preetham for interrogation. He appeared before police on Monday and filed a counter-complaint. A case was registered against Naveen under the same provisions.

Title: 298 home quarantine violations
Content:
People out to buy groceries stopped by cops

Vadodara: Gross violation of home quarantine directives continued in the city with the teams of the Vadodara Municipal Corporation (VMC) health department receiving a series of such complaints. The department has so far had to take help of the police in several cases to ensure people remain inside.

VMC had started collaborating with the police last week to ensure that people advised home isolation do not venture out. VMC officials said that so far it had come to light that 298 persons had moved out of their homes and police had to be roped in to ensure that they do not do so.

“Such cases come to our notice when either the neighbours inform us or when our teams reach their home to check on them and find them missing,” said an official.

The issue was not just about people being found missing, but also about health teams facing heir ire. “They enter into arguments with the team and misbehave,” said the official. In one such incident, the health teams and police had to take a person from Ajwa Road to the quarantine centre located in the same area. It was only after this that the person decided to cooperate. The VMC has also moved four police complaints till now against persons who were violating home quarantine despite instructions. All those who are home quarantined are also served notices asking them to follow the instructions.

So far, 3,897 persons from abroad have reached the city after the outbreak globally. In all, 1,002 persons remain under home quarantine including 291 persons who were advised home isolation on Tuesday.

Title: No new positive case in Vadodara, 3 reports awaited
Content:
Roads wore deserted look with shops and business establishments remain shut on Tuesday

Vadodara: No positive case of COVID-19 were reported from Vadodara on Tuesday and condition of the six who are under treatment is said to be stable.

Reports of three patients, who are currently under treatment, are awaited.

A prisoner from Vadodara Central Jail was admitted in the isolation ward of SSG Hospital late on Monday night after which the total number of those in isolation had reached 14. By evening however, the patients under isolation dropped to 11.

“The jail inmate has also tested negative. We have already informed the police about his medical condition and they will go ahead with the process now,” said Dr Rajeev Daveshwar, medical superintendent of SSG Hospital.

According to sources, the inmate had come to jail on March 20. He is a resident of Ahmedabad and was detained by Ahmedabad city police under Prevention of Anti-social activities Act (PASA).

Vadodara’s chief district health officer Dr Uday Tilawat informed that so far 41 samples of patients suspected of COVID-19 have been tested in the district of which six have tested positive, 32 have tested negative.

Samples of two suspected cases have been rejected while result of one is awaited.

Sources said the GMERS Gotri Medical Hospital too had three patients who have been admitted in the isolation ward. Earlier, in the day, reports of seven out of eight COVID-19 suspects, tested negative of the deadly virus.

The six who have tested positive so far including 49-year-old NRI businessman from Spain and five others who belong to the same group of family and friends, who had either travelled together to Sri Lanka or had come in contact with those who had travelled.

Three of them had travelled to Sri Lanka. Two others had not travelled with this group but had come in close contact and got infected.

Title: Video: Taimur Ali Khan asking you to stay home amid Coronavirus outbreak is the cutest thing ever!
Content: From the Mumbai Police filing FIR against social media trolls to Rhea Chakraborty finding more support as her custody gets extended, here are all the top headlines of the day. Our new segment Bolly Buzz goes beyond the usual mix of news and gossip to give all its readers a roundup of all the newsmakers of the day.

Title: Education sector in state comes to a grinding halt
Content:
Vijayawada: The Covid-19 pandemic has brought the education sector in the state to a grinding halt. The impact of the epidemic has forced the state government to shut all educational institutions till March 31.

Even coaching centres have shut operations. Nearly one crore students are limited to their homes for almost a week now, and there’s every possibility of the lockdown being extended. Several busy academic centres in the state, including Vijayawada, Visakhapatnam, Tirupati, Rajahmundry, Kakinada, Guntur and Anantapur have been witnessing muted activity due to the closure of colleges, schools, universities and hostels.

Other than international students, most universities have vacated students from hostels. Some varsities have also postponed practical examinations. Meanwhile, thousands of teachers and faculty members have also been voluntarily observing self isolation due to the ‘lockdown holidays’.

Prof M Jagannadha Rao, vice-chancellor of Adikavi Nannaya University, has asked students to limit themselves to their homes and refrain from going to crowded places during the lockdown period. “We have already postponed the exams. We have conducted various awareness programmes for students on the prevention of the pandemic,” he told TOI.

Andhra University registrar Prof V Krishnamohan, dean (international affairs) Prof Dhanamjaya Rao and Dr Paul Douglas (chief warden of AU international hostels) have been visiting the hostels housing international students and reviewing measures being taken there in view of the prevalence of the pandemic.

Prof Dhanamjaya Rao said they interacted with international students residing in the hostels. “All students expressed satisfaction regarding the sanitary and hygienic conditions there. We have requested them to follow the self-imposed curfew for a few more days,” said professor Rao.

M Ravikrishna Kumar, a maths lecturer at a corporate college in the city, said his college has asked faculty members too to remain at their homes. “Students attended college even during cyclones and heavy rains. But for the first time, all faculty members have got holidays for an extended period due to Covid-19,” he said.

Title: Search begins for VCs
Content:
Visakhapatnam: The state government has constituted search committees to suggest a panel of three members each for the appointment of vice-chancellors in four state universities, including Andhra University, Visakhapatnam Acharya Nagarjuna University (Guntur), Sri Venkateswara University, Tirupati and Rayalaseema University (Kurnool).

After the search committees submit three names for each varsity to the government, they will be forwarded to the Chancellor, who shall the appoint the vice-chancellors, on the recommendation of the government. The chairman of the committees have been asked to convene meetings and submit the names.

The committee of Andhra University comprises Prof S Jayarama Reddy (state government nominee and chairman of the committee), Prof DN Reddy (executive council nominee) and Prof V Ramagopal Rao (UGC nominee).

The members of the search committee of Acharya Nagarjuna University includes Prof Y Venakatarami Reddy (state government and chairman), Prof Mohammad Suleman Siddqui (EC nominee and Prof M Jagadesh Kumar (UGC nominee).

Prof Y Venkatarami Reddy (state government nominee and chairman), Prof G Gopal Reddy (EC nominee) and Prof VS Chauhan (UGC nominee) are part of the search committee constituted for the Sri Venkateswara University, Tirupati.

The committee of the Rayalaseema University include Prof KV Ramana (state government nominee and chairman), Prof V Balamohan Das (EC nominee) and Prof Sanjay Singh (UGC nominee).

Title: Confusion remains over what’s essential
Content: Visakhapatnam: On the second day of the nation-wide lockdown non-essential commodities such as cigarettes, pan and tea continued to be sold despite a government order clarifying that only essentials services are exempt from the lockdown.Besides, even after 9 am on Tuesday a few of the grocery, chicken, fish and mutton vendors continued their businesses raising questions as to how far the lockdown was successful.Meanwhile, police officials said they have made their best efforts to shut down everything after 9 am and patrol vans were deployed to ensure that shopkeepers down their shutters.“Although we are doing our best, but there is a challenge to ensuring cent percent restrictions. How can you shut down a cigarette shop before 9 am that is also selling milk packets? We are dealing with such issues on a case to case basis,” a senior police official told TOI.Another challenge that cropped up on Tuesday was dealing with delivery executives of food delivery applications.Restaurateurs alleged that while stopping unnecessary movements of people is understandable, but police are also stopping delivery executives. But the government has exempted e-commerce of all essential goods like food, pharmaceuticals and medical equipment.“We have shut our restaurants to people but kept our kitchens open for online deliveries. This is in accordance with the government order. However, police is also stopping our delivery executives and even executives of online apps,” said S Khanna, a restaurant owner.“On Tuesday I tried to place order from three restaurants on the app. While the first two orders got cancelled as the restaurants were closed, the delivery executive refused to deliver the third order stating police are stopping them. After much pursuance the restaurant delivered that order to my home,” said Kanishka Prasad, an IT executive in the city.

Title: This is not the time for politics: Health minister to Naidu
Content:
Visakhapatnam: Deputy chief minister and health minister Alla Kalikrishna Srinivas (Nani), along with M Srinivasa Rao and in-charge minister K Kannababu held a review meet district officials on Tuesday.

Speaking at the meet, Nani said public cooperation is imperative if coronavirus has to be controlled. The district administration is focussing around 2,400 people who arrived in Visakhapatnam from foreign countries in the last one month. Besides,1,400 people have already been identified by local administration. Most of them are in Seetammadhara area (670), Gajuwaka (500) and another 400 are in Anakapalli and its surroundings.

The deputy CM said around 14,038 people arrived in AP from different foreign countries. Around 2,426 people have completed their 28-day observation period; 11,526 people in home quarantine and 86 persons are in hospitals.

The medical staff have so far taken 220 suspected samples of which seven cases have been reported as positive, 168 have been reported negative and reports of 45 persons are pending, he said. He advised that people should follow social distancing and lockdown.

The Visakhapatnam district administration has declared VIMS special hospital and equipped it with 200 beds. A high-end ICU would be arranged in the next 24 hours in the hospital, he said. “We are almost approaching the third stage, so we should be ready with rooms for that. Opposition leader and former CM Chandrababu Naidu should not make comments which could demoralize or obstruct the work of the administration. We request him to help us in controlling coronavirus. This is not the time for politics,” he said.

He further added, “We will get a report from the districts about their requirements to combat coronavirus such as ventilators, personal protection equipment (PPE) and others in a day”.

The government has decided to pay salaries to outsourced and contract employees too in this lockdown period. The CM has already announced provision and Rs 1,000 for families which have ration cards.

Title: Hundreds of flyers stranded at airports
Content:
Visakhapatnam/Vijayawada/Rajahmundry: In the wake of Covid-19 outbreak and the country under lockdown, hundreds of passengers had had a tough time after landing at Visakhapatnam, Vijayawada and Rajahmundry airports on Tuesday.

Airport director M Rajah Kishore told TOI that almost all domestic flights scheduled on Tuesday operated on the day. “With all other modes of transportation suspended in the country there was a rush at the airport on Tuesday. However, there are no more flights from Tuesday midnight till March 31,” he added.

Airline officials said that several passengers were left stranded outside the airport because cabs and autorickshaws were few.

“Outside the airport there was a huge demand for cabs. While a few of the passengers took their own vehicles after landing, several were stranded as there were only a few cabs and autos plying. Many decided to share a particular cab and auto to reach their respective destinations,” said an airline official.

Even airline officials admitted that considering the present situation, there was a rush of incoming passengers at the airport. “This is because many offices are closed or people are working from home. Moreover, many returned home for Ugadi,” the official added.

The situation was the same at the Gannavaram Airport in Vijayawada, were passengers were left stranded upon arrival owing to non-availability of cabs and other means of transport. Seeing the situation the airport director swung into action. “We spoke to transport authorities and arranged vehicles for the passengers waiting for the cabs”, said airport director Madhusudan Rao.

At the Rajahmundry airport Indigo operated two return flights – one to Hyderabad and the other to Bangalore-Vizag via Rajahmundry on Tuesday.

“Passengers at the airport did not face any problem after landing,” claimed airport director, Manoj Naik.

Meanwhile, cargo and offshore helicopters would remain continue to operate at the three airports even after midnight.

Title: Fear over Covid-19, consequent lockdown make for sombre Ugadi
Content: Vijayawada/Visakhapatnam: Ugadi in the state this year will be a low-key affair following the lockdown to contain the spread of Covid-19.This time, with fear around the rising number of Covid-19 cases and the lockdown till March 31, “we are also not in the mood to celebrate the festival in a grand manner,” said V Ravi Teja and V Bhavani, a couple who visited a vegetable market in Vijayawada on Tuesday to purchase goods for the Telugu New Year. “We have also appealed to people to celebrate a safe Ugadi,” they added.Police have also urged people to observe the day by celebrating at home and cooperating with the government order on the lockdown.Political parties in the state have decided to call of ‘Panchanga Sravanam’, the ritual reading of the almanac. The ‘Panchanga Sravanam’ and distribution of Ugadi ‘pachhadi’ at temples stands cancelled following their shutdown in keeping with the government order.Vijayawada police has declared that no festive markets will be permitted on Wednesday and have appealed to people to celebrate keeping in mind the need for social distancing to prevent the rise in number of Covid-19 cases.In Vizag, Visakhapatnam district Archaka Sangham general secretary Ayiluru Srinivasa Deekshitulu told TOI, “People visit temples on Ugadi to offer special prayers but this time we are all praying for this situation across the world to come under control.”K Mahalakshmi, a teacher from Seethammadhara in Vizag said that this time they have decided to keep themselves away from Ugadi celebrations. “Instead, we wanted to stay at home and clean our house,” Mahalakshmi said. Executive director of APSRTC Ravi Kumar said while special buses are operated for Ugadi every year, all services have been suspended this time.

Title: Pune: From today, petrol, diesel only for vehicles providing essential services
Content:
From today, fuel only for essential services vehicles

PUNE: Fuel stations in the district will stop dispensing petrol/diesel to all vehicles from Wednesday, barring those involved in providing emergency/essential services, till further notice. District collector Naval Kishore Ram sent a letter to this effect to all fuel pumps on Tuesday.The essential service providers, as per the letter, include officers/staffers working on essential services, private individuals working for Covid-19 control and eradication, private persons working in the field of essential goods and services as well as those in need of medical treatment or assistance.Ram clarified that fuel should only be given to exempted categories of people mentioned in the lockdown orders given by the Maharashtra government on March 23. These include print/electronic mediapersons, services like bakery and veterinary services for pets, takeaway and home delivery personnel, and grocery and vegetable transporters.District collector Naval Kishore Ram said, “Preventive measures need to be taken to prevent the spread of infection. Hence, starting from midnight of March 13, the Epidemic Diseases Act, 1897, was imposed in Maharashtra. As per provisions in this Act and for immediate control and prevention of the infection of coronavirus (Covid-19), and as a preventive measure to prevent its further spread, dispensing of petrol and diesel in two-wheelers/threewheelers/four-wheelers in Pune district is being prohibited, excluding vehicles of those involved in providing essential services.”Sameer Ladkat, president, Petrol Dealers ’ Association, Pune, said, “Less traffic for the past few days has ensured that we have enough fuel stock in the pumps in the district. Even when this ban is lifted, people need not panic as there will be sufficient fuel to cater to vehicles.”

Title: Hearing on Simhachalam on April 9
Content:
Vijayawada: The high court on Tuesday posted hearing on petitions challenging the appointment of Sanchaita Gajapathi Raju as founder member and chairman of Maharajah Alak Narayan Society of Arts and Science (MANSAS) Trust and chairman and hereditary trustee of Sri Varaha Lakshmi Narasima Swamy Vari Devastanam, Simhachalam to April 9.

The high court observed that there was no urgency in the matter to hear or pass orders at this time of prevailing Covid-19 situation.

Former Union minister Ashok Gajapathi Raju and his sister Sunita Prasad had moved the high court with three separate petitions challenging the appointment of Sanchaita as the chairperson of MANSAS Trust as well as the chairperson of temple trust. The high court had earlier issued notices to the respondents to file counters.

The state government is of the view that the appointment of Sanchaita should be looked from a broader constitutional perspective. At a time when a constitutional debate is going on the issue of gender bias in case of whether or not to allow women into Sabarimala temple, the present appointment need to be looked in broader perspective. Though the deed of the trust has specified the rules of succession it is to be seen whether it is constitutionally allowed and whether it will answer the question of gender bias.

Title: For fourth straight year, IIM-Visakhapatnam records 100% placements
Content:
The average salary for the top quartile of the graduating batch of MBA students (2018-20) is Rs 18.67 lakh per... Read More

VIJAYAWADA: The final placement season of the Indian Institute of Management-Visakhapatnam (IIM-V) has been completed with 100% placements for the fourth consecutive year.

The average salary for the top quartile of the graduating batch of MBA students (2018-20) is Rs 18.67 lakh per annum (LPA) and for the top half, Rs 15.73 LPA. The average salary for the batch is Rs 13.08 LPA. The highest salary package is Rs 27 LPA.

Speaking to TOI, IIM-V director, Prof M Chandrasekhar said that the batch broke all previous records. “Held on a rolling basis, the placement season witnessed more than 75 companies participating in the placement process and making multiple offers. I congratulate the student cohort for scaling new peaks in career goals and setting even higher standards in the extremely rewarding offers received,” said Prof Chandrasekhar.

The IT/ITeS sectors accounted for 39% of all placements, followed by banking, financial services and insurance(BFSI) at 16%. The other dominant sectors were education and technology (6%), infrastructure (6%), manufacturing (6%), logistics (5%), automobile (4%), conglomerate (3%), hospitality (3%), consulting (3%), luxury goods (2%), fast-moving consumer goods (FMCG) (2%), e-commerce (2%), pharmaceutical (1%), media and advertising (1%) and food (1%).

Chairperson, Career Development Services (CDS), IIM-V, Prof Deepika Gupta, said, “Even in the prevailing tough business environment our students bucked the trend and achieved 100% results. This is a loud and clear manifestation of our recruiters’ continuing faith, trust and confidence in us and in the capabilities of our students.”

Title: KCR Shoot at site: Lockdown violators could be shot at sight: Telangana CM
Content:
HYDERABAD: Telangana CM K Chandrasekhar Rao on Tuesday said he will have no option but to give shoot-at-sight orders if people don't stay indoors during the lockdown period. Talking to reporters on Tuesday, he also threatened a 24-hour curfew if people violate lockdown orders.

"Don't create a situation where government is left with no option but to give shoot-at-sight orders to the police," he said. Upset with the way people came out on streets on Monday and Tuesday, he said he may consider asking the Army to take over, besides shut down petrol pumps to keep people off the roads, he said. "Curfew would be implemented from 7 pm to 6am and all shops should be closed by 6 pm daily," he said.

Title: AS Nagar locals oppose quarantine centres
Content: Vijayawada: The proposal to set up quarantine centres at newly constructed houses near Ajith Singh Nagar dumping yard has created fear local public.The public came out on streets opposing the inspection by health department officials.The government has decided to increase the number of beds in the city. Identifying space to establish isolation wards and quarantine centres have became a challenge for the officials.The officials have decided to set up the isolation ward at available spaces in the city which includes, schools, colleges, government convention centers and open spaces available.The newly constructed G+3 buildings at Ajith Singh Nagar was one of the options for the officials to set up the emergency facility.Locals threatened to stage agitation if the government ignored their requests. “Around 7,000 families live in Vambey colony, Luna Center and other colonies in Ajith Singh Nagar. We are afraid of the spread of Covid-19 if officials establish quarantine centres here. Buildings are right beside the dumping yard and that too in unhygienic conditions. Officials should consider our requests,” said K Mariyamma, a local resident.Meanwhile, the Krishna district administration said that it has identified around 1,300 beds in various locations across the district. Pedana, Machilipatnam, Gudivada, Nandigama, Jagiahpeta will soon get beds ready for handling emergency situations.

Title: Doctors warn against use of hydroxychloroquine
Content: VIJAYAWADA: The scramble for hydroxychloroquine, the drug recommended by the Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR) for treatment of Covid-19 for two categories of high risk population, has begun. Doctors and pharmacies across the state are receiving an increased number of enquiries about the drug after the ICMR in a recent advisory recommended it as a prophylactic agent for high risk individuals, including medical personnel working at the frontline of Covid-19 cases and asymptomatic household members/caregivers of Covid-19 positive patients.The advisory also reiterates that placing healthcare workers or high-risk contacts of a positive case on the drug should not instill a sense of false security.Following social media rumours and reports of doctors using antiretroviral therapy (ART) drugs to treat Covid-19 patients, members of the public have been enquiring about ART drugs in the belief that they will boost immunity and prevent them from contracting Covid-19.Speaking to TOI, Dr Ramana Rao, a general physician, said people should avoid the use of hydroxychloroquine or other drugs. “Some people approached our hospital, requesting us to prescribe hydroxychloroquine. We had turned down such requests. The ICMR recommended hydroxychloroquine only for the high risk population and should be given only on the prescription of a registered medical practitioner. I urge the general public to take note of these facts and not to use the medication,” he said.The ICMR advisory states that even after being placed under the drug, medical personnel should follow prescribed measures such as respiratory etiquette, frequent washing of hands, social distancing and using personal protective equipment.They should self-monitor their health and report to health authorities immediately if they develop any symptoms, it states. High risk contacts of a positive case should be limited to home quarantine even after being placed under therapy.

Title: Angry with police, discom field staff threatens strike
Content:
Guntur: Field staff of Central Power Distribution Company Limited (CPDCL) threatened to launch an indefinite strike alleging police highhandedness. Field staff including assistant executive engineers and linemen was allegedly prevented from attending to their duties and sub-stations.

The discom staff alleged that the police canned them while they were attending to their duties in Gurazala and Piduguralla in Guntur district on Tuesday.

CPDCL superintending engineer (SE) Vijay Kumar however appealed to staff to not take a hasty decision. He said that the state government has issued clear instructions to the police to allow electricity staff to attend to their duties.

Title: Lockdown: Cops warn locals, seize vehicles
Content: Tirupati/Vijayawada: Police across Rayalaseema districts on Tuesday booked cases against persons venturing outside and seized vehicles to enforce the lockdown announced by the state government.A total of 99 cases were booked in Chittoor district under different sections of the IPC. Chittoor district collector Narayana Bharat Gupta and superintendent of police (SP) S Senthil Kumar carried out inspections at district headquarters on Tuesday and appealed to people to not take the government’s order on a complete lockdown lightly. “We have seen how the novel coronavirus wreaked havoc in several nations, where the death toll is in the thousands. Social distancing is the only option left with us. People should strengthen the efforts of the state and Union governments, by remaining indoors till March 31,” they said.In Tirupati, police resorted to mild lathicharge against people loitering on the streets. Tirupati SP Avula Ramaesh Reddy warned violators of action.In chief minister Y S Jaganmohan Reddy’s home district Kadapa, 20 vehicles were seized and cases booked against 20 persons for violating Section 144 of CrPC.In Kurnool district, police warned those who had come out onto the streets and said repeated offence would attract a jail term.Meanwhile, in Vijayawada, a traffic constable, Sridhar, was hit by an SUV near Ramavarappadu Junction on Tuesday. The cop was hospitalised and the driver nabbed.Police were deployed to prevent people coming out of their homes and ensure that social distancing is followed. Cops, however, said not everyone was cooperating with the order.Police sources said over 3,000 cops have been deployed in Vijayawada to ensure implementation of the lockdown.

Title: Andhra Pradesh: High court gives farmers two more weeks to submit grievances
Content:
Representative image

VIJAYAWADA: The high court on Tuesday extended the time to submit grievances on the changes proposed to zonal regulations in the master plan of the capital city area by two weeks.

The Capital Region Development Authority (CRDA) had issued a notification proposing to include R5 zone in the master plan to provide house sites to the poor. The CRDA gave 15 days to submit grievances, if any, over the proposed amendment to the zonal regulations of the master plan.

Farmers in the capital city region moved high court opposing the CRDA’s proposal to include R5 zone. The petitioners filed an interim application seeking extension of time as the time for submitting the grievances to the CRDA was to end on Tuesday.

They argued that in view of the Covid-19 outbreak and consequent lockdown imposed by the state government, they could not submit their grievances in time.

The state government opposed the interim application as it was moved on the last day of the time period given by the CRDA. Ample time was given to submit grievances and the lockdown came only two days ago, said the counsel for the government.

The high court considered the request of the petitioners in view of the prevailing situation and allowed the interim application by granting two weeks to submit grievances.

Title: Pune lab gets approval to make 1L diagnostic kits for Covid-19
Content:
Representative Image

PUNE: City-based molecular diagnostics company Mylab Discovery Solutions and Germany’s Altona Diagnostics have been approved by the Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR) to make diagnostics kits to test people for Covid-19.The two companies received approval to mass manufacture the kits after they received commercial approval from Indian FDA/ Central Drugs Standard Control Organisation (CDSCO).“ICMR NIV Pune has completed evaluation of nine non-US FDA EUA/CE IVD kits. Only test kits with 100% concordance among true positive and true negative samples have been recommended for commercial use in India,” the council said in a statement.Currently, the probes required for testing a patient for Covid-19 are procured from the USA and these kits will continued to be used after due approval from Drug and Controller General of India (DCGI) and intimation to ICMR.“Even early stage infection can be detected with highest accuracy as has been seen during tests at ICMR,” Shailendra Kawade, executive director of Mylab, said in a statement.For the government labs, it would cost nearly Rs 1,200 per test kit, about one-fourth of what ICMR pays, and the terms are still being worked out for private labs, he added.“The support and immediate action from regulatory bodies (CDSCO/FDA), evaluation centre of ICMR, NIV, Biotechnology Industry Research Assistance Council (BIRAC) and the central and state governments is commendable,” Hasmukh Rawal, managing director, Mylab Discovery Solutions, said.Altona Diagnostics could not be reached for its comment.The company set up a diagnostics centre in Germany in February 2020.

Title: Coronavirus in Mumbai: Mumbai's first corona infected couple, three-year-old among eight discharged
Content:
Representative image

MUMBAI: “There is only one message I would like to give senior citizens and those battling coronavirus: With good care and patience, you will fight and come out of it,” said a 70-year-old Andheri resident who was discharged on Tuesday after nearly 14 days of treatment. The septuagenarian and his 68-year-old wife, also called Mumbai’s index patients, had tested positive on March 11 following their return from a Dubai and Abu Dhabi trip.

They were among the eight patients to be discharged from the civic-run Kurla Bhabha Hospital on Tuesday evening. After being initially treated at Kasturba Hospital in Chinchpokli— the city’s nodal isolation centre—some were shifted to the Kurla hospital last week after two of their consecutive test reports came negative. Among those who went home was a threeyear-old girl from Kalyan, whose parents continue to be hospitalized, and a 62-year-old Kamothe man.

‘Kasturba doctors are masters’

A 49-year-old US-returned Ghatkopar resident and his 68-year-old domestic help were discharged too.

The three-year-old Kalyan girl’s father, who had tested positive after returning from the US, is currently serious and under treatment at Jaslok Hospital.

Speaking to TOI, the Kamothe resident said, “I was among the luckier ones who didn’t get very severe symptoms. I hardly had any fever or cough. After my initial report came positive, all the three subsequent ones were negative.” He said he was happy to go home but apprehensive about how people in the locality would behave around him.

“My wife and sons had a tough time after news got out that I was positive. I even got a phone call from a neighbour who said his tenants had vacated the house after learning of the infection,” he said. “I hope as people become more aware they understand that it’s just a flu and people recover from it,” he said, adding he was moved out of Kasturba on Sunday along with two others. “People should not step out of their homes and maintain social distancing,” he said. His wife, son and daughter-inlaw, too, are nearing the end of their home quarantine period.

The Andheri couple—Mumbai’s index patients—said they were relieved to be home after all. “Fear and anxiety is there because it’s a new disease, but Kasturba doctors are masters. They know their job. No disease is painless but, of course, multiple jabs through the day for blood tests were no fun,” he said, adding his wife was still battling a stomach bug, but she would be fine now that they were home.

While they were happy to head home, the lockdown posed a hindrance for some. The son of the 68-year-old domestic help said, “Our home is located far from the hospital and now with a complete lockdown in the city, I am unsure of how to bring her back home as public transportation has shut.” He has only spoken to his mother over phone since she was admitted on March 11.

Explaining why the BMC did not wait for 14 days to discharge patients, as was the protocol followed across the country, additional municipal commissioner Suresh Kakani said all these patients had tested negative for the virus. “Once that happened, we didn’t want them to stay very close to positive patients or even on the same premises. Also, a team of doctors was formed to see if any of them had other ailments before they were discharged,” he said.

Title: 'Use 52,000cr cess fund to help labourers'
Content:
NEW DELHI: The Centre on Tuesday asked all states to dip into the Rs 52,000 crore construction cess fund and directly transfer funds through the direct benefit transfer mechanism to help labourers in the sector.

In a letter to CMs of all states, junior labour and employment minister Santosh Gangwar said state chief secretaries must ensure the protection of jobs and wages of workers in private and government firms.

He advised them "to transfer funds in the account of construction workers through DBT (direct benefit of transfer) mode from cess fund collected by the Labour Welfare Boards under the building and other construction workers (regulation of employment and condition of Services) Act".

Title: CR, WR face Rs 220-crore losses over closure of train services
Content:
A Central Railway train

MUMBAI: With suburban and long-distance train services suspended from March 23-31 to curb the spread of Coronavirus, the Mumbai division of Central Railway (CR) and Western Railway (WR) is staring at cumulative losses of over Rs 220 crore.

A CR official said, “We have an average daily earning of Rs 2.50 crore from the suburban network, Rs 6.50 crore from mail/express trains and Rs 5 crore from freight trains.”

CR runs a total of 1,774 suburban services daily, around 80 mail/express trains and 20 freight trains in Mumbai division.

A CR official said, “Freight trains are being run, but while there were 20 goods trains daily, now only four to five trains are leaving as there is no movement of goods by road to freight terminals with the workforce home due to the lockdown.”

Similarly, WR is facing a daily loss of Rs 8 crore, including over Rs 2 crore from the suburban system in Mumbai division. A WR official said, “The losses do not include the refunds to the tune of Rs 3 crore that we have released for train cancellations.”

Meanwhile, Indian Railways is working 24/7 to ensure uninterrupted supply of essential commodities across the nation. Across Indian Railway, on March 23, a total of 474 rakes were loaded with essential commodities like foodgrains, salt, edible oil, sugar, milk, fruits, vegetables, onion, coal and petroleum products. Close coordination is being maintained with the state governments to ensure there is no delay in movement of essential commodities.

Title: India Lockdown rules: Violating lockdown to invite a year's jail
Content: NEW DELHI: The Centre on Tuesday said anyone obstructing its guidelines on complete lockdown of the country for three weeks would be punishable under section 51 of the Disaster Management Act for a term which may extend to one year or with fine or both. The order provides that if the refusal to comply with directions results in loss of lives or imminent danger shall, on conviction, be punishable with imprisonment for a term which may extend to two years.An order, issued by the home ministry after PM Narendra Modi 's address to the nation, further says that anyone spreading rumour (related to Coronavirus ) which turns out to be a false claim, in such cases the authority shall, on conviction, punish such individuals with imprisonment for a term which may extend to one year with fine .Anyone found guilty of misappropriation of funds meant for relief operation would also be liable for punishment for prison term of up to two years. These guidelines are equally applicable for any government officials found guilty.The punitive actions under the disaster act also provides for punishing any corporate found guilty of any of the directives of the government during the lockdown period of three weeks, starting midnight of March 24.As a preventive measure, the guidelines says, no court shall take cognisance of any offence under this act except with the previous sanction of the Central government or the state government, as the case may be. These government authorities have to give a notice of at least 30 days for a case to be instituted.The disobedience to the order of lockdown, however, invites punishment for a prison term of one month or with a fine of Rs 200. But if it causes public disorder, riot, the prison term may be extended up to six months.

Title: Ugadi: Let’s stay home, stay safe and count our blessings this Ugadi
Content:
Finally, an Ugadi with family... but we’ll all stay 7-ft apart

‘This Ugadi is special ’cos my first performance with my daughter Viya will be telecast on TV’

‘For the first time ever I’ll actually get to watch my ‘Ugadi specials’ on TV’

‘We’ll make Ugadi special this year with our hearts’

‘I’m going to miss the Ugadi pachadi, but spending time at home with my dad is the best way to start

the new year’

‘Looking forward to playing carrom with my parents on Ugadi day’

‘Blessed to be spending Ugadi day with my extended family’

‘I’m looking forward to cooking a meal with my mother this Ugadi’

‘Celebrating Ugadi under quarantine brings back memories of Bigg Boss’

‘Let’s forget the rituals and focus on the spirit of the new year this Ugadi’

With six ingredients — raw mangoes, jaggery, tamarind, neem flowers, chillies, salt — that bring in six varied tastes, Ugadi pachadi is a metaphor for life itself. For, what’s life if not bitter-sweet? (Okay, and spicy-tangy-salty as well!) And this Ugadi, that truth has come alive for countless Telugus. As we stand on the threshold of yet another new year, with the fear of COVID-19 looming large, and changing the very world as we knew it, everyone is taking a moment to mull over it all. And all that reflection has only made everyone a lil’ more grateful for the small joys of life. As we enter another new year, our favourite celebrities, who’ve confessedly been too busy to spend festivals at home, tell us what they’re thankful for, how are they are ushering in their new year, and why staying at home with your loved ones is the best way to celebrate Ugadi.We’ve never managed to have a big celebration at home on Ugadi day. All these years, Ugadi has been about my mum making the pachadi in the morning which I have a spoonful of before rushing off for training with my dad. But this Ugadi is different because finally I get to stay at home the whole day. On the agenda is just a lot of chilling and watching TV. I will also work on my fitness and practise on my make-shift badminton court on the terrace. So it’s a special Ugadi alright, since I willbe home with family. But we’ll all be 7-ft apart (laughs). Let’s all pledge to stay home and stay safe.— PV Sindhu, badminton playerEvery Ugadi, I’m under house arrest because my family never lets me go anywhere (laughs). So this Ugadi is no different in that sense. Jokes apart, this year, it’s all the more important that we all stay home because public safety is paramount and there can be no excuse to go out. What better way to start your new year than spending it with your loved ones? Personally, this Ugadi will be special for me because I performed on stage with my four-year-old daughter, Viya. This is the first time we performed together and it will be telecast today at 11:30 am. So in the morning, my mom and wife will make the Ugadi pachadi, after relishing it, we will all sit in front of the TV to watch Viya and me in action. I can’t wait!— Ravi, TV anchorI live with my brother, so it’s just the two of us celebrating Ugadi this year. I’ll be missing out on the Ugadi pachadi because I’m too scared to go outside to get the ingredients to make it. Instead, we’ll be staying home, cleaning the house, washing hands and of course, video-calling our parents. But it’s not all gloomy. Some of my Ugadi specials on television, which were shot a while ago, will be aired today. So for once, I’ll actually get the chance to watch my show on TV rather than watch it on OTT platforms a few days later. I’m grateful to be home with my brother at this time. I hope this crisis is averted soon and that we all have a wonderful year ahead.— Sreemukhi, TV starIt’s just me and my father here in Hyderabad this Ugadi as most of my family is in Ireland. We’re in quarantine and won’t have the usual celebration we have with family every year, but we will have a pooja. This year, our Ugadi is filled with hope to beat corona. We don’t know how to make the Ugadi pachadi, eppudu tinna amma chetide. We have also asked our cook not to come so we will be cooking for ourselves tomorrow too. We don’t know how to cook any festive dishes, so we will makethe festival special with our hearts. And, of course, we will video-call everyone else in the family so we do not miss them too much. Adivi Sesh , actorI will be spending Ugadi at home after a long time. In a way, I think it’s nice that we are all getting a chance to spend time doing nothing other than bonding with loved ones. I think this is a great way to usher in the new year. Ugadi meant going to the temple and visiting cousins. This time it’s going to be different. This Ugadi, it’s just my dad and me at home. we plan to binge watch TV (laughs). I have two sisters — one is in London and the other, in Bengaluru. I’ve been video-calling them every two hours. In fact, because we’re all under self-quarantine, we’re talking more than ever before. This crisis has brought us all closer. The only thing I’m going to miss is the Ugadi pachadi. Because of the long queues, we were unable to buy the ingredients needed to make it. We will make it special someother way though. Eesha Rebba , actressEveryday feels like Ugadi as I’ve been home with my parents. It’s been a while since I’ve spent so much time with them. We’ve been watching movies. Usually on Ugadi day, we have a small get- together. This time, it’s just the three of us. To start with, I’ve been assigned the task of cleaning my room so that’s how I’ll start my day (laughs). Cooking will be next but I am not revealing what’s on the menu. Yes, the pachadi will be there. But what I’m looking forward to the most is playing carrom with them. I found my old carrom board, and we decided to play together. It’s the little things that give you joy. I feel blessed to just be home with family at a difficult time like this. Pradeep Machiraju , TV anchorI stay with my extended family, including my two babayyas and their families. So, this Ugadi is nodifferent for us because we’re all in isolation together. What’s different however, is the fact that every year I have to make it back home despite shoots and sometimes I can’t because I’m in a different state or country all together. But this year, we have been all been spending time together and it’s been wonderful. Can’t wait for Ugadi specials like pulihora mavudkai pachadi , playing games with cousins.– Naga Shaurya , actorThis is a difficult time for all of us all over the world, but it gives us an opportunity to spend Ugadi at home with our loved ones. This year, Ugadi will be a low-key affair and considering we can’t really step out to buy ingredients. My mum and I will be cooking together, so that’s going to be fun. We plan to make a simple meal that includes dal-chawal, aloo fry and soup. Also, given that the stray animals don’t have food to eat, I’ll be doing my bit to feed them too. In our culture, celebrating afestival means being with family. I am just grateful that we have each other in our lives. Rashmi Gautam , TV anchorBeing under quarantine makes me feel like I’m back in the Bigg Boss house all over again. My family members are telling me that they now realise what it was like for me when I was in the house. Jokes apart, Ugadi for us, is usually a fun affair with numerous delicacies, meeting extended family, roaming the roads with friends and chilling endlessly. However, this year it’ll just be me with my parents and sister. The usual bellam annam, pulihora and bobbatlu will be there, but I’m not surewe’ll have the Ugadi pacchadi due to the lockdown. But unlike in the Bigg Boss house, at least we have access to phones, so I’ll be video-calling my cousins. Small mercies!– Roll Rida, rapperThe COVID-19 pandemic has given us all an opportunity to pause, reflect and re-evaluate our lives. On Ugadi, there are no big celebrations for me every year, but a constant fixture is the Ugadi pachadi. This time, however, I don’t think we’ll be able to buy raw mangoes, etc., to make it at home. But I think we should all take this as an opportunity to focus on the spirit of the new year rather than sulking about the rituals we can’t follow. A new year basically means we’re turning over a new page, and we can write whatever we want on it. Let us all emerge as better individuals from this crisis and start afresh.– Nandini Reddy, director

Title: CM writes to PM for raising FRBM limit
Content:
Kolkata: Bengal chief minister Mamata Banerjee has written to Prime Minister Narendra Modi urging him to allow states to go for more borrowing by relaxing the fiscal discipline under the Fiscal Responsibility and Budgetary Management (FRBM) Act in view of the “near catastrophic fiscal parameters” of state following the COVID 19 lock down.

“You would agree that the acutely necessary lock downs and closure of business in many states including our own will severely cripple resource mobilisation by states. There is no doubt that the GST collection will plummet when GST constitutes 70% of the state’s tax collection,” the Bengal said in her letter to PM.

Mamata in her letter also pointed out that the fall in tax collection would adversely hit the Centre’s tax pool and in turn reduce devolution of tax to states.

The Bengal CM urged the PM to raise FRBM limit of fiscal deficit from 3% of the state GDP to 5% that will give states an elbow room to grapple with the “growth-recession.” The Bengal legislature will pass the amendment once the Centre makes the change in the FRBM limit, the CM said.

The FRBM Bill was introduced in Parliament in 2000 by the then finance minister Yashwant Sinha. The Bill was approved by the Union Cabinet in 2003 and became effective from July 5, 2004. The purpose of the FRBM Act was to enforce fiscal discipline in both the Centre and the state with an aim to bring down the burgeoning fiscal deficit to 3% of the GDP. Accordingly, the states passed similar legislation to follow the principle in their state Budgets.

The Bengal CM’s appeal to relax the fiscal deficit cap at 3% comes after the week-long lock down in the state following the outbreak of COVID 19 resulting in scaling down of the economy. The CM fears that this will affect tax mobilisation. Bengal has been grappling with the debt burden left behind by the Left Front regime. The Mamata Banerjee government has been raising crucial capital expenditure, expenditure in the social sector despite the outgo of Rs 50,000 crore as capital and interest repayment of debt through better tax management and also by expanding the tax net. The CM fears that Bengal also other states won’t be able to keep up with the pace for the 2020-21 financial.

Title: Frontline healthcare workers face ostracization from landlords in Kolkata
Content:
TimesView This is reprehensible and must stop immediately. Healthcare workers are putting their lives at risk to serve the greater community. They deserve all our backing in these troubled times.

KOLKATA: At 5pm last Sunday, millions of Indians clapped, rang bells and blew conch shells to laud the efforts of doctors and health workers in the frontline of the war against the coronavirus . A day and a half later, three nurses in Kolkata faced a more personal battle — one against prejudice and social ostracization. They were told in no uncertain terms to vacate their rented accommodation just because they were employees of the hospital where a Covid-19 patient died on Monday.“My landlord, accompanied by some locals from the neighbourhood, came knocking on the doors of my PG accommodation on Tuesday morning and asked me to leave,” said one of the male nurses, who shares the flat with two other colleagues of the private hospital in Salt Lake. The turn of events shocked the trio as everything was fine with the neighbourhood till Sunday. Many locals had even sought their help on different occasion. But the mood changed dramatically when the news of the death of the 57-year-old Covid-19 patient spread like wildfire.“I explained that none of us was involved in the treatment of the particular patient, but they would have none of it. They argued that since we work in a hospital where a Covid-19 patient was treated we should leave and not return to the locality. They made us feel as if we had committed a crime,” the male nurse told TOI.The three colleagues have informed the hospital management about their ordeal and the authorities have assured them of alternative accommodation. The hospital, in fact, had isolated 15 healthcare workers, including six doctors, who were involved in the treatment of the deceased patient. The swab samples of 11 were tested and the results were all negative.Another nurse at the same hospital said he had stopped sending his daughter to tuition classes after other students and their parents started asking her odd questions. “I do not want my daughter to go through the trauma of ostracization and so have decided not to send her to the tuition class for now,” he said.“I wasn’t part of the team taking care of the Covid-19 patient. But so what if I was part of that team? This is our duty and we do that after taking all precautions. One day you clap for us and the next day you shoo us away,” said another dismayed male nurse at the hospital.Another nurse with the Beliaghata ID hospital, the apex facility for Covid-19 in the state where all eight confirmed patients are currently undergoing treatment, was also asked to vacate her rented apartment near the hospital where she lives with her husband. She had gone to visit her native place in Kalyani a few days ago when the landlord called up and asked her not to return. She had to seek police intervention to return to the house.News of such social ostracism is pouring in from across the state and the country as the number of Covid-19 patients rise. In Behrampore, a doctor of Murshidabad Medical College and Hospital was evicted by his elderly landlord on Monday and had to be put up at a hospital facility by the authorities.In Kolkata, several medical students and doctors complained that last week many app-cab drivers had cancelled their rides once they realised that the pick-up address was the premises of a hospital.“We are risking our lives to stop the spread of the virus and treat suspected and confirmed cases. We will go on doing it come what may. I request our society to be with us and not ostracize us for doing our duty,” said Indrajit Malik, a post-graduate student at NRS Medical College and Hospital “It is absolutely shocking that a nurse has been asked to leave her rented house just because she works in ID Hospital? Our society needs to be more sensitive to healthcare providers, especially in such a time of crisis when healthcare providers are the frontline warriors,” said cardiothoracic and vascular surgeon Tapas Raychaudhury.
