Title: Residents stock up on liquor as Panchkula allows vends to open
Content:
Police teams were deployed to maintain law and order at liquor vends in Panchkula, which received a few custom... Read More

PANCHKULA: Police teams were deployed to maintain law and order at liquor vends in Panchkula, which received a few customers on Tuesday. No liquor vend is open in curfew-bound cities of Chandigarh and Mohali.

Soon after liquor vends opened, people started stocking up. A person buying a crate of whiskey said, "This lockdown will be imposed for a long time and liquor is needed in such hard times."

Police teams were deployed to prevent crowding and taverns were closed. People were excited at Haryana government's announcement that liquor vends would be opened on Monday. Police said the situation at all liquor vends was peaceful. On Monday, seven salespersons from three liquor vends were arrested for selling liquor without permission and allowing people to gather at one place.

On the other hand, many Panchkula residents were unhappy with the decision. R K Aggarwal, president, Panchkula Vikas Manch said, "The government should not open liquor vends. This will create more problems in society and vends should be shut down with immediate effect."

Deputy commissioner of police (DCP) Mohit Handa said, "A total of 200 police personnel and 20 special checkposts were laid in Panchkula to maintain law and order. Anyone found violating the norms should be punished under the law. Residents must cooperate with the police at checkposts and during other duties."

Borders of the district remained sealed all day and only people involved in the business of essential commodities were allowed to enter and exit the city. The lockdown was strictly imposed and followed, officials said.

Title: Coronavirus in Noida: All doors shut for 9-year-old labrador as owner tests positive
Content: NOIDA: All doors have shut on Jenny, a nine-year-old labrador, who was rescued on Tuesday by an animal welfare organisation from Patwari village. Jenny was initially handed over to her walker Rajiv Yadav by her owner before he got admitted to a Greater Noida hospital after testing positive for Covid-19.And after Rajiv refused to keep the dog at home fearing spread of infection, members of People for Animals, Greater Noida, rescued her. The rescuers were promised a vacant sanitisation centre to house the dog in the morning, but refused in the afternoon. They have sanitised the dog and housed it in their shelter.“We reached out to the district administration, the chief veterinary officer, SPCA but nobody wanted to take the dog in, so we finally came back with it to our shelter and made separate and special arrangements for it. We have washed and sanitised it,” Kaveri Bhardwaj, People for Animals, Greater Noida, said.“While the canine itself may not be a carrier, his collar and accessories could be contaminated, so mass housing in any animal shelter too is not a possibility, we could house one dog, but if there are more of such incidents, the government might have to create a quarantine ward for pets,” she said.In the morning, Noida Authority veterinarian Prem Chand had sanctioned a vacant sterilisation centre for the dog. But in the afternoon, he backed out, following a decision by GNIDA CEO Narendra Bhooshan.According to Bhooshan, GNIDA would not take any additional responsibility at this time apart from sanitisation and he would not allow a facility to be opened for a dog without the consent of the chief veterinary officer of the district. The chief vet, Virendra Srivastava, could not be contacted, despite multiple attempts.However, vets say dogs have no threat to be infected by coronavirus. “Till now we have heard of two dog deaths, one in China and another in Hong Kong from a possible Covid 19 infection, but these are not authentic reports, there are no legitimate tests available for the dogs here, also these are untested waters for everyone,” said city-based vet Abhishek Daber.“I am under treatment and my condition is improving. I will be getting out and taking back the dog from the shelter soon,” the dog’s owner said on phone from his hospital.

Title: Woman’s prelim test +ve, had no travel history
Content:
Ludhiana: Preliminary test of a woman without a travel history came positive for Covid-19 on Tuesday. “We have received the reports unofficially over a call and it turned out to be positive. On Wednesday morning, we will receive the reports. Four patients are in isolation ward at DMCH and samples of three were sent to a Patiala lab,” said DMCH secretary Prem Gupta.

This is the first local person to test positive in the preliminary examination. Gupta said, “The 55-year-old woman from Gurdev Nagar was admitted to the isolation ward on Monday afternoon with respiratory symptoms. She was screened as per guidelines and samples were sent to Rajindra Hospital, Patiala.”

Deputy commissioner Pradeep Agrawal, however, said, “The prelim test is positive, but the microbiology test is yet to be conducted at Pune. Thus, it is a suspected case. She had no travel history.”

Earlier on Tuesday, the health authorities had said that the final sample reports of seven suspected Covid-19 patients recently admitted to the isolation ward of the civil hospital were awaited. The health department claimed that all the suspected cases kept in the isolation ward had a travel history and faced minor issues. Chief medical officer of Ludhiana Dr Rajesh Bagga said, “In the past some days, the local health department team sent around 25 samples to the test laboratory, which turned out to be negative. However, health officials are still awaiting the final reports of seven more suspected cases, whose samples were sent to the national virology lab.”

“We have sensitised our staff and are carrying out mock drills to prepare them for emergency situations. Authorities have provided adequate number of protective kits to medical staff of the civil hospital to deal with patients facing initial symptoms. The health department has established rapid response teams at the civil hospital and they have been given proper training about taking samples and sending those to laboratories,” he said.

Appealing to citizens not to create panic by spreading fake news on social networking sites, he said everything was under control and people should cooperate with the local administration, police and health officials.

The health department officials asked people to report any cases of illness and about those with foreign travel history. Large-scale awareness drives on the lines of pulse polio campaign have already been launched with the help of local administration in the city, an official said. The drives are led by the health department and have officials from departments of education, anganwari and cooperative. He said more than 2,000 teams have been formed and they would visit all houses in the district and educate people.

Travellers register themselves

The health department has given directions to all foreign-returned travellers to register themselves with the district administration by calling 104/112/01612444193 or contact health department on its helpline number 01612444193 and WhatsApp number 9814310675.

Title: Quarantined man held for roaming near house in Ludhiana
Content:
Representative Image

LUDHIANA: The police arrested a quarantined man found roaming around near his house in Khanna on Monday evening. The 26-year-old accused of Uttam Nagar in Khanna works at a chicken shop and had recently returned from abroad.

Police officials said he had gone to Thailand and returned 10 days ago. He was put in a 14-day quarantine , which was to end on March 27. Police got information from the area residents and caught him. He was booked under Section 188 of the IPC (disobedience of order promulgated by a public servant). He was arrested and later bailed out.

Investigating officer ASI Jagtar Singh said the accused had been warned not to step out of his home and not even come close to his family members. He added that they had pasted a poster on the gate of his house, informing about his quarantine period.

The ASI said medical tests of the accused were conducted and he doesn’t have any health issue now. The accused is unmarried and his family comprises his father and two brothers.

Past case

March 22: Four members of a Sangrur family, including a woman, were found roaming around near Jarg village on the border of Khanna and Sangrur district even as they had a home quarantine stamp on their hands. The civil administration had issued a warning to them and informed the Sangrur district administration.

Title: Ludhiana businessmen set up fund for bodies fighting coronavirus
Content: LUDHIANA: After promising to retain their workers and give them cash advances to combat the Covid-19 lockdown, Ludhiana businessmen have started a fund, proceeds of which will be donated to different organisations fighting the pandemic.On Tuesday, Confederation of Indian Industry (CII), in association with Chamber of Industrial and Commercial Undertakings (CICU), started the fund, donations to which will continue till the curfew is in place in Punjab. The proceeds will be handed over to the beneficiaries after the curfew is lifted.In a big boost to the campaign, Rs 80 lakh were pledged by several city businessmen on Day One. According to Rahul Ahuja, chairman of CII, Punjab, “CII and CICU have started this small initiative under which we are collecting money for several government organisations and other sectors, including Indian Red Cross Society and Police Welfare Fund , among others. Medical equipment , like ventilators, can also be purchased from the fund and donated to hospitals. As we are home due to the complete shutdown, we started this campaign on phone and WhatsApp. Interested businessmen and individuals can contact us at 9814027903 and 9815800622. City businessmen are contributing wholeheartedly. We are anticipating that by the time this campaign ends on March 31, we will be able to collect about Rs 2 crore. Besides this campaign, we are also thinking how to assist the administration and the government in sensitising and making masses aware about Covid-19.”Upkar Singh Ahuja, president of CICU, said, “Rahul and I floated this idea and started the corpus by contributing first. When we discussed it with our friends and in WhatsApp groups, we got a huge response. It’s really incredible that it’s been only few hours since we started the fund with just Rs 2 lakh and the figure has now touched Rs 80 lakh. We are thankful to everyone who has contributed.”A businessman who has contributed Rs 1 lakh said, “This is a great initiative for humanity as government departments and organisations will need major financial aid to battle coronavirus . As due to curfew and restrictions, we cannot go out and do anything for society, this is the best thing to do at the moment.”How to contributeInterested persons can call/WhatsApp on numbers 9814027903 or 9815800622. They can pledge the amount to be contributed along with details, like name and address. The amount can be handed over to CII-CICU representatives after March 31.

Title: Cops make curfew violators do sit-ups and hold ears
Content:
Ludhiana: Even as the Tuesday curfew was almost complete, some residents went out of their houses and could not furnish a valid reason on being questioned. As a result, they not only faced punishment, but also embarrassment.

At some places, cops made them lie down on road and apologise and at others, they made them do sit-ups, holding their ears. Two scooter-borne youngsters at Mata Rani Chowk were made to sit in the ‘murga’ position, a punishment reminiscent of schooldays.

Unlike Monday, fewer people came out on roads. In Dairy Complex, Haibowal, a dairy owner started distributing free milk in the locality, making residents rush there. The Haibowal police reached the spot and dispersed them. Thereafter, the cops ensured that the residents got milk one by one.

Near Clock Tower, cops made two violators do sit-ups while holding their ears. At Books’ Market, two men in a car were made to lie down on the road and apologise. In Giaspura on Monday night, police made people apologise by holding their ears.

On Tuesday, the Munidya police conducted a raid at a packaged food factory in Hari Nagar of Mundiya Kalan and found it open despite curfew. Sub-inspector Harbhajan Singh, in charge of Mundiya police post, said people were working in the factory without precautions. The police have registered a case against factory owners Inderpal Singh and Harjinder Singh under Section 188 (disobedience of orders duly promulgated by a public servant) of the IPC.

Division 8 police booked one Deepak Kumar and his two unidentified accomplices for triple-riding.

Title: 8,000 registered vendors will get you vegetables in Ludhiana
Content:
LUDHIANA: About 8,000 registered roadside vendors will be allowed to supply vegetables and fruits to households during the curfew. The municipal corporation officials will arrange special passes for the vendors so that they do not face any problems.

MC zonal commissioner Neeraj Jain said, “These are the vendors who were registered during a survey for vending zones and were issue ID cards. Now it will be easy to issue passes to them. We have scanned biometrics of these vendors, so only card-holders will be able to sell vegetables. They will be allowed to get stuff from the vegetable markets for supplying to the households.”

The vendors will not be allowed to stand at any particular place for selling the vegetables as public gathering is banned.

On Tuesday, as street vendors did not come and shops were closed, residents remained worried about eatables, groceries, milk and vegetables.

Title: Courier firm employee kills co-worker, 52, on Gill Road
Content:
Ludhiana: A drunk man killed his co-worker at their shared accommodation on Gill Road on Monday night.

The deceased has been identified as Mahavir Sharma, 52, who hailed from Haryana, and the accused as Kulwinder Singh.

Mahavir had been working at a courier company in Grain Market, Gill Road, from the past three years. He along with his co-workers Kulwinder and Naveen Kumar lived on the first floor of the firm.

Shimlapuri police station SHO inspector Amandeep Singh said, “Kulwinder had joined the firm about 15 days ago. Naveen was on night duty and Kulwinder and Mahavir on day duty on Monday. While Naveen was at the office at night, Mahavir and Kulwinder were having drinks at their accommodation.”

“The two had an argument over an issue following which Mahavir abused Kulwinder. In a fit of rage, Kulwinder attacked Mahavir with an iron rod, which led to his death, and escaped from there,” the SHO added.

On Tuesday morning when Naveen went upstairs, he found Mahavir lying in a pool of blood and Kulwinder missing. He called up his employer, who sounded the police.

Cops sent the body to civil hospital and apprised Mahavir’s family of the incident.

Later, the police arrested Kulwinder, who confessed to have committed the crime. “Kulwinder told during interrogation that Mahavir often wrangled with him at work. And when he abused him on Monday night, he lost his cool and attacked him,” the SHO said.

Police said the autopsy would be conducted once Mahavir’s family reached the city.
